HEADLINE: Futures Buying Lifts Stocks; Dow Up 21.12

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, spurred by futures-related buying about an hour before the close. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 21.12 points, to 2,794.37.
Yesterday's advance was not a broad one, as gains on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering declines, 805 to 717. At the same time, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.59 points, to 353.79, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index tacked on 0.69, to 195.33. 
Volume on the Big Board was relatively slow, with only 140.1 million shares changing hands, compared with 158.5 million on Friday.
 
Cutting of Prime Rate
Traders said the decision of some major banks to cut the prime rate to 10 percent from 10 1/2 had little initial impact on the market. Investors continued to be concerned about the outlook for corporate profits, they said, a factor that kept yesterday's advance in check.
''Prime rate cuts could be what's needed to spur a test of recent highs,'' said Harry Laubscher, an analyst at Tucker, Anthony & R.L. Day. ''But even breaking into new high territory won't help much without the aid of a discount rate cut.'' He said that with commodity prices about to rise in 1990, the Federal Reserve Board might be reluctant to lower interest rates anytime soon.
''The first five trading days in January now show a gain, implying a positive performance for the month,'' Mr. Laubscher added. ''As January goes, oftentimes so goes the year. But 1990 could be different.''
Philip Morris was the most active stock, falling 1 1/8, to 41, on a volume of 3.3 million shares. Tobacco stocks fell on the belief that a Federal appeals court, in throwing out a damage award against the Liggett Group on Friday, had made it easier for smokers and their survivors to sue tobacco companies.
 
Decline in Taobacco Group
Attorneys for the plaintiff said that he appeals court ruling favored future plaintiffs because it revived certain standards of liability that had been barred from this and other tabacco cases.
Elsewhere in the tobacco group, Loew's fell 2 7/8, to 120 7/8, and American Brands declined 1 5/8, to 68 3/4.
Pan Am was the second-busiest Big Board stock, rising 1/4, to 3 1/2, on a turnover of 3.1 million shares. Business Week reported in its Jan. 15 issue, that the AMR Corporation, which owns American Airlines, was interested in buying some or all of Pan Am's operations. The article also said there was speculation that Trans World Airlines Inc.'s chairman, Carl C. Icahn, viewed Pan Am as a possible merger candidate for T.W.A.
The Manhattan National Corporation was the biggest percentage leader, rising a point, to 6 5/8. The company said it would begin a tender offer for up to two million shares, or about 24 percent, of its common stock outstanding, at a price of $5.50 to $7.50 a share.
Active blue chips included General Electric, up 3/8, to 66; A.T.&T., up 1 1/8, to 45 3/4; I.B.M., up 5/8, to 100 3/8; Chase Manhattan, down 1, to 33 5/8, and Exxon, up 3/4, to 49 1/2.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 0.83, to 381.62. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index added 0.49, to 458.71.

HEADLINE: Engineer Leads Morrison Knudsen Unit

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Walter C. Bell, an engineer who has overseen construction projects in the Middle East, Asia and Latin America, has been named president and chief executive of international activities of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation. He has been given the mission of directing the giant construction and engineering company's aggressive re-entry into the worldwide market. 
Mr. Bell serves as president and chief operating officer of the international subsidiary, the Morrison-Knudsen International Company. He replaces Richard E. Kohne, who retired as the subsidiary's chief executive after 34 years with the company.
The Boise, Idaho, parent company operated abroad for more than 80 years, but, said Mr. Bell, who is 55, ''We retracted in the 1980's because of economic conditions internationally and differences in the dollar that made U.S. companies less competitive.''
Since 1988, however, when William K. Agee took over the $2 billion company, a new emphasis was put on overseas operations. Within the last year, the international subsidiary opened offices in Tokyo, Manila, London and Warsaw, and now has a $400 million backlog of international work.
Mr. Bell grew up in New York City, where several generations of his family had been involved in construction. He graduated in 1955 from the Polytech Institute of Brooklyn, then served 25 years with the Army Corps of Engineers and joined a Morrison Knudsen subsidiary in 1981.
He and his wife, Barbara, live in San Francisco. They have three grown children.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Declines Sharply As U.S. Rate Drop Continues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against key foreign currencies in active trading yesterday, skidding to a 20-month low against the strong West German mark amid continued concerns about declining United States interest rates.
Currency dealers said a cut in United States commercial banks' prime lending rate yesterday, to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent, helped depress the dollar in foreign exchange trading. Traders said that the cut, which lowers borrowing costs for a number of businesses and consumers, reflected more liberal credit policies by the Federal Reserve since late 1989. 
Lower interest rates tend to depress the dollar because they make dollar-denominated investments less attractive to foreigners.
At the same time, interest rates have been holding steady overseas, particularly in West Germany, where the crumbling of the Berlin wall promises to spur economic growth, dealers said.
Strong interest in the mark pushed the dollar to its lowest level against that currency since late April 1988, according to Ronald H. Holzer, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
The dollar fell to 1.6685 marks, from 1.6895 marks late Friday.
''Continued purchase of marks favors a lower dollar scenario,'' Mr. Holzer said. German rates are holding firm, he said, while the Fed policy is to provide stable to easier credit.
Enthusiasm for the mark was also renewed by Friday's 3.68 percent devaluation of the Italian lira against the other currencies in the nine-member European Monetary System, dealers said.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar closed in New York at 144.15 yen, down from 144.50. Earlier, in Tokyo, where trading ended before Europe's business day began, the dollar closed at 144.52 Japanese yen, up from 144.15. It traded at 144.10 yen in London.
The dollar was also weaker against the British pound. Sterling rose to $1.6530 in London from late Friday's $1.6375, and to $1.6535 in New York, up from $1.6350.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.5245 Swiss francs, down from 1.5445; 5.6965 French francs, down from 5.7777; 1,250.00 Italian lire, down from 1,276.25, and 1.16035 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16075.
Gold prices slipped after a mixed performance overseas.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $403 a troy ounce, down $3.30 from Friday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $401.80 an ounce, off $4.45.
Gold rose in London but fell in Zurich on profit taking.
The late gold bid in London was $404.75 an ounce, up from $404.50 Friday. The late Zurich bid was $404.05 an ounce, down from $405.50.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $403.05 an ounce, up from $401.85 Friday.
Silver prices were also mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery closed at $5.244 a troy ounce, down from $5.318 Friday. Silver rose in London to $5.28 an ounce from $5.27.

LENGTH: 554 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Cuts Funds to U.N. Food Agency Over P.L.O.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The United States has sharply cut its financial contribution to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization as a result of disputes over the agency's support for the Palestine Liberation Organization and its new budget.
Last week, the State Department told Edouard Saouma, Director General of the F.A.O., that the United States would pay only $18 million of its 1989 budget assessment of $61.4 million for the Rome-based agency. That is just enough to keep the United States from losing its vote in the food agency's 49-member governing Council. 
The Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, John R. Bolton, who is the Bush Administration official in charge of United Nations matters, wrote a letter to Dr. Saouma expressing concern about the agency's ''politicization'' and asking Dr. Saouma to ''minimize the chances that the F.A.O. will become futher politicized and endanger even more the support of all its members.''
He also asked Dr. Saouma ''to explore with the Government of Israel how the F.A.O. could most effectively contribute to a nonpolitical, technical study of the agricultural conditions on the West Bank and Gaza,'' which, he said, might lead to ''valid technical assistance programs for the Palestinians.''
In November, the food agency's governing General Conference overwhelmingly approved a resolution asking the agency, which is charged with promoting agricultural development in the third world, to study the farming needs of Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied territories.
The resolution also contained a clause mentioning in general terms ''the need for providing the Palestinian people with the assistance necessary for their economic development in close cooperation with the Palestine Liberation Organization.''
The Bush Administration called the clause an attempt to lend international legitimacy to the P.L.O.'s assertion that it represents a Palestinian state. Other countries asserted that it did not confer recognition on the P.L.O. The United States and Israel were the only agency members to vote against the resolution; 14 nations abstained.
In his letter to the Director General, Mr. Bolton also called the agency's $569 million budget for the years 1990-91 unrealistic. He said the new budget ''failed to win the support of members who will be expected to provide over half the resources required'' and that it also provided for a real increase of 3 percent over the previous level, which he said was unjustified.
The United States has a policy of maintaining ''zero real growth'' in spending by the United Nations and its specialized agencies.
Although the budget was approved by the General Conference, the United States, Britain, Japan, Australia, Israel, New Zealand and the Netherlands voted against. Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Poland and Switzerland abstained.
By paying the agency $18 million last week, the United States reduced the total it has withheld from $143 million to $125 million, and preserved its voting rights in the agency because its unpaid contributions now equal less than two years' assessments.
The Bush Administration and several Western countries tried unsuccessfully to block Dr. Saouma's reappointment for a third six year term in 1987, accusing him of turning the agency into a personal fiefdom.

HEADLINE: Wilder Holds to the Middle as Governorship Nears

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND

 BODY:
Virginia's Governor-elect, L. Douglas Wilder, who captured the historical and sociological imagination of the nation two months ago when he became the first black ever to be elected governor of any state, appears to be relying on the same political principle in setting up his new administration that he relied upon to run his successful election campaign: He is sticking to the middle of the road, avoiding extremes.
The 58-year-old Democrat, who will be sworn in Jan. 13, is off to a notably low-key start, promising no wholesale shakeups and choosing appointees from the state's political mainstream, including some women and blacks, almost all with solid experience in government and politics.
Facing a serious budget deficit because of a fall-off in the Virginia economy and steadily increasing demand for state services, he is searching for ways to rework and modify old programs rather than initiate bold new ones.
Mr. Wilder says he is fully aware that much of the nation, not just Virginia, is watching his moves and that expectation and speculation are factors he must deal with more than most governors, especially when it comes to his future in national politics. But he insists that he has no plan or inclination to turn the state on its political and governmental ear, as his November opponent, former Attorney General J. Marshall Coleman, repeatedly warned he would do. 
 
Keeping on the Track
''It's not my nature,'' Mr. Wilder said in an interview. ''I won the governorship by avoiding extremes and by appealing to a cross section of the state, the mainstream, and I intend to keep on that track. I think there's a message in that for the Democratic Party as a whole, not just in Virginia.''
A typical appointment is that of Col. Robert L. Suthard, the Superintendent of State Police, to be Secretary of Public Safety. In many ways, Virginia's state troopers are the most visible protectors of law and order in a state whose voters have always responded to law-and-order themes. By choosing Colonel Suthard, a widely respected officer with more than 35 years of police experience, Mr. Wilder seemed to be sending a signal of continuity and reassurance.
In a similar manner, when the Governor-elect chose a Secretary of Finance for the Old Dominion, one of the most fiscally conservative states in the country, he reached for experience and continuity and came up with the state's Budget Director, Paul W. Timmreck.
Mr. Wilder has named four blacks to high-level positions in his administration thus far, all with previous government experience, and he has said he intends to increase minority appointments throughout the heavily white Virginia bureaucracy, though he has steadfastly avoided any commitment to quotas.
 
Mainstream Appointments
He chose James W. Dyke Jr., a prominent Richmond lawyer and a member of the State Board of Education, to be Secretary of Education, and Ruby G. Martin, another Richmond lawyer and former director of the Office of Civil Rights in the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, to be Secretary of Administration.
The two other blacks chosen are Eddie N. Moore Jr., the comptroller of the College of William and Mary and a former assistant comptroller in the Virginia Department of Accounts, who has been named State Treasurer, and Dorthula H. Powell, a lawyer for Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Virginia and a former assistant state attorney general, to be Director of Personnel and Training.
In other appointments, as his chief of staff Mr. Wilder has chosen J. T. Shropshire, the clerk of the Virginia State Senate, where Mr. Wilder served for a decade and a half.
Friend and foe alike call Mr. Shropshire the ''Silver Fox,'' as much because of his artful political ways as his graying mane. He is at once a broad-gauge strategist and an incurable gossip, a back-slapper and an arm-twister, a man who can scheme a Republican foe's demise in the morning and then talk fishing with him in the afternoon.
 
''Off to a Very Good Start'
''The reading that I get around the state is that Doug is off to a very good start and that most people are very pleased with what he has done so far,'' said State Senator J. Granger Macfarlane of Roanoke, a close Wilder ally.
The traditional political honeymoon accorded many newly elected officials is probably a factor here. Still, the fact is that not just Democrats but also many Republicans have been hesitant to snipe at Mr. Wilder, although there has been some grousing that the pace of appointments is a bit slow. There will be 4,200 in all, 75 of them full-time jobs.
''He's picking people who know their jobs and who won't shake up things too much, and if it's going slow, that still makes for quiet times,'' said Steve Haner, director of the Republican Caucus in the Virginia General Assembly.
As Mr. Wilder prepares to take over the Governor's office in the porticoed old Capitol here, the hard economic reality is that he will be taking over a state that, while not bankrupt, is facing economic hard times after a long, leisurely stroll down Easy Street. By some calculations, there will be a revenue shortfall of close to $1 billion by 1992, about 5 percent of the state's annual budget.
Unlike Federal law, Virginia law mandates a balanced budget. Since Mr. Wilder opposes any tax increase and the General Assembly seems similarly inclined, he finds himself making plans to fine-tune and slash existing programs. Plans for offsetting inflation in old programs and plans for new programs in areas like education and human services have largely been abandoned.
''It's crunch time,'' the Governor-elect said. ''The easy times are over.''
Still, Mr. Wilder managed to find a bright side.
''All this means I must be innovative,'' he said. ''It's actually an opportunity, a chance to prove I can lead, to put into practice all I have learned over the past 20 years as a state senator and lieutenant governor. Just because I've been elected governor doesn't automatically mean I'm a success.''
Was that not the talk of a politician with an eye on higher office?
''I've got all I can handle here in Virginia,'' Mr. Wilder replied. ''I'm not thinking about anything else.'' Others are. Once in office, Mr. Wilder will increasingly be compared with black politicians elsewhere, especially the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
''It's a real opportunity for Doug Wilder to show that he can run a government, and run it from the mainstream, which is something Jackson has yet to try or do,'' said Larry Sabato, a political scientist at the University of Virginia who specializes in analyzing Virginia politics.
 
Relations With Legislature
''Success would likely have real appeal in the Democratic Party,'' Mr. Sabato said. ''And the budget crunch actually might help Wilder succeed, in a way, because it will provide him leverage for forcing priorities and make it a lot easier to say 'no' to all the people coming at him for something.''
Mr. Wilder's Democratic allies in the Virginia General Assembly would like to see him succeed, of course, with few exceptions. And since Democrats easily dominate both houses of the Assembly, they are in good position to help. But that said, no one expects the legislators to surrender the power of the purse to the new governor without a struggle.
Mr. Wilder, for his part, says that he seeks no fight with the General Assembly and that it is his political nature to avoid fights.
''But there's no getting around that the time has come when we have to take a hard economic look at things,'' he said. ''There's going to be some pain, but there's also got to be a consensus out there somewhere on all this. I'll work to find it. I always do.''

HEADLINE: User Fee to Expand Airports Gains Favor

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Aviation officials in government and industry are expressing growing enthusiasm over the idea of letting airports levy a departure fee on every passenger to help pay for expanding the nation's air transportation system.
Congress has for many years banned such a fee, or head tax. Airline passengers already pay an 8 percent Federal ticket tax, and the departure fee has been viewed as duplicative.
Some Bush Administration officials favor departure fees because they could provide millions of dollars for expanding airports without increasing Federal spending or raising Federal taxes. The linchpin of President Bush's economic policy is opposition to any new Federal taxes. 
Airport officials backing such a fee note that it would be set and collected at the local level, with all the money used for airport projects. The money raised could be used as a down payment to underwrite large borrowings for their expansion plans.
 
'The Time May Be Right'
''I think the time may be right for that,'' said Adm. James B. Busey, the retired naval officer who is head of the Federal Aviation Administration, when asked in an interview Monday if the law should be changed to permit an airport head tax.
The amount of any new fees would be set by airports, but they would probably be about $2 or $3 a passenger, which proposents say is not enough to be onerous to individual passengers but is enough to raise tens of millions of dollars annually at busy airports.
At a seminar on airport financing in Washington today, several aviation industry officials enthusiastically endorsed the idea, and even groups representing passengers seem amenable to the idea.
John J. Corbett, the counsel for the Airline Passengers of America, said that the idea would benefit passengers. They are, after all, the ones hurt by flight delays at crowded airports, he said.
While the aviation agency's most pressing task is to expand the capacity of the nation's air system, in the expectation that air traffic will continue to grow, its most vexing question is how to pay for the expansion.
 
Other Options to be Proposed
Admiral Busey said that the question of increasing fees paid by aviation consumers would be addressed in the Transportation Department's forthcoming national transportation policy paper, scheduled to be published in about a month. Other officials said that the paper, without endorsing a particular form of user fee, would offer a wide range of options for fees that could help pay for expanded spending on all forms of transportation, including highways, mass transit and aviation.
Federal money for aviation programs, including grants to individual airports, now comes primarily from a special trust fund financed largely by the Federal tax on tickets. The trust fund has a surplus of several billion dollars and takes in $3.5 billion annually. But the admiral said the fund will not cover all of the Federal Government's share of expanding airports and the air-controllers system.
And Congress has been reluctant to spend the surplus, which would increase the Federal deficit.
Admiral Busey said that the aviation agency's current plans for modernizing the radar sets, computers and radio networks of the nationwide air traffic control system, along with the costly expansion projects planned by many airports, would rapidly deplete the money now held for such purposes in the Federal aviation trust fund.
Admiral Busey said that the aviation agency must double the amount of money it spends each year on the air traffic control system, which is in the midst of a major modernization program. He estimated the five-year cost of this program at about $13 billion. $7.4 Billion Requested Industry officials say that there are about $7.4 billion of requests for airport grants already on file, while the agency's program of airport improvement grants pay out only about $1.5 billion a year.
Admiral Busey acknowledged that the Administration might, instead of letting airports charge head taxes to pay for their own local expansion projects, decide to raise the 8 percent Federal ticket tax as another way of financing the expansion of the nation's aviation system.
Either approach would require new legislation. Congressional aides said that key committees plan to hold hearings into the subject this year.
Whatever source of new money is chosen, the airlines and airports would be sure to insist upon legal guarantees that all the money actually is spent on aviation programs.
The industry has argued for years that the trust fund has been mismanaged as Congress has kept aviation spending down, using the trust fund's surplus to offset the Federal budget deficit.
 
Airlines Open to Fee
''The present system just plain isn't working,'' said Robert J. Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association. ''It also has to be said that the costs of doing what needs to be done have reached a level at which, even if the trust fund were being fully spent, the present taxes might not be enough. So under that set of circumstances, I think it is fairest to characterize our industry's position as being open minded.''
Airport owners, many of them counties and cities, have long sought permission to charge head taxes on passengers, saying they would be willing to accept legal restrictions on how the money could be spent. Airports major sources of money include bonds, landing fees charged the airlines and private planes and fees charged airport concessionaires like restaurants and automobile rental companies.

HEADLINE: $50 Billion Plan Is Called For to Train Minorities

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The president of the National Urban League called for a $50 billion ''domestic Marshall Plan'' today to train minority workers to help the United States compete in the international marketplace in the 1990's.
John E. Jacob, the president of the 80-year-old civil rights group, said the need for skilled workers to enable American industry to compete with foreign businesses presented a rare ''window of opportunity'' for blacks and other minority groups.
He said the plan, which the league likened to the American aid program in Europe after after World War II. could be financed by money diverted from military spending, which is likely to be cut because of the relaxation of East-West tensions. 
 
Proposal Is Included in Report
Dr. Jacob's proposal was included in the organization's 15th annual report on ''The State of Black America.'' The report emphasized the persistence of problems in education, health, housing, and the judicial system. The problems were addressed in 12 essays by black academicians, physicians, lawyers and other professionals.
The proposed $50 billion program, which would be ''predicated on national need,'' would help alleviate all these problems, Mr. Jacob said.
''America is looking at herself against the Japanese and Europeans and saying, 'We have jobs - how can we fill them?' '' he said.
''America will become a second-rate power unless we undertake policies to insure that our neglected minority population gets the education, housing, health care and job skills they need to help America compete successfully in a global economy,'' Mr. Jacob said.
In the report, Dr. David H. Swinton, dean of the business school at Jackson State University, wrote, ''Despite the momentous changes taking place in other arenas during the 1980's, the movement to gain economic equality for blacks stalled.''
 
Bush 'Was Most Responsive'
Mr. Jacob said the group had presented the program to President Bush last November, and ''I am pleased to report that President Bush was most responsive to the proposals that we put to him.''
But Administration officials have cautioned against expectations of a ''peace dividend'' resulting from the relaxation of East-West tensions. They have warned that military expenditures would not be quickly reduced and that the money saved would go toward shrinking the budget deficit.
In the report, Julius L. Chambers, director of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said that in the last year, the Supreme Court had issued a number of rulings that have led minority members to question whether the Court would continue to be ''an ally'' on civil rights issues.
''The decisions were so chilling that they have even prompted some to question whether the Court is still an appropriate forum to address the remaining obstacles to equal rights and equal opportunities for black Americans, or even to preserve past gains,'' Mr. Chambers wrote.
Dr. LaSalle D. Leffall Jr., chairman of the department of surgery at the Howard University School of Medicine, addressed life expectancy in his essay. ''In general,'' Dr. Leffall wrote, ''black Americans have a death rate one and one half times that of whites, and black life expectancy is declining - from 69.7 years in 1984 to 69.4 years in 1986.''

HEADLINE: Farm Debate to Center on Pesticides

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Proposals intended to make American agricultural practices safer and less polluting are likely to emerge as the most contentious issues in the Congressional debate over national farm policy, farm groups, trade organizations and influential farm policy makers say.
The appearance of environmental issues in the farm policy debate reflects a recognition not only that consumers want food produced with fewer chemicals, but also that the farm economy is substantially better and thus less of an issue now than in 1985, when the last national farm policy law was written.
''We'll spend a great deal of time debating conservation and environmental issues,'' said Randy M. Russell, an agricultural consultant in Washington. ''The farm community, from an economic perspective, is doing relatively well, and the debate this time around will not be on a major rewrite on the underlying farm legislation but rather on a series of other issues, including these environmental issues.'' 
 
Matter of Balancing Needs
The comments by Mr. Russell and other experts who help formulate rules governing the supply of farm products like corn, wheat, rice, cotton and milk came a day after President Bush and Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter unveiled a broad outline of the Administration's proposal for agriculture at an American Farm Bureau Federation convention in Orlando, Fla.
On Monday the President signaled his intention to introduce proposals that will balance the needs of farmers to use toxic chemicals in crop production and the concerns of Americans fearful of increasing pollution and the amount of pesticides on food.
''Many of you here today come from farms that have been handed down from parents and grandparents,'' Mr. Bush said. ''You know that to protect the land is to protect not just your livelihood, but your heritage. We must recognize that productive agriculture and a sound environment can be compatible, especially in terms of water quality.''
Dr. Charles E. Hess, the Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for science and education, said today that the Administration's farm policy proposals would not be made public until next month. But he and other department officials listed some of the broad changes in policy sought by the Bush Administration:
* Farmers who choose to rotate corn or wheat with other crops should be able to do so without financial penalties. Such rotations, which provide environmental and economic benefits, are discouraged under current rules because they reduce the amount of money a farmer is eligible to receive from the Government.
* More money and attention is needed for research on farm practices that reduce the use of toxic chemicals and expand the ability of farmers to control pests and diseases through less polluting techniques.
* New rules would reduce pollution of streams and water supplies from pesticides and fertilizers.
 
Environmentalists Are Opposed
But the Natural Resources Defense Council, a New York-based environmental group, and other environmental organizations will propose measures aimed at sharply restricting the use of pesticides.
In 1985 the Reagan Administration and Congress established a program to pay farmers an annual fee for planting grass or trees on millions of acres of fragile land to control soil erosion. There are currently more than 33 million acres in the Conservation Reserve Program.
One proposal under consideration by the Agriculture Department and Congress to reduce water pollution would identify land that is most likely to enable farm chemicals to seep into groundwater or streams. Farmers could be offered fees to establish wide buffer zones along streams and lakes or to take land out of production.
The emergence of environmental issues were propelled in 1985 with new and sweeping provisions to reduce soil erosion.
''As far as the environmental provisions of the farm bill, farmers are going to be receptive to a number of things done in moderation,'' said Mark A. Maslyn, assistant director of national affairs for the American Farm Bureau Federation. ''Conceptually there is a lot of room for agreement between farmers and the environmental community. The question is how far we go.''
In his speech on Monday, Mr. Yeutter said the Administration will continue policies aimed at aggressively exporting American farm products and reducing Federal farm payments. The value of American farm exports reached $40 billion in 1989, more than 40 percent higher than in 1986. according to the Department of Agriculture.

HEADLINE: The Next Summit's in June. Hurry.

 BODY:
The next Bush-Gorbachev meeting is five months away - only five months. What happens starting now will show whether the two leaders can ride the tigers Mikhail Gorbachev has set loose or whether they'll lose a momentous opportunity to reduce weapons and promote peace.
Mr. Gorbachev needs to keep doing what he has been doing - reforming the Soviet economic and political systems, allowing greater autonomy for Soviet republics and independence for Eastern Europe, showing restraint in the third world and agreeing to arms controls. 
Since the Malta summit meeting last month, President Bush has been talking about a U.S. policy of helping his Soviet counterpart to ''keep going forward.'' Now he has to start delivering.
The first task is to push the U.S. bureaucracy to make the compromises necessary for arms control agreements. Arms cuts are the surest, quickest way to relieve Mr. Gorbachev's economic pressures.
Mr. Bush's second task is to work with Congress to aid the beleaguered Soviet economy.
Finally, the President will need to work to insure that nothing happens in Afghanistan, Central America or elsewhere that derails the improvement in Soviet-American relations.
Mr. Gorbachev knows he can find precious rubles and talent in Moscow's vast military establishment. Accordingly, he has offered to make enormously disproportionate reductions in conventional and nuclear arms. It is overwhelmingly in America's interest to nail down those treaties, fast, while Mr. Gorbachev has the backing of his military. Given the traditionally slow pace of arms talks, Mr. Bush will have to do exactly what he has promised: kick his quarrelsome bureaucrats toward compromises.
Meantime, he'll have to do some stroking in Congress to clear the way for Soviet exports. Soviet goods will continue to face high tariff barriers until Moscow changes its laws on emigration. Those changes are imminent and Congress should then move expeditiously to give the Soviet Union equal trading opportunities. At the same time, Congress should lift the ridiculously low $300 million ceiling on credits and credit guarantees to Moscow.
Neither of these actions would produce a flood of Soviet exports. But they would demonstrate Washington's good will and give Moscow the right kind of economic incentives.
The way is also being cleared to reach an accord on Afghanistan. A deal here to relieve Moscow's costly military aid burden might induce the Soviets to press Fidel Castro to curtail arms shipments in Central America.
Many other issues will arise in the coming months - like Soviet membership in international economic organizations, exchange programs, talks on the future of Europe and cooperation on the environment. But they will have to be subordinated; each of them can be addressed more profitably after force reductions begin. Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush cannot afford to let these vital arms treaties slip away.

HEADLINE: Apartment Rules Will Stop Landlords From Heartless Evictions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''We Now Pronounce You a Family'' (editorial, Dec. 15), on new tenant succession regulations of the New York Division of Housing and Community Renewal, rests on unfounded assumptions. While lesbian and gay couples will be important beneficiaries of expanding protection for family members of deceased tenants in rent-regulated apartments, most of the litigation of this issue has not involved lesbian and gay couples.
Since the Court of Appeals decided Braschi v. Stahl Associates last July, all published lower court decisions relying on that case have involved other than lesbian and gay couples. Frequent beneficiaries have been children taken in by distant relatives or nonrelatives who live as part of a household without formal adoption or official foster care placements, a practice common among the city's poor. 
The proposed regulations adopt objective tests and exclude evidence or inquiry about sexual relationships between household members. The ''egregious invasions of tenant privacy'' you evoke are unlikely. The successor to a lease after the death of a tenant will not be able to ''pass it on to an endless succession of future invitees'' unless that individual establishes the requisites of a ''family'' relationship under the demanding regulations.
The regulations are calculated to deal with the most harmful fallout of rent regulation. The economic incentives for landlords to evict and to repossess apartments (vacancy decontrol or turnovers accompanied by sharp increases in rent) frequently overtake human compassion, resulting in the heartless evictions of grieving survivors, sometimes after decades of residence. Legislative action is needed, but the legislature, politically divided, with the Senate implacably opposed to legislation that might be seen to benefit lesbians and gays, is unlikely to answer your call for action. The new regulations are the next best thing.
 
ARTHUR S. LEONARD
New York, Dec. 16, 1989
 The writer is a professor of law at New York Law School.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Kean Stresses Need to Help Urban Poor

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
In a joyous and familial farewell to the state he governed for eight years, Gov. Thomas H. Kean delivered his final State of the State address today, warning New Jerseyans not to forget the problems and people left behind after an era of buoyant economic growth.
Speaking to a joint session of the new Democrat-controlled Legislature that took office today, Mr. Kean offered a reprise of the state's accomplishments since he took office, including new jobs, reforms in education and a new self-image for the state's 7.5 million residents.
''We forged an identity, we reaffirmed a sense of purpose and we built a new pride in this place called New Jersey,'' said the Republican Governor, who leaves office next Tuesday when James J. Florio, a Democrat, will be sworn in as Governor.
Mr. Kean warned that New Jersey's future now depends on preventing overdevelopment and helping the urban poor in a state where the gap between affluent suburbs and poor cities grew dramatically through the boom years of the 1980's. 
 
'Natural Treasures'
''How much longer can we pile condo on top of condo, strip mall on top of strip mall, in some mad race to fatten the wallets of a few,'' he said, ''while destroying the natural treasures that can be enjoyed by so many?''
''As we settle into our reclining chairs at night surrounded by our VCR's and remote controls and CD's and Nintendo games, do we think of the children in our inner cities who are not worried about escaping the Pac-Man on the video screen but the drug dealer in the tenement on the corner.''
''We will not allow the sturdy foundation of democracy, painfully constructed over two centuries, to be nibbled to pieces by the three termites of selfishness, indifference and greed,'' Mr. Kean said.
Although the outgoing Governor delivers the formal State of the State address this year, it will be left to Mr. Florio to present the Legislature with this year's budget proposal, in an address that is certain to be filled with specific proposals to deal with the state's growing budget problems. Experts say the state may be facing a revenue shortfall of several hundred million dollars this fiscal year, which ends June 30. Mr. Florio is expected to deliver his budget proposal sometime in the next two months.
Mr. Kean's speech was more of a paean to the policies of his administration and a time of good feeling, in which the Governor became the state's greatest booster and a personification of its new image. He is leaving government to become president of Drew University, a small private university in Madison.
''I stand before you with a mind crowded with wonderful memories of eight great years, with a chest filled with pride for the tremendous progress we've made together,'' Mr. Kean said.
He said New Jersey had entered its 84th consecutive month of economic growth, creating hundreds of thousands of jobs for a state that had been suffering the decline of old industries and the recession of the early 1980's.
Under his leadership, Mr. Kean said, school test scores had climbed, drinking water and park land had been protected and innovative programs had been introduced to fight drug abuse and attempt welfare reform.
 
'Real Impact'
''The real impact of our work will be felt by generations to come,'' he said. ''By today's teen-agers who will work in the high-tech labs we built together. By today's first graders who will learn in schools filled with better teachers, higher standards and stronger values that we provided together.''
Mr. Kean admonished the Legislature for not changing the current formula used to distribute state aid to school districts, a troubled system that has raised property taxes. The formula is the subject of a State Supreme Court case that is expected to be decided this year.
The speech was received warmly by hundreds of legislators and current and former state officials who interrupted numerous times with applause. They did not seem to notice what was probably Mr. Kean's least fortunate phrase: ''My tongue tasted irresistible evidence of the patchwork quilt that is New Jersey.''
The new Democratic president of the Senate, John A. Lynch, in introducing the Governor, praised Mr. Kean highly and thanked him for having ''brought notoriety to our state.'' Later, Mr. Lynch criticized Mr. Kean, saying his recital of accomplishments did not include his failure to deal with increasingly bitter tax and fiscal problems facing the state.
''Tom Kean was a Governor who did not want to tackle those issues that would require political capital,'' Mr. Lynch said.
 
Children and Animals
True to the style that earned him wide popularity in the state, Mr. Kean, a member of one of the state's oldest leading families, filled his address with references to little children, small animals and Hollywood celebrities.
Last year, for example, Mr. Kean invoked the image of Vanna White, a star of the television show ''The Wheel of Fortune.'' This year, he compared himself to Sally Field, who portrayed ''The Flying Nun'' in the 1960's television series, and recalled the aid he rendered to a family threatened with the loss of their unlicensed pet raccoon named Gerry Cooney.
He also recounted letters he received from children around the state. Among his favorites, he said, was a letter from a child named Reni.
''Good old Reni,'' Mr. Kean recalled. ''He wrote probably the most candid line I've heard in the past eight years. He said, 'I'm sorry you're leaving office, but that's life, Bud!' ''

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1346 words

HEADLINE: City to Suburb: Commuting Turns Around

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
With a glass-walled apartment 32 floors above the Upper East Side and plenty of friends below, David Perlmutter is happily ensconced in Manhattan. But each weekday morning, the 27-year-old developer drives to work here in the suburbs.
His reverse commuting, up Interstate 87 and the Sprain Brook Parkway and then along the Cross-Westchester Expressway, suits him, he said. ''I get to see a few trees during the day, and then I have my pick of theater, movies and restaurants at night.''
Tens of thousands of New Yorkers -white-collar and blue-collar - are traveling to work against the commuting flow into Manhattan each day. By car, train and bus, they go to the office parks and manufacturing centers of the suburbs, where job growth in the 1980's was more than twice that in the city. On Interstate 95 and the Hutchinson River Parkway in Westchester, the cars going north in the morning to corporate hubs like White Plains and Greenwich and Stamford, Conn., now outnumber those going south, planners at the New York State Thruway Authority say. Similarly, the east- and west-bound lanes of the Long Island Expressway are equally crowded, planners at the New York State Department of Transportation say. 
On the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, which serves Westchester County and Connecticut, ridership out of Manhattan during the morning rush climbed by 61 percent from 1982 to 1989. In the same period, ridership into the city climbed by 9 percent.
The actual number of reverse commuters is still small.
But the railroad is working to make it as easy to leave the city by train as by car through improved schedules, express trains and bus connections on the other end.
''It is the fastest growing market on the railroad,'' said Howard Permut, the director of planning and marketing for Metro-North. ''There's just been a tremendous increase in jobs in the outlying areas, and we've made an effort to improve our service there.''
Christine Johnson, director of transportation planning for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said, ''All of our forecasts indicate that reverse commuting will be the growth area of the future.''
A recent study for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority by the Regional Plan Association, a private nonprofit organization, projected 60,770 new daily trips out of New York City against the commuting flow by the year 2015. 'It's a Breeze' - Or Is It? That would be a 28 percent increase over the estimated 220,100 reverse trips now. And it is more than twice the projected growth in the number of trips coming into the city.
Still, the number of commuters riding into the city each day is many times higher than the number riding out. Metro-North counted 64,900 incoming riders during the morning rush last year and 4,560 outgoing riders.
Many who commute out of the city boast of roomy trains and lighter traffic. ''It's a breeze,'' said William O. Melvin Jr., a 52-year-old managing director for a White Plains investment concern who usually takes the 7:15 A.M. from Grand Central Terminal.
But some say it is not so easy. ''People think that just because you're a reverse commuter you don't have a single car to deal with, but there are tons of people reverse commuting,'' said Helene Bruneheim, an account executive for an advertising agency in Stamford who lives on the Upper West Side.
 
Like the Spokes of a Wheel
Even more common than the reverse-commuting trip is what transportation officials call the intra-suburban trip, from one suburb of New York to another. The dispersal of jobs across metropolitan regions have made this the dominant commuting trip not only in the New York region but also in the nation.
In New York, according to Federal employment data, the number of jobs in the city grew by 10 percent in the last decade, from 3,287,000 in 1979 to 3,627,000 last year. In the 18 counties surrounding the city, the number grew by 21 percent, from 3,766,000 to 4,575,000.
''Even though this was New York City's greatest period of job growth since World War II, you had this extraordinary economic development taking place in the rest of the region,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The network of railroad tracks around New York City resembles the spokes of a wheel, designed to whisk people in and out of the central business district south of 59th Street in Manhattan.
 
New Express Trains for Peaks
As one sign of the growing importance of the suburb-to-suburb trip, Metro-North is spending $1 million to study the possibility of running a new rail line across the Hudson River, either by bridge or tunnel, which would link Rockland and Orange Counties on the west side and Westchester and Fairfield Counties on the east side. It would also connect the railroad's existing north-south Harlem, Hudson and New Haven lines.
In the meantime, Metro-North and other agencies are improving service for reverse commuters. Metro-North has done the most, adding express trains from Manhattan to Greenwich and Stamford during rush hours. Many reverse departures are now minutes apart during peak periods, compared with an hour apart years ago.
The Westchester County Department of Transportation has worked with Metro-North to get people from train stations in White Plains, Rye and Port Chester to offices along the Platinum Mile, as the county calls the corporate stretch along the Cross-Westchester Expressway.
New bus routes were created a few years ago to bring people directly to the office parks housing corporations including Nestle S.A., Nynex, the Bank of New York and General Foods.
 
Considering a 3d Track in Mineola
''It's a good mix of white-collar and blue-collar jobs,'' said Eric B. Langeloh, the county's Commissioner of Transportation. ''We like the fact that they're taking mass transit, and we do need labor here.''
N.J. Transit has also responded. In 1984, reverse train service on the busy Northeast Corridor line, running through Edison, Newark, New Brunswick and Trenton, was increased from hourly to half-hourly departures. And in the last five years, the agency has greatly expanded bus service from New York City to the Meadowlands area and from Newark to outlying jobs.
The Long Island Rail Road, with 3,800 reverse commuters during the morning rush, is considering laying a third track in Mineola. L.I., to reduce time between departures, now more than an hour on some lines.
''There are some gaps in service, because we only have two tracks, and we need both for the majority of people who commute into New York City,'' said Susan McGowan, a spokeswoman for the railroad.
 
'The Same in Both Directions'
Some reverse commuters say they feel neglected. Sean Dennis Cashman, who lives in Greenwich Village and is dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at Adelphi University on Long Island, said, ''The railroad's priority is the people going from the suburbs to the city, and if there is a problem, it's your train that gets bumped.''
Also on Long Island, the New York State Department of Transportion acknowledged the tremendous movement on the Long Island Expressway away from New York City by scrapping a plan to relieve congestion that would have added a single lane for traffic toward the city in the morning and away from it at night.
''We're not even considering it anymore, and the reason is that the traffic flow is about the same in both directions, morning and evening,'' said David Ernst, the director of communications of the Department of Transporation.
Mr. Ernst said labor shortages, especially at the low end of the job market, have pulled many people from Brooklyn and Queens to work in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and from the Bronx to clerical, service, maintenance, warehousing and manufacturing jobs in Westchester and Fairfield Counties.
''Anyone on Long Island will tell you the difficulty of finding employees at the lower pay levels,'' Mr. Ernst said. ''Those people simply can't afford to live on Long Island, and so they commute from the city.''

HEADLINE: METRO DATELINES;
Coopers & Lybrand Leases New Offices

DATELINE: MANHATTAN

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins took time out from the city's financial woes yesterday to announce a new tenant for a large portion of one of Manhattan's midtown office towers, which he said was proof that ''in good times and bad New York City remains at the heart of the international economy.''

LENGTH: 800 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
Donna Wall, a substitute kindergarten teacher, was half an hour into a crayons-and-scissors exercise at the Bartlett Elementary School in Lowell, Mass., when she realized that some of the students, having finished their assignment, were wandering all over the classroom.
Suddenly, a seventh grader came through the door, introduced herself as a volunteer aide, clapped her hands and brought the class to order. ''There I was, a high-powered educational policy-maker, and it took a seventh grader to bail me out,'' Ms. Wall said.
Until April, Ms. Wall was Commissioner for Basic Education for the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, a post from which she supervised 501 public school systems and wrestled with problems like a $99 million deficit in the special education budget. 
Last spring, she decided to forsake the power lunches and political horsetrading and return to the classroom. In October she put her house on the market, bought a new car and began touring the country as a substitute teacher. Her travels have already taken her to 12 schools in the Northeast. This week she is off to Maryland, with plans to reach the West Coast by the end of this school year.
''I wanted to teach and to talk to principals and teachers and children,'' she said. ''My children are grown, so I had the time, the flexibility and some savings.''
By now she also has interesting new insights into how public schools look from the bottom as well as from the top.
Ms. Wall, who is 51 years old, started as a high school home economics teacher, but for the last 14 years she has served as a superintendent of schools and state official. As a newly minted substitute teacher, her first collision with educational bureaucracies came soon. ''My idea was to get paid as a substitute teacher to offset some of my travel costs,'' she said. ''But I discovered it's usually not worth the time it takes to do the paperwork to get certified. So I usually volunteer my services.'' Her first assignment was a seventh-grade language arts class in Torrington, Conn. ''I was scared,'' she said, ''and I was surprised at how scared I was. I was trained to teach high school, and my other jobs were pretty well defined. The idea that anyone can teach young children is nonsense.''
By the second day, however, Ms. Wall was in control. ''I had a small class of boys with behavior problems,'' she recalled. ''Some of them tried to convince me that they should be dismissed 10 minutes before the bell, but one kid said, 'You know she won't buy that.' It felt good that they accepted me as being in charge.''
When not teaching, Ms. Wall has had the chance to observe what she called some ''marvelous teachers,'' including Judy Platt, an English teacher at the Lincoln-Sudbury Regional High School in Massachusetts. ''They were doing Othello, and she was an actress as well as a teacher,'' Ms. Wall said. ''I discovered afterward that this was a mixed-ability class, but it was obvious that all the kids understood the play. We don't set high enough expectations for our students.''
There were emotional downers, too - like the kindergarten class in a poor section of Lowell. ''There was this one little boy whose clothes were absolutely dirty, and he couldn't sit still for more than two minutes,'' she said. ''I'd try to teach the other children, and every few seconds I would have to stop and move him back to his seat. I realized afterward that I had done almost nothing for him, and that the time I had spent with him impacted on the other children.''
Ms. Wall said her travels have altered her perspective of how school systems really work. ''I now realize how many people there are who make decisions affecting schools - from legislators and education committees to professional organizations that support every phase of the enterprise,'' she said. ''I also realize how few of these people have any background in running schools and classrooms.'' If she ever returns to running a school system, she said, she has resolved to spend more time educating such people about what she is doing.
She said that she was also impressed by the lack of accountability at the lowest levels. ''In the business world there is a bottom line,'' she said. ''People know what they are supposed to produce. In education, there is no bottom line that people agree upon. We've got to come up with one.''
Ms. Wall is keeping notes on her journey for some articles and maybe a book, and she is thinking about trying to establish a foundation to allow others to follow in her footsteps.
''It's important to break down the distance between policymakers and teachers,'' she said. ''I'd like to see teachers working as interns in state education offices, and I'd like to see more bureaucrats in the schools, not just to observe but to teach.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Plan Unveiled for Improving Minority Education

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Citing a ''glaring gap between minority and nonminority educational achievement'' in the United States, a group of educators and business and community leaders presented an extensive plan today to improve the education of minority students.
The main recommendations call for revamping schools so that teachers, administrators and curriculums respond to the individual needs of the students. The report gives examples of schools in Rochester, Miami, New Haven and other cities that have been reorganized so that ''student achievement is the main criterion against which teachers, principals, and administrators are judged and rewarded.''
The group, the Quality Education for Minorities Project at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, based its report a two-year national study financed by a $1.2 million grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York. 
 
'Demographic Revolution'
Shirley M. McBay, who directed the work, said of the study: ''We believe this project is timely, for our nation is now experiencing the beginning of what we call an American demographic revolution. Nearly one-quarter of all Americans are minority and by 2020, at least one-third of the nation will be non-white.
''Yet despite these momentous changes, and despite the passage of more than 35 years since the Brown v. Board of Education decision, minority students still attend schools that are both separate and unequal.''
In Brown v. Board of Education in 1954, the Supreme Court overturned the doctrine of separate but equal education and ordered public schools desegregated.
The study focused on black Americans, American Indians, Mexican Americans and Puerto Ricans who Ms. McBay said are ''traditionally underserved'' by the educational system.
Among the proposals, many of which the group said would help all pupils, are that schools improve nutrition programs for young pupils so that they are ready to learn in classes, revise curriculums so that the cultures of minoritiy groups are emphasized, reduce class sizes, require participation in community service programs, extend the school and year, establish summer residency programs on college campuses for older students to improve mathematics and science skills and extend Federal and state school aid to cover all children whose families are on welfare.
Other recommendations include increasing family and community involvement in education and raising teachers expectations of students.
''A rising tide lifts all boats,'' said Thomas W. Cole, Jr., president of Clark Atlanta University, who spoke on behalf of the organization.
But the report said financing all the recommendtions for one year would cost $27 billion.
 
Response Is Positive
Initial response to the report was positive.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who is a leader among the governors on education issues, said the report corresponds to the proposals drawn up by the governors and the White House after the ''education summit'' last fall, which was attended by President Bush.
Gov. Gary Carruthers of New Mexico said that many of the recommendations in the report are ''right on target'' and are in line with programs he has tried to implement in New Mexico. ''I believe that restructuring is in order because we must focus on the needs of the students as opposed to those of the institutions,'' he said.
David Merkowitz, director of public affairs at the American Council on Education, also praised the report.
''It is important to recognize that the obstacles and opportunities of different groups are different.'' He said the report also ''exploded some of the myths'' about minorities and education, like minorities are less capable of learning, that educating minorities is impossible because of problems like drugs and poverty and unemployment.
Over the course of the two-year study, the organization held nine regional hearings to determine what works in educating minorities. The group says that it found many successful programs, which it will use as models in implementing its plan, such as the two schools with new programs aimed at minorities in New Haven by James Comer and his colleagues at the Yale Child Study Center.
Ms. Mcbay said that such programs are usually under financed and ''operate mainly outside the traditional educational system.'' The goal of her project is to make these exceptions the norm in American education.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 10, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 1; Living Desk

LENGTH: 1646 words

HEADLINE: Children's Names: Mirror of a Society

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
IF a child's name tells more about the parents than it does about the child, then the 1980's may well be remembered as a decade in which some parents were self-indulgent, ambitious, proud of their heritage and just a little outrageous.
Luci was spelled with an i and Tyffany with two y's. Michael became Mykell. There were Jennifer Wongs and Ashakulu Johnsons. Boys were Leslies; so were girls.
''I don't think anyone could imagine how ingenious the America public could be when it comes to names,'' said Dr. Leonard Ashley, a professor of English at Brooklyn College and the author of ''What's in a Name?'' (Genealogical Publishing, 1989). 
Unlike the 1960's, when parents were naming their children with social and environmental concerns in mind (Sunshine, Moon and Peace), in the 1980's, more and more parents chose names that reflected their heritage and ethnic origins and their economic status. Many chose names that were gender-neutral or names they believed would set their children apart from others.
''People no longer go to the Bible or literature in choosing names for their children,'' Dr. Ashley said. ''They go to television or their ethnic roots, or they simply use their imaginations.''
Last month, at a regional meeting in Washington, the American Names Society, whose members often serve as consultants to corporations that want to find appropriate names for products, devoted two days to exploring the differences in choosing personal names based on race, region and sex. Such concerns are also reflected in the public's fascination with personal names and surnames.
''For over a hundred years, there have been naming fads and trends,'' said Dr. Cleveland Kent Evans, an assistant professor of psychology at Bellevue (Neb.) College, who has researched white, black and Hispanic names in the United States. ''Today, I think people, blacks especially, are more into finding different and unusual names for kids.''
For example, one black woman, Kelly A. Tillers, a commercial real-estate broker in Manhattan, was going to name her daughter Bianca until one of the characters on a her favorite soap opera, ''All My Children,'' chose that name for her television offspring. ''Then it became too phony,'' said Ms. Tillers, whose daughter is now a year old.
So she called her Chiara, a name she overheard in an Italian restaurant. ''It just sounded right,'' she said.
Zahmu and Malyka Rose Burgin, a Philadelphia couple who adopted their African names several years ago, looked no further than the carved wooden African map on their living-room wall to choose a name for their son, Zaire, now 2 months old.
Dr. Ralph Slovenko, a professor of law and psychiatry at Wayne State University in Detroit and an expert in onomastics, the study of the origins and uses of names, believes the new trends reflect a growing ''appreciation and awareness'' of ethnicity as well as social changes, in particular the women's movement.
''Whereas before everybody wanted to be in the melting pot and have assimilated names, some of the new immigrants are keeping their names,'' Dr. Slovenko said.
The women's movement has resulted in gender-bending names like Beverly, Carol (or Carroll), Kerry, Shawn or Chris, which are being used for both girls and boys.
Indeed, some women consider traditional feminine names a handicap in the business world and are choosing neuter names for their children. Dr. Slovenko said: ''Usually, it's a statement by the mother that this is still a man's world. Said one mother who gave her daughter a man's name, 'It'll look good when she applies to medical school.' ''
While these changes were taking place, most parents were still choosing traditional names for their children. For the 25th year in a row, more New York City parents named their newborn sons Michael than any other name in 1988, the latest year for which statistics are available from the City Health Department.
Jessica led the list of names for baby girls for the third year in a row. In 1988, a Gallup Poll produced similar results, with Michael leading the list for boys, followed by Christopher, and with Mary leading the list for girls, followed by Jessica.
''In the 1990's, more and more names will come from television and soap operas, said Dr. Ashley, the Brooklyn College professor, ''so you'll have Ashleys, Alexises and Crystals. Matthew will be around for a long time, as will names that are feminized versions of boys' names like Danielle, Stephanie and Michelle.''
Many black Americans began adopting names from authentic African or Islamic sources during the civil-rights and black-power movements of the 1960's and 1970's, rejecting the names given to slaves by their English-speaking masters. They have been joined by new immigrants to the United States who are not Americanizing their traditional African and Caribbean names.
In the 1980's, some younger black parents went a step further by creating names that many readily admit come out of thin air. This trend has been the subject of considerable controversy, highlighted recently by an essay, ''Names Can Hurt,'' in the April 1989 issue of Essence magazine.
The essay's author, Cathy M. Jackson, a freelance writer, denounced ''cumbersome, unpronounceable, phonetically awkward names for the rest of his or her life.'' In another section, the author wrote, ''Little black children don't need any more bricks added to the societal load they were born with.''
Mrs. Burgin of Philadelphia said her mother voiced similar concerns about the name her grandson would be given.
''Don't give him a name we can't pronounce or he can't spell,'' she recalled her mother's saying before Zaire's birth. ''My feeling was that if we named him Zachary, he would have to learn how to pronounce it and spell it. Our culture is African-American, and we shouldn't feel embarrassed by embracing our culture.''
Dr. Ashley also sees the trend as positive: ''People say Afro-American names are getting weird. They're just weird to people who expect tradition. I think they're just becoming more original.''
But some blacks worry that as names become readily identifiable as being black, their children will be stigmatized.
''It depends,'' said Dr. Evans of Bellevue College. ''Part of it is whether you think it is positive or negative to have a name which is identified with one race or the other. When a person applies for a job, it could make it easier for those who are prejudiced to consciously or unconsciously discriminate.''
Dr. Ashley said that the 1980's were also a time when more American Jews either chose traditional Hebrew names like Ari, Moshe and Rebecca for their children or returned to their families' original surnames.
At the same time, many Asians turned their names around, so that the surname or family name no longer comes first, Dr. Ashley said. And many Hispanic parents are giving their children traditional English first names: Robert Rodrigo Lopez, for example.
Other parents have tried to avoid names that would pigeonhole children or seem dated later.
''You have to consider that the child will have to live with this name for the rest of their lives,'' said Eileen Taylor of Ellicott City, Md., who is the mother of five, including 2-year-old twin girls. She and her husband, Jack, settled on the names Katherine (who is called Katie), Brendan and Laura, and for the twins, Mary Clare and Meg.
''They're all classy names, yet not too trendy,'' Mrs. Taylor said. ''So years from now someone won't turn to them and say: 'Oh, that name was popular in the 80's.' ''
For years, experts have been divided on whether a name can be predict or affect future achievement. On one side of the argument are those like Drs. Slovenko and Ashley, who cite anecdotal evidence that people assume their identities through their names.
''Consider that John Minor Wisdom, Pleas Jones, William Justice and Learned Hand are judges,'' Dr. Slovenko wrote in the April 1980 issue of the American Journal of Psychotherapy. ''Russell Brain is a brain surgeon, William Dance is a dancing instructor, William Key is a jail warden, Cardinal Sin is an archbishop, Groaner Digger is an undertaker.'' But in a 1985 study of 25,000 children in the St. Paul-Minneapolis school system, Dr. Martin E. Ford, a developmental psychologist who teaches at Stanford University, found no correlation between names and academic achievement or social competence.
''What truly happens, once people know the person behind the name, the name becomes insignificant as a factor in their psychological development,'' Dr. Ford said.
Yet those on both sides of the argument agreed that parents obviously believe names will have an effect on their children's lives. This explains why upwardly mobile and working-class parents alike are choosing what Dr. Ashley describes as ''Waspy'' sounding names like MacGregor for girls and Maxwell and Winthrop for boys.
''The image they want for their kids is something wealthy and glamorous,'' Dr. Evans said. ''That's why you have so many names taken from television or famous stars. Whitney became popular overnight when Whitney Houston got big. The irony is that names that have that glitzy image are actually not what wealthy people name their kids.''
Deborah Cofer, the executive assistant to the president of North General Hospital in Manhattan, said she was thinking more about a ''rare, precious jewel'' than about the renowned Fifth Avenue jewelry store when she named her daughter Tiffany. That was 13 years ago, before Tiffany became one of the 80's most popular girls' names (No. 7 in New York).
''To say the least, I was a bit annoyed at all these Tiffanys,'' Ms. Cofer said. But her daughter has ''grown into'' the name, she added. ''My Tiffany only wants the finest, most expensive things. This name thing is costing me a bundle. Maybe I'll have it changed.''
