LENGTH: 1459 words

HEADLINE: Revival Bought With Tourist Dollars

 BODY:
A small but growing number of American towns, no longer able to prosper from the industry, mining or farming that once defined them, are using imagination and ingenuity in hopes of snaring some of the tourist dollars that usually flow to big metropolitan hot spots.
Some of these communities are spending millions of dollars on sometimes offbeat and risky ventures that often have little relation to their history or image.
Chicopee, Mass., wants to turn its Connecticut River waterfront into an Amazon jungle, complete with monkeys and exotic birds. Kemmerer, Wyo., plans to become a virtual J. C. Penney theme park. Gary, Ind., is promoting casino gambling. And places that do not already have football field-sized aquariums are quickly drawing plans for them. 
Officials of these towns say they hope that a metamorphosis that involves revamping their downtowns and imposing new building codes will create places that people will drive out of their way to visit and to spend money.
''It's happening overnight,'' said David Edgell, director of policy and planning for the United States Travel and Tourism Administration, an agency of the Commerce Department. ''What people are doing may seem unbelievable.'' But, he added, many communities had proved that tourism can rebuild economies that might have otherwise faded with the paint on the town hall.
Already there is a Swedish theme town - albeit with palm trees - in California, and Bavarian-style towns are springing up across the West. Festivals that were once held annually for just the local community have expanded into gigantic productions that celebrate everything from squid to Shakespeare.
Behind these changes is the recognition that tourism is the third-largest retail service industry in the United States, employing six million people. In 1989, travelers in the United States spent more than $330 billion on goods and services, according to a Commerce Department study.
That study said spending by visitors was becoming an increasingly effective economic development tool for rural areas. Tourism can replace agriculture and industry as a community's livelihood, the study said.
''One of the major changes in thinking is tourism,'' said Matt Kane, a policy analyst for the Northeast-Midwest Institute, a economic research group based in Washington. ''Before it was part of a diversified approach. Now everybody is putting their eggs in one basket.''
 
May Be a Fad
But Mr. Kane, the author of ''Economic Development: What Works at the Local Level,'' warned that tourism might be a fad. ''In the 70's, you saw the building of industrial parks. In the 80's, it was the microchip industry. The major push now is tourism.''
Mr. Kane said tourism could be part of a good strategy, but it could be disastrous for towns to rely on tourism alone. ''Tourism is very seasonal and very cyclical,'' he said. ''When the economy flattens and people have less money to spend, just watch what happens to all the fancy hotels that have been built.''
Still, there are some long-term success stories. One is Leavenworth, a town in the mining and logging area of central Washington state, about 120 miles from Seattle. Leavenworth is often lauded as the oldest and most successful example of a dying town that was resuscitated by tourism.
Leavenworth's downturn, which began in the early 1940's, followed the pattern of many other communities hit hard by a changing manufacturing base and the resulting unemployment. By the end of World War II, Leavenworth's timber and mining industries had pulled out, stores were boarded up and more than half its population had moved. The final blow came when the railroad stopped serving the town, which is in a valley of the Cascade Mountains.
In the late 1960's, after two decades of economic decline, the town of 1,600 people emerged as a Bavarian village, even though it had no real ethnic German community. Today the town, framed by mountains and waterfalls that inspired the Bavarian theme, is a picture postcard of prosperity.
The boarded-up storefronts have been replaced by antique shops and beer halls. Chalet-style motels cannot be built fast enough to keep up with demand. Retailers, many of whom dress in Lederhosen year round, say that 1989 was their best year.
''It was pretty scary going in,'' said Laura Jobin, director of the Leavenworth Chamber of Commerce, who grew up in the town. ''People said the idea would never work, but we had hit rock bottom. What were our choices?''
Leavenworth transformed its face in less than five years, and by 1970, tourism was the town's major industry. Even though the nearest large city, Seattle, is two hours away, a million people a year visit the town. Leavenworth officials get 50 to 60 inquiries a year from as far away as Japan asking how they did it.
 
Massachusetts Rain Forest
On the East Coast, Chicopee, a Western Massachusetts industrial city of about 50,000 just north of Springfield, has seen scores of manufacturers pull out since the 1970's. Officials paid a design firm, Cambridge Seven Associates in Cambridge, Mass., $75,000 to come up with an idea to attract new business using an abandoned electrical plant where toxic wastes are stored.
The first idea was to build an aquarium large enough to gain national recognition, but too many other places, including Baltimore and Mystic, Conn., already had them. So the design firm proposed turning the aging plant on the muddy Connecticut River into a $25 million Amazon rain forest.
''It's a very ambitious concept,'' acknowledged Thomas Haberlin, Chicopee's community development director. But he said feasibility studies had shown that projected economic growth would justify the conversion.
''With the state government turning from poor to terrible, we've had some doubts expressed,'' Mr. Haberlin said. ''But there really aren't any alternatives.''
Cambridge Seven is involved in other town projects. It designed a $30 million freshwater aquarium on the banks of the Tennessee River in Chattanooga, Tenn. That city, like many of the firm's other clients, is economically depressed and hopes tourism will help. ''It's like changing a city with one building,'' said Peter Chermayeff, the firm's founder and vice president.
 
Homage to J. C. Penney
Not all places have the aspiration or can raise the millions of dollars needed to bring large projects to life. But the economic development offices in towns even as small as a few thousand are scurrying for a niche that might tap new sources of revenue - sometimes with quirky ideas.
Unemployment and an exodus of young people have plagued Kemmerer, Wyo., home of the nation's largest open coal pit. That moved Kemmerer to try to capitalize on its place as the home of the original J. C. Penney store.
The southwestern Wyoming town, which is near the Utah border, already has a J. C. Penney museum and a J. C. Penney boardwalk. There are now plans to restore the original store and the boarded-up downtown area, all using the J. C. Penney theme. ''People get real excited about J. C. Penney here,'' said Steve Golnar, the city's administrator. He said the project had prompted interest from top Penney executives.
Thomas Griffo, a J. C. Penney Company district manager whose territory includes Wyoming, emphasized that the company was not behind Kemmerer's plan. But he added that J. C. Penney ''may be spending some monies to bring in some of the old look'' of the original store.
 
Indiana Casino Plan
Not all of the places taking bold steps are rural. Gary, Ind., a city of about 130,000 in the Chicago metropolitan area, has lost a third of its population since the steel industry collapse. It is counting on the Indiana Legislature to approve the construction of five casino hotels along Lake Michigan. The city's Economic Development Office projects that the hotels will generate $800,000 million in gaming revenues annually and employ thousands.
''Nobody else is going to employ 25,000 people off the bat,'' said Karen Williams, a city spokeswoman. ''Casinos have the most impact in the shortest amount of time. We simply can't wait 10 or 15 years.''
Though some projects may appear frivolous, some say it may be more foolish not to try.
''Structurally, the economy has changed so much that the economic conditions that created these towns 100 and 200 years ago just aren't there any longer,'' said B. J. Reed, an associate professor of public administration at the University of Nebraska in Omaha, who advises community and business leaders in dying towns.
''In the long run, it is desperate,'' Mr. Reed said. ''Unless these towns can find a viable economic base or just retain what they have, they simply have no justification to exist.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Subsidy, Not Tax, To Spur Recycling

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
LIKE a desert cloudburst, a Bush Administration initiative to encourage recycling made a brief splash last week and then disappeared without a trace. But the idea of taxing manufacturers who do not make maximum use of recycled materials, reportedly shot down by Administration political operatives distressed by the mere mention of the T-word, is likely to rise again - if only because Washington is under increasing pressure from state and local officials to do something about the municipal garbage mountain.
At first glance, Federal ''user fees'' on bulky paper, glass and plastics made from virgin materials might seem heaven-sent to those who favor market-oriented solutions to environmental problems. In fact, the idea may prove too clever by half. A more practical alternative, some economists suggest, would be to subsidize recycling where there is a direct payoff to municipal budgets. 
It is hard to find a big-city mayor these days who is not losing sleep over where to put the garbage. And it is even harder to find a community willing to stow more debris underground or vaporize it in incinerators. William Rathje, who is in charge of the University of Arizona's Garbage Project, estimates that only a small percentage of the 3,000 landfills closed between 1982 and 1987 have been replaced. That is why the Environmental Protection Agency wants to cut the output of waste by 25 percent in the early 1990's.
The E.P.A.'s target would seem realistic. Barry Commoner, the biologist and environmental advocate, has estimated that 84 percent of household waste could be recycled without heroic effort. But for every willing supplier of recyclables there must be someone willing to do the recycling. And it is by no means clear that it would pay industry to reclaim a substantially greater flow of used materials, even if the stuff was delivered free to the factory gate.
That is where demand-side tax incentives might fit in. The Administration plan, apparently modeled after a proposal circulated by the Coca-Cola Company, would have put a tax on the production of the bulky materials that ultimately clog the waste stream. Manufacturers would get offsetting rebates for the tonnage of recycled material they used.
Such taxes are appealing because they look a lot less Big Brotherish to business and a lot more efficient to economists than, say, regulations requiring the use of a fixed proportion of recycled material in manufacturing. But as Lester Lave, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University, notes, there are still plenty of problems.
To work efficiently, the tax on each offending substance would have to equal the savings achieved by not burying or burning it. Yet no one really has a handle on what these savings would amount to, Mr. Lave argues. Nor does anyone know how they will change over time as the technology of disposal changes, or whether legislators will be able to excercise the political flexibility to adjust the tax rates once they are in place.
What is clear, though, is that the costs of garbage disposal vary widely from place to place. A ton of old newspapers, for example, costs a lot more to dump on crowded, ecologically vulnerable Long Island than on the dry plains of Texas.
Administrative issues further cloud the practicality of fees on virgin materials. Would the tax be waived on exports? How about imports, where the quantity of recycled materials used would be hard to measure?
A more modest but less problematic approach, Mr. Lave says, would be to leave disposal decisions to localities, some of which already have ample reasons to offer financial incentives for recycling. For example, a city that is paying $60 a ton to bury unsorted garbage in a distant landfill would be wise to insist that residents separate old newspapers, and then pay a paper mill $50 a ton to take them off the sanitation department's hands.
It goes against the grain to give those who produce garbage a free ride. But there would be far less political resistance to subsidy carrots for recycling than tax sticks for not recycling. And the incentives could be far better directed. It makes little sense, for example, to pass on the financial burden of recycling old telephone books to small towns and cities with plenty of room for environmentally safe landfills.
Paul Portney, an economist at Resources for the Future, in Washington, offers a variation on the same theme. The garbage problem may be obvious, he says, but the least-cost solution is not. And the risk is that Washington will impose an elegant fix when in some cases it would be cheaper, if messier, to get rid of the garbage in the old-fashioned ways.

HEADLINE: U.S. Forgives Portion Of Kenya's Loan Debt

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The United States today formally agreed to forgive all economic-assistance loans to Kenya, as part of an effort to give economic relief to Africa, including some of the continent's poorest countries.
The debt-relief effort, which was announced last July, is also aimed at rewarding African countries that have started to tighten their belts to improve their weak economies.
The United States Ambassador here, Smith Hempstone, signed an agreement that covered $44.7 million of Kenya's total outstanding debt of $175 million. The remaining $130 million will be forgiven over the next two years, if Kenya adheres to an economic reform program reached with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. 
 
Total of $735 Million
In all, the United States has pledged to cancel debts of $735 million owed by 12 sub-Saharan African countries. The per-capita incomes in those countries range from a low of $150 in Zaire to a high of $390 in Ghana.
The debt forgiveness reflects continuing concern about declines in Africa's well-being. ''Over all, Africans are almost as poor today as they were 30 years ago,'' the World Bank said in a major report in November.
Of the 44 countries of black Africa, more than half are severely in debt and have structurally weak economies, the World Bank said last month in an assessment of world debt. The economies are weak because of heavy dependence on volatile commodities, like coffee and tea, for exports; rapidly growing populations, and very little investment. Many of the economies have also been buckled by official corruption.
 
Differs From Reagan Policy
The decision to forgive the United States' debt is part of a policy adopted by the Bush Administration last year to do more to help the poorest countries. The Reagan Administration had refused to go along with some other Western nations, notably Britain, France, Canada and West Germany, which began canceling the official debts of sub-Saharan countries after an economic summit meeting in Toronto in 1988. The Reagan Administration chose instead to give the countries more time to pay.
By the end of 1988, the foreign debt of sub-Saharan Africa was about $140 billion, the World Bank reported. In comparison with Latin America's debt of hundreds of millions of dollars, the sub-Saharan debt is relatively small. But unlike the Latin debt, much of which is owed to commercial banks, Africa's is mostly owed to governments and multilateral agencies like the World Bank.
Economists have pointed out that the annual cost of servicing Africa's debt is about $12 billion. As poor as it is, Africa continues to be a net exporter of resources, paying more in debt service than the total of what it receives in foreign aid and earns from commodity exports, according to the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa.
Don Harrison, deputy chief of the Planning Analysis and Research Division at the United States Agency for International Development, said that servicing the debt consumed much of the foreign exchange needed to purchase goods and services and supply investment capital for economic growth and development.
 
Kenya Among the Better Off
Of the 12 countries where Washington is forgiving its loans, Kenya is one of the most prosperous, with a per-capita income of $330. But even so, Western donors including the United States have expressed concern at the Kenyan Government's growing reliance on foreign aid to pay for spending and budget deficits.
The donors have also informed the Kenyans that the Government is seeking too many large-scale commercial loans from abroad for items like aircraft for the national airline and a 60-story office tower.
The United States is canceling its economic loans for countries including Nigeria, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Cameroon, Malawi and Madagascar. Some of the loans, dating back 25 years, when Kenya obtained independence from Britain, were granted largely for spending on public works.

COMPANY: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR ECONOMIC COOPERATION (90%); INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR TRADE & INDUSTRY LTD (90%); INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR COMMERCE & INDUSTRY GAMBIA LTD (90%); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (90%); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (90%); INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION & DEVELOPMENT (84%);

HEADLINE: A Slow Start Is Seen for The Infiniti

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The initial sales of the Nissan Motor Company's Infiniti, the newest Japanese entrant in the profitable luxury car segment, have not been as strong as expected, some industry analysts and dealers say.
More than 1,700 of the cars were sold from the time of their introduction, in early November, to the end of December. Some analysts said they had expected greater sales, based on the 50 dealers lined up to sell the cars, the volume of shipments from Japan and the heavy consumer traffic in Infiniti showrooms.
Analysts say the Infiniti's initial results can be attributed to the industrywide slump and the timing of the car's introduction, which coincided with the normally slow holiday period, rather than to any flaw in the car or its marketing strategy. 
''The issue of Infiniti's slow sales does not center on the product or its distribution,'' said Christopher W. Cedergren, an analyst for J. D. Power & Associates. ''It is linked to something that Nissan has little control over, and that is the decline in overall auto sales.''
 
Nissan Expects Steady Growth
Nissan executives defended the Infiniti's early record, saying they expect the car's sales to grow steadily.
''We would be really pleased if no one could keep the Infiniti in their dealerships,'' said Don Spetner, a spokesman for the division. ''But two or three years from now, no one will remember what time of the year we launched the car or whether it had any impact on sales.''
The Infiniti's initial results have also focused renewed attention on Nissan's unconventional advertising campaign, which features images of natural settings and talks about a Japanese instinct for balance and harmony in design, but never shows the car.
Several dealers credited the ads with distinguishing the Infiniti from other models and generating curiosity among prospective buyers. But fewer than 5 percent of the more than 35,000 customers lured to Infiniti showrooms by late December decided to drive the car home, according to Nissan. The figure is considered somewhat lower than normal, Mr. Cedergren said.
 
'A Lot of Negative Reaction'
To the relief of some dealers, Nissan plans to include glimpses of the car in new ads. ''At this point, not showing the car on television has been a hindrance,'' said Mike Charapp, executive vice president of Rosenthal Infiniti in Tysons Corner, Va. ''We're getting a lot of negative reaction from the customers.''
But Mr. Charapp said the sale of 35 Infinitis in December ''put us right about where we wanted to be.''
Ron Hrapsky, who manages an Infiniti dealership in Houston, said sales had been ''a little lower than we expected, and our inventory is a little higher than we would like.''
 
'We've Done Very Well'
Robert M. Dekoy, sales manager of Loeber Infiniti in Chicago, said, ''For a largely unknown, brand new product at the slowest time of the year, we've done very well.'' Mr. Dekoy said he had less than a month's supply of cars, suggesting that sales had been adequate since the dealership opened on Nov. 8.
Over all, the end of the year was mixed for the luxury car makers, including those in Europe that stand to lose the most from the new thrust by Toyota and Nissan into the prestige segment. December was the best month of the year for Mercedes-Benz, and Volvo posted record sales in the fourth quarter. But BMW, Porsche and Jaguar had weak results in December.
The Toyota Motor Company's Lexus, the other major new luxury offering from Japan, fared well in December, with sales of 4,500 cars. The Lexus has thus topped Toyota's target of 16,000 sales since the car was introduced in August.
But given the growing competition in the luxury car segment and industry conditions, Toyota executives have decided to scale back their sales targets for 1990 by 20 percent, to 60,000 Lexus sedans and coupes from 75,000.
''As we get into 1990, both Lexus and Infiniti will have to work harder than they expected to sell cars,'' said Mr. Cedergren of J. D. Power. ''In a sluggish sales environment, no one will have a guaranteed situation, no matter how good their cars are.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Adding Noise to Cut a Car's Noise

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
Automobile engineers seeking to make a car quieter have typically padded body panels with a bit of cloth or fiberglass and added rubber to motor mounts. Now, researchers at Lotus Engineering in Britain have devised a way to cut interior noise with microphones and microchips, a technique dubbed ''anti-noise.''
The basic principle of anti-noise -stifling sound by creating the acoustic mirror image of the unwanted noise - has been known for decades. But it is the recent use of specialized computer chips, called digital signal processors, that made it possible for Lotus to develop a lightweight noise-muffling gear that should add only about $150 to a car's price if the car already has a stereo. 
Lotus has tested its anti-noise device in a variety of vehicles and expects to produce the system commercially within two years.
The engineers at Lotus, which is owned by the General Motors Corporation, have tackled one of the few areas of automotive technology that has improved little in recent years. Cars have become faster and more frugal with a gallon of gasoline, but most have not become quieter. And the smaller-engine models tend to be noisier than heavier cars.
Indeed, the four-cylinder engines now commonly used are more economical, but have more inherent vibration than six- or eight-cylinder versions, and lightweight bodies are more resonant, amplifying engine vibration, exhaust and road noise into a constant drone of background noise. Traditional noise reduction techniques add weight and are only partly effective.
 
Sound Is Analyzed
So Lotus researchers turned to electronics. They mount microphones, which monitor noise, in the car's passenger compartment and feed the information to a small computer. The computer analyzes the sound and produces a signal, through the car's stereo speakers, that is identical in pitch and volume but reversed, so that the peaks of its sound waves coincide with the troughs of the original noise, effectively canceling most of what is known as the resonant boom. The anti-noise signal is not audible on its own and does not interfere with music reproduction.
While the concept of reducing noise by producing twice as much of it seems odd, it is by no means new.
''The first patent we dug up was filed in the U.S. in 1934,'' said Malcolm McDonald, general manager of noise, vibration and harshness for Lotus Engineering, the research and consulting unit of Group Lotus, the British sports car company. The procedure has been made possible recently by ''advances in digital signal processing and the modern digital signal processing chip,'' Mr. McDonald said. He added, ''We are using not just one speaker, but four or six and feedback from six microphones; it's the ability to process that all very rapidly which has made it possible.''
 
A Computer on a Chip
Like the microprocessor at the heart of a personal computer, a digital signal processor is essentially a computer on a chip. But it is optimized for certain intense kinds of computation rather than the general purpose input and output functions of a standard microprocessor. Thus, digital signal processors, like the Texas Instruments Inc. chip used by Lotus, are extremely fast and can process several tasks at once.
Digital signal processors are also relatively inexpensive, allowing Lotus to add an anti-noise system to a car already equipped with a good stereo system for about $150. Previous anti-noise systems, also known as active noise cancellation devices, have cost $18,000 to $25,000, limiting their use to aircraft cockpits and industrial installations. Mr. McDonald said the cost could drop as low as $15 in a few years.
Mr. McDonald declined to name customers for the system as Lotus's consulting contracts are confidential. But he said the company was working with a number of auto makers around the world and had installed anti-noise devices in more than 30 cars. The greatest noise reduction was 27 decibels in a van; in typical cars, the noise level was reduced by 10 to 20 decibels. Every 10 decibels cut is half the noise, on a logarithmic scale.
 
'It Gets Far Quieter'
''It's quite dramatic,'' said Peter Egan, senior editor of Road & Track magazine, who drove several antinoise-equipped cars at Lotus's headquarters. ''You can get in a cheap little econobox car that's pretty noisy; flick the switch and it gets far quieter, much smoother sounding,'' he said.
Mr. Egan noted that four to six pounds of anti-noise equipment could accomplish more than 100 pounds of sound-deadening material. ''I think there will be a lot of interest when people understand what it is and what it can do,'' he said.
The Lotus anti-noise system is designed to curb mainly lower frequencies, where most ''booms,'' or crests of resonant background noise, occur. In addition, the Lotus unit cancels only constant noise, so sounds like speech and police sirens are not affected. But an advantage of the system over traditional methods is that it can simultaneously reduce noise from several sources, and at different points in the car.
''When it was cut in at full boom, the noise-reducing effect of the system was immediately impressive,'' Steve Cropley, editor of the British magazine Car, wrote after driving an antinoise-equipped Toyota Celica. The magazine has often described this model as ''boomy'' at British freeway speeds. ''It wasn't that the engine itself seemed to get much quieter, but the oppressiveness of the boom vibration, which seemed to arrive at the ears from every direction, was simply eliminated,'' Mr. Cropley wrote.
 
Starts Auto Vibration
Booms are a problem to auto manufacturers because the insides of car bodies have a resonant frequency, much like the inside of a guitar. Noise that excites that resonance sets the car to vibrating, creating a standing wave of sound that is almost self-sustaining. But this same principle actually works for the Lotus system when anti-noise is applied.
Because the boom is a resonance, ''You need very little power to excite it, very little to cancel it,'' Mr. McDonald said. The Lotus system uses only one watt of power to cancel a standing wave by 20 decibels, he said. In contrast, one headlight consumes 55 watts. This means the car need not have a huge stereo system to employ anti-noise devices.
Lotus will offer anti-noise systems to all automobile manufacturers when the system is produced, within two years, the company said. But it has no plans to incorporate it in its own cars, neither the $80,000 Turbo Esprit nor the just-introduced $35,000 Elan. Part of the reason is that these cars are quite boom-free by design, Mr. McDonald said, but he added that part of the reason was that ''a sports car needs to sound like a sports car; it has to make a certain amount of noise.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Finish Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Concern about a rush of new longer-term securities continued to build in the credit markets yesterday as dealers prepared to place bids on $7.5 billion of seven-year Treasury notes.
The worries, expressed by many over the course of the session, had little ultimate impact in the secondary market for Treasury securities, where prices were little changed and volume remained light.
Once again, participants said that the bulk of the day's activity was concentrated among longer-term issues, which have been under selling pressure since the start of the year. Meanwhile, prices of bills and shorter-term note were firm. 
 
Worry About the Japanese
''In the long end, there is concern about upcoming supply, and there is a real worry about whether the Japanese will be players this year,'' one government bond trader said. ''The Japanese bought 40 percent of the last two bonds that were auctioned, and they probably won't do that again. There is a fear factor out there, and as a consequence there is nobody home in the long end.''
The flow of new issues begins today, when the Treasury is expected to auction $7.5 billion of new seven-year notes. In coming weeks dealers will be asked to cope with an expected $5 billion worth of new long-term bonds from the Resolution Funding Corporation and the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions in February.
Concern about potential Japanese interest in upcoming Treasury auctions - a trait of the 1980's that has been carried into the new decade -was heightened recently by a dramatic narrowing of interest rate differentials around the world.
With yields on securities in strong-currency countries like West Germany and Japan at levels that have not been seen in years, some market participants and analysts are concerned that foreign capital once headed for the United States may flow elsewhere.
''As of Tuesday's close in Japan, the yield on the 10-year Government bond stood at 6.18 percent,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''That is less than 200 basis points under comparable yields on 10-year Treasuries. In April and May, that spread was over 400 basis points.''
A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Worries Called Overblown
But some market participants said the worries were overblown because making money in an environment where interest rates were declining was easier to accomplish than in a market where rates were moving higher.
''Over the last three or four months, my colleagues in Tokyo have had a stance that rates in Germany and Japan were going up, and the only market where the trend was not up was the United States,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''As long as the belief continues to exist that those forces are in motion, it doesn't make a difference what the spread is.''
Treasury prices ended the day little changed, despite all the worries. In late trading, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 100 13/ 32, down 1/32, to yield 8.08 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 1/8, unchanged on the day, to yield 8 percent.
Meanwhile, the seven-year notes to be auctioned this afternoon were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.99 percent.
 
Bill Rates Off a Bit
Treasury bill rates eased slightly. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.52 percent, down three basis points. Six-month bill rates dipped by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.41 percent. One-year bill rates fell by a like amount, to an offered rate of 7.25 percent.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by a competitive bid offering of $120 million worth of general obligation bonds from the State of Washington.
A bid from an investment group led by Goldman, Sachs won the issue, which consists of serial and term bonds.
Maturities on the serial bonds range from 1991 to 2010, with coupons from 5.70 percent in 1991 to 6.80 percent in 2010.
The term issue, which matures in 2015, carries a coupon of 6 3/4 percent.
The issue is rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary corporate bond market said that prices of most issues were unchanged to down an eighth of a point. Municipal bond prices dipped by about an eighth of a point, according to traders.

HEADLINE: THE U.S. AND PANAMA;
PANAMA TO ASSIST U.S. ON DRUG WAR

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Panama's new civilian Government signed an accord with the United States today in which it pledged to cooperate in efforts to crack down on narcotics trafficking and money laundering.
The broadly worded agreement was announced here by Melvyn Levitsky, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters. It was described by American officials as a necessary legal prelude to restoring a variety of preferential trade agreements that were suspended by Congress over the last two years, during the step-up in American efforts to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
But Mr. Levitsky made it clear that he and other officials hoped that in signing the pact, the three-week-old Panamanian Government had committed itself to a whole range of measures to combat drug traffickers, including rules to discourage the use of the banking system for disguising deposits of drug money. 
 
Secrecy Laws in Question
Ideally, American officials said, this would involve modifications in Panama's strict bank secrecy laws, which were instituted more than 20 years ago by General Noriega's predecessor, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, and which helped transform this country into a major international banking center.
But the prospect that the Government might move to loosen rules insuring the confidentiality of bank accounts has disturbed many bankers and entrepreneurs here, and could become a major point of friction between the Bush Administration and President Guillermo Endara.
Some United States officials suggested that Panama could subject its bankers to the same requirements as American banks.
''It's what we want a lot of countries to do,'' a senior American diplomat said. ''They should keep records of transactions in the same way we do in the United States, that is, of deposits of U.S. dollars over $10,000 and then make those records available to us on request.''
 
Up to Panama, the U.S. Says
Mr. Levitsky insisted that the United States would not try to impose controls on Panama.
''It's for the Panamanian Government to decide how to structure its banking regulations,'' Mr. Levitsky said. ''We have some ideas, and we can certainly talk with them, but it's ultimately their decision.''
''But,'' he added, ''I think the bankers will see that if Panama is pictured as a place where you can still launder money, it's not good for banking, it's not good for commerce, it's not good for the country.''
President Endara had no immediate statement on the four-page ''mutual cooperation agreement,'' which was signed by Ramon Lima, Deputy Minister of Government and Justice and Secretary Levitsky.
But an American official involved in talks with Mr. Endara on Tuesday said that specific measures that might grow out of the pact were not discussed, and a senior Endara aide said later that ''it's too early to say what we're going to do.''
 
Police Force May Be a Problem
Besides possible changes in banking regulations, American officials also said the Panamanians would have to decide how to structure their newly created police force to deal with drug trafficking, a decision that would undoubtedly be complicated by the fact that many members of the new Public Force served under General Noriega and may themselves have been involved in drugs.
''It's going to be hard to find wholly clean people,'' the senior American diplomat said. ''They'll have to watch their officer corps very carefully.''
During the talks on Tuesday, the senior diplomat said, American officials told the Panamanians that it would be important to keep their drug-enforcement units separate from the rest of the police ranks.
''The money is so big that you want to insulate whatever kind of organization you have working on drugs against the temptation,'' the diplomat said.
He and other United States officials acknowledged that bringing Panama into partnership in the war on drugs would be a delicate and probably long-term problem.
''We do not want to give an indication that we're taking advantage of the situation to impose a bunch of stuff on the Panamanians,'' one American official said.
''In the first place, if you try to impose it, it will bring resentment later and it won't be as effective. So we want to work with them gradually to do this.
''That's why,'' he said, ''this is a very general agreement today, and we'll have to come back here and talk about some of the specifics when they're ready to do it.
''But they're not ready yet,'' the diplomat said, ''because you've got a very small number of people at the top who are very committed but who do not yet have a support structure to deal with it.''
 
Money-Laundering Center
Although President Bush and other officials have characterized the American overthrow of General Noriega last month as a major victory against drug trafficking, many law-enforcement officials say that over the years Panama was far more important as a money-laundering center for billions of dollars in drug profits than as a narcotics transshipment point.
The institution of the bank-secrecy laws here helped build a network of more than 600 banks and bank offices in Panama, whose deposits totaled $40 billion in 1987. At the time, law enforcement officials say, banks here were laundering untold amounts of money.
But after the imposition of a series of economic sanctions by the Reagan Administration - which led to a general strike and the shutdown of the banking system in March 1988 - deposits shrank to $15 million as customers took their money and ran.
As a result, American officials say, Panama's importance as a money-laundering center waned as drug traffickers shifted their accounts to other offshore accounts in such places as the Cayman Islands, the Bahamas, Uruguay and Europe.
For that reason, Panamanian bankers say that modifying the bank secrecy laws is equivalent to closing the barn door after the horse is long gone. Worse, they say, it will new customers at precisely the time when Panama needs all the help it can get rebuilding its shattered economy, whose gross national product dropped 20 percent in 1988 alone.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Seek Lower Federal Role in Transportation

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
In a preview of the Bush Administration's national transportation policy, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner today called for state and local governments to pay more of the costs of programs that have been financed primarily by the Federal Government.
''We believe recipients of Federal transportation aid should pay a larger share of project costs,'' Mr. Skinner said in a speech at the annual meeting of the Transportation Research Board, a private, nonprofit organization.
''Reduced dependence on Federal money,'' he said, would be a fundamental precept of the new transportation policy, which is to be published by the Administration in February after President Bush delivers his State of the Union Message and submits his budget for the next fiscal year to Congress. 
Mr. Skinner's speech suggested that the policy, under development at the Transportation Department since Mr. Bush took office a year ago, would bear the hallmark of economic conservatism: reliance on deregulation and on state and local government and private enterprise.
 
Policy Seen as Compromise
Officials involved in developing the policy said it represented a compromise between the views of Mr. Skinner, who is considered an economic activist, and the President's more laissez-faire economic policy advisers, including Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget.
But the officials maintained that the Administration's internal review of the transportation policy was not a fight between competing views of economic policy. As evidence, they said Mr. Skinner last month accepted without argument the budget office's outline of his department's budget for the fiscal year 1991. By contrast, some departments often return to the budget office with a final plea for more money after receiving its recommendations.
Moreover, Mr. Skinner, a former Bush campaign aide who was head of Chicago's mass transit authority, has frequently said that he is committed to the President's declared policies of not raising taxes and of generally freezing Federal spending levels.
In his speech, the Secretary agreed with the mainstream opinion of transportation experts: that the nation's congested and decaying network of roads, railways and airports must be rebuilt, and that the investment of billions of dollars in the transportation system will virtually pay for itself by promoting economic growth and productivity.
 
The 'User Fee Principle'
But his message is sure to disappoint some in the transportation industry, including the operators of urban mass transit systems, who have been urging a sharply higher level of Federal spending paid for by increases in taxes, including the Federal gasoline tax. That tax helps pay for the construction and maintenance of Federal highways, but it also helps subsidize mass transit systems.
Mr. Skinner said in his speech today that the Government's transportation policy would seek ''new and creative ways to apply the time-tested user fee principle.'' He said this would include ''making it easier for other levels of government to levy user fees for transportation improvements.''
Ideas favored in the Transportation Department include allowing local airports to charge departure fees on all passengers. The policy will also call for more private investment, like the operation of toll roads by private corporations, Mr. Skinner said, and will seek further deregulation of interstate trucking.
At a Washington seminar on airport financing on Tuesday, several aviation officials endorsed the idea of letting airports levy a departure fee on passengers to help pay for expanding the air transportation system. Airline passengers already pay an 8 percent Federal ticket tax. A departure fee has been viewed as duplicative, and Congress has banned such fees for many years.

GRAPHIC: photo: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, who said the national transportation policy will call for less Federal involvement. (NYT)

HEADLINE: Turnaround on the Farm As Price of Milk Rises

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAIZE, Kan.

 BODY:
Gene Woodward stood looking out over a barnyard where his cows stood chewing, a cold drizzle dampening their black and white flanks. Their bellies were full and their udders heavy with milk.
This was clearly a healthy and productive herd in an industry for which things are looking up after a long history of problems. And as a result of a six-month surge in milk prices, Mr. Woodward is enjoying healthy profits. 
''Dairying is good right now, with prices at $15 a hundredweight,'' Mr. Woodward said as he sought shelter from the rain. But he added that feed prices have also been rising and that nobody can predict how long the sudden jump in milk prices will last. Some experts say a downturn is already in sight.
Mr. Woodward's mood, like that of his neighbors, Paul Siler and his son, Bob, reflects a general ebullience in dairy regions. But industry experts doubt that a long-lasting resolution of the dairy industry's problems and tight profit margins has been found.
 
Farmers Glad, but Cautious
''The mood has been one of elation for six months because of the prices,'' said Zane Akins, chief executive officer of the Holstein-Friesian Association, an organization of breeders and herd owners. ''The rise has made it possible for them to pay off some debts, but you don't see anybody rushing out to buy a lot of new equipment. They've been operating in a business without much of a profit margin.''
In what the experts call a sort of economic accident, prices paid to dairymen started rising last July, when payments to farmers in the major dairy states of Minnesota and Wisconsin averaged $11.76 per 100 pounds. By December the price had risen 31 percent. At the same time retail prices in the north-central states were rising more than 10 percent.
For a long time the number of dairy farmers, like that of farmers in general, has been falling, despite costly Government efforts to support prices and profits. From 1978 to 1988, the number of dairy operations dropped 40 percent, to 220,880 from 369,210.
 
Outpacing Consumption
In 1949 Congress passed legislation that, with few basic changes, continues to regulate dairy operations. It mandates that the Government buy dairy products at prices calculated to enable processors to pay at least a specified price - now $10.60 a hundred pounds -to dairymen for their milk.
As a result, while dairies produced more than consumers could use, the surpluses piled up. By 1983 nonfat dry milk in storage totaled over 1.3 billion pounds, about a year's supply. Supporters of the program viewed this as a cushion against scarcity; its critics saw the surplus as needless and costly.
In 1985 and 1986 the Government began a concerted effort to reduce the surpluses and cut the dairy program's cost. It began buying herds of cattle for slaughter to cut milk production and sought to get rid of the surpluses by giving millions of pounds of cheese and dry milk to programs like school lunches and soup kitchens.
The cattle-buying appears to have had little impact. Though it helped continue a long-term decline in the number of dairy cattle, genetic improvements in the remaining herds went on increasing milk production.
 
Roller Coaster and Surge
Disposing of the surpluses was another matter. In mid-1989, drought and forage problems resulted in a rarity for the industry - a decrease in production. It came at the same time as an unforeseen drop in foreign milk production produced a surge in demand for American dairy products.
But because American warehouses had been emptied of the surpluses of nearly everything except butter, the cushion against scarcity was no longer there. Prices spurted.
The surge came after a roller-coaster ride of sorts for industry profits. Operating margins - the difference between cash costs and money received after an allowance for depreciation - amounted to $322 a cow in 1987, but fell to $134 in 1988.
''That's poverty wages for most farms,'' said Mr. Akins, the industry expert. ''For a farm with 100 cows -and that's a good-size farm, usually involving several members of a family and often more than one family -that's only $13,400 a year.''
With the surge in prices, the net income from dairying rebounded in 1989, according to Department of Agriculture estimates, to $253 a cow. For a 100-cow farm, that would amount to about $25,300 a year.
 
Farm Pays for Educations
Experiences, of course, vary widely from farm to farm. In 1987, according to an Agriculture Department study, operating margins ranged from about $5,900 for dairy farms with milk sales of $30,000 a year to an average of more than $500,000 a year for those with sales above $1 million.
Mr. Woodward, who is 45 years old, runs an efficent 106-cow operation with his father and a brother. Their cows produce about 18,700 pounds of milk a year, he said, about 4,800 pounds more than the national average. The farm, which helped send Mr. Woodward to college many years ago, has also paid for college educations for his son and daughter.
Mr. Woodward's neighbors, the Silers, offered figures showing even greater production, about 20,800 pounds a cow for their 99-cow herd. They also showed figures indicating a profit margin of $580 a cow this year, far above the national average.
''It's the production that does it,'' Paul Siler said, citing improvements in his herd. ''In the last 10 years we've come up about 5,000 pounds. If we were still making the 15,500 pounds a head we made 10 years ago, we wouldn't be in business.''
Mr. Woodard said dairying ''can be a good life if you enjoy it enough to work seven days a week every month of the year.''
''When most people were devoting Christmas Day to their families, we still had to take care of the cows,'' he said. . ''It's hard work, but I wouldn't have it any other way.''

HEADLINE: Lean Budget Plan in California

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 10

 BODY:
Gov. George Deukmejian today proposed a lean $53.7 billion budget for California, calling for freezes in spending on health, welfare, AIDS programs and other social services.
The spending plan for the next fiscal year, Mr. Deukmejian's last year as Governor, represents an increase of 7.3 percent over the current year's budget, and is double the state budget proposed when he took office seven years ago. But it does not keep pace with rapid increases in state program costs, chiefly for welfare and prisons.
Although the budget left little room for new programs, Mr. Deukmejian, a Republican, did propose a new $2 billion loan program to aid first-time home buyers and $15 million to build low-income housing in areas devastated by the earthquake in October.
 
Objections by Democrats
Final negotiations on the budget will begin in May, when the latest revenue figures are available. But early indications are that Democrats, whose votes are need for passage in the Legislature, will fight for increases in money for health and welfare services and cuts elsewhere in the budget.
Governor Deukmejian said the state's revenue grew by 8.4 percent last year, but mandatory cost-of-living increases in benefits under programs like Aid for Families with Dependent Children and Services for Home-Bound Elderly and Disabled Californians would force the state budget to grow by 11 percent.
He proposed that the Legislature enact bills to freeze such aid programs at current levels so as to balance the budget.
''We must face reality,'' the Governor said. ''Any government whose base budget is on autopilot to grow 11 percent a year - beyond inflation and population growth - is headed for trouble.''
Budget drafters are also hamstrung by an initiative approved by the voters in 1988 that requires that 40.9 percent of tax revenues go to the public schools.

HEADLINE: Several Governors Oppose Plan on Acid Rain

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Several governors whose states have already cut the air pollution causing acid rain today denounced a plan that would have them help pay for reducing the problem in other parts of the country.
At a news conference here, the Alliance for Acid Rain Control, a coalition of governors, environmentalists and business leaders from states that have made a substantial investment to reduce the smokestack emissions that lead to acid rain, said the plan was unfair.
''It's hard to see why consumers in states that have already done their part should be paying a second time for those who have dragged their feet on environmental protection,'' said Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota, co-chairman of the alliance. He was joined by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin and Gov. Mike Sullivan of Wyoming. 
The alliance issued a study indicating that utilities in lower Midwestern states like Ohio, Indiana and Illinois that were responsible for much of the pollution charged substantially lower electric rates than power companies in states that have already acted to clean up their emissions. But government officials and utility spokesmen in that band of states disputed the rate survey findings. They also said that, under pending Federal legislation, their states would be required to bear too heavy a share of the economic burden of reducing acid rain.
Legislation proposed by President Bush to strengthen the Clean Air Act, awaiting action in somewhat revised form in Congress, would require, among other things, that coal-fired power plants reduce their smokestack emissions of sulfur dioxide, a major contributor to acid rain, by 50 percent, or 10 million tons, by the year 2000.
Acid rain is created when sulfur and nitrogen oxides flow up into the atmosphere and fall back to earth as acidic rain, snow, fog and dust. Much of this pollution originates in the industrial Midwest but is deposited in the Northeast and Canada, where, according to scientific studies, it destroys aquatic life, damages buildings and may play a role in damaging forests.
 
Utilities Want Costs Shared
Utilities from the lower Midwestern states, supported by their state governments, contend that acid rain is a national problem and that the cost of dealing with it should be shared by the entire nation. Several members of Congress from the Midwest have called for the addition of a cost-sharing provision to the pending legislation.
Representative Philip R. Sharp, Democrat of Indiana who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Energy and Power Subcommittee, said the pending legislation ''is fundamentally unfair and flawed because it asks 13 states to make emissions reductions not only for themselves but for others as well.''
The President opposes the cost-sharing proposal on the ground that it would be tantamount to a tax on the states with lower sulfur emissions and a subsidy for the heavily polluting states.
''Asking other states to pick up the tab for their cleanup is like asking a middle class family to help a rich family absorb the financial shock of losing a tax loophole,'' Governor Thompson said.
But John L. Stowell, chairman of the Coalition for Acid Rain Equity, a group of utilities and companies that is pressing for cost-sharing legislation, said that the alliance study released was misleading and that there was actually little difference in rate structures.
Mr. Stowell said the study lumped industrial rates, which are lower because they are offered at a discount to heavy users, with residential rates. Because the Midwest is more heavily industrialized than other areas, the combined rates are lower, he said. But he added that residential consumers in the Midwestern states pay just as much as in other parts of the country.
In addition to those at the news conference, the alliance includes the Governors of Colorado, Massachusetts, Montana, New Hampshire, New Jersey and North Carolina. Former Governors Scott M. Matheson of Utah, Anthony S. Earl of Wisconsin and Bruce E. Babbitt of Arizona are also members.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
For Judge in Keating Case, Being on the Bench Is Not Sitting on the Sidelines

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
It was a moment that Judge Stanley Sporkin obviously relished.
Seated in his elevated chair in a packed Federal courtroom in downtown Washington last Friday morning, Judge Sporkin peered down at a nervous Charles H. Keating Jr., the man the Government has accused of causing the largest savings and loan failure on record. For the first time, Mr. Keating was testifying under oath about the savings and loan collapse.
Over the next six hours of a preliminary hearing, Judge Sporkin questioned, interrogated, debated and chatted with Mr. Keating about Mr. Keating's contention, spelled out in a lawsuit, that the Government had unfairly seized his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. Judge Sporkin's performance ran the gamut - from expressions of near-compassion for Mr. Keating to blunt anger at the banker's lawyers. 
''We knew Sporkin liked to ask questions, but we didn't know how much he liked to ask questions,'' said one Keating attorney.
 
In the Middle, Again
To his friends and critics, it was classic Stan Sporkin, variously provocative and gentle, witty and tough, skeptical and respectful, a no-nonsense judge who does not shrink from getting into the middle of a good legal debate.
Beyond this, Judge Sporkin's performance on the bench marked the latest chapter of a highly visible and unpredictable Washington career, 30 years of Government service that has left both strong supporters and detractors.
''You've just got to call them the way you see them,'' said Judge Sporkin, whose favorite posture in the courtroom seems to be leaning back in an almost supine position on his chair with his half-rim glasses perched on his forehead, eyes peering at the ceiling. ''But you've got to be fair and treat people decently.''
And to the surprise of Mr. Keating's attorneys, who had warned the Phoenix real estate developer that he might be in for some rough attacks by Government lawyers or Judge Sporkin, the 57-year-old judge at times seemed almost friendly to the man regulators say embodies the abuses of the savings and loan industry.
 
The Lawyers Are Scolded
As the day progressed, Mr. Keating turned from a subdued, almost uneasy witness to a man emboldened in his pronouncements that he had been wronged by regulators, obviously welcoming the public forum Judge Sporkin had granted him.
But the judge did not have kind words for Mr. Keating's lawyers. When one stood up in the afternoon and objected to the scope of questions his client was being asked, Judge Sporkin's temper flared.
''You're not going to strong-arm this court,'' he scolded the lawyers.
It was hardly the first time in recent weeks that Judge Sporkin has drawn attention. A 'Keystone Kops' Operation? Presiding over the Charles Lewis case, in which the former employee of the District of Columbia was charged with dealing cocaine, Judge Sporkin would not permit the Government to have Mr. Lewis testify in secret that he had sold drugs to Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. So the allegation, denied by Mr. Barry, came out in open court, drawing front-page attention and dominating local television news shows.
Judge Sporkin also criticized as a ''Keystone Kops'' operation the drug arrest in Washington's Lafayette Park set up by the Government to use as an illustration in a nationally televised speech by President Bush.
Indeed, in a city where many public people fall into a knee-jerk ideological mold, whether liberal or conservative, the person of Stanley Sporkin, a Republican who switched his registration to independent, is complex and unpredictable For years, he was a thorn in the side of the conservative business establishment. As head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division from 1974 to 1981, he brought dozens of highly visible and embarrassing cases against corporate giants, accusing them of making payoffs to foreign officials.
 
A Strange Leap in Seen
But to his liberal friends, he made a strange leap, taking the job as general counsel at the Central Intelligence Agency in 1981 under his friend William J. Casey. Mr. Sporkin later paid a major role in formulating a legal justification for the covert sale of arms to Iran. (Later, some of the profits from the sale went illegally to the Nicaraguan contras, a deal that Judge Sporkin denies knowing about.) ''Stanley has a feeling for proper conduct that overrides everything else,'' said Irving M. Pollack, a former commissioner of the S.E.C.
''That is what people don't undertand,'' he said, adding that they mistake his aggressiveness for meanness. ''It's just the opposite. He understands that all of us are not godly.''
For his part, Judge Sporkin maintains that the various twists in his career fit neatly into what he terms a view of public policy tinged with ''naivete.''
 
Doesn't Like Compromise
''The premise I operate on is that this is the greatest country the world has ever known, that the freedoms we have and the free enterprise system are the reasons it's so good, and that you cannot afford to compromise those freedoms,'' he said.
''The bribery cases were done on that premise,'' he added. ''I was told that this was done all over the world. My answer was that it is not legal, and it is wrong, and that you cannot accept these shortcomings just because everyone is doing it. The system must work as nearly perfect as possible.''
Judge Sporkin justifies his work at the C.I.A. in the same way, that an effective intelligence network is essential to national security. Moreover, he had become very close to Mr. Casey when he was with the S.E.C. So when Mr. Casey offered him a job at the C.I.A., he jumped at the opportunity.
''Casey was probably the brightest man I have ever met in my life,'' Judge Sporkin said. ''I believe in our country, and I believed in what the C.I.A. was doing, and it was fine.''
 
His Father's Footsteps
Now, on the Federal bench, he sees his work as only an extension of the earlier phases of his career.
And indeed the appointment to the bench was the fulfillment of a lifelong desire for Judge Sporkin, whose father, Maurice Sporkin, was a Federal judge in Philadelphia when Stanley Sporkin was growing up.
After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from Pennsylvania State University, where he majored in accounting, he earned a law degree at Yale in 1957, beginning a 29-year path that ended in his appointment to the bench by President Ronald Reagan in 1986.
Judge Sporkin is married to an artist, Judith, and has three grown children.
 
Don't Fence Him In
As he has done in other positions, he moves beyond the immediate scope of his office. Since the stock market crash of 1987, he has repeatedly made speeches on the need to reform the nation's securities markets, drawing on his S.E.C. experience, and has proposed a very controversial proposal for reform that would call for considerable governmental intervention.
Among other things, he would support a law that would ban certain highly popular types of computerized program trading, creating a system in which speculators would not be able to use such new investment tools as stock-index futures to influence the value of the stock market.
''Our markets are extremely important and becoming more so every day, particularly as more pension fund money is put into them,'' Judge Sporkin said. ''But just think of the guy who had to cash out his pension fund the day after the market crashed. It went down because of speculation, not because the underlying economic value of those stocks had changed dramatically. We have to protect those people from this type of volatility.''
 
The World Is Smaller
He says there is a growing need for an international securities commission to regulate global trading as securities market become more and more linked internationally.
Judge Sporkin has also been outspoken on another issue that has become, in a chilling way, very real to him and his colleagues: the protection of Federal judges.
A member of a task force studying that problem, he says judges need to have, at a minimum, mobile telephones issued to them in order to stay in touch with their offices. But ultimately, he predicts the Congress will have to appropriate funds for security personnel.
He notes a judge now only gets protection when there is a known threat.
''There is a tremendous gap between the protection we get and what other government officials get,'' said Judge Sporkin, who declined to discuss whether he personnally had received any threats.
 
Wide-Ranging Curiosity
Some say the activities outside his immediate caseload indicate that Judge Sporkin finds his current position somewhat confining, that he is seeing too many drug-related cases and that his wide-ranging intellectual curiosity, as well as his penchant for plunging into public policy debate, is not being satisfied.
He acknowledges that the speeches he has made on the need for market reform and for a more centralized regulation of the banking and securities industries are an effort to ''keep my mind from getting dull.''
The only other time his temper flared at Mr. Keating's attorneys was last August, when they filed a motion that Judge Sporkin disqualify himself because he was head of enforcement at the S.E.C. when the agency brought a securities-fraud case against Mr. Keating.
''That's what I call a chutzpah argument,'' the judge told Robert K. Huffman, a Keating lawyer. ''It doesn't make any sense that I have to now recuse myself in every case that came under my supervision over 20 years, that ridiculous.'' Something to Prove? But if Judge Sporkin has something to prove to his critics, he seems to be trying to do that in the Keating case.
In his days at the S.E.C., he was called heavy-handed and unfair by his critics, who said he brought cases that were more embarrassing than substantive. To some extent, that reputation has stuck.
Now, in his comments from the bench and in interviews, he seems bent on setting the record straight. And he might succeed. Attorneys on both sides give him high marks for his fairness.
''He has gone out of his way to be sure everyone has the opportunity to present what they wanted to present,'' said John E. Lundin, a Keating attorney who is a partner at the Phoenix law firm of Gallagher & Kennedy. ''I have become very comfortable being before him.''

HEADLINE: Letter: On Yugoslavia;
Why Not Ethnic Self-Determination?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''A Single Yugoslavia, Pluralized'' (editorial, Dec. 29) identifies the two main political and economic trends that exist in Yugoslavia: Slovenian and Croatian push for pluralism and market economy, and Serbian quest for recentralization. Your endorsement of pluralism is commendable.
However, by advocating a continuation of ''a single Yugoslavia'' as the only solution to the political and international problems in the country and in the region, you are a priori limiting the freedoms of the component nations to determine their own future. Thus, beside your support of a genuine pluralistic society, you should also encourage implementation of the principle of self-determination, and for once the rest of the world should respect the wishes of those peoples. 
Furthermore, you imply that the nations in that part of the world are not mature enough to choose for themselves, and therefore Washington, Moscow and others should ultimately decide their fate. While the international involvement is perhaps unavoidable, that should not limit the freedoms of those nations even before the process of democratization has begun. Why, for example, should the Slovenes, Croatians and others not be free to choose if they wish to continue as part of the Yugoslav state or not, just as the Baltic nations are questioning their union with the U.S.S.R.?
There is no reason why these and other nations cannot participate directly in the European and world community. By forcing them to continue to be a part of an undesired union (historical evidence strongly supports this claim), we are not resolving but prolonging the international and political crisis in that region. We should support the processes that will bring about genuine personal and national freedoms. Half-measures will resolve little and please few.
 
ANTHONY CUVALO
 Columbus, Ohio, Dec. 30, 1989
The writer is lecturer at the Ohio State University international studies center.

HEADLINE: Don't Despair of the World the Young Will Build;
Wrong on 60's and 80's

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It's not hard to discern that Christopher Lasch is another frustrated unfulfilled 1960's protester who agonizes over the economic and political successes that our country has experienced in the 80's. In speaking of today's youth he states: ''They do not find it easy to think that things are going to get any better. The dream of a better world collapsed in the late 60's, and nothing has taken its place.'' 
Professor Lasch is wrong on both counts: he doesn't understand today's youth, and he doesn't understand the 60's. I was a college student from 1966 to 1970, and I can assure today's youth that the spirit of the 60's was full of hypocrisy and a false perception of the outside world. Doing drugs was the popular culture; it was safe to drop acid and get in touch with yourself. Today's youth would find this shocking, but in the 60's Communism was in.
It was chic to have a copy of Mao Zedong's little red book, and some chanted in protest ''Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh, N.L.F. is going to win.'' They wanted the United States out of Vietnam, so that peace could come. We got out, and the boat people let us know what it was like living under ''peaceful'' Communist tyranny. The youth of the 1960's have come to understand their immature babble, and that's why they have become the entrepreneurs of the 1980's, and most assuredly today's youth will follow right in our tracks.
Nor does Professor Lasch portray today's youth accurately. He says: ''they doubt the existence of the future . . . it is no wonder that young people long ago ceased to trust their elders.'' Excuse the bluntness, but this tired, unoriginal language is liberal claptrap.
I have 20 nieces and nephews, 6 have recently graduated from college, another is in college, and 2 more are in high school. Not one, among them or all their friends I've met, comes nearly close to the negative social character Professor Lasch portrays. Indeed, I am struck by how optimistic and, dare it be said, patriotic these young people are. They even translated Bruce Springsteen's antiwar, anti-Vietnam ''Born in the U.S.A.'' into a star-spangled patriotic anthem.
Professor Lasch seems to like malaise and just hopes that the sky will fall. It's sad, because it won't, and all the joy of life will pass him and his ilk by.
 
PAUL ATANASIO
 New York, Dec. 28, 1989

HEADLINE: Albany's Optimism Wanes As Budget Shortfall Grows

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 10

 BODY:
After several months of maintaining what analysts said was an overly optimistic view of New York's finances, the Cuomo administration today acknowledged that the state would end the fiscal year with a shortfall of almost $700 million.
Just a few weeks ago, administration officials had been denying reports that the shortfall would top $500 million.
The new estimate puts the shortfall at almost three times the last official estimate, which was released in November. The administration's latest revision of its budget figures reflects a pattern established during the last fiscal year, when the administration revised its financial estimates at least a half-dozen times. 
In a statement issued late this afternoon, the state's Budget Director, Dall W. Forsythe, attributed the growing budget gap to lower-than-expected tax collections in a number of areas.
 
Diminished Expectations
''Throughout the Northeast region of the United States, an economic slowdown has undermined projected revenues,'' Mr. Forsythe said.
The figures were released just six days before Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is to present his budget for the next fiscal year, which starts April 1. The dire circumstances they portray are likely to further diminish the already low expectations that most officials here have for the Governor's budget.
Because the budget gap has been acknowledged only late in the fiscal year, administration officials said it is unlikely that action will be taken to correct it before the next fiscal year. This means that the state will probably have to borrow hundreds of millions of dollars to meet its expenses through March. It also means that the shortfall for the fiscal year that starts in April is likely to grow to more than $2 billion. It is estimated now to be almost $1.5 billion.
Cuomo administration officials said that in the budget they will release on Tuesday they will present a plan to deal with the current year's gap as well as next year's.
 
Decline in Revenue
In November, the administration forecast a shortfall for the current fiscal year of $270 million. At that time, officials said costs for Medicaid and foster care were higher than anticipated and business-tax collections were lower than expected. By cutting state agency budgets by 2 percent, the administration was able to save roughly $130 million. This left a gap of $140 million in a total budget of almost $30 billion.
Until recently, adminstration officials insisted that the gap would not grow because tax collections would pick up in the second half of the fiscal year. But they said today that most taxe revenues had continued to decline.
Mr. Forsythe said that by the end of December, personal-income-tax collections were $260 million less than projected in November, while business taxes were off $166 million from earlier estimates. User fees and taxes were down $67 million and other tax revenues were off $73 million.
Financial analysts said they were disturbed by the new figures. ''The news is worse than we anticipated,'' said Hyman Grossman, a managing director of Standard & Poor's. ''We're going to have to see how the Governor tackles this next week.''
The state's worsening financial problems parallel those of New York City. Recently, Mayor David N. Dinkins, who has said the city is facing a budget gap that would total $200 million, indefinitely delayed hiring a class of more than 1,800 police recruits to save money.

HEADLINE: An Office Tower On Park Ave. Will Be Rebuilt

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
The 32-story former ITT building in Manhattan will be redesigned and substantially rebuilt starting early next year, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday, making it ''the first new building project on Park Avenue in more than a decade.''
Plans for the redevelopment of the building at 320 Park Avenue at East 51st Street, which is owned by Olympia & York, were announced by Mayor Dinkins and ITT officials at a City Hall news conference.
The project, expected to be completed in 1993, will create an estimated 1,160 temporary jobs in the construction field and another 480 in supporting fields, as well as generate more than $17 million in taxes and other income to the city, said Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. 
John E. Zuccotti, the president and chief executive officer of Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.), the American subsidiary of the Toronto-based real-estate giant, emphasized that the redevelopment involved no city subsidies or tax abatements. Mr. Zuccotti, whom Mr. Dinkins described as ''an old friend in a new job,'' was First Deputy Mayor in the administration of Mayor Abraham D. Beame.
 
Asbestos Removal
It was the second time this week that the Mayor had held a news conference at City Hall to help announce a private project.
As he did earlier, when the accounting concern of Coopers & Lybrand announced it had leased 600,000 square feet of office space at 1301 Avenue of the Americas, Mr. Dinkins pointed out that New York City, despite its financial problems, ''continues to produce and to generate jobs and revenue as companies and individuals invest in the future and grow.'' Coopers & Librand did not receive any city subsidies nor is it creating any new jobs.
The Park Avenue building, which was built in the 1960's, was acquired by Olympia & York, the largest commercial landlord in the city, in 1977. The building's primary tenant, ITT, will move early next year to another location - ''within New York City, of course, '' the Mayor said.
''With the building vacant,'' Mr. Dinkins added, ''Olympia & York will address an asbestos problem there.'' But he said that the owners will undertake ''a total redesign of the building, stripping it down to its original steel structure.''
The reconstructed building, like the current structure, will contain about 660,000 square feet of office space, said Meyer S. Frucher, the subsidiary's executive vice president for development. But he added that the existing steel frame will be reconfigured, providing larger tower floors and smaller base floors, giving the building a new look. It will be reclad in granite and reflective glass.
Mr. Frucher said the redevelopment would not affect an automobile showroom and a Japanese restaurant in the building. ''We will build around them,'' he said. The New York office of Skidmore Owings & Merrill will do the architectural work.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Casinos Fight Plan for Taxes On Gifts to Gamblers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 10

 BODY:
Atlantic City's casinos today tried to head off talk of a new tax on the complimentary items they dole out to high rollers with a study that they say shows Nevada is a far more hospitable place to do business.
Thomas Carver, head of the Atlantic City Casino Association, said at a news conference today that the casino industry is feeling the pinch of dropping profits. He said the industry is also hoping that Governor-elect James J. Florio will address some of the serious problems that plague the seaside resort. 
''It's often been said to us, 'You knew the rules of New Jersey when you came here,' '' Mr. Carver said. ''That's probably a fair statement. But one segment could change, and that's the issue of taxation.''
Some lawmakers have talked of extending the luxury tax on Atlantic City hotel rooms to cover the complimentary rooms, food, and beverages given out by the gaming halls to heavy bettors. Talk of such a tax expansion has been coupled with a search for sources of financing for a new convention center.
 
Lower Taxes in Nevada
A study by a Rutgers University professor, David Listokin, showed that the casino industry has paid $3.6 billion in local, state and Federal taxes and regulatory fees since the start of gaming in 1978; 58 percent of that has gone to the state.
New Jersey casinos pay taxes at a rate twice as high as those in Nevada, the study said.
''If New Jersey taxed us at the same rate that Nevada taxes its casinos, then we would have earned approximately $250 million more between 1978 and 1988,'' Mr. Carver said.
He said he is not proposing that New Jersey lower its 8 percent tax on casino revenues. But he said lawmakers should move with caution if they want to raise taxes.
He said that casinos are already weathering tough financial times, and that placing a greater burden on them could hurt a critical source of state revenue and the underpinnings of the economy in the Atlantic City area.
