HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
FOR many adults, the amount of money they make and how they choose to spend it is the most private of affairs. Money is a topic laden with symbolism, a source of pride or of shame, a standard for measuring success and competence after concern with school grades or football touchdowns has passed. It also brings about conflicting feelings of competitiveness between parents and children, who can be both proud and jealous of each other's success.
For many families, financial facts and figures are at least as private as their sex lives. The adult who talks freely about sexual partners will almost always consider an inquiry about salary invasive. Information shared with accountants is treated with roughly the same concern for privacy as a confession heard by a priest. 
Money is also a topic filled with emotions and memories, for the ability to make important financial decisions without getting one's parents' permission is a marker of adulthood. All of this makes money a stressful subject for many adults and their parents to discuss, especially if they have disparate incomes or different approaches to family finances.
''I don't talk to my parents about money at all, except to let them know that we're doing fine,'' said Darlene A., a 31-year-old office manager in Minneapolis who asked that her full name not be used. She has not broached the subject since she left her parents' home in rural Wisconsin after graduating from high school.
''When the topic comes up, I feel very uncomfortable,'' she said, adding that her parents would be upset by the way she and her husband handle their financial affairs. ''I think they would feel bad because I have more education and make more money.''
''We don't save money; we're more into make it now, spend it now,'' she explained. ''They paid $5,000 cash for their home in the 1950's. They got their first credit card three years ago and may use it once a month to put gas in their car.''
The intense emotions that Darlene associates with money are not unusual. She worries about her parents' approval, even though she and her husband are financially more successful than her parents. The mere mention of family finances makes her feel as if she is being judged and reminds her of childhood experiences. She handles the situation by avoiding the topic. Other adults and their parents find that discussing family finances usually leads to arguments.
''I see this in families where money means a lot in terms of who's worthwhile and who holds the power,'' said Dr. Carol Rubin, a psychologist in Newton, Mass., and a co-author of ''When Families Fight'' (William Morrow, 1989, $16.95). ''When adult children and their parents fight, the issues often go back to childhood.''
Each generation's approach to personal finance reflects childhood experiences. People who grew up during a financial depression imbue money with different characteristics than do those who grew up when high inflation meant that saving was foolish and buying on credit was prudent. Those whose parents viewed money as a symbol of their love or authority sometimes have difficulty distinguishing between the two, especially during times of crisis.
Dr. Kenneth O. Doyle, a financial counselor and a professor of family social science at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, has been studying how family members handle money at different ages. He has found that the symbolic ways in which an adult uses money are based upon the type of loss a person fears most.
''Money is often used as a talisman against a loss of affection, competence, reputation or control,'' he said.
Dr. Bernard Poduska, a professor of family sciences at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, who has taught psychological counseling skills to financial advisers, said, ''One of the things that money can do is make the intangible tangible.''
''Some children grow up hearing things like, 'How much do you love me? Look how much I spent on you,' '' he explained.
 
Making It Easier to Talk
EXPERTS on family relationships recommend the following steps to make it easier for adults and their parents to discuss finances.
Acknowledge that money is an emotional subject. ''When you talk about finances you're talking about feelings,'' said Dr. Bernard Poduska, a professor of family sciences at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah. Discussing money will be more difficult if you do not acknowledge that you associate net worth with self-worth.
Avoid falling back into old, outdated roles. It is very easy for either generation of adults to take on the role of young child or all-knowing parent. This simply aggravates the problem.
''If the parents help out a child financially, that can be a throwback to an earlier style of relationship,'' said Dr. M. Duncan Stanton, the director of the family division of the department of psychiatry at the University of Rochester. ''The parent wants to be benevolent, but the adult children may feel like they're no longer independent and are being pulled back into a child's role.'' Be willing to accept each other's differences. Recognize that each of you has the right to determine your own goals and the amount of risk you are willing to take. Respect the recipient's dignity. Parents, for example, sometimes find it uncomfortable to accept even much-needed money from their children. Asking for money or even endorsing a check from their children can hurt their sense of pride. It is often less emotionally painful to arrange for a regular automatic transfer of funds from the donor's bank account to the recipient's. A little formality in handling loans can be good for everyone. If you lend money to a family member without specifying the terms in writing, both the lender and the borrower can be unsure of what is expected of them. This can foster feelings of dependency and anger on the part of the borrower, especially if he or she is an adult.
Typically, this happens when adults borrow money from their parents for a major purchase like a house. Each generation can become confused about how much of a say they have in how that and other money is spent. Does accepting a loan or a gift mean you must abdicate some control over your life? Do you have the right to put some constraints on the money you are lending?
''Making a loan as a businesslike transaction helps the adult child's self-esteem,'' Dr. Stanton said.

HEADLINE: Ozone Issue: Economics of a Ban

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
As industrial nations move toward a ban on ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons - the refrigerant used in air-conditioners and refrigerators -by 2000, another problem looms: the likely replacement, although an improvement, also harms the atmosphere.
The problem grows out of the Montreal Protocol, an agreement signed by most of the developed nations in 1987, pledging to cut by half the production of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's for short, by 1998 to preserve the earth's protective ozone layer. This summer, chemical industry officials and environmental groups predict, the agreement will likely be strengthened to a complete ban on production by 2000.
The issue now being debated is how long the likely replacement for CFC's will be used. Environmental advocates are pushing for an early phase-out date for the best available replacement - hydrochlorofluorocarbons, or HCFC's - as a means of spurring research to find alternatives that do not damage the ozone layer. 
But chemical companies reply that moving quickly to phase out the replacement for CFC's could result in a critical shortage of refrigeration fluids that will be essential to preserve food and drug supplies later in the decade. The chemical producers explain that unless they are assured enough production time to recoup their investments, they will not build factories to make the replacement.
The chemical companies contend that they need assurances of up to 60 years of production of the replacements to justify making multibillion-dollar investments in new factories to meet the projected demand.
 
Difficult Trade-Off
The result is a public policy debate that pits environmentalists against chemical makers led by the Du Pont Company. And the dispute illustrates the kind of difficult trade-off that will increasingly be encountered as the global drive to protect the environment runs into economic and practical obstacles.
Shortages of refrigerants, should they occur, would be more than an inconvenience. Some 75 percent of the nation's food supply depends on chilling at some point along the processing and distribution chain, while blood supplies and many medicines also need to be continuously chilled.
More than two billion pounds a year of CFC's are used worldwide, about a third of that total in the United States; the uses include not only refrigeration but fields like insulation and electronics.
When released to the air, the CFC's and other chlorine-containing gases rise to the upper atmosphere and break into their constituent elements by solar radiation. The chlorine released is widely believed to attack the layer of ozone that shields the earth's surface from harmful solar waves. CFC's are estimated to constitute almost 60 percent of the man-made ozone-depleting elements that enter the atmosphere.
Substitutes for CFC's that are not hazardous have been found for many applications. But the best replacements in cooling equipment, refrigerant producers say, are hydrochlorofluorocarbons. Yet HCFC's contain ozone-depleting chlorine, too, although at a much lower level than CFC's.
''HCFC's represent a significant improvement,'' said F. Anthony Vogelsberg, environmental manager for Du Pont's Freon Products division. ''They have one-tenth the lifetime and one-tenth to one-twentieth the ozone-depletion potential. But they do not represent zero risk.''
Most big chemical companies insist that HCFC's are the best replacement until a new generation of compounds can be developed that do not contain chlorine. But environmental groups, seeking to force the pace of technological development, are urging that an early date be set for elimination of HCFC's as well.
Michael S. Clark, chief executive of Friends of the Earth, said CFC makers did little to develop non-chlorine replacements after CFC's were removed from aerosol cans in this country in 1978 because of concerns about the atmosphere. ''There ought to be a lot more research on refrigerants,'' he said. ''There certainly was not much done in the 1970's.''
 
Research 'Hiatus' Feared
David Doniger, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, which has pushed for the CFC ban, has similar concerns. He said development of HCFC's, as well as the chlorine-free hydrofluorocarbons, was placed ''on the back burner'' in 1980. ''We lost six to eight years of research,'' he said. ''We do not want another hiatus in development.''
Other materials can be used as refrigerants, but are either unproved or have known drawbacks. Ammonia, widely used before CFC's were developed, is toxic. Other potential candidates are flammable, corrosive or need to operate at pressures too high to be practical for home appliances.
A provision to ban HCFC production by 2010 is expected to be introduced in the Senate this year when legislation to renew the Clean Air Act comes up for debate.
Some companies, including Du Pont, which produces half the CFC's used in this country, are balking at building plants to produce HCFC's unless they see a way to recover their costs. ''We need a 20-year life cycle to pay for these investments,'' Mr. Vogelsberg said. ''So if you say, 'Phase out by 2010,' that means do not build after 1990.'' Du Pont favors using the materials until sometime between 2030 and 2050.
 
Estimated Cost in Billions
Mr. Vogelsberg said the company would have to invest about $1 billion over the next decade to have enough HCFC production to supply its share of the current CFC market. Worldwide, he said, $4 billion to $6 billion will have to be spent to produce substitutes to CFC's.
Du Pont has built several pilot plants to make HCFC's in small quantities, but is holding back on large operations until the deadlines for phasing out HCFC's are clarified. Other chemical producers are going ahead with production plants, but with misgivings.
William M. Corcoran, an official of Allied-Signal Inc,, said the company believes its HCFC investments represent a ''great risk.'' Officials of ICI Americas Inc. have said that if the United States attempts to impose more stringent standards than other countries, the whole movement to phase out CFC's may be thrown into confusion.
Users of refrigerants are also concerned. Most are still trying to figure out how to adapt their designs to use HCFC's, which have less lubricating ability than CFC's, in equipment that customers expect to run for 15 to 20 years without maintenance. Industry officials say there is $135 billion worth of cooling devices in operation in the United States that are dependent on CFC's.
 
'A Wrench in Planning'
''Talking about putting time limits on HCFC's throws a wrench in corporate planning,'' said Kevin Fay, director of the Alliance for a Responsible CFC Policy, an industry group. ''These are products they expect to be still selling in 2010.''
But it is equally unrealistic to decide now to permit HCFC's until 2050, argues Mr. Doniger of the Natural Resources Defense Council, since the effect of chlorine on the atmosphere is still not fully understood. ''It does not make any sense to talk about dates beyond 2020, because it is beyond the planning horizon of businessmen,'' he said.
He said Congressional sponsors of proposals to put time limits on HCFC's might compromise on when the phasing out would begin, giving the producers more time to recover investments. ''This is a very important moment,'' he said.
As supplies of CFC's dwindle, they will also become more expensive, if only because of a special tax imposed by Congress last year. The producer price of CFC had been averaging about $1 a pound. But starting this year, the most commonly used compounds will be taxed at $1.37 a pound, and the tax is to increase to almost $5 a pound by the end of the century. The average refrigerator needs a few pounds of the material.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Market Uneasy On Fears About Soviets

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Fears about political turmoil in the Soviet Union helped undermine a record-setting stock market rally, causing prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange to skid over the last week in an increasingly nervous investment climate.
On Wednesday, investors on the Tokyo Stock Exchange succumbed to concerns that ethnic unrest in the Soviet Union threatened President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's hold on power, sending the Nikkei average of 225 stocks down 254.95 points, to 37,696.51, after a 343.50-point decline Tuesday.
Last Friday, the index tumbled 438.12 points on another rumor, which proved unfounded, that Mr. Gorbachev had canceled all of his scheduled January meetings with foreign leaders because of growing political unrest. The 3 percent decline from Friday to Wednesday yis comparable to about an 80-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. Bond prices have also fallen steadily this year and interest rates have popped upward. 
There was evidence today that the fears may have begun to ease as the stock market rallied. The Nikkei index gained 473.62 points, or 1.3 percent. to close at 38,170.13.
 
'Realistic Appraisal'
Still, the market remains worried.
''Perestroika was a theme that had been driving the market last year because people thought it would stimulate a whole new round of global economic growth,'' said Lawrence S. Prager, senior analyst at the Nikko Securities Company. ''What the rumors have shown is that people are now making a more realistic appraisal of the economic prospects for Eastern Europe.''
Reflecting the unsettled state of the markets, the dollar has risen against a weakening yen. The dollar reached 145.30 yen in Tokyo Wednesday, up from 144.95 in New York late Tuesday, despite heavy dollar selling by the Bank of Japan. Currency traders said the central bank has intervened in the foreign-exchange market every day this week, in a largely unsuccessful effort to stabilize the yen.
Even though the dollar selling was apparently ineffective, the central bank's governor, Yasushi Mieno, said at a news conference Wednesday that the bank would continue to intervene when necessary.
 
Overreaction Seen
''I think in part people were too optimistic at the end of last year and so they were surprised when interest rates rose at first, so they have overreacted by selling the yen and bonds too much,'' said an executive at the Industrial Bank of Japan. ''But there is a real edge to what is happening. Everybody is anxious about everybody else, what the other person is doing.''
Some analysts described the tumble as more a symptom of a growing nervousness here than a direct result of concerns about troubles in the Soviet Union. In particular, there are worries about the domestic political situation, with an election approaching. There have been reports in the Japanese press that another stock and influence-peddling scandal may be brewing.
In addition, the stock market has been falling on relatively light volume, a sign that big institutions have not joined in the selling.
Shares of smaller companies listed on the second section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange have continued to reach record highs, indicating that speculative interest in the market has not died, analysts said.
 
'Red Chip' Stocks
Nonetheless, the stories about the Soviet Union have clearly hit a raw nerve among investors, who had been betting, perhaps too heavily, that Japanese companies were poised to capitalize on the opening of the Eastern bloc economies.
The market rally late last year had been led by what came to be known as ''red chip'' stocks, shares of companies expected to benefit from the economic opening of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Share prices of the major trading companies, heavy machinery makers and electrical equipment producers all rose sharply in the expectation that they might be able to increase their exports to Eastern Europe.
The recent rumors have hit these shares particularly hard. Two trading companies, Mitsui & Company and the Marubeni Corporation, fell Wednesday, as did Komatsu, which produces tractors, and Toshiba Machinery.

HEADLINE: Banks Told to Add Reserves

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Federal regulators have ordered banks to more than double their reserves for loans to Argentina, an official said today.
The move is expected to reduce bank profits in the fourth quarter. 
In letters to the nation's largest banks, banking agencies instructed them to increase loss reserves on loans to Argentina to 35 percent of the loan amounts, from 15 percent, when they report October-December results, said an official of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, who asked not to be identified.
The move stems from a recomendation by the Interagency Country Review Committee, which coordinates third-world lending matters among banking agencies, including the F.D.I.C., the Federal Reserve Board and the Comptroller of the Currency.
Some banks probably already have loss reserves large enough to cover 35 percent of their loans to Argentina. But others, like Citibank and the Bank of America, have proportionately smaller loss reserves for third-world debt than their competitors.
Jim Mitchell, a spokesman for the BankAmerica Corporation, said the bank was aware of the new reserve requirement but declined to say how it would affect his institution.
In the third quarter, the nation's 12,800 commercial banks collectively recorded a $744 million loss. The industry was pushed into the red by $5.3 billion in third-world debt losses at five large banks.
Argentina owed $6.2 billion to United States banks at the end of September. Its economy has deteriorated sharply and its currency, the austral, has lost 99 percent of its value over the last year. Citicorp

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields End Week Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday.
According to analysts at Donoghue's, yields are returning to near-normal levels after rising because of end-of-the-year factors. Yields will move down, they said, but it will take longer because of pressures on the domestic market resulting from rising interest rates abroad. 
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market mutual fund fell 29 basis points, to 8.10 percent, while the 30-day yield fell 2 basis points, to 8.24 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Taxable Fund Assets Up
Assets of taxable funds rose $9.6 billion, to $366.6 billion. Donoghue's analysts said much of the increase came from consumer funds, whose assets increased by $6.9 billion, to $287.7 billion.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios declined by one day, to 38, as managers played on higher short-term rates.
Best among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's were the Alger Money Market Portfolio, distributed by Fred Alger & Company of Jersey City, and Dreyfus World Wide dollar Money Market Fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation in Garden City, L.I., Both funds had a return of 9.04 percent, or about 94 basis points better than the average yield in the week.
Tax-exempt assets increased by $4.7 billion, to $69.9 billion, reflecting a rise in rates. These higher short-term rates made money market funds more attractive since the yields usually lag behind market changes and remain higher for a few weeks longer. The average seven-day compounded yield decreased 43 basis points, to 5.64 percent. The taxable equivalent was 7.83 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 8.41 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
The top-performing fund during the week was the Evergreen Tax-Exempt Money Market Trust, distributed by the Fidelity Distributors Corporation in Boston. Donoghue's said the fund posted a return of 6.40 percent, or about 76 points better than the average.
By contrast, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed bank money market accounts down 2 basis points, to 6.33 percent, and the average yield for six month C.D.'s fell 2 basis points, to 7.90 percent.
Certificates with longer maturities were down, except for five-year C.D.'s, which were unchanged at 7.91 percent. One-year C.D.'s fell 2 basis points, to 7.93 percent, and two-and-a-half-year C.D's dropped one basis point, to 7.89 percent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Continue to Slide; Dow Off by 15.36

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
The stock market continued to retreat yesterday on sharply higher volume.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished 15.36 points lower, at 2,750.64. Futures-related program selling was given some of the blame. Volume rose to nearly 176 million shares, from 155 million on Tuesday. 
The loss for the day was the fifth in six sessions since the Dow opened the new year with a gain of 56.95 points on Tuesday, Jan. 2, to close at 2,810.15, its highest level ever. Since then, the Dow has given up 66.55 points, with its only daily gain coming in Monday's session, when it was up 21.12 points.
Other, broader indicators have also fallen below levels they reached on the first trading day of the year. Yesterday, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.31 points, to 347.31. It had closed the first day of the year at 353.40. The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 1.23 points yesterday, to 192.12. It had finished at 195.04 on the opening day.
 
Concern Over Rates
''The market's slippage is tied to the anticipation of lower interest rates, which do not appear to be in the cards before April,'' said Alan Titunik, executive vice president and managing director of the Davis/Dinsmore Management Corporation. He cited bullish signals in the economy that might dissuade the Federal Reserve from easing credit further.
Mr. Titunik suggested that many traders were waiting to see what the bond market would do before they committed further to stocks. Yesterday, the credit markets showed little movement, with the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond unchanged at a price of 100 16/32, to yield 8.08 percent.
The 1,053 stocks that declined in price on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday were more than double the 516 issues that advanced.
Among individual issues, Citicorp slipped 1/4, to 27, and was the most active stock, with a volume of nearly 3.7 million shares. Canada's financially troubled Campeau Corporation, owner of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, is under pressure to come up with a restructuring agreement that will satisfy Citibank, Citicorp's banking subsidiary and Campeau's senior creditor. Traders said that if this is not accomplished, Citibank can declare $2.34 billion of debt in default on Monday.
 
Mining Issues Advance
Gold stocks were buoyed by rising gold prices, nervousness about the Japanese and United States stock markets and uncertainty over the outlook for the dollar. Gold soared $8.20 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to $412.40 an ounce. In response, ASA Ltd. jumped 2 3/8, to 59 5/8; Homestake Mining, 7/8, to 20 3/4, and Sunshine Mining 1/4, to 3 3/4.
Newmont Mining, also a precious metals producer, rose 2 3/4, to 50 3/8. A Drexel Burham Lambert analyst, Nicholas Toufexis, re-emphasized his ''buy'' rating on the stock, citing it as being relatively inexpensive.
Pepsico dropped 1 5/8, to 60 3/4. Analysts estimated that the company's earnings would come in at $3.35 to $3.40 a share for 1989, up from $2.90 a share in 1988.
Active blue chips included Philip Morris, off 1/2, to 39 3/4; General Electric, up 1/8, to 64 3/4; A.T.& T., off 1/4, to 45; I.B.M., down 3/8, to 99; G.M., off 3/8, to 43 1/2, and Bristol-Myers Squibb, up 3/4, to 56 1/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index dropped 2.15 points, to 378.29, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index plunged 6.07 points, to 450.70.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Seven-Year Notes Well Received

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A successful auction of $7.5 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes helped to bring prices in the credit markets off their lows yesterday. As a consequence, prices in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds closed narrowly mixed.
Sellers emerged early in the session, encouraged by a sharp run-up in energy prices. But the results of the auction, plus a fall in stock prices, helped to offset developments in the oil markets. 
Market participants said the auction went smoothly, even though Japanese interest in the securities seemed minimal.
''Considering everything that has been going on lately, from the worries about inflation to selling of long-term securities by the Japanese, it was a terrific auction,'' said Neil Dubrow, a vice president at Voute, Coats, Stuart & O'Grady, a bond trading firm in Greenwich, Conn. ''The seven-year is a very attractive piece of paper.''
At the auction the notes were sold at an average yield of 8.02 percent, down from the 8.08 percent average yield produced at the last seven-year note auction on Oct. 11.
Mr. Dubrow and others said that much of the demand for the new notes emanated from speculative accounts that would use the securities in arbitrage-related trading activity. Such trading commonly involves a swap between two similar issues based on an anticipated change in price spreads.
 
Interest in Notes Intensified
Interest in the notes intensified after the auction results were released, and by late yesterday the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.98 percent.
The results had a salutary effect on prices in the secondary market for Treasury securities. By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 100 1/2, up 3/ 32, to yield 8.08 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 2/ 32, down 2/32, to yield 8.01 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 10/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.90 percent.
Meanwhile, Treasury bill rates dipped further. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.48 percent, down by four basis points, or hundreths of a point. And six-month bill rates dipped by six basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.36 percent.
The decline in bill rates coincided with a slide in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market. Yesterday the Federal Reserve did not conduct open market operations when the funds rate was at 8 1/4 percent, the level most analysts see as the Fed's target.
Later in the day the rate slipped to a low of 7 7/8 percent, but analysts said the decline was due to technical factors associated with the end of a two-week bank reserve maintenance period.
''We expect funds to open the new reporting period on Thursday at 8 3/ 16 percent,'' analysts at MMS International, an economic information service company, said in their daily market commentary. They added that ''we expect the funds rate target to remain at 8 1/4 percent at least through early February.''
 
New Taxable Bonds
New taxable bond issues priced yesterday included a $250 million offering from the Province of Manitoba and a $500 million asset-backed transaction for Sears, Roebuck & Company.
The Manitoba offering, 8.80 percent 30-year debentures that mature Jan. 15, 2020, was priced at $99.682, to yield 8.83 percent, or 73 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/8 percent 30-year Treasury bonds at the time of pricing. The debentures are noncallable for life.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the transaction, which is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Sears, Roebuck offering, which is backed by receivables from the retailer's consumer credit cards, matures on Jan. 15, 1995. The 8.75 percent notes were priced at $99.459, to yield 8.80 percent, 87 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 7 3/4 percent five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Dean Witter Reynolds acted as lead manager for the transaction, which is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's. The securities are noncallable for life.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Florida's State Board of Education offered $125 million of general obligation bonds at competitive bid. A bid from an investor group led by First Boston won the issue, which consists of serial and term bonds.
Coupons on the serial bonds range from 5.60 percent in 1990 to 2010 on bonds maturing in 2010. The term issue, which matures in 2019, carries a coupon of 7.10 percent. The issue is rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the high-yield ''junk bond'' market, completion of RJR Nabisco's sale of its Del Monte processed foods business for $1.48 billion to a group led by Merrill Lynch & Company was the focal point of activity.
Traders said a flurry of buying activity followed the announcement, but that by late in the day prices of most RJR securities were down by about a quarter of a point.
News that the Campeau Corporation will make timely payments to suppliers did not help lift prices of Allied Stores and Federated Department Stores, Campeau's major retailing subsidiaries.
Despite the news, most traders said they still expected Campeau's huge debt burdens to force the company to file for bankruptcy. But they added that such a development would not have a big effect on prices of Allied and Federated's outstanding bonds.
''We are all waiting for the Campeau shoe to drop,'' one junk bond trader said. ''But once they do file there will probably be little change in prices. Allied and Federated debt is already trading at levels associated with companies that are in Chapter 11.''

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
European and Asian Buyers Push Gold Sharply Higher

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Precious metals prices climbed yesterday, led by increased demand for gold in Europe and Asia.
Dealers attributed much of the renewed buying to the weakness of the domestic and Japanese stock markets in recent days.
Concern about the ability of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to overcome political and economic problems has also contributed to the rise in gold. 
At the close of the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for delivery this month settled at $412.40 an ounce, up $8.20 on the day. The same silver contract climbed 8.2 cents an ounce in sympathy, to $5.316. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, spot January platinum futures settled at $497.90 an ounce, up $9.
 
Tokyo Stock Slump Cited
''Aside from increasing concern about President Gorbachev's position in Europe and elsewhere, this week's slump on the Tokyo and other Asian stock markets prompted more investors to turn to gold,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''Later, when the New York stock market began to weaken further, it also helped the gold market.''
Ms. Raptopoulos said reports that the Soviet Government had doubled prices of gold jewelry to discourage consumers from exchanging their paper money for precious metals, gems and other traditional stores of value also buoyed the precious metals market.
Bradford H. Hughes, energy analyst at Cargill Investor Services, said the latest weekly report by the American Petroleum Institute showed a sharp decline in the nation's stocks of gasoline and a modest decrease in heating oil but only a slight reduction in the supply of crude oil.
''Compared with a year ago, stocks of gasoline and heating oil are way down, while crude oil supplies are sharply higher,'' Mr. Hughes said. ''As a result, gas prices led the advance, followed by heating oil. Crude oil prices rose in sympathy, largely on the belief that the strong byproduct markets would eventually help crude.''
In any event, the close of the New York Mercantile Exchange found the spot, or nearest, unleaded gasoline delivery, February, up 3.45 cents a gallon, at 64.33 cents, while the same heating oil contract soared 1.83 cents a gallon, to 66.88 cents. The spot February delivery of the high-grade West Texas Intermediate crude oil rose 83 cents a barrel, to $22.90.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Volatile Day; Central Bank Action Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher yesterday against major foreign currencies in volatile trading following reports of central bank intervention.
Currency dealers said the dollar initially fell because of the continued strength in the West German mark. But they said the dollar was later lifted by reports that the Federal Reserve bought dollars for marks and that West Germany's central bank sold marks for yen.
''That was the story of the day,'' said Linda McLaughlin, a trader with Chemical New York Capital Markets Group.
Dealers said the market was awaiting new data that will shed more light on the United States economy. Tomorrow the government is set to release reports on December producer prices and retail sales.
In late New York trading, the dollar stood at 145.55 yen, up from 144.92 yen late Tuesday. The dollar again weakened against sterling, which rose to $1.6625, from $1.6585.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6825 marks, up from 1.6730; 1.5165 Swiss francs, up from 1.5145; 5.7265 French francs, up from 5.7025; 1,257.25 Italian lire, up from 1,251.25, and 1.15855 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16055.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Tuesday, were: 1.6795 West German marks, down from 1.6823; 1.5120 Swiss francs, down from 1.5260; 5.7145 French francs, down from 5.7305; 1.8815 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8970; 1,255.00 Italian lire, down from 1,257.75, and 1.1585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1610.

HEADLINE: Bush Hails a Thaw in China; Congress Is Skeptical

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
President Bush today hailed the lifting of martial law in China as ''a very sound step,'' but he found little support in Congress for his view that China's action was significant or that his policy toward Beijing was effective.
Republican as well as Democratic lawmakers said they were not persuaded by Administration statements that China had taken an important step toward ending political oppression there.
Representative William S. Broomfield of Michigan, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Affairs Committee, said the lifting of martial law ''is more blue smoke and mirrors and would not fool anybody in Congress into believing that the Chinese leadership was moderating its oppressive rule.''
In Beijing, a few people strolled in Tiananmen Square, which was reopened with the lifting of martial law on Wednesday, and quietly speculated about whether the shifting political breezes may be carrying the first signs of a thaw. [Page A3.] But Mr. Broomfield said the Government's move ''simply shifts the responsibility for oppression from the military to the police.'' 
 
An Unusual Rebuff
The unusually stern rebuff from a Republican normally supportive of the President suggested that Mr. Bush's high-level diplomacy with Beijing had not produced enough results to reverse sentiment in Congress.
Lawmakers have voted overwhelmingly in favor of economic, military and political sanctions against China, which imposed martial law in Beijing in a violent crackdown on dissent in early June.
Representative Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee, said tonight: ''I am pleased that China has lifted martial law. But I don't think that suggests that a policy of democratization is suddenly taking place, or that China is any more worthy of our friendship.''
''We should not forget what happened in Tiananmen Square,'' said Mr. Edwards, who holds the fourth-ranking position in the House Republican leadership.
With conservative Republicans saying that there was bipartisan opposition to Mr. Bush's policy, and that the United States should not support any World Bank loans to China, the President's handling of Beijing appeared to be returning to the forefront of debate here. The issue has been overshadowed in recent weeks by the invasion of Panama and by events in Rumania.
 
Other Possible Steps
But Congressional aides and Administration officials said the criticism of Mr. Bush's policy might diminish if China takes a few more steps, like freeing some of the student leaders from prison and allowing the dissident Fang Lizhi to leave China. Mr. Fang, an astrophysicist, took refuge in the American Embassy in China after the violent crackdown in June.
Administration officials have declined to say whether Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, asked the Chinese to lift martial law when he visited Beijing in July and in December. It is widely believed here that Mr. Bush was hoping for such a step, and that the White House expected the lifting of martial law to help turn Congressional sentiment in favor of the President's policy.
On Wednesday, liberal Democrats criticized Mr. Bush for easing his opposition to World Bank loans for China. Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, said that the lifting of martial law was ''an empty gesture.''
In an interview today, Representative Dan Burton, a conservative Republican from Indiana, said, ''There are an awful lot of conservatives who feel just as strongly as Nancy Pelosi.''
Opposition to Mr. Bush's policy on China ''cuts across party lines,'' Mr. Burton said. ''I am a great supporter of President Bush and Vice President Quayle. But I believe that this opening to China, this easing up on China, without any substantial changes there is totally wrong. People on both sides of the aisle in Congress - Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives - feel disappointment with the trips to China'' by Mr. Scowcroft and by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger.
 
'Why Can't China Do It?'
Mr. Burton said the United States should continue to oppose World Bank loans to China because the lifting of martial law was ''a superficial, cosmetic change.''
''For us to give any assistance to a continuing repressive regime like Communist China, when the countries of Eastern Europe are making dramatic progress toward democracy, is just ludicrous,'' he said. ''If East Germany and Rumania can make democratic changes, why can't China do it?''
Mr. Bush described the end of martial law as ''a good sign.'' He reaffirmed his policy, saying: ''I do not want to isolate China by no contact and set the clock back. And, of course, we welcome the lifting of martial law, a good sign.''
''I view the lifting of martial law as a very sound step,'' he said at a brief picture-taking session at the White House. ''For those that are interested in human rights and the reform that was on the move and that we'd all like to see go forward, there's no way you can look at that and not say it is very positive.''
 
Passports Revoked
Lian-Chao Han, vice president of the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars, which represents most of the 40,000 Chinese students in the United States, said that Beijing was trying to ''track down leaders of the democracy movement at the same time it tries to improve its international image and show the world that China is back to normal.''
The New China News Agency, the official Chinese press agency, said Sunday that Beijing was revoking the passports of three prominent Chinese exiles who had founded the overseas Federation for Democracy in China.
The Chinese Ministry of Public Security said that the three were wanted as criminals because they had ''incited, plotted and directed the turmoil and counterrevolutionary revolt in China.''
The three are Yan Jiaqi, president of the federation, which was founded in Paris in September; Wan Runnan, one of China's leading businessmen, and Chen Yizi, who advised Zhao Ziyang before Mr. Zhao was ousted in May as leader of the Chinese Communist Party.
The State Department declined today to specify additional steps that China should take to establish democracy. But in response to a question, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said that China, like other countries, should allow ''peaceful demonstrations.''
Although Tiananmen Square was reopened to the public, police officers and other security personnel were on the alert for signs of trouble.
Responding to news reports, State Department officials said they did not have evidence to determine whether China was keeping its commitment not to sell medium-range missiles in the Middle East.
China dismissed press reports that it was planning to sell M-9 ballistic missiles to Syria as ''utterly groundless,'' and Miss Tutwiler said, ''We take these public comments at face value.'' An Arabic-language newspaper in London said this week that China had promised to sell ''advanced weapons'' to Syria.

HEADLINE: A European Market for Consumer Goods Opens

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Recent developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe offer the United States an opportunity to establish conditions that will serve both its domestic economic needs and its interests in promoting world peace and stability. Unfortunately, to judge by published reports, the United States appears to be missing the boat.
A principal reason for the unrest in Eastern Europe is the inability of controlled economies to satisfy the longings of their people for basic consumer goods. It is unlikely that the industries in these countries can satisfy those needs in the near future. Nor are the countries likely to produce the necessary foreign exchange to buy them in the West. However, if these goods do not soon become available, the reform movements may wither, and repressive regimes may take their place. 
The United States should embark on a major program to make available to the countries of Eastern Europe the dollars to buy consumer goods in the United States. The United States should create a fund for this purpose and agree to receive in return nonconvertible foreign exchange pegged at a fixed exchange rate in relation to the dollar to be used for investments in the foreign countries or to be converted into dollars at some future time.
Such a program would enable the reform movements in Eastern Europe to meet longings for basic consumer goods without spending foreign exchange they do not have. Such a program would create unparalleled opportunities for American industry to gain a foothold in what may become enormous future markets. It would capitalize on the reputation American consumer goods still enjoy in Europe and create markets for American goods for a long time in the future. Such a program would also stimulate American industry to do better in seeking out new markets. It would permit American industry to give the Japanese and Europeans a run for the East Europeans' money.
And it need not add a penny to the United States budget. For the United States could simply use whatever it can take out of its military budget and put it into this program for the heart of Eastern Europe. Furthermore, American industry would not have to suffer from military cutbacks because it could focus on making products more likely to contribute to human happiness. And it would give the United States a long-term policy for economic growth and optimum employment.
The program can readily be implemented with the cooperation of Eastern leaders. They appear to have little choice but to hail the United States for its initiative.
 
HANS SMIT
New York, Dec. 27, 1989
 The writer is director of the Parker School of Foreign and Comparative Law at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Saints Ready for Indoor Season Opener

BYLINE: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 11

 BODY:
Introducing some of his players at a news conference today, Tom Flatley, the general manager of the New York Saints, described Scott Huff as an enforcer. Huff seemed to preen.
There is no position entitled enforcer in the Major Indoor Lacrosse League and its officials are chary of promoting violence as a feature of the game. ''We don't want to scare away the mothers,'' Flatley said. 
''But let's face it,'' said Huff, who is a midfielder. ''This is a contact game. What we're selling is speed, hitting and scoring. Me and Richie are the hitters.''
Rich Mullen, like Huff, played a little football in college, at C. W. Post, and they go into the corners to ''dig the ball out like in ice hockey,'' Huff said.
Indoor lacrosse is a blend of outdoor lacrosse and ice hockey, played by six-man teams on an artificial turf surface about the size of a hockey rink with boards around it. The Major Indoor Lacrosse League is in its fourth season and seems to have found an audience.
The Saints will open their season Friday night here in Nassau Coliseum against the Philadelphia Wings, who beat them, 11-10, in last season's championship game. The Saints-Wings rivalry is the most intense in the league and Coliseum officials are hoping for a crowd of 10,000.
According to Coliseum figures, the Saints averaged 8,600 in four home games last year and that average has climbed since the first season, when the team played at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
 
The Other Teams
Other franchise locations are the Baltimore Arena for the Thunder; Joe Louis Arena in Detroit for the Turbos; the Centrum in Worcester, Mass., for the New England Blazers, and the Civic Arena in Pittsburgh for the Bulls. The Washington Wave was moved to Pittsburgh by Chris Fritz and Russ Cline of Kansas City, Mo., who own all of the franchises.
Fritz, who is president of the league, and Cline, senior vice president, are partners in an entertainment promotion business in automobile, concert, convention, sports and trade show areas. Cline said that the league is marginally profitable and that the gross revenues, for example, went from $800,000 the first season to $3 million the second.
They plan to put franchises in several other cities beginning with Chicago and Los Angeles. But expansion will wait until economic stability is achieved, Cline said.
Indoor lacrosse features constant action through four 15-minute periods, a 45-second shot clock and an average of 72 shots and 24 goals a game. It's a rough game in which boarding, slashing and cross-checking can draw penalties.
''From a spectator standpoint I think we've got an edge on hockey and soccer because we've got scoring and they don't,'' said Flatley, a longtime high school lacrosse coach at Sewanhaka High in Elmont, L.I.
The players are former college athletes who hold conventional jobs, but have a passion for their sport and play for little money. The salary scale runs from $100 a game for a first-year player to $300 for a four-year veteran.
The season, eight games for each team plus playoffs, ends in late March and then many of the Saints will change into the uniforms of the Long Island Lacrosse Club to play the outdoor game.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Havel Traces Passage 'From Jail to the Castle'

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Jan. 11

 BODY:
President Vaclav Havel's third-floor office in the Prague Castle these days has the urgent chaos of a theater stage the day after opening night. Mail is piled on the floor. Young secretaries and assistants rush in and out. Unwanted paintings stand around against the wall like discarded scenery. Telephones ring and ring and often go unanswered.
The Czechoslovak President, tieless in black denim jeans and a lavender shirt, is a world-renowned playwright who looks younger than his 53 years. He said in a brief interview today that the theater was not where he had found the most useful guideposts in what he called ''this curious passage from jail to the castle.'' 
''Jail gave me extremely good preparation for my work in this office,'' he said. ''In the first place, it taught me not to be surprised by anything. Second, it cultivated in me some instincts which I need in this office, and third, it facilitates for me the solving of one of the many problems we have to deal with, such as the state security and the dark forces in our country.''
 
Five Interviews in a Day
One was apparently the instinct of choosing his words carefully. But he has yet to learn how to husband his time, something he had plenty of in his five years in jail over the past 21 years. His staff, not yet fully organized, had scheduled five separate interviews for him today, and to save time, he answered questions put to him in English by replying in Czech without a consecutive translation. He spoke into a tape recorder only after reflecting, and insisted on switching it off at the end of each answer.
Czechoslovakia has begun talks with the Soviet Union on withdrawing the 70,000 soldiers that have been stationed in the country since the Warsaw Pact invasion of 1968, a pullout that the Czechoslovaks want to be completed by the end of this year.
When he was asked whether Czechoslovakia would remain a member of the Communist alliance after that, Mr. Havel said: ''If a totalitarian system is dismantled, some peculiarities remain. Some things I cannot discuss with The New York Times before I discuss them with President Gorbachev in Moscow.''
Aides said Mr. Havel would make his first official visit to Moscow next month. He said he also expected to take a trip to the United States soon to visit President Bush, Congress and other representatives of American civic, cultural and business life. Expectations of U.S. ''I expect from the United States several things,'' he said. ''First, understanding for some peculiarities of Czechoslovak foreign policy.''
He added: ''I expect moral support for the processes taking place in Czechoslovakia. I expect significant economic help, on the basis of equality, and not on the basis of somebody big and rich giving presents to somebody small and poor.''
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who plans to go to Moscow early next month, may also stop in Prague, some officials here say.
Mr. Havel was unanimously elected President by the Czechoslovak legislature at the end of last month, but immediately said he saw his mission as insuring that a new Parliament was democratically elected later this year. Asked whether he would be willing to serve a new term after that, he replied:
''The President of the Czechoslovak Republic is elected for five years. He has to be elected 40 days after the first meeting of the Federal Assembly after elections. Who this President will be, naturally, I do not know. Nor do I know whether I will or will not be among the candidates, or if I am among the candidates, whether I will accept.
''Nevertheless, I know that I am capable of estimating how long this country needs me in this office and when it needs somebody better than I, or simply somebody different. As soon as my homeland does not need me in this office, I will with great appetite devote myself to my original profession, and write or even work in some kind of theater.''
 
Attends One of His Plays
On Wednesday night, he attended a Czechoslovak performance of his 1975 play, ''Audience,'' set in a provincial beer brewery like the one in Trutnov where he worked during one of his correctional periods. The 45-minute play is an extended, beery encounter between an intellectual in exile and his brewmaster-overseer. Mr. Havel stayed talking to the two companies doing the play here, the American Actors' Studio and a Czechoslovak group, until well past midnight, according to Michael Zantovsky, his new press aide.
Asked today whether any of his former jailers or interrogators had written to congratulate him on his office, Mr. Havel referred to the piles of unanswered mail and said perhaps there were some letters in there.
''I was visited in the Civic Forum by a delegation from Bory Prison, where I was jailed,'' he said. ''There were three people in civilian clothes who were trying somehow to attract my attention. I did not recognize them, and said to them, well, since your release you've grown beards and gotten fatter, and I apologized for not recognizing them.''
''They said, 'We are not prisoners, we are representatives of the correctional institute in Bory, and we have come to tell you that you should immediately dismiss the head of the jail,' '' Mr. Havel said. ''At that time our friend Dagmar Buresova was already Minister of Justice. So I passed on their messsage and I assume that she took care of it.''
 
Moral Authority an Asset
In Mr. Havel's new job, his greatest power is the moral authority he gained in two decades of persecution by the discredited Communists who took over in 1968. The day-to-day running of the machinery of state is in the hands of the Government, now led by a Communist, Prime Minister Marian Calfa.
Mr. Havel's 20 or so close aides, mainly personal friends, said they were still not sure how many people were on the President's staff, or what all of them did.
Unlike his predecessor, Gustaf Husak, Mr. Havel lives in an apartment downtown, is driven to work in his own dark-green Renault 21 four-door car, presented as a gift by President Mario Soares of Portugal, and has put modern art up on his office walls, including a painting of two nudes by the Czechoslovak artist Jiri Sobko.
''I knew that if I accepted this high state office, that I would have to deal within minutes, hours, and days, with problems that had been growing and accumulating for 50 years,'' Mr. Havel said.
One of these was tensions between Czechs, Slovaks and other ethnic groups in the country, but he said he believed this problem was not as acute in Eastern Europe as in the Soviet Union. By convention in Czechoslovakia, the President has had to be a Czech and not a Slovak, but Mr. Havel said in a New Year's Day speech that he did not see why the highest office in the land should be barred to them.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 17, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about the rise of Vaclav Havel to the presidency of Czechoslovakia misstated the country's system for dividing high offices between Czechs and Slovaks. A conference last year between the Government and the opposition agreed that the President must be a non-Communist Czech since the Prime Minister, Marian Calfa, was a Communist Slovak. In the past, Slovaks have held the presidency.

LENGTH: 778 words

HEADLINE: Fewer Flights, but More Air Traffic Delays in 1989

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
The number of air traffic delays rose sharply last year, especially at the nation's five most congested airports, Government officials reported yesterday. Aviation experts found the figures particularly disturbing because delays increased even though the number of flights fell slightly.
Government and industry officials attributed the increase to unusually severe weather, which they said accounted for more than half the delays. They also cited a shortage of air traffic controllers and intermittent computer failures. And they pointed to the proliferation of hub airports, where flights are concentrated, and the bunching of flights at peak hours. 
Some experts warned that with only one large airport slated to be built over the next ten years - in Denver - and air traffic expected to increase steadily, the nation is heading for more congestion.
The data are based on numbers from 22 of the nation's busiest airports.
Other figures from the Transportation Department show that the number of flights that arrive late has held steady, in part because airlines have altered their schedules to accommodate air traffic delays. #5 Airports With Half the Delays The Federal Aviation Administration defines delays as planes held up at some point in the flight by air traffic controllers for 15 minutes or more. Such delays increased 13 percent last year to 308,393. At the same time, the number of flights fell by about 1 percent, to 4.6 million. Seven percent of all flights encountered air traffic delays.
Five airports, three of them in the New York area, accounted for more than half the delays. They were La Guardia Airport (delays up 113 percent); Kennedy International Airport (delays up 52 percent); Newark International Airport (delays up 17 percent), and San Francisco International and O'Hare International Airport in Chicago (both with delays up 11 percent).
''This was a bad year,'' said David Hurley, director of air traffic operations for the F.A.A.
Stan Matthews, an official at the aviation agency who investigated the problems at La Guardia, said the sharp rise there was caused by unusually bad weather, especially in the spring, and the increasing use of larger jets, which means controllers must space takeoffs farther apart. In September, a USAir Boeing 737 slid off the end of a runway, killing two people and forcing controllers to close one of the two runways for five days, causing additional delays.
 
Increasing Flight Times
While the F.A.A. figures in flight delays show a marked increase, figures from the Transportation Department that measure the number of late arrivals do not.
The department found that the number of flights arriving 15 minutes late or more have remained steady, with about 78 percent of all flights arriving on time.
Industry analysts said one reason for the discrepancy is that airlines have been increasing their scheduled flight times, so planes being delayed by controllers might still arrive on time. ''To a certain degree, they are massaging the numbers,'' said George James, president of Airline Economics, a consulting concern in Washington. ''If they stretch that schedule a little bit, they're going to have happy passengers.''
But not everyone is happy. ''I've been delayed seven hours and waiting in line for four,'' said Ron Johnson, speaking recently in Detroit of his effort to fly to Virginia Beach, Va., from Colorado Springs - a trip with stops in Denver and St. Louis as well as Detroit.
Some people emphasized the shortage of air traffic controllers. R. Steve Bell, president of the controllers' union, said that the Government is still short 3,000 fully trained contollers. Mr. Hurley of the F.A.A. said he could not confirm that number, but he acknowledged that the agency is short of fully trained controllers. He added, ''We're satisfied with the number of people we have in the pipeline.''
 
A Ripple Effect
About 90 percent of controllers responding to a recent General Accounting Office survey said airline scheduling practices were their biggest headache.
''When it comes to scheduling, the airlines control their own destiny,'' said Joe Bellino, Great Lakes region representative for the controller's union.
When weather deteriorates, controllers must space planes farther apart and sometimes need to direct planes around storms. Rather than have planes enter holding patterns at their destinations, controllers delay planes on the ground.
Bad weather at an airline hub causes delays far beyond that city. ''If something happens at Chicago early in the morning it will have a ripple effect thoughout the entire nation,'' said Duane Dupon, a controller at O'Hare.

HEADLINE: Business Wary About End Of Martial Law in Beijing

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 11

 BODY:
While foreign companies welcome the lifting of martial law in the capital, the action is unlikely to have an immediate effect on their commercial or investment activities here, officials of a dozen companies said today.
The foreign business executives in interviews described the lifting of martial law, effective today, as a necessary condition for a better business climate. But they added that except for improving the prospects for the tourism industry, the move would be largely cosmetic and symbolic.
''The Chinese can, of course, put soldiers at will overnight back where they were before, and we all know that,'' said an American businessman who asked not to be identified. ''The same problems remain whether or not they move a few people dressed up in fancy uniforms from one particular, visible location to one that is not so visible.'' 
 
Deteriorating Economy
For most companies, the dominant concerns are the result of China's deteriorating economy: tight credit, reduced demand and shortages of raw materials and foreign exchange.
''A lot of people were experiencing problems well before June 4 due to recentralization and a credit squeeze,'' said Matthew D. Bersani, an associate at the Beijing office of the American law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. ''None of those problems go away, even if Sino-American relations were perfect.''
The tourism industry stands to gain the most from the lifing of martial law, which was imposed in certain areas of the capital on May 20, and hoteliers say the change will allow tour operators to offer more travel packages without insurance restrictions. Many insurance companies either raised their prices or were reluctant to give insurance for companies offering tours to China as long as martial law was in effect.
The cold winter has been a particularly bleak one for the tourism industry, and some hotel managers say they believe this year's tourist season, which begins in March, will start slowly.
 
Unlike a Faucet
''You can't just say there is no more martial law, and then have everyone willing to come to China,'' said Gerhard R.E. Schmidt, general manager at the Palace Hotel, which he said is currently operating at 50 percent occupancy. ''It's not like a faucet you can switch on and off.''
Many companies hope for a softening of tensions between China and the United States, Japan and other Western countries. Once bilateral relations improve, their logic goes, Government lending will follow, paving the way for more trade and better business opportunities, greater confidence, and then more commercial lending and investment.
American businesses still say they are looking to the resumption of lending by the World Bank, and particularly the Japanese Government, for a stimulus to their commercial activity. In some cases, such loans are expected to provide the financing for a number of big-ticket imports that companies in China say they cannot afford without outside financing.
For the World Bank, the lifting of martial law will not directly lead to a change in its lending policy, but there will probably be an indirect effect if the action substantially improves the view of China taken by the World Bank's pivotal shareholders, like the United States.
 
Change Is Needed
Commercial banks, however, will not necessarily jump into the market once the World Bank resumes lending. Foreign bankers say a great deal more substantive change is needed before the capital market for China resumes its former scale and vibrancy.
For a lending market to re-emerge, a sizable number of banks must be willing to share the risk of underwriting or participating in China loan syndications, and at least some of the preconditions for this are that the World Bank and the Japanese Government resume their lending programs.
''Lifting martial law is a small step in the right direction,'' said an American banker in Beijing. ''The World Bank loans being re-established is a little bit of a bigger step in that direction, and an official position by the Japanese banks toward China is another pretty big step in that direction.
''When there is a large enough universe of banks that are prepared to go back to China and take China risk, then we can do our business.''

LENGTH: 1785 words

HEADLINE: Pleased With Past, Kean Looks to Future

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Eight years ago a former Assemblyman named Thomas H. Kean moved his belongings and a wobbly new administration into the Statehouse here, after stunning the public and himself with a 1,797-vote victory over Representative James J. Florio.
This week Mr. Kean is packing up. He is taking with him a reputation as one of New Jersey's most successful governors. What he leaves behind are a daunting set of problems for his successor, the man he so narrowly beat in 1981.
Mr. Kean today is praised by Democrats and Republicans as the leader who presided over New Jersey's economic rebirth and who helped transform the state's image from a troubled, toxic land bridge between New York and Philadelphia to a tourist haven and a home of good government. He also carved a place for himself in the Republican Party with his dedication in the Reagan era to the environment, education and extending an appeal to black voters. 
 
'It's Wrong for Democracy'
In an interview this week in his office, where moving boxes still littered the floor, Mr. Kean, who is 54 years old, said he looked forward to his new life at Drew University, where he takes over as president next week, as a time to think and talk about subjects beyond New Jersey: United States foreign policy, which he hopes will remain warily anti-Communist, and the Republican Party, which he says must stop writing off minority voters.
''It's wrong,'' said Mr. Kean, who won re-election in 1985 with 62 percent of the black vote. in 1985. ''It's wrong for the party. It's wrong for democracy. It's wrong for the people you are trying to help.''
When Mr. Florio is sworn in as governor on Tuesday, he will confront a budget crisis that, experts say, could require hundreds of millions of dollars in new taxes or cuts in services.
He will also be under pressure to repair an automobile insurance system that outraged voters and vexed Mr. Kean year after year. And within months, he is likely to face a State Supreme Court decision on the financing of public education that could result in a painful overhaul of the state's tax system.
To many Democrats, the problems that Mr. Florio inherits are proof that despite Mr. Kean's popularity, his years in office were not flawless. They fault him for not doing more to help the state's poor cities, to relieve rising property taxes and to limit the growth that brought more traffic jams and urban sprawl to the nation's most densely populated state.
Unlike other governors who rode the Northeast's economic boom to popularity in the 1980's, like Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut, Mr. Kean was able to get out while the getting was good, many Democrats say.
 
Russo's Review
As those same states now face growing deficits and their governors see their popularity erased or falling, Mr. Kean is leaving the unpopular dirty work of balancing budgets to his successor.
''I give him high grades,'' said John F. Russo, a Democrat and the departing president of the New Jersey Senate, who at times was at odds with the Governor. ''But he was so popular that he was in a position to do the politically hard things that he never got around to, like taxes and the cities.''
When Mr. Kean took over in 1982, after waiting through a month of recounts to confirm his election, unemployment in New Jersey stood at nearly 10 percent. Thousands of manufacturing jobs had been lost in the 1970's and state government lurched from crisis to crisis.
In his first year, Mr. Kean seemed at times overwhelmed by the problems of a state parodied for its crime, pollution and corrupt politicians. But by 1986, New Jersey's sprawling suburbs had become magnets for high-technology industries and corporate offices. During the Kean years, the state gained 600,000 new jobs, unemployment dropped to 4 percent and each year the state reported large surpluses.
 
Economic Boom
''It is a brilliant success story of the 1980's,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. ''There were very few states that showed that kind of improvement.''
Much like Mr. Dukakis in Massachusetts, Mr. Kean would later take credit for the spectacular growth that passed through the entire Northeast, an economic turnaround that would have lifted New Jersey's economy no matter who was governor. Critics point out that despite Mr. Kean's anti-government rhetoric, New Jersey's budget doubled to $12 billion from $6 billion during those years.
But economists, business leaders and academics familiar with the policies of many states during those years generally praise Mr. Kean for encouraging business growth.
''As we look at the Northeast and the New England states we see governors of varying abilities who all looked very good, who were buoyed by the reinvention of the Northeast, '' said George Sternleib, university professor of urban studies at Rutgers University.
''But did Tom Kean optimize the stirring of the economy? Here you have to give him a very positive grade. He restored confidence in the state.''
Mr. Kean, the scion of a wealthy family that includes the first constitutional governor of New Jersey, William Livingston, cultivated his role as the state's promoter, appearing in television commercials to extol the state's strengths, from the casinos in Atlantic City and the beaches along the Jersey Shore, to the Giants, Jets and Nets lured to the Meadowlands from New York.
 
Public Relations and Pride
He also had the state invest heavily in roads and transportation, passed numerous environmental measures and won a series of educational measures, including a rise in the minimum salary for teachers and a plan to permit the state to take over poorly run public school systems.
Polls showed that New Jerseyans' pride in their state jumped, while the Kean public relations campaign and his landslide re-election in 1985 caught the eye of the national press and Republican politicians around the country. Mr. Kean appeared as the keynote speaker at the 1988 Republican convention.
''The coalition that Kean was able to assemble in the 1980's is precisely the coalition the party needs to acquire to survive,'' said Roger Stone, a conservative Republican consultant in Washington who worked on the Reagan, Bush and Kean campaigns: ''the party of civil rights, the party of fiscal conservatives and social moderates.''
During a 90-minute interview in his office this week, Mr. Kean demonstrated the same unpredictable amalgam of ideas and symbols that proved so successful in his years as Governor, a blend of liberal social instincts and conservative economics, a proud patrician's detachment and a folksy street-corner charm.
 
Concern About 'Peace Dividend'
In a rare departure, he repeatedly raised his concerns on issues of national and foreign affairs. He said he will urge the party to vie for black voters while continuing its commitment to a strong defense and pro-business tax policies of the Reagan years.
One concern he voiced was the temptation to dismantle quickly the military buildup achieved under Mr. Reagan.
No matter how alluring voters this year find the prospect of the ''peace dividend'' that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York suggested in his State of the State message last week, Mr. Kean said, the politics of Eastern Europe are too unsettled and the future of Communism too unclear to reduce America's military capacity.
''The world is going through a dangerous period,'' Mr. Kean said. ''I don't think you let your guard down in a time of uncertainty.''
The Governor, who often listens to tapes of Paul Robeson on the way to work, talked of his days as a college student when he experienced a first blush of admiration for Fidel Castro, and of the wrenching disillusion that followed, an event he described as the root of his strong anti-Communism.
 
'Tremendous Shock'
In the late 1950's, Mr. Kean said, his older brother, Robert, was married to a Cuban woman, and Mr. Kean, on visits to Havana, was inspired by reports of a romantic revolutionary in the mountains who promised to end the tyranny of the Batista regime.
But after the 1959 revolution, Mr. Kean said, he quickly learned through his sister-in-law's family of the brutality of the Castro regime, the suppression of freedoms and the Communists' torture and imprisonment of democratic opponents to Batista.
''It was a tremendous shock and disillusionment, and yet it was an educational experience,'' Mr. Kean said. ''Very honestly, what I had seen in Castro, I spotted in Ortega.''
Although it was little noticed, Mr. Kean, as Governor, supported aid to the Contras fighting the Sandinista government of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in Nicaragua. Today, he said, the United States must continue to apply pressure to the Governments of Nicaragua and Cuba and the leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.
Of his political accomplishments, Mr. Kean said, he was most proud of surveys that showed he has sustained his popularity with black voters even after eight years in office. Republican politicians around the country, he said, were resisting evidence that black voters could be enticed away from the Democratic Party.
''Look at the facts,'' Mr. Kean said. ''If they had less than half the votes I got on a percentage basis across the country, they would control both houses of the United States Congress. If nothing else moves them, that ought to.''
 
Possible Job in Washington
The one thing that could draw Mr. Kean quickly back into debate over New Jersey issues, he said, is if Mr. Florio decides to follow the advice of many of Mr. Kean's Democratic critics who say the state must raise its income tax.
Mr. Kean said the new governor may be forced to raise taxes on items like gasoline, liquor or cigarettes to make up the difference between expenditures and disappointing state revenues. But raising the income tax would destroy the probusiness environment that he said spurred the boom of the 1980's.
Mr. Kean has been mentioned in Washington as a possible replacement for the Secretary of Education, Lauro F. Cavazos, or for another position in the Bush Administration. If the Administration wants him, he said, he would not rule out a future job in either domestic or foreign affairs after a stint as president of Drew, a small private university in Madison, not far from his home in Livingston. But now, Mr. Kean said, he needs a hiatus from public life.
''This position, as wonderful as it is, is somewhat isolating,'' Mr. Kean said of the governorship. ''I need to touch again. I need to find out what people are thinking, particularly to touch base with this new generation.''
