HEADLINE: Cuomo Pledges Rise in Spending In Range of 4%

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Pledging to keep state spending increases in the next fiscal year below the inflation rate, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would present a tight budget next week that would grow by a little more than 4 percent.
If Mr. Cuomo holds to his pledge, the budget increase would be the lowest in more than a decade.
Speaking at a news conference here today, the Governor said the budget that he will present to the Legislature next week ''should grow no more than the inflation rate.'' He estimated that the inflation rate for the coming year would be 4.5 percent. 
The Governor's remarks came just one day after his administration acknowledged a budget gap for the current fiscal year of almost $700 million. That figure is almost three times the gap that the administration projected in November.
In pledging to hold spending growth under the inflation rate, Mr. Cuomo cautioned that he was speaking only about the state's general fund, which is made up of most tax revenues that are not dedicated by law to special uses. He said he was not making the same pledge about the state's overall budget, which includes Federal funds as well as money earmarked for specific purposes.
 
Shifting Inflation Estimate
The state's overall budget usually grows substantially faster than the general fund budget, and Mr. Cuomo has sometimes been accused of moving money out of the general fund to make the state's spending increase appear lower. The Governor has denied those accusations.
Last year, too, Mr. Cuomo pledged to keep the state's general fund spending increase below the inflation rate. He fulfilled this pledge but only after agreeing to increase his estimate of the inflation rate. It is now projected that state spending for the current fiscal year, which ends March 31, will be roughly 5 percent higher than the year before. The inflation rate is now projected to be 5.2 percent.
In recent years, it has not been uncommon for state spending to grow from year to year by more than 8 percent, even in times of relatively low inflation.
Maintaining overall spending growth at less than the inflation rate is likely to require substantial cuts in some areas. That is because there are many areas, like health care and prisons, for which spending is likely to increase at a rate faster than inflation.
 
Reaction Is Mixed
At today's news conference, Mr. Cuomo appeared to be trying to take steps to blunt the criticism that will inevitably greet his budget proposal. ''You have to be able to say no,'' he said. ''And please don't talk to me about excruciating privation. Because that's not true.''
But advocates for the poor said that despite the Governor's statements they were concerned that his spending proposal would cause real suffering. ''I think it's going to be a disaster,'' said Patricia Croop, executive director of Senses, a coalition of religious and social services groups.
Business groups, in contrast, praised the Governor for his emphasis on spending restraint.
''Governor Cuomo hit the nail right on the head today when he said that the solution to this year's budget puzzle is to control spending,'' said Daniel B. Walsh, president of the Business Council of New York.

HEADLINE: POP/JAZZ;
2 Successes In the Quest For Creative Uniqueness

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
Two of jazz's great individualists, the singers Betty Carter and Abbey Lincoln Moseka, will step on stage tonight and give a lesson or two on how to secure a place in jazz history. After a phrase or so, the singers will show off carefully constructed personalities built not out of economic necessity, but out of an act of the imagination. Living examples of a jazz law that demands originality in exchange for greatness, they know just how to turn the nuances of the personal into something powerfully evocative. The most repressed audience crumbles under their emotional weight; the two women can draw tears from a rock.
''I don't sleep well if I'm compared to someone else,'' Ms. Carter said. ''To be creative you have to do something different. My style has evolved because I know more about Betty Carter than I did 20 years ago or 2 years ago or yesterday. I'm constantly trying to learn about me. 
''That search for self-knowledge comes out in the risks I take, changing tunes around, making something familiar into something else. And that's risky because you can offend the composers' intent. My peers, the audience and musicians my age, like their standards the same way every time, and if I come up with a new idea, that they don't dig.
''On a simpler level, I avoided other people's material, and never listened to them, unless I heard them accidentally on the radio. There are a lot of singers who spent a lot of time copying other singers; they're still in Cincinnati or in Philadelphia. I knew that what I had to develop was Betty Carter.''
 
Billie Holiday Was First
Ms. Moseka said she learned about originality ''from witnessing other people.''
''The first singer I heard was Billie Holiday, when I was 14,'' she recalled. ''I had heard singers in church, and I was singing in school. But she was the first singer I ever heard who was an individual; I heard Coleman Hawkins around the same time, and it did something for me. For a while, I would listen to Sarah Vaughan on the radio, Nat (King) Cole, Frank Sinatra, Rosemary Clooney, all of whom had an individual sound. Back then, it was shameful to sound like someone else - the point is to value yourself.''
Since both Ms. Moseka and Ms. Carter are singers, they have an added emotional advantage over jazz instrumentalists. Using well-thought-out arrangements, both women block off and underscore meaning in their tunes. By adding unpredictable time signatures to a standard, Ms. Carter will wake it from a slumber. And both singers have utterly distinct sounds.
 
'Betty Be-Bop'
Ms. Carter has been receiving her fair share of attention recently; not only has her album ''Look What I Got'' spent months on the jazz charts, but she also won a Grammy last year and appeared on an episode of ''The Cosby Show.'' She first gained acclaim as a member of Lionel Hampton's orchestra in 1951, when she was labled Betty Be-Bop for her be-bop virtuosity. Her voice, from the earliest recordings on, is immediately distinct, an alto that can be insistent when working through a modal piece, or delicate and nuanced - dusty one moment, polished the next - when navigating her molasses-slow ballads.
''I knew I couldn't be Sarah Vaughan,'' she said. ''I never bothered buying records, because I knew that I was an individual, and knew that I had to get to that, to explore the individuality.''
 
Tackled Tougher Subjects
Ms. Moseka's ascent has been different. Early on in her career she spent time working on the cabaret circuit. In the late 1950's, she became involved in ground-breaking projects with Max Roach, to whom she was married for several years, and started tackling tougher subjects, joining the jazz elite, recording with Sonny Rollins and Kenny Dorham. Her voice, at times tinged with sarcasm and anger and at other moments filled with a joyous intelligence, makes tunes shiver with intensity.
''It really started when I was a child, between 5 and 6,'' Ms. Moseka said. ''I'm 1 of 12 children. My father always had a piano in the house, and when I would go to the piano I must have done it respectfully, because people left me alone. That's where I learned to concentrate.''
Both women have actively supported young musicians. At Fat Tuesday's through the weekend, Ms. Carter will be using the newcomers Marc Cary on piano, Tarus Mateen on bass, and Troy Davis on drums. Over the last decade, Ms. Carter has been turning out fully formed jazz musicians at a rate equaled only by that other jazz academy, Art Blakey. Her bands, invariably tight and always thrilling, are training grounds for young musicians to learn the discipline necessary to attack some of jazz's larger problems.
''It's marvelous; the music is really turning around,'' Ms. Carter said. ''There are more young musicians than I dreamed would be possible, and they're not as overwhelmed by the commercial thing as five years ago. People want things with substance, so they have to deal with this music.''
 
'One of the Elders'
Ms. Moseka, who will be backed by James Wiedeman on piano, Kenny Davis on bass, and Mark Johnson on drums in her sets at Condon's, keeps her musicians longer. One recent graduate of her academy is the saxophonist Steve Coleman, who brought most of the other members into her band.
''The musicians in my band are as good as any I worked with when I first started out,'' Ms. Moseka said. ''They're brilliant. For me, there is an increase of young musicians around, but I don't know how inclined they are to breaking the rules, throwing the baby out with the bathwater. When Clifford Brown came through town, everybody knew his sound, and he was only 26 when he died. I know there are a lot of young musicians who have expertise and are our next crop. It makes me feel older. Times have changed, and I'm one of the elders now.
''But it's exciting when somebody is imaginative and does something different. Then the music grows. When a musician has something specific to say - not how smart you are, or how good you can play - that's what it's all about.''
Betty Carter will be performing at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street. Shows are at 8, 10, and midnight, tonight and tomorrow, and 8 and 10 P.M. on Sunday. The cover is $15, and the minimum $10. Information: 533-7902. Abbey Lincoln Moseka will be playing at Condon's, 117 East 15th Street. Shows are at 10 and midnight tonight through Sunday; the cover is $12.50 at a table, but there is no cover at the bar. There is no minimum. Information: 254-0960.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Mexican-American Drama on 'Wonderworks'

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
One of public television's more adventurous and distinguished excursions into family entertainment, ''Wonderworks,'' returns for a new season this weekend, having been moved to 10 o'clock on Sunday mornings on Channel 13 from early prime time. The series is produced by a consortium of stations that is headed by WQED in Pittsburgh and that, perhaps significantly, does not include Channel 13.
In any event, the premiere is a two-hour two-part production called ''Sweet 15.'' Marta Delacruz (Karla Montana) is a 14-year-old Californian of Mexican descent and, in typical teen-ager fashion, squeals a lot with her friends about makeup and boyfriends. In Mexican tradition, a girl's 15th birthday is a special ''coming of age'' occasion celebrated with a mass and a quinceanera party. The more elaborate, the better. 
Viewers first meet Marta at her friend's lavish quinceanera, where she notices the streetwise Ramon Sanchez (Panchito Gomez), a Puerto Rican teen-ager who has recently shown up in the neighborhood with what one wary young woman describes as ''no plans, no suitcase and no manners.'' Marta's protective father, Samuel (Tony Plana), goes on instant alert.
The Delacruz family is slowly climbing the economic ladder. Samuel has been made a manager at his factory. He brags about owning his own house and having his own secretary and even having his own parking space. Listening to his wife, Inez (Jenny Gago), he agrees to give Marta a proper quinceanera, though insisting that she be escorted by her cousin - a lummox.
Then come the complications, with something of a vengeance. The father has led his children to believe that he is a United States citizen, but, in fact, he is an illegal alien facing deportation unless he can prove he has worked in this country for a certain number of years. Though he has held many jobs, he mostly used aliases and he sees little hope of his former bosses remembering him. Rather than face the humiliation of begging for mercy, he begins talking about returning to Mexico. The new circumstances force him to cancel the quinceanera, further straining the relationship between Samuel and the justifiably puzzled Marta.
The plot logistics are patly contrived, but ''Sweet 15'' provides unusual glimpses into ordinary Hispanic-American lives, which, on television, are too often limited to the circumscribed worlds of drug dealing and gang violence. But with the accelerated growth of Hispanic communities across the nation, more serious attention is clearly warranted. PBS is a main conduit, not least because Congress has appropriated $9 million for more programming about minorities.
Curiously, although ''Sweet 15'' is produced by Richard Soto, who co-produced and edited the fine film ''The Ballad of Gregorio Cortez,'' its writer, Sharon Weil, and its director, Victoria Hochberg, are not of Hispanic heritage. A question has indeed been raised in some quarters: given the scarce opportunities for minority talent, who should be employed to tell a story about Hispanic teen-agers? Mr. Soto is unfazed. ''I don't think ethnicity matters,'' he said. ''I think it's the sensibilities that count.''
The solid proof is in his production. A cast of fine Hispanic actors, supported in small roles by Jerry Stiller and Susan Ruttan, gets an invaluable chance to shine. Ms. Montana is positively beguiling. There are a good many Hispanic names in the closing technical credits. That's going in the right direction. On the whole, ''Sweet 15'' makes the process all the more pleasant. Welcome back ''Wonderworks.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
The directors of the Campeau Corporation took steps to allow the company's American retailing divisions to operate independently. After four days of meetings at the company's Toronto headquarters, the directors said Campeau's U.S. operations would be overseen by a new board, with a majority of American residents. The board will appoint a new chief executive and chairman, and Robert Campeau, the Canadian real estate entrepreneur who founded the company and remains its chairman, will no longer have a voice. [Page A1.] 
 
Some of the biggest losses from Campeau's spending binge for department stores have been borne by individual investors who bought into ''junk bond'' mutual funds that invested heavily in bonds issued by the Campeau Corporation. Some of those bonds are now worth only 10 percent of what investors paid for them. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
 
The chairman and chief executive of UAL warned employees that a recapitalization of the company, which owns United Airlines, would ''cripple United financially.'' In a letter, he urged them and their unions to begin to put together a buyout plan that would give employees a majority stake in the company. [D1.]
 
J. P. Morgan & Company reported a 40 percent decline in its fourth-quarter profits and a loss of $1.27 billion for the year. Analysts were disappointed at the quarter's results and said they would remain depressed until the short-term cost of funds fell relative to the long-term return on investments. [D1.]
 
A leading mergers and acquisitions adviser resigned. Eric J. Gleacher will leave Morgan Stanley, where he has worked since 1983, to start his own firm. Morgan Stanley named two managing directors in the merger area, Bruce D. Fiedorek and Stephen M. Waters, to be co-heads of the department. [D1.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Japan's ''voluntary'' quotas on automobile exports to the U.S. will be extended, the Japanese Government is expected to announce soon. But Japan's primary manufacturers say that the action is now an annual political gesture that has no effect on the sales of Japanese cars. [D1.]
 
General Motors said it was in advanced stages of negotiations to assemble cars and engines in Hungary. The arrangement would be the first direct involvement by a U.S. auto maker in what is expected to be a huge market in Eastern Europe. [D2.]
 
The lifting of martial law in China is likely to have little immediate effect on commercial or investment activities, officials of a dozen foreign companies said. [A3.]
 
MARKETS
 
Stocks rebounded as investors sought bargains in the wake of the market's recent weakness. The Dow Jones industrial average, closed the day up 10.03 points, to 2,760.67, after giving up in previous days all of the 56.95 points it gained on Jan. 2. [D6.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in sluggish trading as dealers moved to the sidelines before the Government's reports on producer prices and retail sales, which are scheduled to be released this morning. [D14.]
 
The dollar ended slightly lower in late New York trading in which dealers focused mainly on the cross rates between foreign currencies and the dollar. Gold prices rose modestly. [D15.]
 
Grain prices fell and soybean prices rose in light volume as traders awaited details of several Agriculture Department reports released after the close. [D15.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
The undervalued yen is to blame for the chronic American trade deficit with Japan, a scholar asserts. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
Ammirati & Puris is buying itself back from Omnicom, ending a protracted negotiation. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Trade Pressures On the Japanese

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE drop in the Tokyo stock market earlier this week, attributed partly to fears of turmoil in the Soviet Union that could weaken the outlook for Japanese involvement in Eastern Europe, knocked down the yen and lifted the dollar. The weakening yen is likely to worsen the huge United States trade deficit with Japan and intensify the increasingly bitter dispute between the two countries.
But the Japanese may be facing troubles in Europe as well. Kenneth S. Courtis, market strategist and chief economist of the Deutsche Bank in Tokyo, said the yen was also undervalued against the European currencies. He said he thought the yen ''could rise to the 150's against the dollar'' from its current 145, and said he feared that a serious trade crisis was boiling up between Japan and the United States and Europe this year. 
While pressing Japan to open its markets to correct the trade imbalance, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has been putting heavy stress not on currency values but on ''macroeconomic factors,'' especially the high United States budget deficit and low national savings rate, and the high Japanese savings rate.
Mrs. Hills said in an interview on Wednesday that the decline in the dollar after 1985 had little effect on the trade imbalance because ''Japan has maintained its export prices near their 1985 levels, to avoid losing market share.'' In a news conference earlier this week, Mrs. Hills said, ''When the yen gets stronger or the yen gets weaker, the trade balance does not change.''
But Edward M. Bernstein, the first research director of the International Monetary Fund, said he considered that the undervaluation of the yen had been crucial to Japan's persistent balance-of-payments surpluses, not only with the United States but also with the rest of the world. This, to him, suggests a serious and universal exchange-rate misalignment, because of the yen. Abolishing Japanese import barriers, though desirable, would do relatively little toward cutting the United States trade deficit, Mr. Bernstein said. He regards the increase in the American budget deficit since 1981, the last year the United States had a surplus in its balance of payments on current account, as a factor in the trade deficit, but finds it only half as important as the fall in the personal savings rate since 1981. That rate, historically steady at about 7 percent of disposable personal income, plunged from 7.5 percent in 1981 to a low of 3.2 percent in 1987. It recovered partly in 1988, to 4.2 percent, and in 1989, to 5.4 percent.
With this improvement in its savings rate, and the decline of the dollar after 1985, the United States trade deficit did improve with other countries, but not with Japan. The American deficit peaked in the third quarter of 1987 at an annual rate of $162.4 billion. In the third quarter of 1989 it was down to an annual rate of $111 billion. But of that $51.4 billion fall, the deficit with Japan came down only $6.4 billion, while the deficit with Europe fell $26.5 billion, almost to zero.
Mr. Bernstein, now a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution, believes the chronic American trade deficit with Japan, hanging on at $50 billion or more, is chiefly the result of the undervaluation of the yen. And he believes this represents deliberate Japanese policy. He said in a letter last month: ''I think we ought to ask ourselves why the dollar has depreciated by 12 percent against the D-mark since the end of August but has been unchanged against the yen. I think the answer is in the billion-dollar bond buyer of Japan who is encouraged by Japanese legislation and policy.''
Japanese funds invested in dollar bonds, money market assets and deposits will lose money in terms of yen, he said. But in strengthening the dollar and weakening the yen, this policy spurs Japanese exports and helps explain why the securities of Japanese export companies have been so strong even in the softening Tokyo stock market. ''With massive investments and new capacity coming on stream, and a weakening yen headed for the 150's against the dollar,'' said the Deutsche Bank's Mr. Courtis, ''Toyota looks like Mike Tyson.'' So do other Japanese exporters.
The danger to Japanese producers is that import-competing industries in the United States and Europe will press their governments to take countermeasures against them.
One way for Japan to head off such measures would be to let the yen appreciate relative to the dollar and other currencies, to reduce its trade surplus. That surplus reached $95 billion in 1988, of which 55 percent was with the United States.
Another solution would be for Japan to raise the wages of its workers, to match the economic value of their productivity, thereby raising consumption, reducing savings and the foreign trade surplus.
Such measures, however, are unlikely to appeal to capital-rich Japan. Mr. Courtis believes that the strategies more likely to gain Japan's support are these: ''Invest like there's no tomorrow''; seek to tie corporate America's interests into its own, as through joint production and capital transfers; yield to American pressure when the going gets tough, as in the present plan to give favorable tax treatment to importers; diversify to other foreign countries, especially in East Asia, and use the Japanese stock market as a means of generating ''oceans of low-cost capital.''
The current nervousness of the Tokyo market, however, suggests that none of these approaches is foolproof.

HEADLINE: G.M. Near Agreement On Venture in Hungary

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that it was at an advanced stage of negotiations to assemble cars and engines in Hungary.
Such an arrangement would be the first direct involvement by a United States auto maker in what is expected to be a huge market in Eastern Europe.
The plan puts the auto maker a step ahead of its American rivals in the quest to become positioned to exploit Eastern Europe's growing car market and its low-cost labor, industry analysts said. 
''Potentially, car sales in Eastern Europe can double or triple in the next decade. If G.M.'s not there early on, then Volkswagen and Fiat will be,'' said John Casesa, analyst with Wertheim Schroeder in New York.
 
Up to 200,000 Engines
While a General Motors spokesman refused to discuss details, the Hungarian news agency MTI-Econews said today that the auto maker and a Hungarian company called RABA will soon sign a preliminary agreement.
MTI-Econews said the joint venture would produce between 100,000 and 200,000 car engines a year and assemble 10,000 to 15,000 of G.M.'s Opel Kadett cars, mainly for export, at a plant near the Hungarian border with Austria.
''There is an incredible need for personal automotive transport product in Eastern Europe,'' said Joseph Phillippi, analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York.
Mr. Casesa, of Wertheim Schroeder, said there are currently 115 vehicles for every 1,000 people in Eastern Europe, compared with 728 vehicles for every 1,000 people in the United States. He said the Eastern European figure could rise to 300 to 400 vehicles for every 1,000 people in the next 20 years.
 
Others Moving Quickly
While General Motors might become the first United States manufacturer to assemble cars in Eastern Europe, other car companies are moving quickly to capitalize on the political and economic reforms sweeping the region.
The Suzuki Motor Company of Japan announced earlier this week a joint venture with a Hungarian concern and other partners to build subcompact cars in Hungary.
Two other well-positioned car makers are West Germany's Volkswagen A.G., which already has an engine venture with East Germany, and Italy's Fiat S.p.A., which has been helping the Soviet Union and Poland develop cars for years.
But Michael Luckey, who heads the Luckey Consulting Group, said one of the problems companies face in Eastern Europe is bringing the work force up to Western skill and productivity levels.
Expanding in Eastern Europe is particularly critical for General Motors because the car maker's European operations currently produce the bulk of its profits. Its North American operations are losing money.

HEADLINE: Chip Index Posts Rebound

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded in December as United States semiconductor shipments and orders increased, signaling a recovery from the summer slowdown, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.
The trade association, based in Cupertino, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1 for the three months ending in December, up from 0.93 in November and a revised figure of 0.92 in October. The book-to-bill compares orders to shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry's performance. A ratio of 1 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $100 was ordered, indicating steady demand.
At $1.22 billion, three-month orders for December were up 4.2 percent from $1.172 billion for the period ended in November and 6.5 percent higher than the figure posted a year ago, which was $1.15 billion.
Three-month average shipments for December totaled $1.22 billion. At $1.28 billion, United States market shipments for December were 6.7 percent higher than November's $1.20 billion and 3.7 percent higher than the figure posted a year ago, which was $1.24 billion.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Security Prices Down

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in very sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers moved to the sidelines in advance of two important economic reports today.
The market's lethargic tone came as a surprise to some participants, who said they thought there would be some positive follow-through from Wednesday's successful auction of seven-year Treasury notes.
''The auction was a catalyst for people to do something,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''But today there is complete and utter inaction.'' 
This morning the Government will release producer price and retail sales data for December. Since most analysts are expecting that the December cold snap caused a big jump in producer prices, Mr. Capra and other participants said the retail sales numbers were likely to generate more interest.
 
Retail Sales Estimate
In advance of the report, most analysts were expecting that retail sales rose by a healthy six-tenths or seven-tenths of a percentage point last month, after a gain of eight-tenths of a point in November.
Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago, said that an increase of that size could well overstate consumer activity because of last month's weather.
''Retail sales may appear to be strong, but they could be influenced by one-time factors,'' Mr. Kahan said. ''Because of the cold weather, energy prices went up, which may boost overall sales figures for gasoline and heating oil. Similarly, there could be some boost to spending in the aftermath of Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco earthquake.''
Unlike most of his colleagues, Mr. Kahan is forecasting that the sales figures will show a decline of 1.2 percent.
As often occurs, dealers chose to sell Treasury securities in advance of the release of the reports.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 100 5/32, down 11/32, to yield 8.11 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 29/ 32, down 5/32, to yield 8.03 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 15/32, down 3/32, to yield 7.92 percent.
 
Auction of One-Year Notes
Yesterday the Treasury sold $9.5 billion worth of one-year notes at its monthly auction.
The bills were sold at an average discounted rate of 7.21 percent, up from the average 7.14 percent rate recorded at the auction in December.
Reflecting recent strong demand for short-term securities by individual investors, the Treasury received $1.1 billion worth of non-competitive bids for the new bills. The amount was more than double the size of non-competitive bids at the last one-year note auction, and was the largest since the one-year bill auction held Jan. 11, 1989.
Meanwhile, rates rose in the secondary Treasury bill market.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.54 percent, up six basis points, or hundredths of a point. And six-month bill rates rose by three-basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.39 percent.
Activity in the corporate bond market was dominated by a $750 million offering from the Eastman Kodak Company. The 9.20 percent five-year issue was priced at $99.897, to yield 9.226 percent, 1.30 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 7 3/4 percent five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the transaction, which is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The issue, which was increased from $500 million because of strong demand, quickly sold out. Investor reaction to the sale of Kodak debt stood in stark contrast to a $350 million offering of 15-year notes by the company in the fall of 1988.
That issue was the first deal to be priced in the aftermath of the takeover of RJR Nabisco by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm. Investors, fearful that the RJR transaction might be a harbinger of other huge corporate takeovers, reacted negatively to the Kodak offering.
 
Kodak Issues Snapped Up
But investors snapped up yesterday's sale of Kodak securities even though the issue did not contain ''event risk'' language that offers bondholders protection in the event of a takeover.
As the interest rate on yesterday's offering suggests, Kodak paid dearly for choosing not to include event-risk language.
According to data from Salomon Brothers, new issues of A-rated ten-year bonds issued by industrial companies were priced at an average spread of 1.13 percentage points over 10-year Treasuries in the week ended Jan. 4. For five-year issues the spread would normally be much narrower.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most intermediate-term issues were unchanged to up an eighth of a point. Most long-term issues, meanwhile, dipped by about an eighth of a point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most actively traded issues were unchanged to down by about an eighth of a point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Bank reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Jan. 1. The third, most closely watched measure, M-2, fell by $5.9 billion. The report had no effect on prices in the fixed-income markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Down a Bit; Gold Prices Up Modestly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly lower yesterday after a session in which dealers focused mainly on cross rates between foreign currencies rather than the dollar.
Gold prices rose modestly, with bullion for current delivery gaining $1.60 an ounce, to $414, on the New York Commodity Exchange.
''It's essentially been a cross market,'' said Robert White, manager of corporate trading at the First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. ''It isn't so much the dollar. It's the yen against the market. It's the market against the Swiss.'' 
The Swiss National Bank's president, Markus Lusser, said that Swiss interest rates might remain above rates in West Germany for some time to prevent the Swiss franc from weakening further against the German mark.
 
Swiss Franc Up Sharply
Higher interest rates would make the currency more attractive for investors to hold, and Mr. Lusser's comment drove the franc sharply higher.
''The market is just a bundle of nerves'' because there is no clear trend for the dollar, Mr. White said.
Dealers are watching political developments in Eastern Europe closely for signs of instability, which might lead investors to rush into dollars as a safe haven, he said.
Traders are also keeping a keen eye on United States interest rates for any sign of credit easing by the Federal Reserve, which would tend to make the dollar less attractive, he said.
In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 145.45 yen, down from 145.55 late Wednesday.
Late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.6795 marks, down from 1.6825; 1.5065 Swiss francs, down from 1.5165; 5.7215 French francs, down from 5.7265; 1,253.75 Italian lire, down from 1,257.25, and 1.1562 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1585.
The dollar rose slightly against the British pound. The pound fell to $1.6597 from $1.6625.
Silver for current delivery closed unchanged at $5.306 an ounce on New York's Comex.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up 4.8% in '89, Most in 8 Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Paced by big increases for energy and tobacco, producer prices jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in December to bring 1989 inflation by this measure to 4.8 percent, the highest rate since 1981.
Last month's rise was somewhat more than expected, and traders said the report contributed to a skid in stock prices and a further creeping up of interest rates in the credit markets. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 71.46 points, to 2,689.21, and bond yields rose as traders worried that the report would make the Federal Reserve reluctant to ease interest rates further. [Pages 35 and 38.] But many analysts contended that the latest figures were not so bad as they seemed. The markets focused on the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which these analysts said was heavily influenced last month by special factors. They also noted that an index based on earlier stages of production showed a decline in prices. 
''It doesn't appear to us to represent an acceleration'' of the pressures that lead to higher consumer prices, Alfred G. Smith, an economist for the NCNB Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., said of today's report.
Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade group whose members pay the prices used in calculating the indexes, said, ''I don't see any cause for fundamental concern.''
When food, energy and tobacco are excluded, he noted, the December increase was only one-tenth of a percent. Food and energy are subject to big month-to-month swings, and tobacco prices jumped 4.5 percent because of a year-end industry price increase that has not yet been fully incorporated into the index's seasonal adjustment process. Tobacco accounts for nearly 3 percent of the index.
Still, some analysts shared the markets' worries that today's report might prompt the Federal Reserve to be more cautious about cutting interest rates. And Neal M. Soss, chief economist for the First Boston Corporation, cautioned against trying to explain away each statistic showing a jump in inflation. He said it was disappointing to find inflation ''this stubborn'' after many months of slower economic growth.
On the other hand, a separate report today showed a meager rise of two-tenths of a percent in December retail sales, and the Federal Reserve will undoubtedly regard that as a reason to consider some additional credit-easing, analysts suggested.
The 4.8 percent annual increase for finished goods compared with 4 percent in 1988 and 2.2 percent in 1987 and was the highest since the 7.1 percent increase of 1981, the year when oil prices peaked.
The Producer Price Indexes reflect the prices received by domestic producers for commodities in various stages of processing. Unlike the Consumer Price Indexes, imports and services are not included.
One Producer Price Index tracks finished goods, which are defined as those ready for sale to the final individual or business user; an intermediate-goods index gauges the prices of semifinished items that require further processing or completed items that are used as parts of other products, and a crude-goods index measures prices of items entering the production chain for the first time. For example, wheat would be a crude good, flour an intermediate good and bread a finished good.
One striking sign of weakness in American industry was that the producer price category for durable manufacturing materials, like metals, tumbled 1.6 percent in December, the biggest monthly decline since April 1980. The durable materials component, which is part of the intermediate index, fell 3.4 percent for all of 1989, in sharp contrast to surges of 10.1 percent in 1988 and 11.6 percent in 1987.
Over all, intermediate goods edged down one-tenth of a percent for the second straight month, after showing no change in October. For the year, intermediate goods rose 2.4 percent, less than half the 5.6 percent advance in 1988.
Crude goods, whose prices fluctuate widely, jumped 1.8 percent in December, to bring the 1989 increase to 6.9 percent, more than twice the 1988 increase of 3.1 percent. Crude oil soared 35 percent last year, the biggest increase since 1979, after it fell 18.1 percent in 1988.
 
Energy Up 10% for Year
Among finished goods, energy costs climbed 1.4 percent after falling 3.3 percent in November, ending the year up nearly 10 percent; in 1988, the index's energy component fell 3.4 percent. The index's gasoline prices last month were unchanged, after seasonal adjustment, but on an unadjusted basis, prices were down 2.4 percent, according to the Labor Department report.
Food prices advanced five-tenths of 1 percent, compared with an eight-tenths increase in November, as increases for beef, dairy products and eggs slowed, and pork and turkey prices turned down. Prices rose, however, for fresh vegetables, processed fruits and vegetables, and pasta.
For the year, foods rose 5 percent, with eggs up 40.9 percent, the second straight leap of that magnitude, partially because of higher feed prices and the reduction in flocks caused by the 1988 drought.
Much of last month's rise for consumer goods other than food and energy reflected the advance in tobacco prices and higher prices for cars and light trucks.
In recent years, the tobacco industry has been raising prices twice a year, but the Government's statisticians have not yet been able to adjust fully for this since their seasonal patterns are based generally on the most recent five-year period.
Prices of capital equipment rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month to finish the year 3.7 percent higher than a year earlier.
The index for finished goods now stands at 115.3, with 1982 equaling 100. That means a basket of goods that cost $100 in 1982 now costs $115.30.
 
Wide Monthly Variations
For the first five months of 1989, the index averaged monthly increases of more than seven-tenths of a percent, but three of the next six months showed price declines and the average increase was less than one-tenth of 1 percent. December's increase was the biggest since September, which upon revision today showed an increase of eight-tenths instead of the nine-tenths first reported.
Price declines for manufacturing and construction materials were even more widespread in December than in November. Copper and brass mill shapes dropped 6.4 percent, while aluminum shapes declined for the seventh straight month. Lead and zinc also fell, as did nondurables like plastic resins, industrial chemicals, phosphates and inedible fats and oils. Construction materials and components fell for the second straight month, with their full-year 1989 rise at 2.4 percent.
In crude goods, energy and food prices rose more than in November, while decreases slowed for basic industrial materials. Crude energy jumped 2.2 percent as petroleum and natural gas rose faster than in November, while coal fell, offsetting its big November increase.

LENGTH: 1682 words

HEADLINE: As Market Struggles, So Do Some Co-op Buildings

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
At least 88 residential cooperatives with nearly 9,000 apartments in the New York City area are facing severe financial difficulties. And the number of such co-ops is growing, causing concern among owners and in the State Attorney General's office, which monitors co-op conversions.
''I am expecting that figure to escalate with the downturn of the market,'' said Fred Mehlman, the assistant attorney general in charge of the state's Real Estate Financing Bureau.
The main problem, lawyers and regulators say, is the struggle by some professional co-op converters to pay the monthly maintenance costs on apartments they have not yet sold.
 
Trouble in a Weak Market
These converters - also known as sponsors - are in trouble because of cash shortages resulting from the weakening real-estate market. A handful of condominiums are also affected. 
Maintenance payments cover the installments on a building's underlying mortgage as well as its utility bills, staffing costs and real-estate taxes, among other expenses.
If the bills are not paid, creditors, like the bank holding the underlying mortgage, could foreclose on the building. In these extreme cases, owners could potentially lose the money they have invested in their apartments.
The problem was first acknowledged by Mr. Mehlman last November. At that time, only a few modest buildings in Brooklyn and Queens were known to be facing financial problems. But now all types of buildings in various kinds of neighborhoods - including two in Westchester County and one on Long Island - are on the Attorney General's list. Among them are the 2,700-unit Tudor City complex in midtown Manhattan, a luxury building at 1045 Park Avenue, at 86th Street, and a small co-op at 305 Eighth Avenue in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.
 
Looking for Saviors
But state officials and lawyers are working on solutions, including finding new investors with deeper pockets to take over the sponsors' obligations.
The people most likely to be affected are those who bought apartments in the 2,300 buildings converted in the last four or five years, because these buildings have the most unsold units. Until now such troubles occurred rarely, and only in cases of personal mismanagement; now they are more a function of the economy.
Among the buildings being studied by the state finance bureau are 50 sponsored by Time Equities Inc., one of the largest converters in the city. It has filed statements notifying state authorities that it is trying to renegotiate loan payments with its lenders so it can continue to meet its obligations to its co-ops. Maintenance payments are still up to date in these buildings, although it is uncertain if they will remain so.
Thirty-eight more buildings are the subjects of investigations that were started by Mr. Mehlman's office after tenant-shareholders complained that their sponsors had failed for several months to make maintenance payments or to meet other financial obligations to the co-op corporations.
 
Recalling the Depression
In addition to the buildings reported to the Attorney General's office, lawyers specializing in co-op clients say they are handling several such cases after rarely seeing them before. They said they will be collecting definitive numbers later this month.
If the troubled buildings go into foreclosure or bankruptcy, buyers could be left with worthless investments, something that has not occurred in New York since the Depression, said Harold Lubell, chairman of the Co-op and Condominium Committee of the Real Property Section of the New York State Bar Association.
In other buildings, maintenance payments are rising sharply and special assessments are being levied to help cover the money lost through the disappearance of sponsor income, Mr. Mehlman said.
In all, some 5,000 buildings have been converted from rental to co-op status in New York City since the first wave of mass conversions started in 1976. Thousands of units in these buildings are still owned by sponsors because state conversion laws permitted rent-regulated tenants to remain as renters if they did not want to buy. In most cases, the rents these tenants paid did not cover the monthly maintenance charges that the sponsor-owners had to pay on their apartments.
 
Loss of Deductibility
This was not a problem when values were rising and sales were brisk, Mr. Lubell said. Sponsors were able to make up the cash-flow losses by using them as tax deductions, by making hefty profits when tenants died or moved away and by selling occupied units to investors at deep discounts.But the Tax Reform Act of 1986 limited the deductibility of the losses. Then the co-op market softened, values began falling and sales became harder to make. As a result, some sponsors no longer have the cash reserves to cover their monthly shortfalls. In other instances, vacancies did not occur at the expected rate.
''The balloon is bursting on these deals,'' said Alan Kazlow, a lawyer with Dreyer and Traub, a firm specializing in co-op matters.
The first rumblings of trouble came in November, when Time Equities filed statements with the Attorney General confirming ''an adverse change'' in the company's financial circumstances. The statements have covered 50 buildings to date, although Francis Greenburger, the chairman, said there may be more. Such a filing must be made to fulfill requirements on disclosing a building's finances to buyers.
The Council of New York Cooperatives, an alliance of co-op buildings, is receiving calls ''on a daily basis'' about such troubles, said Mary Ann Rothman, the executive director. It has scheduled a workshop on the topic for Jan. 24 and will hold a call-in TV show on Cable Channel 25 on Feb. 13.
The Co-op and Condominium Committee of the New York State Bar Association is sponsoring a seminar on the topic on Jan. 19. Questionnaires will be circulated to determine ''just how widespread the problem has really become,'' Mr. Lubell said. The committee will discuss actions that might be taken ''so that shareholders do not lose their investments,'' he said.
 
Calling in the Loans
Lawyers say there is another reason the problem is likely to spread. When the market was at its height two years ago, many occupied units were financed for as much as 50 percent of the full market value they would have had if vacant. Now, many such units are worth even less. Thus lenders, as they see the value of their collateral sink, may start calling in the loans they provided to sponsors to carry these units.
''It's going to become very, very complicated,'' said Stuart Saft, vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
What is expected to happen is the development of two classes of co-ops: those that will retain value because the units are almost totally owner-occupied, and those whose values may drop because so many units are still under sponsor control.
For the ordinary shareholder this can have costly implications. Randall Carnahan, an insurance broker who is the former president of the 31-unit co-op at 305 Eighth Avenue in Park Slope, saw the monthly maintenance on his two-bedroom apartment rise from $250 to $500 after the sponsor, who still owned 19 units in the building, defaulted. When Mr. Carnahan was transferred to Rhode Island recently, he did not even try to sell, ''because nobody would even think of buying until we sort ourselves out,'' he said.
 
Proceed With Caution
Anyone purchasing a co-op is now being advised by lawyers to request a copy of the co-op corporation's financial statement from the building's managing agent. The lawyers say questions should also be asked about how many apartments are still owned by the sponsor. If the number seems large - a third or more - the buyer might wish to proceed cautiously. The buyer might also check with the Real Estate Financing Bureau of the Attorney General's office to see if complaints about the sponsor have been filed.
Mr. Mehlman said his office is discussing regulatory changes; one would make the filing of liens on co-ops compulsory. The bureau is also discussing legislative changes, like increasing the number of units that must be sold before a conversion can be approved. Under current rules, a conversion can take place only after 15 percent of the units are sold.
But officials and lawyers specializing in co-op matters insist that there are other solutions. Some co-ops are exercising their rights under corporation bylaws and lease provisions to take over the defaulting sponsor's units and use the rents or sales to cover costs. Others are negotiating with the banks to refinance loan delinquencies.
Still others are finding buyers who see disaster as opportunity. One is Arthur Cornfeld, president of ABC Properties, an investment concern. He has taken over the sponsor's holdings at 140 West 58th Street, a 31-unit co-op building, paying what he considered a fire-sale price for the apartments - $3 million for 25 units plus 6 units structured as condominiums for use as offices by professionals like doctors and dentists. Three apartments have already been vacated and sold for a net return of $500,000, Mr. Cornfeld said. He has also pumped sorely needed capital into the building.
Gary Aigen, treasurer of a 50-unit co-op at 320 West 83d Street, said his co-op was solving the problem by accepting installment payments. Its sponsor, Mr. Aigen said, fell $30,000 behind on maintenance, failed to pay $100,000 owed to the reserve fund and was not paying contractors on schedule. So far, the co-op has recouped $100,000 of the outstanding balance.
The buildings where apartments are still owned by Time Equities have not been adversely affected so far. Beatrice Berkowitz, president of the largest of the Tudor City buildings, insisted that nothing had changed. Annice Alt, treasurer at 250 Cabrini Boulevard in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, where Time Equities still owns 48 of the 76 apartments, agreed. ''Of course we are concerned,'' she said. ''But there is really nothing we can do except wait and see.''

HEADLINE: Pentagon Imposes a Hiring Freeze That Could Eliminate 50,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced today that he had imposed a freeze on civilian hiring through Oct. 1, a move that Pentagon officials said would probably eliminate more than 50,000 jobs from a work force of 1.05 million civilians.
Pentagon officials said they hoped to let attrition reduce the number of civilian employees over the next nine months, averting the need for layoffs on Oct. 1 when the 1991 fiscal year begins.
Mr. Cheney has said publicly that he expects military spending to decline in the next few years, but the hiring freeze announced today is one of his first concrete steps in that direction.
President Bush is to present his 1991 budget on Jan. 29, and officials have said it will call for cuts in both military personnel and civilian employees as well as propose what Mr. Cheney has termed extensive base closings. 
''As the armed forces are reduced over the long term in light of limited budgets, a changing world situation and future negotiated agreements,'' Mr. Cheney said in a statement issued by the Pentagon, ''the department must make corresponding reductions in the size of the civilian work force that supports the armed forces.''
Today's announcement came several hours after Mr. Bush, in a speech to the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce, warned Congress against cutting ''the muscle out of our defense'' as a way to provide more money for other programs. [Page 11.] Mr. Cheney announced on Thursday that he was making management changes for the 1991 fiscal year that would eliminate 8,000 civilian and 8,000 military jobs from the Pentagon's acquisitions and logistics bureaucracy.
A senior Pentagon official said that some of those jobs being eliminated would be among the total lost during the freeze, although it was not possible to predict how many. He explained that budget planners expect that some of the employees whose jobs have been identified for elimination would resign this year before the 1991 budget takes effect and they would not be replaced.
The Pentagon hiring freeze and the Bush comments both appeared aimed at persuading Congress, which returns to work on Jan. 23, that the Administration is moving on its own to reduce the Pentagon budget and bureaucracy, and any effort by Congress to make deeper cuts would be damaging to national security.
The Pentagon last imposed a hiring freeze in 1982, but it lasted only for a few months.
Pentagon officials have said that Mr. Cheney will propose a budget for 1991 that amounts to $295 billion in outlays. a cut of about 2 percent from 1990 with inflation taken into account.
 
Some Urge Deeper Cuts
As Mr. Cheney prepares to defend his proposal, some lawmakers are already calling for far deeper cuts, and Pentagon officials say they must at least plan for the possibility that Congress will appropriate significantly less money than $295 billion.
''It's better not to hire people than it is to fire them,'' said one Pentagon official. ''By the time the dust settles and October rolls around, it's going to be a lot easier to make these decisions.''
Pentagon now has about 927,000 full-time civilian employees around the world and another 123,000 on a part-time basis.
According to Pentagon figures, as many as 80,000 civilians leave the payroll each year. If the freeze is in place for about nine months, from Jan. 11 to Oct. 1, officials estimated that the total number of jobs eliminated would be more than 50,000.
Officials said they could not predict how this would be divided between full-time and part-time positions.
 
Exceptions to the Freeze
In a directive to the Pentagon's civilian employees and military officers, Mr. Cheney provided for some exceptions to the prohibition on hiring civilians. They included these:
* Hiring commitments made before Jan. 11.
* Medical, safety and security workers.
* Political appointees, subject to the approval of the Defense Secretary or his deputy, who are working on management improvements or the President's anti-drug program.
* People identified by the heads of the military department, the inspector general or the directors of other Pentagon agencies who are deemed ''essential to maintain an important national defense capability.''
It was unclear how many people might be hired under these exceptions.
 
Freeze Called 'Inefficient'
Lawrence Korb, who served in the Reagan Administration from 1981 to 1985 as Assistant Secretary of Defense for manpower, installations and logistics, termed a hiring freeze a ''grossly inefficient way to reduce personnel.''
''It's very difficult to fire Federal employees,'' Mr. Korb said. ''It's easier to avoid the tough decisions, and take the flak from people you haven't hired yet.''
With a freeze, Mr. Korb said, reductions will come ''willy-nilly.''
''Maybe this year all the typists will retire at once, and you'll have too many metal workers and not enough typists,'' he said. ''Or the opposite could happen.''

HEADLINE: Rebels' Allies Stand Firm in Salvador

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Every morning he combs the local newspapers, looking anxiously for the names of captured and killed guerrillas.
He knows that one morning the newspaper may break his heart, informing him that one of his two sons fighting with the rebels has been killed.
This Salvadoran did not flinch, however, when his sons were recalled to active duty three days ago after several weeks of rest following the big rebel offensive in November. 
Although both sides in the civil war have accepted United Nations mediation, this man and many other Salvadorans expect another major military strike by the rebels in the next few days.
 
Faith in the 'Revolution'
''There's no solution without revolution,'' he said, requesting anonymity. When his teen-age daughter told him recently that she wanted to become a scientist, he says he told her, ''What this country really needs now is revolutionaries.''
The man's story illustrates the deep commitment of rebel supporters. It also suggests why a quick end to El Salvador's civil war is unlikely, even if the two sides promptly begin negotiations.
The announcement on Thursday that the rebels had decided to accept United Nations mediation appears likely to usher in a period of intermittent negotiations and fierce fighting. In this country, at least, talking and killing can proceed simultaneously.
The war has aggravated the deep social divisions that drove the rebels into the hills in the first place. Economists say that the country's distribution of wealth is even more lopsided now than it was in the years leading up the outbreak of fighting. This is the case despite a much-heralded land-reform policy introduced in the mid-1980's.
 
The Lost Decade
In El Salvador, as in much of Latin America, the 1980's are often called ''the lost decade.'' Although the economy has expanded somewhat, few of the benefits have trickled down to the poor. Half of all adult Salvadorans are unemployed or underemployed.
The war, the flight of capital, a hurricane, a devastating earthquake, two droughts and persistent corruption have offset $4 billion in United States aid, of which $1 billion was military.
Poor families have been hit the hardest. The average Salvadoran family struggles to survive on an income that is about a third less in real terms than at the start of the war. Infant mortality has surged as rural access to safe drinking water has plummeted.
Nonetheless, the country has managed to hold five relatively fair elections since 1982. And last year, power was transferred for the first time this century from one civilian Government to another.
 
A Bit More Breathing Room
The military has resisted numerous right-wing calls for coups, and the power of the civilian President, while still limited by the armed forces, has increased.
The slaying of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter here on Nov. 16 refocused world attention on human rights abuses by El Salvador's rightist forces. President Alfredo Cristiani said this week that an inquiry had shown that the country's military was behind the attack on the priests, who had vigorously argued for a negotiated end to the civil war.
But while most guerrillas in the early 1980's said they joined the movement because of savage brutal rightist repression, rebels are now more likely to cite the country's desperate economic situation than human rights abuses.
The November offensive showed that the guerrillas retain broad support, more than enough to continue their military struggle. ''While it's doubtful the guerrillas can win, they can't lose, at least in the short run,'' one Western diplomat said as the November offensive wound down.

HEADLINE: Cairo Ousts Hard-Line Interior Minister

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 12

 BODY:
President Hosni Mubarak dismissed his Interior Minister today in what seemed intended as a show of increased authority. The announcement signaled the most dramatic change of the political lineup here in months.
A presidential decree announcing that the Interior Minister, Zaki Badr, had been replaced by a police official, Mohammed Abdel-Halim Moussa, gave no explanation for the dismissal.
But Egyptian commentators linked the move to coarse outbursts by the hard-line Interior Minister against newspaper columnists, writers, opposition figures and Islamic scholars. The outbursts were reported this week. 
''Is this the position of the Government? Is this how the state is going treat us?'' a commentator, Mustafa Amin, said in an editorial today, referring to what he said were reports that Mr. Badr had ordered assaults on Egyptian men with beards, the usual emblem of Islamic fundamentalism.
 
Accused of Going Too Far
''I think our political theater has gone too far,'' said Ahmed Baha Ed-Din, another commentator, comparing Mr. Badr to actors departing from the scripts that they were supposed to follow.
Mr. Badr had led the Government's crackdown against Islamic fundamentalists and had sanctioned tough measures against thousands of detainees. The measures brought outcries from Egyptian and foreign human rights groups about police behavior and reports of torture.
He had also scuffled in Parliament with opposition legislators accusing his ministry of human rights abuses and was known for his ready recourse to obscene language about his adversaries. The authorities said last month that he had been the target of a car-bomb attack in Cairo, but the circumstances are unclear.
This week an opposition newspaper began a chorus of calls for the resignation of the 53-year-old Mr. Badr when it published a report on a meeting he addressed in a provincial town. There, he was said to have used crude epithets to describe opposition politicians and newspaper commentators, including those who questioned his activities in today's official press.
 
Held Office Since 1986
Some diplomats said today's newspaper commentaries may have been intended to prepare Egyptians for the announcement of Mr. Badr's dismissal, a move that many Egyptians seemed to welcome in private conversations.
Since 1986, when he took office, Mr. Badr has acted as Mr. Mubarak's iron fist in the official campaign against purported cells of Islamic militants from the organization that assassinated President Anwar el-Sadat in 1981. He was once quoted as saying he viewed Islamic extremists as ''mad dogs, with all respect to dogs.''
The Minister made widespread use of the emergency powers in force since then to jail adversaries without trial. The authorities have pursued a two-track approach to fundamentalism in Egypt, the most populous nation in the Arab world and Washington's most prominent Arab ally in Middle East diplomacy.
While those fundamentalists ready to renounce violence are tolerated, those seeking the violent overthrow of the secular Government faced constant harassment and pressure from Mr. Badr's ministry and from the police forces under its command.
Western diplomats said the policy was likely to continue, possibly in a less flamboyant manner, under his successor, Mr. Moussa. Before his appointment to the Interior Ministry, Mr. Moussa was Governor of Asyut, one of Egypt's most troubled provinces, where Islamic fundamentalism has deep roots. Last month hundreds of people were detained after street battles between the police and Islamic protesters there.
 
New Assertiveness Seen
Mr. Moussa, 59 years old, has also worked as the head of the Interior Ministry's public security department, until October 1987.
Mr. Mubarak took office after the assassination of Mr. Sadat and has since been seen as a cautious figure, relying on aides to carry out his policies, in contrast to the styles of his predecessors, Mr. Sadat and Nasser.
Last year, however, the President dismissed his powerful Defense Minister, Mohammed Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, showing what diplomats depicted as a new assertiveness.
But Western financiers have registered concern at Mr. Mubarak's increasing desire to take charge of all decision-making, saying it slows the already ponderous process of economic change that Cairo is pursuing in inconclusive negotiations with the International Monetary Fund.

HEADLINE: Obsession in Boston: Mystery of Couple's Deaths

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The story of Charles and Carol Stuart has become an obsession here, from the drawing rooms of Back Bay to the bar stools of Revere, the working-class suburb where Mr. Stuart grew up.
Radio talk-show hosts say they have difficulty making callers discuss anything else. Previous preoccupations like the Massachusetts economy and the specter of more taxes have been pushed aside by revelations about Mr. Stuart.
''The last time this happened was when the Red Sox were in the World Series,'' said Jerry Williams, the host of a weekday radio show on WRKO. 
Investigators say Mr. Stuart leaped to his death in Boston Harbor from the Tobin Bridge last week after learning that he had become the prime suspect in the deaths of his wife, Carol, and baby boy, Christopher.
Mr. Stuart's account to the police was that a black gunman jumped into their car and shot him and his wife after they left childbirth classes at Brigham and Women's Hospital on Oct. 23. Mrs. Stuart, seven months pregnant, died of a gunshot would to the head; Mr. Stuart was hospitalized for a stomach wound; their son, Christopher, was delivered by Caesarean section and died 17 days later.
 
Calls for Resignations
The moods of those who phone the talk shows range from disbelief, as in, ''How could he shoot his pregnant wife?'' to fury, as in, ''How could he have fooled the whole city?'' Callers are highly critical of the Boston police and the Suffolk County District Attorney's office.
Today a Suffolk County grand jury resumed hearing witnesses in the case, but the focus shifted to Mr. Stuart from the earlier suspect, a black man arrested on the basis of what Mr. Stuart had told the police. Mr. Stuart was found dead in Boston Harbor on Jan. 4.
Among the witnesses were Gary McLaughlin, a State Police radio dispatcher who took Mr. Stuart's phone call reporting an attack on his wife and himself, and David Maclean, a high school friend of Mr. Stuart. Law-enforcement officials say Mr. Maclean has told them Mr. Stuart asked him late last summer to help kill Mrs. Stuart.
 
Misplaced Sympathy
For the most part Bostonians seem upset that they poured out sympathy for a man who turned out to be a killer. Boston has 100 or fewer homicides a year.
''Mr. Stuart has ruined everybody's faith and trust in Boston,'' said Richard O'Connor, a real estate agent. ''Boston is a small town and I've always enjoyed living here, being able to walk through the Esplanade at night with my dogs or strike up a friendly conversation with someone on the street. What he has done has really hurt everyone in some way or another.''
Bob Cataldo, an insurance salesman in Revere, said, ''This was a shock to everyone and a blow to the city.''
There have been calls for the resignations of Mayor Raymond L. Flynn and Police Commissioner Francis M. Roache, said Stephen Hill, host of a morning call-in show on WILD, an A.M radio station whose programs focus on issues important to blacks.
Mayor Flynn rewrote his State of the City speech to discuss the case and its effect on the people of Boston. ''I must report with more than a little sadness that the state of the city, or better, the mood of the city, ranges from disbelief to cynicism to anger,'' the Mayor said in the speech Wednesday night.
He defended ordering ''an aggressive police response'' in the Mission Hill neighborhood, where Mr. Stuart said the shooting occurred. People have charged that in the police search for the suspect Mr. Stuart described, their doors were broken down and their apartments ransacked.
A group of black legislators have asked the United States Attorney here, Wayne A. Budd, to look into possible civil rights violations. ''Was I wrong? I don't think so,'' the Mayor said. ''But it turned out we were all victims of a sinister hoax.''
 
Book Hunters in Town
Publishers and literary agents have descended on reporters (and been descended upon by them). ''We've already been faxed a proposal by two Boston Herald reporters,'' said Stuart Applebaum, a spokesman for Bantam Books in New York.
Kevin Cullen, a reporter for The Boston Globe who is covering the case, said he had had five or six calls, book offers and screenplay proposals. ''I've said, 'Listen. I've got too much work to do,' '' said Mr. Cullen. ''It didn't surprise me. It just confirmed everything I thought about California and the movies and books and all that. When they smell blood, they don't wait around.''
A producer for ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' said she thought Matthew Stuart, Mr. Stuart's younger brother who went to the police with information that made Charles Stuart the chief suspect, might consider discussing the episode on national television but said her call was not returned.
 
Television Special Planned
CBS has announced plans for a television special based on the footage its ''Rescue 911'' film crew shot the night of the shootings. The camera crew were riding in a Boston ambulance when the call came in from Charles Stuart's car phone: ''My wife's been shot! I've been shot!''
Home Box Office, the cable television company, says it would like to produce a movie as well. Sheila Shayon, assistant to the company chairman and director of special projects, said: ''This guy was like a lot of people all of us know. You want to say, 'Whoa, there but for the grace of God go I and a lot of other people.' ''

HEADLINE: Congress Is Warned by Bush Not to Cut Pentagon Budget

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Seeking to fight off deeper cuts in the military budget than those proposed by the Pentagon, President Bush today warned Congress against trying to ''naively cut the muscle out of our defense'' to provide more money for other programs.
In the second of a series of speeches leading to his State of the Union Message, which he is to deliver on Jan. 31, the President warned that he would not support new domestic programs paid for with money taken from the military budget.
Mr. Bush spoke of his ''excitement'' about the changes sweeping Eastern Europe. ''But in this world of change,'' he told members of the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce, ''one thing is certain: America must be ready.'' 
The President renewed an attack on Congress that he began Monday in a visit to Orlando, Fla., complaining that four big bills he sent to Congress last year have not yet been acted on: legislation to cut the capital gains tax, a child care measure, amendments to the Clean Air Act and tougher penalties against drug dealers.
 
'Jungles of Capitol Hill'
These issues are expected to be considered by Congress in the coming session, and Mr. Bush appears to be assured of winning the cut in the capital gains tax rate that he sought last year. The President, who irritated Democratic lawmakers on Monday by denouncing the ''demagogues who call this a tax cut for the rich,'' said the four issues ''are bogged down in the jungles of Capitol Hill.''
''The clock is running,'' he said, ''and America's patience is running out.''
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said he was disappointed with the President's comments. ''George Bush was offering his hand to the Congress, and now he appears to be giving Congress the back of his hand,'' Mr. Gephardt said in Washington.
''Frankly, the President hasn't given us much of an agenda,'' Mr. Gephardt added. ''He's complaining now that we're not acting on his agenda. As I remember last year, we worked on almost everything he asked us to do, and what we didn't get done we're likely to complete in the first few months of this year. There hasn't been any foot-dragging.''
Commenting on events in Eastern Europe, Mr. Bush said he welcomed ''the dynamic changes'' taking place in that region. ''I strongly support Mr. Gorbachev's perestroika and his commitment to peaceful change and openness,'' he said, referring to the Soviet President and his economic and political policies. ''But this is not a time when we should naively cut the muscle out of our defense posture.''
 
Panama Illustrates the Need
Mr. Bush suggested that his invasion of Panama underscored the need to maintain a high level of military readiness. The United States needs ''a strong defense, a ready and highly effective defense force,'' he said, adding, ''If proof of that were ever needed, we saw it last month in the courage of our troops in Panama.''
The President noted that there has been increasing pressure to cut military spending because of the reduced tensions in Eastern Europe and that some lawmakers have advocated using this ''peace dividend'' to increase spending on social programs.
''That's like the next-of-kin who spend the inheritance before the will is read,'' Mr. Bush said.
