HEADLINE: At 85, Shirer Rounds Out His Story

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
William L. Shirer, now 85 years old and, by his own admission, slowing down a bit, gives this illustration of what he calls his lucky habit of being in the right place at the right time.
He was traveling by train in 1930 from Afghanistan to Europe and while going through Iraq he noticed a conspicuously biblical signpost identifying his train station as Ur Junction.
''I thought that there might be a story there,'' he said, remembering that Ur was the native place of the patriarch Abraham. He quickly interrupted his journey and found the famed British archeologist Sir Charles Leonard Woolley, who was in the process of discovering the first signs of Sumerian civilization. Mr. Shirer said he had stumbled entirely by good luck on an important event, which he duly reported for The Chicago Tribune, his employer in those days. 
Mr. Shirer then resumed his travels, eventually to stumble - as he might put it - across such other ''good stories'' as the rise of Hitler, the appeasement at Munich, the fall of France, World War II and the trials at Nuremberg. Mr. Shirer is a man who knew Gandhi, attended press conferences by Goebbels, spoke to the French Prime Minister Eduard Daladier, and observed Hitler at close quarters, watching carefully his facial expressions, for example, at the 1936 Berlin Olympics when the American Jessie Owens left in ruins the Aryan theories of racial superiority. And so, not surprisingly, he has called his just-completed three-volume memoir of his life and times ''Twentieth Century Journey.'' The last volume, ''A Native's Return,'' will be published this month by Little Brown.
 
'Egotism' With a Purpose
''It's certainly an act of egotism,'' Mr. Shirer said during an afternoon talk at his home in Lenox, Mass., referring to the practice of autobiography. ''But in the back of my mind,'' he continued, ''it was to make it a part of 20th-century history.''
These days Mr. Shirer lives a quiet life, spending a part of the winter in Florida to escape the cold. Photographs in his earlier volumes show him stout and dark-haired with a bristling mustache. Now a white fringe of hair and a white beard give him a bit of the look of a 19th-century Russian novelist (appropriate since he is hard at work on a book about Tolstoy's last years).
''A Native's Return'' covers what might be the least unusual period of his long life - from 1945, when he returned from Europe for good, to 1988 -though the last episode he describes in detail is a return trip he made in 1985 to Paris and Berlin, where he had passed so many years of his youth.
But even if the events of the latest volume are less turbulent and momentous than those of earlier volumes - particularly ''The Nightmare Years,'' which covers his experience of the rise and fall of European fascism - it describes plenty of events. Mr. Shirer was dismissed from CBS in 1947 because, he suggests, he was too ''liberal'' in the Sunday radio commentary he gave every week. He was blacklisted during the MacCarthy years after he was listed, falsely, as a Communist in the journal known as Red Channels.
 
Drew on Nazi Archives
There followed several economically difficult years, during which Mr. Shirer lectured, wrote a couple of not very distinguished novels, and slowly depleted his savings. In the mid-1950's, he got the idea to write a history of Nazism, drawing on the vast numbers of German archives seized during the war and kept in various warehouses in this country.
The idea was rejected, Mr. Shirer says, by several publishers who seemed to believe that nobody was still interested in Nazism. But Simon & Schuster paid him a $10,000 advance and he spent five years in what he now calls a ''delirium'' of writing to produce - in 1960, with the creditors knocking on the door - his extraordinarily successful ''Rise and Fall of the Third Reich.'' The book is still the standard volume on the history of Nazism for the general reader.
Mr. Shirer has in a sense lived the central episode of his long life, the Nazi experience, three times - the first as a journalist, the second as a historian and the third time as memoirist - and each time the experience was different.
''When you're there as a newspaperman you know that you're just scratching the surface,'' he said. Then, acknowledging that he was tempted at times to practice a bit of self-censorship as a CBS Radio reporter to avoid being expelled from Germany, he continued, ''You often wonder, should I publish this or should I keep it to myself?''
 
The Madness Was Grasped Later
As an example of scratching the surface, Mr. Shirer said that he and his colleagues often kept watch on Nazi Party headquarters, and when there was a large collection of cars outside they knew that some kind of meeting was being held. But the full madness of the Hitler years could be grasped only through scrutiny of the extraordinary Nazi archives - Mr. Shirer calls them ''the greatest single historical find ever'' - captured by the Allies after the war.
''Take the Munich agreement, for example,'' Mr. Shirer said. ''I was there that day.'' Mr. Shirer was referring to the day in 1938 when the British Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain, and the French Prime Minister, Edouard Daladier, attempted to appease Hitler by acceding to his demand to annex the German-speaking portions of Czechoslovakia.
''I attended two press conferences by Chamberlain and spoke briefly to Daladier, but I didn't get to the bottom of the agreement,'' Mr. Shirer said. ''I didn't know how things had come about.''
Years later, Mr. Shirer continued, ''the minutes of the Munich meetings showed that Chamberlain and Daladier were over-anxious to give Hitler anything he wanted.''
Asked if he could offer some insight into the meaning or spirit of the era he had lived through and chronicled so thoroughly, Mr. Shirer responded with a recollection of his father who, he said, was a devout Presbyterian from Chicago and a criminal prosecutor whose views of the world were utterly different from those of his wayward son. His father, he said, was a deeply religious optimist, a believer in progress who was in these respects a product of an optimistic time. Mr. Shirer himself, influenced by the worst horrors of history, emerged without religious conviction and, if not pessimistic - since that is a word he does not like - certainly more skeptical about human prospects.
 
Opposing Experiences
''My father lived through a period when there was peace in the world,'' Mr. Shirer said. ''He took it absolutely for granted that life was getting better, more civilized.''
''But it isn't true.'' Mr. Shirer said. ''My experience was the opposite in the sense that I became aware of how savage men can be. Also the fact that we now have acquired the means of blowing up the world means that all thinking had to be radically changed. The bomb marks a great dividing line in history. You can't talk about wars anymore because of the atomic bomb.''
''My father was an orthodox Presbyterian and I'm sure he believed in heaven and hell and that sort of thing,'' Mr. Shirer said. ''For me all that is gone.''
He hesitated at this point in the conversation, worried, he said, about sounding ''pontifical.'' But when pressed to describe the images that remain brightest in his mind, he said, after a moment's thought:
''One of the things that has given me a tremendous amount of admiration is the indomitability of the human race. I remember the refugees from Nazi Germany who didn't know what tomorrow would bring. But they had some indomitable quality. They were not weeping. They were determined to survive. And they did.''Time Warnerd(Little Brown)

HEADLINE: Japan Does Good, and Well

 BODY:
It's a stylized performance. The politician up for re-election dons the statesman's mask and travels abroad in search of good visuals. But the trip to Europe by Prime Minister Kaifu of Japan is no mere ritual play for attention. It's the clearest sign yet that Japan is ready to use its economic power for responsible political ends. 
The world's largest donor of foreign aid, Japan has largely confined its largesse to Asia. Now it's reaching out, with a constructive package of $1 billion in aid for Poland and Hungary.
Washington has long encouraged Tokyo to put economic aid to political use. The United States might now take its own advice by increasing its own aid to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Japan, with half the G.N.P. of the U.S., gives as much aid as the U.S. to these countries. So does West Germany, with one-fifth America's G.N.P.
Japan had already pledged $150 million to Poland. Now it offers $500 million in loans, and an equal amount to Hungary. More important than loans, which these heavily indebted countries will have trouble using, Japan is trying to stimulate private Japanese trade and investment.
Japan's statesmanship is hardly selfless. The Japanese expect to accrue economic benefits from aid. One is direct: earmarked aid boosts Japanese exports. A second benefit is less immediate: to develop Eastern European markets as a hedge against any closing of Western Europe. And Japanese products there could enter the European Community as it opens its import gates to the East. That's one reason Suzuki is investing in an automobile plant in Hungary and Daihatsu plans another in Poland.
But Japan's aid to the East may be tied as much to political as to economic ends. To a Soviet Union anxious not to be left behind Eastern Europe's economic advance, it's an inducement to normalize relations with Japan.
The two countries have remained technically at war since 1945. But Tokyo won't sign a peace treaty unless Moscow gives back four small islands it seized then. An exchange of visits by President Gorbachev's Politburo ally Aleksandr Yakovlev and by Japan's Foreign Minister have raised expectations of the islands' return. Mr. Gorbachev may find a way to accommodate Japan when he goes to Tokyo next year. Then, Soviet-Japanese rapprochement could lead to restructuring of the Soviet economy as well as Far East diplomacy.
That's the sort of political payoff for foreign aid Washington needs to think about.

HEADLINE: Japan Goes Full Throttle on Tests of Magnetic Levitation Trains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We wish to correct errors and misperceptions on high-speed magnetic levitation transport in the letters by Frederick Lightfoot and Fletcher Prouty (Dec. 30).
Mr. Lightfoot is confused about the principles of superconducting maglev when he asserts that it is not practical to maintain thousands of miles of superconducting cable at low temperature. Maglev guideways are not superconducting. They use aluminum loops or sheets at normal temperature. The only superconducting magnets are on the vehicle, which induce currents in the guideway directly underneath. As long as the vehicle keeps moving, these induced currents levitate it inches above the guideway. 
Superconducting magnets for maglev vehicles are simple and practical. Thousands of more sophisticated magnets operate in magnetic resonance imaging medical machines, as well as in scientific laboratories. In the next few years the United States plans to build the superconducting supercollider, using magnets more complicated than those for maglev. If the same length of magnets contemplated were used in maglev vehicles, they could provide 30 percent of total United States transport (auto, truck and air).
Mr. Lightfoot is also wrong about superconductivity in fusion. It is not a difficult problem to shield superconducting magnets from heating by fusion neutrons and gammas.
Mr. Prouty questions the safety of operating magnetic levitation vehicles above the 160 to 180 miles per hour maximum speeds for high-speed rail trains because of potential for increased damage if vehicles collide with foreign objects or trash on a ground-level guideway. He also questions high-speed operation in tunnels or enclosed guideways.
In our view, 300 m.p.h. maglev can be as safe as the best high-speed trains. Maglev guideways will generally be elevated well above ground level to clear obstructions. This is practical and economical because maglev vehicles are light compared with trains, and the guideways need virtually no maintenance. Keeping trash and objects away from elevated guideways will be much easier than for ground-level tracks. Moreover, maglev vehicles float above the guideway, making them less likely to hit objects than conventional trains.
Japan has operated the high-speed ''bullet train'' at 140 m.p.h. for 25 years with no fatalities and the world's highest traffic volume. The speed is constrained by track maintenance limits, not safety. Every night, 3,500 people work on the ''bullet'' route to maintain the track. Higher speeds would require more maintenance and wear it out even faster.
Japan Railways has been testing full-size superconducting maglev vehicles in the last decade. The Japanese system is based on the concepts we published in the late 1960's and early 70's. They have demonstrated safe operation at 300 m.p.h. Japan Railways next plans to build a 50-kilometer first section of a 300 m.p.h. maglev system from Tokyo to Osaka. Most of the route will be in tunnels because of mountainous terrain and high population density near cities.
Clearly, Japan does not agree that 300 m.p.h. maglev is potentially unsafe or that operation in tunnels is not feasible.
 
JAMES R. POWELL
GORDON T. DANBY
 Shoreham, L.I., Jan. 3, 1990
 
The writers, inventors of superconducting magnetic levitation, are, respectively, a senior nuclear engineer and a senior physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

HEADLINE: Is New York's Tax Cut Slipping Away?

BYLINE: By Roy M. Goodman; Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, is chairman of the State Senate's Taxation Committee.

 BODY:
It appears Gov. Mario Cuomo is preparing to torpedo the state income tax cut millions of New Yorkers were expecting this year. No other conclusion can be drawn from his State of the State message, where in 178 pages of text he never once mentioned the pending reduction. The omission casts a shadow over the final phase of the four-year Tax Reduction Act, which became law in 1987.
The last reduction, scheduled to take effect Oct. 1, would lower the maximum income tax rate to 7 percent from 7.5 percent. It forms part of a tax cutting program the Legislature first began back in 1978, when taxes on earned income were as high as 12 percent. 
The income tax cut the Legislature promised this year would put $400 million back in New Yorkers' pockets in the 1990-'91 fiscal year, which begins April 1, and more than $1.3 billion in the 1991-'92 year. The Legislature must stand by its promise.
Stability and predictability are critical factors in business planning, and tax rates are the most crucial consideration when a business decides whether to stay the course or leave New York for more congenial tax climates.
Despite our cuts, New York taxes paycheck income at far higher rates than neighboring states: New Jersey (3.5 percent), Connecticut (0 percent), Massachusetts (5.4 percent), Pennsylvania (2.1 percent).
The rationale for tax cuts is to keep business in New York, and provide more jobs. There are more than one million jobs in the state now than in 1983. In the last two years, 100,000 people have left welfare rolls. Since we started to cut taxes, tax revenues have increased, not decreased. According to Cuomo administration figures, revenues have grown by about $5.4 billion since the current tax reduction program began in 1987 - an average growth rate of 7.7 percent a year. These increases occurred largely because lower tax rates stimulated economic activity and created new jobs. Higher corporate earnings and more salaried workers mean more tax revenues.
Opponents of income tax cuts say such cuts favor the wealthy and hurt the less affluent. Actually, low income taxpayers have been the biggest beneficiaries of tax reduction so far. We have removed 320,000 low income taxpayers from the tax rolls, and the final tax cut, if implemented this year, would remove 480,000 more.
The remaining cut would have the most beneficial impact on taxpayers with incomes ranging from $35,000 to $75,000 - middle class taxpayers who form the backbone of our economy.
And if the state faces a deficit in the next fiscal year? We continued the tax cut program in the current fiscal year in the face of a $1.7 billion budget deficit. We handled the deficit not by cancelling the tax reduction but by refinancing some debt, increasing some excise taxes and cutting back planned spending.
We can again cut the planned spending in order to preserve the final phase of the tax cut. The essential budget problem is that although state revenues have risen, they have not risen fast enough to keep up with ever-higher state spending.
In the current fiscal year, spending will have gone up by about 8.5 percent, compared with an expected national inflation rate of 4.2 percent. If we can hold further spending near the inflation rate, as Mr. Cuomo has pledged to do, while reducing waste, we can keep the tax cut on schedule and still provide essential services for the poor and downtrodden.
In pursuing these economies, we should have a strong ally in Governor Cuomo, who on Sept. 14 told the New York State Business Council: ''I am opposed to the idea of deferring the tax cut, or raising taxes. . . . We must keep the tax cut we promised. . . . And, if you have to deal with this problem of revenues, then find a way to deal with it by restraint in spending, by fighting waste.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (98%);

HEADLINE: Wilding Is a Crime, Except in Law

BYLINE: By Andrew Stein; Andrew Stein is president of the New York City Council.

 BODY:
Whatever else needs to be done in New York City, we must maintain law and order. No constructive social program can work if we descend into chaos.
On Halloween last year, the fear of mob violence kept many New Yorkers at home. Thousands of teen-agers went on bloody rampages in several boroughs. They moved spontaneously in packs of 20 or 30 and assaulted people at random. Many of the victims were women and the elderly. In commercial neighborhoods there was mass thievery. Dozens of stores were trashed. The police arrested more than 250 of the young hoodlums, but many times that number walked away scot-free. 
Unfortunately, many of these kids, and others like them, are out on the streets terrorizing the public again. That's a safe statement to make because most of the youngsters arrested for the rampages won't serve a single day in jail. The majority are under 16 and can only be charged in family court, where incarceration for such offences is rare. Even those indicted as adults can probably plea-bargain the charges down to misdemeanors and avoid serving any time.
Because the public was truly outraged about the most notorious ''wilding'' incident - the rape and near murder of a jogger in Central Park -no doubt anyone convicted of that attack will get a stiff sentence. But there has been little response by the city government to the widespread concern over wilding in general.
After the Central Park attack, violent incidents continued to occur with depressing regularity. People were beaten up on the subways, stores were trashed and shopkeepers terrorized. Since no one was murdered or raped, however, very little attention was paid to the problem by the criminal justice system.
Recently I attempted to gather data on these violent crimes. I was amazed to discover that the statistics do not even exist. One reason cited by police and criminal justice officials is the absence of any specific charge for group assault. Under the criminal code, an individual arrested for participating in an assault with 10 or 20 or 30 others is charged no differently than someone who acts alone. Since arrest figures are compiled on the basis of the charge made in court, the police say they are unable to track wilding or wolfpack crimes.
But you can't fight a crime problem if the crime fighters can't even track the problem. New Yorkers who have been physically victimized, or who live in fear as they ride the subways or walk the streets, know these crimes as a category apart.
With society so immobilized, the kids who do the wilding become more brazen. According to news reporters, gangs who come into Manhattan from Brooklyn now chant: ''Manhattan makes and Brooklyn takes.''
Many argue that harsh criminal punishment is not an effective response to the rising problem of youth violence, that we must deal with the root causes such as poverty, lack of recreational activities and youth unemployment. No doubt such measures are necessary, but there must be the deterrent of certain punishment - meaning real jail time - as well.
Spreading terror on the city's streets and subways is serious, and the criminal code must be changed to reflect that reality. Participation in a group attack should be made a separate crime with a stipulation for automatic minimum sentences. And group assault should be added to the list of those crimes under which a juvenile is tried as an adult.
Such legislative changes will take time. In the meantime, the city must deploy its cops to combat these mobs. The police should begin to gather intelligence on wilding attacks, identify the schools and subways where they are most likely to occur and beef up their presence there. School officials should be encouraged to warn all students that if they are caught, the authorities will try to send them to jail.
Society has a right to declare that some crimes are more menacing and injurious than others. Now, kids on the streets are easily enticed into wilding by their peers because they believe it to be a risk-free activity, virtually a sport. We must begin to send them the message that the criminal justice system regards this as a very serious crime.

HEADLINE: Virginia Adloff, 86, A Writer on Africa And Southeast Asia

 BODY:
Virginia Thompson Adloff, an author and teacher who wrote extensively on the countries of Southeast Asia and French-speaking Africa, died on Tuesday at the home of her sister in La Jolla, Calif. She was 86 years old and a longtime resident of Manhattan. 
Mrs. Adloff, who wrote under her maiden name, was married to Richard Adloff in 1943. Together they traveled for four decades and wrote several books on political, economic, social and cultural developments in Asia and Africa and on the islands of the Pacific and the Indian Ocean.
A native of Newtonville, Mass., she was raised in New York, received a bachelor's degree from Vassar and a doctorate from Columbia.
In World War II she was with the Office of War Information, specializing on Southeast Asia. After the war, she and Mr. Adloff contributed to scholarly journals, translated works from the French and wrote 11 books, including ''The Left Wing in Southeast Asia,'' published in 1950; ''The Emerging States of French Equatorial Africa,'' (1960), and ''The French Pacific Islands: French Polynesia and New Caledonia'' (1971).
From 1961 to 1972, Mrs. Adloff taught political science at the University of California. In the 1978-79 academic year she was the first Distingushed Scholar in Residence at the Institute of International Studies in Berkeley. In 1973 she became the first American woman elected to France's 250-member Academie des Sciences d'Outre-Mer.
She is survived by her husband and her sister, Juliet Pitt.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY, 13, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 Producer prices jumped 0.7 percent in December, bringing inflation for 1989, by this measure, to 4.8 percent, the highest rate since 1981. The monthly rise was somewhat more than expected, and traders said the report contributed to a skid in stock prices and higher interest rates in the credit markets. But many analysts said the figures were not so bad as they seemed. [Page 1.] Retail sales rose 0.2 percent in December, the Government reported, and holiday spending was the weakest since 1985. For the year, sales rose 5 percent, the weakest gain in seven years. [35.] At least 88 residential cooperatives in the New York City area are facing severe financial difficulties. The number is growing, causing concern among owners and state officials. [1.] 
 
 
 
Companies
 U.S. Memories has failed to attract enough investors and will be abandoned, people in the computer industry say. The cooperative venture of American computer chip manufacturers had planned to respond to Japanese challenges by building a $1 billion factory to make computer memory chips, using money donated by computer and semiconductor companies. Although many computer industry executives expressed interest in U.S. Memories, they did not in the end make the financial commitments necessary for its survival. [1.] Campeau's move to establish independence for its troubled American retail operations failed to generate confidence among financial analysts, but gave new support to managers of the department stores controlled by Allied and Federated. [35.] A decision by Campeau to seek bankruptcy protection for the two big American retailing units would buy valuable time but would diminish the company's control over its future. [37.] Ford Motor says it will sell Ford Aerospace, which makes weapons and satellites, amid growing signs that military spending will decline. Ford's directors approved the sale, which had been anticipated, on Thursday. [35.] Five former Salomon executives will join First Boston. Last year, the five had founded a bond-trading ''boutique'' called Voute Coats Stuart & O'Grady. [35.] Air France says it will acquire control of two French airlines: Air Inter, a large French domestic airline, and Union de Transports Aeriens, a long-haul carrier. The complex $670 million deal is likely to trouble the European Community's antitrust regulators. [37.] General Motors is beginning a new round of cost-cutting measures, including voluntary separation packages for salaried employees. It is also freezing new hiring with the exception of college graduates with ''key technical skills.'' [37.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Stock prices tumbled amid new concerns about interest rates and a resurgence of inflation. The Dow Jones industrials dropped 71.46 points, or 2.6 percent, to 2,689.21, in their sharpest drop since Oct. 13. For the week, the Dow fell 84.04 points, or 3 percent. [35.] Treasury bond prices tumbled and yields climbed, largely because of heavy overnight selling of domestic and U.S. securities by Japanese and European institutions. [38.] The dollar was mostly higher in U.S. trading, amid continued uncertainty about the political future of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. Gold prices were generally higher. [43.] Prices of grain futures were mixed and soybeans futures closed lower on the Chicago Board of Trade, in reaction to the release of an Agriculture Department crop report. [43.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 A Federal appellate court has ruled that state governments are immune from charges of patent infringement. As a result, inventors who try to enforce their patents against state agencies will have their cases thrown out of court. Patents. [36.] Professional investors caution against euphoric buying of stocks that may benefit from trade with the East bloc. Some believe better opportunities may lie in East Asia. Your Money. [36.]

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Rose 0.2% Last Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Retail sales rose two-tenths of a percent in December, and holiday spending was the weakest since 1985, the Government reported today. For the year, sales increased 5 percent, the slowest gain in seven years.
Analysts said the figures reflected a steepening slide in consumer spending, once an area of strength in last year's economy.
''It seems that consumer spending is dead in the water,'' said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fugi Securities Inc. in Chicago. 
Walter Loeb, a retail analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, said, ''The consumer basically is in hiding.'' He credited bargain promotions for most of the consumer spending that did occur.
 
Slowest Since Recession
 The Commerce Department said retail sales totaled $1.71 trillion last year. The 5 percent gain compared with 7.1 percent in 1988, and was the slowest since the 2.9 percent rise in the recession year of 1982.
December sales, which totaled a seasonally adjusted $144.4 billion, followed a gain of five-tenths of a percent in November.
Because many consumers begin their Christmas shopping just after Thanksgiving, many analysts combine sales in both months to assess holiday spending. Half or more of retail profits come from business done between Thanksgiving and Christmas.
The combined November-December sales were just 3.8 percent above the corresponding period of 1988, which posted a 6.6 percent gain over those months of 1987. The 1989 holiday gain was the most sluggish since a 2.9 percent rise in 1985.
David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York Government securities dealer, said consumers were spending only when they got a bargain.
''That's obvious in the case of auto incentives and all of the discounts at Christmas,'' Mr. Jones said. ''Consumers did come out of their shell and spend at Christmas, but only because department stores offered them discounts.''
 
Decline at Department Stores
 Even so, department store sales did not fare well and were down four-tenths of a percent in December.
Many analysts said consumer spending would continue to be dominated by bargain-hunting, at least through the first half of the year.
Sales of durable goods - expensive items like cars and household appliances expected to last more than three years - fell six-tenths of a percent in December after edging up one-tenth of a percent in November.
Durable goods, which are often financed by loans, have been particularly affected by tighter Federal Reserve credit policies and have been the subject of extensive promotions, especially for automobiles.
But most auto incentives ended with the introduction of 1990 models in October, and vehicle sales dropped seven-tenths of a percent in December on top of a decline of four-tenths of a percent in November.
Auto sales, which represent about 22 percent of retail sales, ended the year up just 2.2 percent, compared with a 10.3 percent gain in 1988. It was the lowest since 1980, when sales registered a decline of 8.1 percent.
Excluding autos, overall sales in December were up four-tenths of a percent.
 
Furniture Sales Drop
 Sales of durable building materials rose one-tenth of a percent, on top of a rise of seven-tenths of a percent in November, while furniture and other home furnishings declined 1 percent, after an increase of seven-tenths of a percent a month earlier.
Sales of nondurable goods rose six-tenths of a percent, after gaining eight-tenths of a percent in November.
Sales were up six-tenths of a percent at grocery stores and 1.3 percent at gasoline stations, both partly the result of higher prices. Apparel sales advanced one-tenth of a percent.
Despite the holiday season, sales at restaurants and bars were down nine-tenths of a percent, and drugstores posted a decline of 1 percent.
For the three months from October through December, overall retail sales were up 3.6 percent.

HEADLINE: 71.46 Drop Puts Dow At 2,689.21

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices tumbled yesterday amid new concerns about higher interest rates and a resurgence of inflation. The drop followed declines in other important stock markets around the world.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 71.46 points, or 2.6 percent, to 2,689.21.
Yesterday's drop in the Dow industrials was the largest in 13 weeks, since a plunge of 190.58 points on Oct. 13. In terms of points, it was the 13th-largest drop on record. For the week, the Dow fell 84.04 points, or 3 percent. 
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 183.9 million shares, from 154.4 million on Thursday. Traders said large institutions were buying and selling in only moderate volume.
 
1,483 Declines on Big Board
 The declines were broad based, with stocks that fell in price outnumbering those that rose by 1,483 to 217.
One factor in the decline, analysts said, was a report by the Commerce Department that the Producer Price Index rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December, sharply higher than the four-tenths of 1 percent many economists had predicted. For the full year, producer prices rose 4.8 percent.
The Commerce Department also reported that retail sales rose two-tenths of 1 percent in December, in line with what most had expected.
But some people on Wall Street contended that developments in the overseas financial markets, particularly in Japan, had a greater impact on stocks in the United States than the two economic reports.
 
Higher Global Interest Rates
 ''Global interest rates are rising dramatically,'' said John Groveman, president of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company in New York, ''which put pressure on our bond market and, of course, our stock market. This is no time to be a hero.''
Mr. Groveman pointed out that the interest rate on the benchmark long-term Japanese bond rose to yield 6.45 percent, from 6.265 percent. It was the first time the yield on that issue had exceeded 6.35 percent since Oct. 5, 1987, shortly before the worldwide plunge in stock prices on Oct. 19, 1987.
Lower bond prices, a decline in the yen and political uncertainties continued to unnerve Japanese investors yesterday. In Tokyo, the 225-stock Nikkei index lost 653.36 points, or 1.71 percent, to 37,516.77.
In London, the Financial Times 100-stock index lost 37.8 points, or 1 percent, to 2,380.1. The West German market avoided the sell-off, with stock prices mixed.
David B. Bostian, managing director and chief investment strategist at Jesup & Lamont Inc. in New York, said renewed apprehension about the political situation surrounding President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union continued to unnerve markets around the world.
Mr. Bostian added, ''The immediate concern that I have is that if the market does not stabilize next week it could touch off mutual fund switch selling, which was one of the dominoes in the 1987 decline.''
Switch selling involves switching from stock funds into money-market funds, and vice versa.
''It's just a technical decline,'' one trader said about the drop. ''The break below 2,700 was the last blow for the Dow. Other market measures were trading below their year lows at the opening.''
Analysts said data on producer prices and retail sales also depressed dollar and bond prices, which exacerbated the weakness in equities.
The dollar opened sharply lower, but recovered to rise against both the Japanese yen and the West German mark. By late in the day, the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue was off 20/32, to 99 17/32, with the yield climbing to 8.17 percent, from 8.11 on Thursday and 8.06 percent a week ago.
Among broader measures of the market, the Big Board composite index dropped 4.46 points yesterday, to 188.32, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.60 points, to 339.93.
The 12-point circuit breaker on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was put into effect at 2:06 P.M., Eastern standard time, but was activated for only a few minutes.
When the S.&P. 500 declines 12 points, the circuit breaker goes into effect and trades in stock-index futures cannot be made below that level for 30 minutes. Offers can be made at the limit price, however, or above it.
The Dow industrials fell 53 points in the first hour of trading. By 11:30 A.M., the loss had narrowed to 38 points before the drop continued. The average remained about 42 points lower through the early afternoon but by 2:30 had fallen 69 points. It extended that deficit to about 79 points about 3:30 P.M. before rebounding somewhat toward the close.
 
Airline Stocks Decline
 The Dow transportation average fell 25.07 points, to 1,140.65, pulled down in part by UAL's 4 3/4-point drop, to 159 1/2.
Philips Industries was a big percentage loser, dropping 2 3/8, to 15 5/8. Analysts said the company's announcement after the close of trading on Thursday that it could not obtain financing for its proposed leveraged buyout reflected its lower profit estimate, the dull outlook for its main markets and disarray in the arranging of such buyouts.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index fell 7.12 points, to 372.23, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 9.14 points, to 439.72.

HEADLINE: Stretch Limousines: Is Party Over?

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

 BODY:
The market for stretch limousines - the new-money status symbols of the 1980's - is shrinking.
Production is falling, companies are folding, and the car surgeons in this once-booming industry are predicting lean times. A slowing American economy, layoffs on Wall Street and a depressed real estate market have all crimped the pocketbooks of the former free spenders who were so fond of the sleek, smoked-glass behemoths. In fact, the stock market crash in October 1987 marked the real turning point for the industry, analysts say. 
The loss of the economic exuberance of the early 1980's has cut into the sales of the dozens of companies that convert top-of-the-line Cadillac and Lincoln models into stretch versions and reduced demand for the services of hundreds of livery companies in cities like New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.
A sure sign of the troubles of the stretch limousine business came last week when the A. H. A. Automotive Technologies Corporation, unable to make payments on its loans, went bankrupt. The Canadian company was one of the largest makers of outsized limousines in North America.
''There has been a tremendous shakeout in our business,'' said Jack Schwartz, president of Dillinger-Gaines Coachworks Ltd., a big New York-based producer of stretch limousines. ''You'll see a few more people who will go out of business in a little while.''
Few products have inspired as much devotion and animosity as the stretch limousine. Its proliferation during the 1980's tended to divide people, especially those with high-paying jobs like investment bankers, lawyers and others, into two camps: riders who viewed the limousines as a well-earned reward for hard work, and naysayers who refused to set foot in what they viewed as a hallmark of nouveau riche bad taste.
 
Some Strong Attachments
 So undoubtedly, a decline in the business will get a mixed public reaction. Nonetheless, many apparently view the limousines as a necessity. For some people, said Dr. Elliot Wineburg, an assistant professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, the stretch limousine ''is almost as important to them as wearing a necktie is to other people.'' Dr. Wineburg recalled that one of his patients was as attached to his limousine as he was to his gold pinkie ring.
And in the stretch limousine industry, there is nothing but concern. Reliable statistics are scarce but the available figures portray a sharp contraction.
There are 57 companies making 5,800 stretch limousines annually, down from an output of 7,000 in the peak year of 1987, according to Limousine & Chauffeur magazine, a California-based trade publication. For most of the 1980's, stretch-limousine production grew steadily, from 2,500 in 1980.
 
Production Trimmed
 Even conversion companies that say their business is thriving have become more conservative. Mr. Schwartz of Dillinger-Gaines, for example, said his company recently closed a plant in Florida, which had supplemented the output from its main factory, in Lindenhurst, N.J.
The Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury division said sales of its Lincoln Town Car line have declined 60 percent in the current model year, which began last October, compared with the period a year earlier. Ford blames a delayed introduction of the 1990 model for some of the falloff. Reporting its most recent available figures, General Motors said it sent 1,069 of its special ''coach builders'' Cadillac Broughams to converters during the 1989 model year, down from 2,070 the previous year.
The demise of A. H. A. Automotive Technologies was apparently hastened by an anti-dumping suit filed last August by John Gore, president of Southampton Coachworks Ltd., of Farmingdale, L.I. The suit itself, analysts say, was an indication of the intense competition and straitened circumstances of the stretch-limousine industry. Mr. Gore said his company's sales fell more than 15 percent last year.
After a four-month investigation, the Commerce Department announced on Jan. 3 that because A.H.A. had been charging significantly less in the United States for the same model limousine it sold in Canada, it would have to pay a 4.84 percent dumping penalty on each limousine exported to the United States. Two days after the ruling, A.H.A., which in December had defaulted on loans, was placed in receivership.
Stretch limousines have been around for decades. But until the 1960's, they were always custom-built. During that decade two companies, the Lehmann-Peterson Company and Hess & Eisenhardt started buying luxury Cadillacs and Lincolns, chopping them in half, adding 60 or 72 inches to the chassis and the body and loading the interior with expensive gadgetry.
The new wealth generated by the economic growth of the 1980's created a golden era for limousines and, it seemed, the bigger the better. The expanding demand brought in a flood of new limosine services, often one-man operations.
Converters pay about $27,400 for Cadillac Broughams and $29,000 to $30,000 for Lincoln Town Cars. Cars sold to converters contain special features, like bigger engines, larger transmissions, reinforced shock absorbers and either more powerful or more efficient alternators to run the gadgets.
Prices for stretch limosines, the bulk of which are sold to livery companies, range from $40,000 for the basic model to more than $80,000 for the more extravagant.
''The only option is a fax machine,'' Mr. Schwartz said. Price tag for the car: $85,000.
The industry is one of intense personal rivalries and flamboyant rhetoric. A handful of companies all claim to be the largest in the industry.
In addition to falling demand, the producers are coming under increasing pressure to comply with safety requirements.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Global Investing For the Cautious

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
The tumultuous events of Eastern Europe in recent weeks have given rise to capitalist hopes, and many small investors have rushed to buy shares of companies that they expect to profit from trade with East Germany, Poland, Hungary and other East bloc nations.
West German companies in particular should profit, many investors reasoned, and the Frankfurt stock market rose 13 percent in five weeks. The Germany Fund surged 157 percent on the Big Board last year. But seasoned professionals, cautioning against euphoric buying, say that the Frankfurt market rose too far too fast and that Asia actually offers better buying opportunities. 
Simon G. Fenton, vice president of Kleinwort Benson International Investment Ltd., called such gains ''overanticipation.'' Although he sees greater returns in the markets outside the United States than in the United States market over the next year, in part because of a marginally weaker dollar, he expects it will take several years to realize substantial profits from the business opportunities being created in Eastern Europe.
''The best opportunities are in Far Eastern markets,'' Mr. Fenton said, particularly Singapore and Malaysia, while uncertainties in Europe make the continental markets less attractive.
Looking toward 1992, when trade barriers are to fall in the European Community, he said, ''the jury is still out as to which way the E.C. will lead the world's economy'' - toward greater trade freedoms or toward greater protectionism by creating a more formidable Western European bloc.
The domestic unrest that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev faces in the Soviet Union add to Europe's uncertainties, he said.
But even if overseas markets make only small gains, an American investor in those markets would profit even more if foreign currencies outperform the dollar, as Kleinwort Benson predicts. The firm expects the yen to rise 8 percent against the dollar in the next year and the West German mark to rise 5 percent.
Of course, few market experts thought the dollar would be as strong as it has been in the last year, when by and large American equity investors made their greatest gains at home. Still, Mr. Fenton said, a well-diversified portfolio should have at least 10 percent of its holdings overseas, and ideally 40 percent.
Kleinwort Benson, a London-based firm with offices in New York, manages international investments for institutional and individual investors and is adviser to the Kleinwort Benson International Equity Fund, a no-load mutual fund that focuses on foreign markets. Over all, Kleinwort manages $15 billion.
William S. Stack, managing director and chief investment officer of the Lexington Management Corporation, Saddle Brook, N.J., whose funds include the Lexington Global Fund, looks for companies that perform well throughout the world. He also expects the dollar to weaken.
''We don't look country by country,'' he said. ''There is a big world market. Honda has 60 percent of its earnings inside the United States; Coca-Cola has 60 percent outside. Which is the American company?''
By holding assets worldwide, investors can iron out exchange-rate risk and achieve more diversity and a greater return with less volatility, he said. On a total-return basis, Lexington Global has risen 59.8 percent since it was founded in March 1987 -and it made money even in that crazy year of the October stock market collapse - compared with a 36.4 percent gain on a total-return basis for the Morgan Stanley Capital International World Index and a 33.1 percent rise by the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index in the year.
At present, however, Mr. Stack says, ''I'm cautious.'' The fall of the Berlin wall helped catapult West German stocks upward. But the buyers were foreign, he noted, while Germans took the opportunity to sell into the rising market.
Over the long-term, the stunning events of Eastern Europe will be good for Europe economically, he said, but a quick mass migration of East Germans into West Germany could strain Bonn's social and economic system. That means West Germany has an incentive to invest in East Germany, building up the country's infrastructure and making it attractive for East Germans to stay at home, he continued, but that is a long-term proposition.
Mr. Stack sees opportunities for long-term gains in the Hong Kong, Taiwan and Japanese markets, where Lexington Global has 30 percent of its holdings. He sees some of the best opportunities in third world nations that need foreign investment in both public works and consumer goods.
''I'm a long-term bull,'' he said, but near-term, he said he believes that there could be corrections in Japan, West Germany and the United States.

HEADLINE: Air France Buying Into 2 Carriers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 12

 BODY:
In a move likely to trouble the European Community's antitrust regulators, Air France announced today that it would acquire control of two French airlines: Air Inter, the large French domestic airline, and Union de Transports Aeriens, a long-haul carrier.
Air France said it would pay $670 million to acquire a 54.58 percent stake in U.T.A. from Chargeurs S.A., a Paris-based holding company that owns 82.9 percent of the carrier.
Since Air France already owns 37 percent of Air Inter and U.T.A. owns 35.8 percent of that airline, Air France emerges with majority control of Air Inter as well. Air Inter, which carried 15.7 million passengers last year, is Europe's largest domestic airline and ranks fifth in total passengers carried. 
Last October the European Commission, the community's executive branch, found that a cooperative agreement between Air France and Air Inter was anti-competitive because it called for sharing revenues, profits and losses.
 
Commission Might Act
 Analysts suggested that the commission might conclude that today's accord was intended to circumvent that decision. But French officials say the accord gives France's flag carrier the same hold over its foreign and domestic markets that other European flag carriers have in their own markets.
Air France and Air Inter compete on several domestic routes, as well as on five international routes that Air Inter recently started to serve.
''The problem here is that the European Community likes to get involved in these matters,'' said Peter Bergius, an airline analyst with Kleinwort Benson in London. ''This could end up being delayed for some time.''
Today's agreement could create tension between the European Community and the French Government, which has sought to regroup France's airlines to strengthen Air France's competitive position.
 
Improved Performance Expected
 In a joint statement, Air France's chairman, Bernard Attali, and the Chargeurs chairman, Jerome Seydoux, said the agreement would permit ''the formation of a group that will be better able to compete on an even footing with large global companies.''
Industry analysts said the transaction was part of an effort by European airlines to increase their size to compete with giant American and Asian carriers.
The accord said Air France and U.T.A. would maintain their respective identities. U.T.A. has many routes from France to Africa and Asia, and last year it started flying to Newark International Airport from five provincial French cities, including Marseilles and Bordeaux. It also flies between Paris and San Francisco.
Under pressure from state-owned Air France, the French Government in 1988 denied U.T.A. permission to fly from Paris to Newark. The European Commission has been conducting an antitrust investigation over France's denial of routes to U.T.A.
 
'Some Economies of Scale'
 ''There will clearly be some economies of scale for U.T.A. and Air France,'' said Mr. Bergius, the analyst.
Before the deal was announced, U.T.A. stock was trading at 2,770 francs, or $486, a share. Air France, which by some measures is Europe's No. 2 airline, behind British Airways, said it would buy 930,000 shares at 4,083 francs, or $716, a share.
U.T.A. owns 19 aircraft and earned $137.4 million on revenues of $1.07 billion in 1988. Air Inter owns 53 aircraft and earned $26 million on revenues of $1.3 billion in 1988.
Under the accord, Air France has the right of first refusal to buy the other U.T.A. shares owned by Chargeurs. The agreement still needs the approval of the boards of Air France and Chargeurs.

HEADLINE: Treasury Bond Prices Fall Sharply

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices tumbled and yields climbed yesterday, largely because of heavy overnight selling of domestic and United States securities by Japanese and European institutions.
A sharp rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for December also put pressure on bond prices. The increase resulted in new fears about inflation and reduced the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would ease credit further.
Dealers said plunging prices in the Japanese stock and bond markets spilled over into Europe and then depressed stocks and bonds in the United States. 
 
Benchmark Bond Up to 8.17%
 In late trading in New York, the Treasury's benchmark long-term bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, were being offered at 99 17/ 32, down 20/32. This caused the yield to climb to 8.17 percent, from 8.11 percent Thursday and 8.06 percent a week ago. At 8.17 percent, the long-term bond's yield is the highest since just before stock prices fell sharply on Oct. 13.
Among other representative Treasury coupon issues, the 7 7/8 percent notes of 1999 fell 12/32, to 98 17/32, for a yield of 8.09 percent, and the new 8 percent issue of 1997 lost 10/32, at 99 22/32, to yield 8.06 percent, up from the average 8.02 percent produced by the auction of this issue last Tuesday. The 7 5/8 percent issue of 1993 dipped 1/32, to 98 28/32, for a yield of 7.96 percent, and the 7 5/8's of 1991 were unchanged at 99 15/32, with the yield remaining at 7.92 percent.
The wave of selling began after the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasushi Mieno, said in a speech that the central bank's priorities were to strengthen the yen and hold down inflationary pressures.
These remarks caused the yield on the benchmark Japanese long-term bonds, the No. 119 4.8 percent issue of 1999, to climb quickly to 6.45 percent, from 6.265 percent. It was the first time this bellwether Japanese bond yielded more than 6.35 percent since Oct. 5, 1987 - two weeks before stock prices plunged around the globe.
 
Fears Over Election
 ''The Japanese markets have become increasingly unsettled as next month's national election nears,'' said Philip Braverman, chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the large Japanese financial house. ''There are fears among Japanese investors that the election, which is scheduled for Feb. 18, may lead to more stringent controls on the economy and perhaps moves to renationalize some major industries.''
Some of the selling in Japan was also attributed to the approach of a three-day national holiday, when many financial houses seek to square their accounts. In Japan, Monday is Adult Day and the United States cash market in Treasury securities will also be closed in observance of the Martin Luther King holiday.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., said ''the decline in domestic Treasury securities prices would have been far greater were it not for the even weaker stock market.''
He added, ''Aside from the weakness in the Japanese and other overseas markets, the fixed-income sector had to contend'' with the sharp rise in December producer prices.
Mr. Harris said the rise in wholesale prices raised the specter of renewed inflation and was viewed by many investors as precluding any further easing of interest rates by the Fed.
Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, said fears that the day's economic data would inhibit the Fed from easing credit could be attributed to the central bank's action early in the session. The Fed drained reserves from the banking system through four-day matched sales of Treasury paper to dealers and other financial institutions. The Federal funds rate, the rate that banks charge one another for temporary loans, was 8 1/8 percent at the time and closed at that level.
Meanwhile, discount rates were mixed on Treasury bills, which are immediately influenced by any change in the funds rate. The 90-day bill rate fell 7 basis points, to 7.49 percent, partly on shifts of funds from the stock market. The rate for the six-month bill rose 3 basis points, to 7.44 percent, and the one-year bills gained 2 basis points, to 7.23 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Uncertainty Over Gorbachev Cited as Dollar Rises in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A wave of uncertainty over the political future of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, pushed the dollar mostly higher in domestic dealings yesterday, overshadowing two bearish reports on the United States economy.
Gold prices generally rose. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid price of $414.50, up 90 cents an ounce. But on New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery slipped 80 cents a troy ounce, to $413.20. 
The dollar fell overseas and traded sharply lower in domestic dealings after negative reports on United States inflation and retail sales.
But late in the session, traders said that speculation that Mr. Gorbachev may not survive the intense political pressure surrounding Lithuanian demands for secession caused the dollar to climb.
During a trip to Lithuania, Mr. Gorbachev promised a referendum on a law that would require the Soviet republics to hold their own votes on breaking away, but currency traders said there were rumors that he was not supported by Moscow.
''The speculation is that Gorbachev is not dealing from a large power base anymore,'' said Kevin Lawrie, a vice president at the Bank of Boston's New York office.
''And when in doubt, buy the buck,'' he said, referring to the dollar as the ''safe haven'' currency during times of political instability.
Despite the uncertainty, Marc Chandler, an analyst with Chicago-based Money Market Services International, stressed that ''the economic fundamentals continue to work against the dollar.''
Indeed, the Labor Department reported that prices at the producer level rose by a higher-than-expected seven-tenths of 1 percent in December, lifting 1989 inflation to 4.8 percent for the worst annual showing in eight years. Separately, the Government said retail sales edged up just two-tenths of 1 percent in December after rising five-tenths of 1 percent in November.
The reports, which point jointly to higher inflation and an economic slowdown, initially rocked the dollar and took their toll on stock prices, pushing the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials down by more than 71 points at the closing bell. The financial markets interpreted the reports as a sign the Federal Reserve would not lower interest rates in the near future.
In New York, the dollar finished at 145.74 yen, up from 145.45 yen on Thursday. Against the West German currency, the dollar rose to 1,6860 marks, up from 1.6795.
In London, one British pound cost $1.6705 late yesterday, more expensive for buyers than Thursday's late $1.6575. In New York, it cost $1.6610 to buy one pound, more expensive than $1.6598 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.4975 Swiss francs, down from 1.5065; 5.7410 French francs, up from 5.7215; 1,256.00 Italian lire, up 1,253.75, and 1.1573 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1563.
Gold prices ended the week at a bid $416.25 a troy ounce in London and $416.75 in Zurich, a $4-an-ounce rise in both centers. Dealers said trading was active. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $414.35 a troy ounce, up from $411.75.
Silver prices rose. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery finished at $5.330 a troy ounce, up from $5.306 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Grains Mixed, Soybeans Off After Crop-Report Release

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of grain futures were mixed and soybeans futures closed lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade in reaction to the release of a crop report by the Agriculture Department.
On other markets, orange juice prices rose, precious metals were mixed, copper fell, energy futures dropped, and livestock and meat futures declined.
Wheat settled 3 1/4 cents lower to 3/4 cent higher, with the contract for March delivery at $4.01 1/2 a bushel; corn was 3 3/4 cents to 4 1/4 cents higher, with March at $2.42 1/4 a bushel; oats were one-half cent to three-fourths of a cent lower, with March at $1.43 a bushel; soybeans were one-half cent to 4 1/4 cents lower, with January at $5.65 1/2 a bushel. 
The Agriculture Department report, released on Thursday, showed that farmers planted about 57 million acres of winter wheat for harvest this year, up 3 percent from the previous crop. The department estimated the 1989 corn crop at 7.5 billion bushels and soybean production at 1.9 billion bushels; both estimates were lower than expected.
Soybeans were sharply higher at the opening, but fell back because of weak cash prices and strong growing conditions in South America.
The smaller-than-expected corn harvest bolstered corn futures prices.
The reduced number of seedings sent wheat futures higher at the open, but only the July new-crop contract ended on the plus side because of somewhat dry conditions in pockets of winter wheat.
Orange juice futures were sharply higher on New York's Cotton Exchange as the Agriculture Department's first estimate on the orange juice crop since the December freeze indicated losses were as severe as anticipated. The agency had projected a 1989-90 orange harvest of just 130 million 90-pound boxes, but that estimate has been slashed 29 percent, to 92 million boxes. That is the smallest production estimate since the 1964-65 season.
Frozen concentrated orange juice was 5 cents to 12 cents higher, with January at $1.975 a pound.
Copper prices were off sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York as concerns about the economy and the slumping stock market led to selling. Copper was 2.40 cents to 3.30 cents lower, with February at $1.063 a pound.
Energy futures were lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 1 cent to 41 cents lower, with February at $23.13 a gallon; heating oil was 0.57 cent lower to 0.33 cent higher, with February at 69.65 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.50 cent lower to 0.01 cent higher, with February at 65.09 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Charge Cards That Pick Up the Pieces

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Now that American Express has set the pace, Mastercard and Visa are running close behind in providing charge-card programs that insure purchases against loss, damage or breakage.
Until recently, only holders of what are known as ''gold'' or ''preferred'' credit cards qualfied for these plans. But now a growing number of banks offer them with standard cards.
''That's definitely becoming the trend for the new year,'' said Robert B. McKinley, the editor and publisher of Bankcard Update, an industry newsletter published by Ram Research and Publishing in Frederick, Md. 
The first program was introduced by American Express in 1987. Under it, merchandise bought with one of the company's charge cards will be replaced, or its cost will be refunded, if it is lost, stolen or damaged within 90 days of purchase. A companion program extends the manufacturer's warranty on a product, sometimes for as long as a year.
 
Card Wars
 Both Mastercard International Inc. and Visa U.S.A. Inc. now offer similar programs as part of the standard benefits on their preferred or ''gold'' bank credit cards.
The purchase protection programs are the latest skirmish in a continuing credit-card war. Many banks are using various incentives as well as low annual fees and interest rates to lure preferred card holders from rival banks or to entice regular card holders to take the preferred cards. Added to that is stiffened competition between Visa and Mastercard, on the one hand, and American Express on the other.
The purchase-insurance programs come at a price to the issuers. Gregory Holmes, a spokesman for Visa, said the annual cost to the company was about $4.34 million, or about 62 cents for each of its 7 million accounts. Since the program began, some 3,400 Visa card holders have made claims under the program.
Many recent credit-card incentives, like travel services, have not drawn great consumer interest. But the purchase protection plans are getting high marks, even from critics of charge cards.
''These appear to be the first credit-card enchancements to have any value,'' said Elgie Holstein, executive director of Bank Cardholders of America, a consumer organization with headquarters in Herndon, Va.
He should know. Last year, Mr. Holstein lost a new watch worth about $125 shortly after buying it with an American Express card. He said that after putting in a claim, he was asked to furnish copies of his homeowner's insurance policy and the receipt for the watch. Some four weeks later, he received a check for its full price.
''It didn't happen overnight, and I had to take a couple of steps,'' Mr. Holstein said. ''But it happened.'' The protection plans offered by the three major charge-card companies are similar. All are supplemental to any homeowner's insurance held by a customer. As a result, they pay only those amounts that are not covered by the policy's deductible or that exceed its limits. Annual payments are generally limited to $50,000 on each account, though the limit on jewelry, watches and furs is lower: $2,500.
There are important exceptions. Things like traveler's checks, negotiable instruments, pets and plants are often not covered by credit-card insurance. And in a claim involving a theft from a car, the vehicle must have been locked and must show signs of forced entry. As in Mr. Holstein's case, refunds can take a month or more, rather than the blink of an eye suggested by recent television commercials.
In a large claim, an insurance inspector may also pay the card holder a visit, said James M. Erlick, an American Express vice president for card member services. He declined to say how big a claim would have to be to bring such an inquiry or how many claims had received such scrutiny.
The documentation required on claims depends on the type of loss, Mr. Erlick said. A police report is needed, for example, to substantiate a theft. In damage cases, smaller items must be mailed to the charge-card company, while larger items can be photographed. Claims must be filed within 45 days after an item is lost or damaged.
Those who monitor the credit-card market said consumer reception of the programs had been good. ''We have not heard any complaints about them,'' said Spencer Nilson, the publisher of the Nilson Report, a charge-card industry newsletter in Santa Monica, Calif.
The choice of a charge card should be based on interest rates, not incentives, consumer advocates say. But efforts by some banks to attract preferred card customers has led to wide differences in both interest rates and annual fees.
 
The Fine Print Bears a Look
 The biggest benefits are reaped by those who qualify for preferred cards without annual fees and can afford to pay their monthly bills before interest is due, said Mr. McKinley, the Bankcard Update publisher.
Some bank cards require a minimum savings account balance. Other bank offers may lose their attraction on closer examination.
For example, the First Deposit National Bank in Tilton, N.H., is offering a preferred Visa card without an annual fee. But the card does not offer a grace period, which means that interest on purchases begins accruing immediately.
 
SAYING GOODBYE TO AN OLD CARD
 
Here are some tips from Bank Cardholders of America, a consumer group, on changing credit cards:
* Wait to cancel a high-interest card until you have selected - and received - a lower-interest one.
* Tell the new bank you want to close your old credit-card account. That bank may advance you cash at the lower interest rate to pay off the old card's balance. But be sure the fee for the advance is minimal.
* Cut your old card in half and mail it to the issuing bank with a note saying you want your account closed.
 A list of banks that issue low-interest credit cards is available for $1.50 from Bank Cardholders of America, 560 Herndon Parkway, Suite 120, Herndon, Va. 22070.

HEADLINE: U.S. WEIGHS SHIFTS IN AFGHAN POLICY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
President Bush sent a delegation of senior American officials to South Asia today to accelerate efforts to find a negotiated settlement of the war in Afghanistan.
Nearly a year after Soviet troops withdrew from Afghanistan, the American-armed guerrillas seem no closer to military victory in the effort to establish a non-Communist government in Kabul. .
The mission to South Asia, led by Robert M. Kimmitt, the No. 3 official at the State Department, is unlikely to produce a reversal of longstanding American policy itself. But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visits Moscow early next month, and officials are clearly analyzing all the options on Afghanistan. Among the possibilities are a cutoff of arms from both superpowers, a coalition government, or a larger role for the United Nations. 
The Kimmitt trip comes as the United Nations is also stepping up the pace of its Afghan diplomacy with a visit to Moscow by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is to meet on Monday with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [Page 15.]
Mr. Kimmitt will meet in Pakistan with Afghan guerrilla leaders and Pakistani officials. He also plans to visit Saudi Arabia, which helps finance some Afghan guerrilla groups. The delegation will also visit India, where Mr. Kimmit may meet the new Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, to discuss Afghanistan and other issues.
The delegation led by Mr. Kimmitt, who is Under Secretary for Political Affairs, includes Peter Tomsen, the special American envoy to the Afghan rebels; Michael E. Malinowski, a former consul in Peshawar, Pakistan; A. Peter Burleigh, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Intelligence and Research; William J. Burns, deputy director of the State Department's policy planning staff, and Sandra Charles, a member of the National Security Council staff.
Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said the trip did not signal a change or formal review of American policy toward Afghanistan. But Afghanistan will be high on the agenda when Mr. Baker meets Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Moscow on Feb. 6 and 7.
Among the policy options are a larger role for the United Nations, simultaneous termination of arms deliveries by both Moscow and Washington, and the creation of a coalition government including Afghan guerrillas and some Communists not closely identified with the current Government. Another option is to ask the exiled King, Mohammed Zahir Shah, to return to Afghanistan and help unify the country.
 
A Hard-Liner's Softer Views
The United States insists that Najibullah, the Afghan President, resign as part of any political settlement. But the Soviets refuse to abandon him and note that he has shown much more staying power than Washington expected. In February 1989, American officials were predicting that the Najibullah Government would crumble within a few months.
Representative Charles Wilson, a Texas Democrat who is a staunch supporter of the Afghan rebels, visited Moscow this month at the invitation of the Soviet Government, and he came back saying he would no longer insist on military victory for the Afghan guerrillas.
Mr. Wilson once explained that he wanted to help the rebels in Afghanistan because ''it's the only place in the world where we are killing Russians.'' But in an interview this week, he said: ''The trip to Moscow softened me. I got a better understanding and appreciation and sympathy for the Soviet position. I saw what a God-awful mess they're in. My No. 1 objective now is a negotiated solution.''
''The mujahedeen have got to be more flexible,'' Mr. Wilson said, using the Arabic word for holy warriors, as the Afghan rebels style themselves. ''It's not desirable now for anybody to be hanging from lampposts.''
The Congressman said he detected ''some flexibility in the Soviet position'' and ''an extreme desire on their part to get this irritation out of the way.''
 
Objections to Najibullah
Richard N. Haass, director of Near East and South Asian affairs at the National Security Council, said the Afghan guerrillas ''will not sit down and talk with or work with Najibullah'' because he is ''seen as being responsible for too much destruction and devastation.'' Mr. Najibullah is associated with the Soviet invaders of Afghanistan and ''has lost political legitimacy,'' he said.
''The Soviets have only departed Afghanistan in form, not fact,'' Mr. Haass asserted. ''What enables Najibullah and his associates to hang on is Soviet military and economic assistance, now estimated at $250 million to $300 million a month,'' or $3 billion to $3.6 billion a year.
American military aid to the Afghan guerrillas is estimated to have totalled $600 million last year, but the exact figure is a secret.
The departure of Soviet troops from Afghanistan ''does not provide much opportunity for cheering,'' Mr. Haass said. ''The fighting and the suffering continue. Afghans continue to die. More than three million Afghans remain refugees in Pakistan.''
Mr. Haass said that ''Najibullah and his closest associates will have to agree to transfer political power as part of a process leading to a settlement.'' Beyond that, he said, ''we are not wedded to any single political course or political outcome.''
 
Inflexibility Is Assailed
Selig S. Harrison, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, who has followed Afghanistan for 35 years, said he was disappointed with the Administration's position, as described by Mr. Haass. ''It does not indicate any flexibility on a key issue: support for the U.N. as a vehicle for bringing about a political settlement,'' Mr. Harrison said.
Nor, he said, does the Administration show any willingness to halt arms deliveries to the guerrillas in return for Moscow's willingness to halt military aid to the Kabul Government.
The United States supports the rebels' government-in-exile based in Pakistan.
''In effect,'' Mr. Harrison said, ''the United States is hostage to Pakistan's policy, which is to stall movement toward a political solution until the Afghan interim government becomes capable of prosecuting the war more successfully. That means indefinite American involvement in the Afghan civil war because the interim government was created under Pakistani sponsorship and is seen by many Afghans as a Pakistani tool.''
State Department officials said they were encouraged by reports of serious rifts in the Afghan armed forces and the recent defection of more than two dozen Afghan Army officers. Such reports emerged last month after many officers, including several generals, were arrested for plotting against the Kabul Government.
But the Washington policy suffered a setback this week when France announced plans to reopen its embassy in Kabul, becoming the first Western power to be represented in the Afghan capital since the Soviet pullout last February. The United States has encouraged the diplomatic isolation of the Najibullah Government.
