HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: The Oil States -- A special report:
3 States, Once Fat on Oil, Try to Break With Past

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Fearfully contemplating a future without oil, Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma are trying to reinvent themselves.
From the populism of the bayou to the conservatism of the old frontier, political cultures molded by the economy of oil are under siege. Business mores symbolized by the handshake contract have become outmoded. Powerful elites who held sway over city halls and country clubs have been swept aside.
The outcome of all these changes is so uncertain that experts offer a remarkable range of business and economic forecasts. 
A. Robert Abboud of Houston, chairman of the First City Bancorporation, is so optimistic that he calls the business opportunities in Texas ''a ticket to heaven.''
But Adm. Bobby R. Inman, who has headed two major Texas-based computer firms since he left the Central Intelligence Agency in 1982, said there is a serious risk that ''if we do not make some tough decisions or we make the wrong decisions, this region could end up like a very large Mississippi.''
The decline of oil deprived the region of the natural advantages that once put it so far ahead in the race for economic health and gave it the boastful self-confidence that has become its international image. Now business leaders and politicians are discovering that the transition to an age in which success rests upon brains rather than brawn requires profound changes in attitudes and expensive changes in public policy.
 
Loss of Security
Gone with the bust is a deep sense of security that flowed from a rich natural endowment. It has been replaced by a sense of all-out competition that starts with neighboring communities and extends to San Diego and Osaka. Oil patch cities like Dallas, which once considered themselves irresistible magnets, now see themselves as contestants in a desperate race to lure the businesses that will create jobs in the next century.
''We can't settle for just being cotton pickers anymore,'' said Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana, one of the major proponents of change in the region.
''Our natural resources were so plentiful,'' he said, ''that all we had to do was harvest them to get rich, whether it was cotton or oil and gas or lumber or cattle. But in this world today it is no longer enough to be asset-rich unless your No. 1 asset is human beings.''
 
The Bust
 
End of Dependency On Oil Money
 Two years of steady but unspectacular recovery have not dimmed the memory of the painful oil price busts of the 1980's.
The oil and gas industry provided Texas with 28 percent of all state taxes collected in 1981 but by last year that had dwindled to 9 percent. In Louisiana employment in oil and gas extraction dropped by more than half from 1981 to 1987 as the state lost about 9 percent of all its nonagricultural jobs.
The search for new vocations was evident in September among the 440 young, mostly affluent Texans who danced the two-step and devoured brisket at a barbecue at the Y. O. Ranch, a hill country spread that is considered a Texas icon for its 110-year history and its herds of longhorn cattle.
Charles Schreiner 4th, one of the ranch owners, commissioned a polling firm to survey his guests and found that nearly 39 percent of his friends thought the best investment opportunities in Texas for the 1990's lay in high technology industries. Among the revelers, who came from many of Texas's oldest and most influential families, only about 9 percent favored putting money into oil and gas ventures.
The ranch barbecue was called to commemorate ''The New Spirit of Texas,'' but the celebration may have been premature. The region has experienced a slow, steady recovery since the oil bust bottomed out in late 1987, with the Houston area showing particular resilience. But experts put many question marks in their long-term forecasts.
In all three states the relationship between the public and private sectors is being realigned. Government's basic responsibilities, especially regarding education, are being re-examined and final decisions are coming hard.
Traditionally a region where individuals paid low taxes, the oil states have had to defy the national trend during the era that made ''no new taxes'' a rallying cry to make up for lost revenues from the oil industry. Texas and Oklahoma have enacted substantial tax increases since the oil busts that have brought their levies close to the national average. Now there is talk of raising taxes some more.
 
Fiscal Luxuries Under Attack
In Oklahoma, Gov. Henry Bellmon, a Republican who is retiring this year, has been battling much of the conservative establishment that backed him through a long political career. He is asking for the second $250 million tax increase in three years along with a program of drastic school reform.
In Louisiana, Governor Roemer, a liberal Democrat, has been trying to wean the state from the populist largess instituted by Gov. Huey Long in the 1930's. Governor Roemer insists that fiscal luxuries like a homestead exemption, which frees most homeowners from property taxes, were viable only when the oil industry made vast contributions to the state treasury. So far, however, he has had only limited success in overhauling the tax system to transfer some of the burden from businesses to ordinary citizens.
In Texas, the ''good business climate'' has been as sacred as the Alamo. But now there is growing debate as to what exactly promotes the growth of business.
Joe R. Feagin, a sociologist at the University of Texas at Austin said: ''A large and powerful number of people in Texas still adhere to the frontier notion that low taxes, low services and minimal government is the way to prosperity. But the true Texans have been diluted by people who moved here during the boom, bringing along the notion that government is worth paying for if it is efficient and effective.''
An indication of how much Texas has changed came last October when Lieut. Gov. Bill Hobby, a Democrat, shocked the state by suggesting that Texas would have to enact an income tax soon, thus losing its status as the only big industrial state without either a personal or corporate income tax.
The Lieutenant Governor, also a lame duck, argued that an income tax was the only way to comply with a Federal court order that requires an overhaul of public school financing. Neither Gov. William P. Clements Jr., a Republican, nor any of the 14 candidates vying for his office in elections this year accepted the idea despite an estimate from the State Board of Education that the schools will need an additional $5 billion over the next five years.
While the education issue preoccupies much of the country, it is especially potent in these three states because they have consistently come in well below the national average in spending per pupil and in graduation rates. Across the region the business community has taken the lead with executives like Paul F. Roth, president of the Texas division of the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company arguing that a weak school system ''wasn't such a crucial factor when oil and cotton fueled the Texas economy.''
''Today,'' Mr. Roth said, ''this weakness represents an economic time bomb.''
 
The Adjustments
 
Ostentation Is Out; Basics Are Back
 As the politicians debate the future, millions of individuals are adjusting to rapidly changing perceptions of economic opportunity.
In a region once marked by a highly speculative business mentality, executives have been chastened first by massive losses and now by a credit market that finances only the most solid proposals.''It's back to basics on all kinds of deals,'' said Scott Ziegler, of Ziegler Cooper Inc., a Houston architecture and design firm. ''If the fundamentals aren't right, the deals don't get made because that euphoric period of breaking the rules and taking big risks is long gone now. No one is building monuments to themselves anymore.''
Ostentation is out, even in the oil business. Old boy networks have been shattered by bankruptcies. ''Diversification and high tech have become the buzzwords,'' said Barton Smith, chairman of the economics department at the University of Houston. ''Diversification just means anything but oil, and no one knows what high tech means.''
And even two years of economic recovery have yet to repair some of the region's human losses.
''Families have lived in New Orleans for generations with no thought of leaving, but no more,'' said Walter R. Stuart 4th, one of five brothers who are heirs to a prominent banking family that traces its history in Louisiana to antebellum days. The five Stuarts, a lawyer, two doctors, an interior designer and an investment banker, have all left the state, primarily for economic reasons, and they are scattered across the country.
The dispersion of talent has been widespread. As oil drilling activity began to pick up again last year, rig operators in west Texas reported a shortage of ''roughnecks.'' the skilled handlers of oil field machinery. They simply moved on when the rigs went idle. Recent studies have documented a steady emigration by Oklahoma's most talented high school graduates.
''The downside to this situation is that we'll never get our kids back,'' Governor Roemer said. ''If the price of oil shoots up and we decide we don't need reform because things are O.K. again, we'll never see all those people who have left, especially the young people, because they've realized there is no future here without fundamental change.''
Some scholars argue that these events are a more drastic version of changes taking place nationwide.
Stephen Klineberg, a sociologist at Rice University in Houston, said: ''As the world enters the post-industrial age the United States is shifting gradually from an economy based on wealth in commodities to one that primarily exploits knowledge. The oil states are facing that shift sooner and more dramatically than the rest of the country, and so we can see the process more clearly here.''
Mr. Klineberg added: ''People feel that the old formulas proved inadequate, and there is some sense of what the new formulas should be. But there is not enough certainty or confidence about what needs to be done for people to make hard decisions.''
 
The Future
 
Brighter Prospects, But Clouds Remain
 A cautious view of the future should be expected in a region that has been on an economic roller coaster ride unlike anything experienced by any other part of the country in the postwar era.
During the 1970's the price of oil increased fivefold primarily as a result of turmoil in the Middle East and actions by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. As oil rigs blossomed in areas previously considered too costly to explore, personal income grew much more rapidly than in the nation as a whole, drawing streams of workers fleeing recessions elsewhere.
Then, in 1982 and again in 1986, oil prices tumbled, falling from $37 a barrel to a low of $10. The collapse of exploration and drilling was only one point of pain in the demise of an entire economy based on heavy borrowing and a belief that the boom could never end. In Houston the value of real estate dropped as much as 30 percent, a larger loss than most cities experienced in the Depression.
 
Oil Prices Have Risen
Since the dark days of 1986 the price of oil has climbed back up, and for a year has remained stable in the range of $18 to $22 a barrel. The cheap price of crude and a more competitive dollar led to an expansion of the region's substantial petrochemical industry. And with the national economy growing steadily, the availability of cheap land, labor and services in the oil states has helped the recovery, particularly in Texas and Oklahoma. In Houston, business bankruptcies in the first half of last year were down 44 percent as against the same period of 1988, and sale prices for single-family houses rose more than 7 percent.
To varying degrees across the region people are now at least certain that the worst has passed. While unemployment is still above the national average, job growth over the last two years has scored steady gains of from 1 and 2 percent across most of the region, as against an average that has hovered near 3 percent for the nation overall. The exception has been the Houston metropolitan area, which suffered the fastest crash in Texas and experienced the most rapid recovery, scoring employment growth of 3.5 percent in late 1988 before leveling off last year at a rate of about 2.8 percent.
''The Texas economy has turned around, no doubt about that, but it still has some turning to go,'' said Tom Frost, chairman of Cullen/Frost Bankers, Inc., the only one of the 10 largest bank holding companies in Texas to survive without a buyout or a bailout.
''Some people have started feeling good about how far they've come from the dark days.'' he said. ''Even so the economy down here doesn't have much zip. Local entrepreneurs are just building up enough confidence to get back into action, and many of us in banking are still in the trenches.''
Experts are only now trying to measure how the economic and social landscape was altered so they can start predicting what it will look like in the future. And economic performance in the next few years will powerfully influence the process of long-term change that started during the bust.
Although the oil market remains somewhat unpredictable and vulnerable to political events in the Middle East, most experts agree that the price of crude is unlikely to reach a level that would justify the kind of high-cost exploration of the oil patch.
A wave of increased drilling activity appears to be getting started as the industry bets that the price of natural gas will rise in the long term. But for the next several years, experts predict that the industry will remain consolidated and somewhat cautious. Many businessmen believe opportunities still exist in the oil business, but that the nature of those opportunities is changing.
For instance, John Calaway, president of the Edge Petroleum Company, which specializes in seismic research, argued that the region will be ''the place where you find the brains and the technology, the home of the people you need to get energy out of the ground anywhere in the world, but not necessarily the home of the people who own the reserves.''
The decline of oil is such that even that role may be difficult to secure. The petroleum engineering faculties at the University of Texas in Austin and at Texas A & M University were once the chief training grounds for the American oil industry. In 1982 they had 2,729 undergraduate majors between them. Last fall they enrolled only 208. ''The region is now much less dependent on oil, and in Texas especially the mix is much more similar to that of the country as a whole,'' said William C. Gruben, senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. ''As the number of jobs related to oil and gas extraction was shrinking, whatever growth there was took place in other sectors, especially in manufacturing and some services. Even if prices go up, the chances of oil taking a dominant position again are very slight.''
The past year has brought a number of positive signs. The Exxon Corporation joined the march of other major corporations, like the GTE Corporation, in moving its corporate headquarters to Dallas. Texas used all its clout in Washington to land the superconducting supercollider, a massive atom smasher that will cost at least $5 billion and is expected to produce high-tech spinoffs. More modest efforts also got off the ground, among them San Antonio's Texas Research and Technology Foundation, a marriage of nearly $70 million in private money with the University of Texas system. The foundation broke ground on a research park where scientists will have a chance to turn their discoveries into commercial products.
 
High Tech: A Painful Lesson
But people in the oil states are painfully learning that high tech sometimes just glitters. Austin has had consistent success in luring major computer firms, like Sematech, the Government-industry consortium for semiconductor research. But it is suffering through zero growth and a glutted real estate market.
Moreover, a huge cloud hangs over the recovery in the bust's twin legacy of an overbuilt real estate market and a debilitated financial sector. Vacancy rates have shown the first signs of shrinking in some cities. But now the Federal Government is about to begin selling off the more than 30,000 properties it inherited from failed financial institutions. Some 65 percent of those parcels are in the three oil states and the sale threatens to further depress prices.
In the view of some of the region's leaders, a quick end to the lingering pain of the oil bust might harm the region in the long run. ''If there is a real slackening of the depression mentality,'' Governor Roemer said, ''we won't finish the education reform, we won't finish the fiscal reform, because people won't feel things are bad enough to require fundamental change.''

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

HEADLINE: Pope Warns on Rekindling of Rivalries in East

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Pope John Paul II today hailed the ''irrepressible thirst for freedom'' that has ''broken down walls and opened doors'' in Eastern Europe, but he warned that the rapid political changes could unleash nationalist feelings and ethnic conflicts.
The Pope did not single out any country by name, but his comments suggested concern about such developments as nationalist tensions in the Soviet Baltic republics and the anti-Turkish sentiments that have surfaced anew in Bulgaria in recent days.
''The aftereffects of World War II, let loose 50 years ago, call for vigilance,'' he said in an address to the Holy See's diplomatic corps. ''It is always possible for secular rivalries to re-emerge, for conflicts between ethnic minorities to be rekindled, for nationalisms to be exacerbated.'' 
In his speech, a review of world events over the last year, John Paul in effect spun the globe, touching on leading international issues, continent by continent. He included a brief reference to Panama that some diplomats said later could be interpreted as a request that the United States withdraw its troops quickly.
''Here, too, the civilian population suffered more than anyone else,'' he said. ''It is hoped that the Panamanian people can return to a normal life without delay, in the dignity and freedom to which any sovereign people have a right.'' The mention of ''normal life'' and sovereignty struck some who heard the Pope as an allusion to American troops.
For the most part, though, he concentrated on the remarkable shifts in Eastern Europe, which Vatican diplomats maintain were brought about in part by the Polish-born Pope. He helped promote these changes, they say, by lending moral and religious support during difficult years, especially in Poland, where the downfall of the Communists last summer set in motion similar developments throughout the Eastern bloc.
In speaking to the diplomats, representing 120 countries, the Pope noted the presence of the Polish Ambassador, Jerzy Kuberski, as a symbol of improved relations between the Holy See and the East. The Vatican restored diplomatic ties with Poland last year.
More indirectly, the Pope seemed to praise the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a reference to ''responsible politicians'' who had made possible Eastern Europe's ''long pilgrimage toward freedom.'' John Paul met Mr. Gorbachev at the Vatican last month in the first encounter between a Kremlin leader and the Pope.
It was now time, he said, for the West to help the emerging democracies of the East to ''regain fully a place that belongs to them in a Europe of today and tomorrow.'' But at the same time, he offered a lament that Western Europe, while democratic and prosperous, was not the best tutor for nations ridding themselves of Communism.
 
Western 'Countervalues' Assailed
The West is burdened with ''countervalues like egoism, hedonism, racism and practical materialism,'' he said, adding that it would be a mistake for Eastern Europeans to follow the same path as they expand liberties.
''Too often, unfortunately, the Western democracies have not known how to use the freedom won in the past at the price of hard sacrifices,'' he said. ''One can only regret the deliberate absence of every transcendental moral reference in the management of so-called developed societies.''
This has been a recurring theme for John Paul, who sees spiritual values in general, and the Catholic Church in particular, as having been threatened as much by Western secularism as by overt Communist hostility to religion. But in emphasizing matters of the soul, the Pope did not neglect Eastern Europe's material needs.
He met this afternoon with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, and reportedly said Eastern Europeans could use the Japanese work ethic to rebuild their devastated economies.
According to Japanese officials, Mr. Kaifu asked what Japan could offer in the way of assistance, and John Paul replied, ''One thing I have to ask you is that the diligence of the Japanese people be introduced in these countries.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Intelligence;
Kremlin Watchers Cope With Data Glut

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
After 40 years of foraging for bits of data on the Soviet Union and its allies, American intelligence analysts are struggling to cope with a cascade of information, including Kremlin statistical reports, periodicals and word-of-mouth from foreign business travelers and military officers who can visit once-forbidden reaches.
The ability to tap new veins of data has already prompted major changes in the way experts in the Pentagon, the State Department and intelligence agencies operate, officials said in interviews this month.
''It used to be that you'd go through reams and reams of stuff and just come up with dross,'' said a senior Bush Administration official who is well-versed on the process. ''Now there's so much gold that they could work round the clock.''
 
Technology and Mindsets
The changes range from the increased use of computers and other advanced technology to simple efforts to break old mindsets about the Communist system. The sheer volume of publicly available data has led officials to use more ''open source'' data, and less secretly gathered information, in preparing analyses of events for policy makers. 
Officials contend that their insights into Soviet society and politics were sharp even before the new avalanche of information began in the mid-1980's. ''We did a pretty good job on groundwork studies that looked at the fundamental bankrupty of the bureaucracy and the economy,'' Richard J. Kerr, the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, said in a recent interview. ''We've been writing about this in detail for 10 years, probably more.''
But the consensus of Government and private experts is that the C.I.A. and other agencies underestimated the Soviet Union's economic and social problems and failed to detect the potential for political upheaval in Eastern Europe.
Their hope is that the new data, combined with new ways to analyze it, will produce a more sophisticated view of East bloc changes and how American leaders may deal with them.
 
Like Redrawing a Map
A Defense Department official involved in the process likened the task to redrawing old and trusted maps that have guided American views about Soviet intentions.
''They had wonderful features and roads,'' he said. ''We could change the roads from two lanes to four-lane highways, but they all ran in the same direction and went through the same towns. What has happened now is that all the roads just went off our maps.''
He and other officials agreed to be interviewed only if they were not identified, and some required that their agencies not be named as well. They include some of the Government's top analysts of Soviet and Eastern European issues. The analytical work is concentrated at the Central Intelligence Agency, the Defense Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency and the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research.
In a community of intelligence experts that dissects everything from nuclear strategy to sugar-beet harvests, the Sovietologists are the kings of the analytical hill. The pressure to handicap Kremlin events accurately, a former Government official said, is enormous, not just because of the implications that a serious error carries, but because of the prestige at stake.
In the tight community of intelligence experts, Soviet analysts have long been criticized as too clubby and too cautious, especially by political conservatives who have long held a dimmer view of the Soviet empire's future. Analysts and other officials bristle at suggestions that their work has been seriously deficient.
But even so, officials agree that analysts missed cues that would have pointed more urgently to the political turmoil seen in the East bloc today.
 
Estimates Were Overly Rosy
Well before 1980, they said, intelligence experts were issuing overly rosy estimates of growth in the Soviet economy. They also played down reports from Soviet emigres of growing social and political unrest.
An official said it became apparent to analysts in 1987, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, began pressing his plan of political restructuring, that ''all the props were getting knocked out from under the regime'' and that basic changes were inevitable. But even then, experts believed erroneously that the response would be evolutionary.
''Anyone who would have written about East Germany's disintegration a year ago would have been laughed out of the Government,'' another senior expert on the Kremlin said this month, echoing many others' comments about the Soviet Union and other East bloc nations. ''We were totally surprised.''
Officials also agree that the intelligence experts suffered another problem during much of the 1980s: inexperience. At the C.I.A., the largest analysis center, three-quarters of the analysts employed in 1985 were hired in the preceding five years, a senior Administration official said.
The new information flowing out of the Soviet Union today presents a far greater challenge. It is stunning in its breadth and complexity, experts say, but ragged in its quality and usefulness. Assembling it, and deciding what needs more study, is a monumental job in itself.
Examples abound: Moscow recently released the first figures since 1928 on suicide in Soviet Union, an important indicator of social stability. It also may be possible soon to subscribe to regional newspapers throughout the Soviet Union, a prospect eagerly awaited in part because it would provide local officials' versions of political meetings they attended on trips to Moscow.
Such reports are available infrequently and are often dated when they are received, an official said.
 
Information From Travelers
Military experts on arms-control missions inside the Soviet Union return with firsthand observations on Soviet defenses and technology, just as Soviet observers do in this country. So do business executives and tourists who now can visit areas and people that Government officials cannot easily see.
''What we've done is to look at alternative means of collection that weren't previously given the same importance,'' the Director of Central Intellligence, William H. Webster, said in an interview. ''We have mobilized significant places in American industry, professionals and others who have access that we don't have and which we could not likely get over a sustained period of time.''
On the other hand, reliable figures on the economy are rarer than ever despite new openness about Soviet spending, an expert said. Backroom insights into Soviet politics are still nonexistent; like their predecessors 20 years ago, disgraced Soviet officials still resign for ''health reasons.'' And understanding the jockeying within the ruling elite, analysts say, remains an art akin to reading tea leaves.
''Why doesn't someone sign an obit for Sakharov?'' one asked. ''Here's Pravda from Dec. 16. Ligachev didn't sign it. Why? Maybe he didn't like him. We don't know.'' Yegor K. Ligachev, a senior member of the ruling Politburo, is considered one of the more conservative members of the Kremlin leadership.
 
Changes in Soviet-Watching
Several Government officials said that Mr. Gorbachev's ascension marked the start of changes in the American intelligence community's approach to Soviet-watching. Within the C.I.A., for example, officials created a separate Soviet analysis office, an action later followed by other analytical agencies.
In a move that now looks prescient, the Soviet Union's Eastern European allies, which once were analyzed in the same C.I.A. office, were spun off to a division that watches Western European affairs.
Most important, experts have changed the mix of information they now use to evaluate changes in the Communist bloc. Mr. Webster said in an autumn interview that there was ''no question'' that the ''open side of the business has become more important'' than the secret side as the flow of public data increases.
The C.I.A. has set up new bureaucracies to examine issues like the Soviet labor movement that were unheard of even five years ago. It and other intelligence agencies have placed a new emphasis on economics, recognizing that military might depends in large part on domestic economic strength.
While the individual changes are often subtle, their collective impact weighs large on the analysis business, which has long been skewed to spotting war preparations and other military thrusts and parries.
A top Government analyst estimated this week, for example, that his agency's Sovietologists devote half their effort to nonmilitary issues now, compared with a third just a few years ago.
Some agencies are experimenting with optical scanners and computer programs that can read and translate into English some basic foreign texts, a senior official said, and the processing of radio and television broadcasts has been partly computerized as well.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Aid From the West;
New Bank to Help East Bloc Revive Its Economy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Senior officials from the leading industrial nations and Eastern Europe are to meet here on Monday to plan the establishment of an Eastern European development bank. The bank would lead to one of the largest regional assistance efforts since the Marshall Plan.
Representatives from 34 nations are expected to agree to put at least $10 billion into the bank, which has provisionally been named the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Eastern Europe.
European officials said the bank would be modeled after the World Bank and would provide loans, economic guidance and technical assistance to Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, East Germany, Rumania and Bulgaria. 
 
Money for the Private Sector
The bank's principal aim will be to help finance the development of the tiny private sector in Eastern Europe nations as they move toward a market economy. In addition to making loans, the bank will provide loan guarantees as well as make equity investments in some enterprises.
French officials said an accord to set up the bank might not be signed until next month. The reason is that the Foreign Ministry and Finance Ministry officials who will meet in Paris on Monday and Tuesday still have to agree on the exact capitalization of the bank as well as what its membership and structure will be.
European officials said the bank might not lend money for another 12 months because once the accord is signed, many governments and parliaments will have to approve their capital contributions to the bank.
Eastern European officials are eager for the bank to become operational; they say they lack the money to finance large-scale development of their private sectors.
 
Community Leads the Effort
The European Community has been the principal engine behind the new development bank, with the leaders of the 12 community nations voting to back a French proposal to form such a bank when they met in Strasbourg, France, last month.
A competition has already developed over where the bank will be based. Denmark has asked for the headquarters and so has Austria, even though it is not a member of the European Community. The French Government is pushing for Strasbourg to be the seat, while some West Germans are lobbying for Berlin.
Under the European Community's plan for the development bank, the Community nations would put up slightly more than 50 percent of its capital and would hold slightly more than half the seats on its board.
European and American officials said there was a provisional agreement for the United States, Japan and the four largest Community nations -France, West Germany, Britain and Italy - each to take an 8.5 percent stake in the bank.
 
Money From Moscow
European officials said the United States had agreed to the community's call to give the Soviet Union an 8.5 percent stake in the bank, but on the condition that Moscow would make its capital contribution in hard currency.
Nonetheless, Washington is said to have reservations about Soviet membership in the bank. ''The Americans have been the most hestitant nations about Eastern European and Soviet participation in general,'' a European official said.
Several countries were uncomfortable with asking the Eastern European nations to make capital contributions to a bank that is being set up to give them financial assistance. Others that support Eastern European membership say it is important for those nations to have a voice in shaping the bank's policies.
Under the Community's plan, the six Eastern European nations would be asked to take a 6.5 percent stake among them.
Other members of the bank will be Canada, Switzerland, Austria, Turkey, Australia, New Zealand, Yugoslavia, Malta and the Scandinavian nations.
 
Differences Over Size
Some Western officials have voiced discomfort that the Eastern European nations will be attending Monday's meeting even though the industrialized nations have yet to reach agreement on some delicate issues.
''There are differences over the size of the fund and over what types of projects the money should be channeled to,'' a Western official said.
The French originally called for capitalization of $18 bllion, while the British, reluctant to see Eastern Europe become even more indebted, proposed $6 billion. At a meeting last Tuesday in Brussels, the Community agreed that the capitalization should be $12 billion. The Americans and Japanese still have to approve that level.
Under the Community's plan, the bank would have intitial capital of $3.6 billion when it is started, with its capital base growing subsequently.
The British have also created some heat by asserting that the loans should go strictly to the private sector. But officials from France and some others European nations say the loans should also be available to governments to improve basic infrastructure, like roads and telecommunications.
 
Below-Market Interest Rates
Another debate will be over whether the bank should be able to lend money at concessional rates. The British have argued against this, saying loans at below-market interest rates should be made to only the poorest nations, namely those in Africa.
Before the formal meeting begins on Monday, there will be a preliminary meeting on Sunday night to discuss some details regading the bank.
Some officials said the new bank could, like the International Monetary Fund, attach conditions to its loans; for instance, that the countries make certain economic changes.
International relations experts said the new bank was one of the first major East-West projects in which Western Europe has taken the initiative. At last July's economic summit meeting in Paris, the seven leading industrial nations decided that the European Community should coordinate food and other aid efforts to Eastern Europe.
 
American Budget Deficit
At the meeting, European and American officials said the European Community had been chosen to lead that effort out of recognition of Western Europe's greater familiarity and proximity to Eastern Europe. Another reason for the choice was that Western European governments have greater resources for such aid than the United States does because of the huge American budget deficit.
The Paris meeting will be the first of several landmark meetings between Eastern and Western nations over the next few weeks. This week in Vienna senior military officials from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact are to meet in Vienna to discuss their military strategies to help prevent misunderstandings.
The United States will be represented at the Paris meeting by David E. Mulford, Undersecretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, and Robert P. McCormack, Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs.
The chairman of the meeting will be Jacques Attali, a senior adviser to President Francois Mitterrand of France.

HEADLINE: THE U.S. AND PANAMA;
Peruvian Still Outraged By Invasion of Panama

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 13

 BODY:
High above the presidential palace here, the flag of Panama flutters next to that of Peru.
''It will stay up there until the Yankee troops get out of Panama,'' Peru's President, Alan Garcia, said defiantly in an interview on Friday.
Of the leaders of Latin America's major countries, Mr. Garcia is the only President to go beyond the flurry of protest notes that expressed regret or condemnation after the December invasion. He is bluntly and publicly offering the kinds of criticisms made frequently but privately by Government officials in Bogota, Brasilia and Buenos Aires. 
 
Says Invasion Is Illegal
''By what authority does the United States kidnap citizens and judge them?'' Mr. Garcia asked, referring to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his associates. ''The invasion was an illegal search of an entire nation. And what you get from an illegal search is worthless in court.''
In a two-hour, passionately argued interview, the President, who leaves office in six months, said he believed that his Latin American colleagues would eventually join him in outspoken opposition to the invasion of Panama by the United States.
He predicted that Latin American public opinion would react negatively in coming months to the ''circus'' of a trial in Florida of General Noriega -''a barbarian brought before a court of imperial Rome.''
Mr. Garcia added: ''As much as Noriega was a dictator, he will be seen more as a Latin American than as a dictator. People are going to have compassion for him.''
Before the invasion, Mr. Garcia, a democratically elected civilian, sharply criticized General Noriega, and he indicated no change of heart on Friday. He described the deposed dictator, who long worked closely with the United States through the C.I.A., as ''the Frankenstein of the State Department and of the Pentagon.''
 
Calls Government Illegitimate
But he argued that Panama's new Government, led by President Guillermo Endara, was also illegitimate.
''The fact that Endara took the oath of office on a North American military base takes away all of his legitimacy,'' Mr. Garcia said, echoing a criticism heard elsewhere in Latin America.
''Once the carnival of the invasion is over, the protests will start, and American troops are not going to solve the internal economic crisis,'' he said.
Mr. Garcia said that to put Panama's democracy on a solid footing, Mr. Endara should set a date for new elections and President Bush should ask the Organization of American States to replace American troops with an inter-American peacekeeping force.
Mr. Garcia recalled his Ambassador from Washington last month and announced that he would boycott a presidential summit meeting in Colombia next month. Intended to promote a joint approach to cocaine trafficking, the meeting was to be attended by the Presidents of the United States, Bolivia, Colombia and Peru.
''I will not attend the meeting as long as North American troops are illegally in Panama,'' Mr. Garcia repeated on Friday, adding that he would probably send a high-ranking substitute. ''While Latin America is invaded, it would be unworthy on my part to sit down with Mr. Bush.''
 
Fear of Interventionism
Mr. Garcia also expressed a worry that is reflected daily in newspaper headlines here and in Colombia: that the United States military victory revived dormant American interventionism. Two incidents last week - the dispatch of United States warships to waters off Colombia in the name of drug prevention and the surrounding of the Peruvian Embassy in Panama by American soldiers hunting Noriega associates - provoked nervousness in Colombia and Peru before the efforts were abandoned.
''The invasion of Panama has set relations between the United States and Latin America back 30 years,'' Mr. Garcia said, leaning angrily over his massive wooden desk in the palace.
''Now Mr. Bush feels backed by North American public opinion to intervene in Peru's Huallaga Valley war, in Bolivia's Santa Cruz de la Sierra,'' he said, referring to two areas that account for about 75 percent of the coca leaves grown worldwide for cocaine production.
On the drug issue, Mr. Garcia said he favored tracking drug-laden airplanes with radar and stopping them with a joint interdiction force, provided that agreement can be reached with his neighbors and with the United States.
''No one wants to be a drug-producing country,'' he said.
 
Disappointed at Reaction
He confessed disappointment with what he called Latin America's ''lukewarm'' reaction to the invasion of Panama. Indeed, several of his countrymen have backed the American intervention as a necessary evil.
Mario Vargas Llosa, the front-runner in Peru's current presidential election campaign, said recently, ''The Panamanians are celebrating in the streets the overthrow of the dictator Noriega.''
Mr. Garcia's own Ambassador to Panama, Mario Castro Arenas, resigned two weeks ago in protest over his nation's opposition to the intervention.
''The North American military actions in Panamanian territory did not invalidate the genuinely democratic election,'' Mr. Castro told a Panamanian newspaper last week, referring to the nullified election last May that Mr. Endara is widely believed to have won. ''The image of an invading army subjugating a people is not accurate in the case of Panama.''
Looking around the continent, Mr. Garcia said that Latin America's weak response to the American intervention was due to several factors: widespread condemnation of General Noriega, a traditionally ''submissive attitude before North America'' and a new fear that Latin America would be ''marginalized'' as new investment, foreign debt relief and trade preferences were channeled to Eastern Europe.
''The United States feels it can ignore and mistreat Latin America, because it is more interested in Eastern Europe,'' the President said, touching on a new worry in South America. ''Latin America is wounded, but her leaders won't say anything.''

HEADLINE: Praising 'New Mainstream,' Wilder Takes Virginia Oath

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Lawrence Douglas Wilder, a grandson of slaves, was sworn in today as Governor of Virginia in a 30-second ceremony that changed the political face of the United States.
Standing under a bright January sun, a cold breeze whipping colorful pennants of state and nation, Mr. Wilder repeated the oath of office in a clear but distinctly Southern drawl, then took his place in the line of elected Virginia governors that began with the Revolutionary patriot Patrick Henry and has included figures like Thomas Jefferson, Henry Lee, Harry F. Byrd and Mr. Wilder's immediate predecessor, Gerald L. Baliles.
But never before in Virginia, the centerpiece of the Confederacy, nor in any other state, had a black assumed a governorship by virtue of winning a popular vote.
''I am a son of Virginia,'' Mr. Wilder declared in his inaugural address, in which he paid repeated tribute to the ''new mainstream'' in this rapidly changing state. 
That mainstream, made up of blacks and the moderates who now crowd Virginia's burgeoning urban areas, gave him his narrow victory over former Attorney General J. Marshall Coleman in November. That victory, in turn, made him not only Governor of the Old Dominion but also the nation's highest-ranking black elected official, a political figure to be reckoned with nationally, a symbol not just of a changing state but of a changing South and a changing nation.
 
The Faces of Change
That change was evident everywhere on Richmond's Capitol Hill today. Blacks and whites sat side by side in the bleachers reserved for dignitaries. They cheered side by side, fought off the chill wind side by side. Arrayed in front of Mr. Wilder was a sea of faces, mostly black nearest the podium, turned up toward him, proud, expectant, people who had come from distant corners of the state and the nation to be part of history, people who had come from as close as the next hill over, where Mr. Wilder was born almost 59 years ago in a segregated neighborhood racked by poverty.
The cheers began before Mr. Wilder could speak, even as an artillery unit was still firing off a 19-gun salute. Once he began, he was frequently interrupted by cheers. But when he spoke of freedom, there was silence.
''We mark today not a victory of party or the accomplishments of an individual but the triumph of an idea, an idea as old as America, as old as the God who looks out for us all,'' he said.
''It is the idea expresssed so eloquently from this great Commonwealth by those who gave shape to the greatest nation ever known, Jefferson, Madison, Mason and their able colleagues. The idea that all men and women are created equal, that they are endowed by their Creator with certain inalienable rights, the right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.''
The cheering began again. It rolled across the Capitol grounds, reverberating off the walls of the Capitol building and finally washing over the statues of Stonewall Jackson and other Virginians who in earlier times held another interpretation of the idea touched upon by Mr. Wilder.
But that was before growth, much of it fueled by Federal spending and Federal projects, gave Virginia a population of more than six million people, many born elsewhere.
 
'Proof Positive' of Cooperation
''This is a great day for Virginia,'' Lina Smith, a 66-year-old black woman from Portsmouth, said as the inauguration began. ''We have had to overcome so much. It has been so hard for us. But now he has taken this great step, and I don't think things will ever be the same again.''
Garland Stith, a retired black merchant from Emporia, said Mr. Wilder's inauguration was ''proof positive of what people can accomplish when they work together.''
While the inauguration was infused with much heady pride and expectation, Mr. Wilder was careful to note that Virginia still faces hard times. He did not belabor the point, but early on he warned that tighter economic times are looming for the state after more than a decade of great prosperity.
''But progress will still be possible,'' he said. ''Opportunity can be expanded. Freedom can be increased. We are on hallowed ground today, and the steps we take from this place must be steps of honor. We shall not pause. We shall not rest upon laurels, for we have not fulfilled our destinies. While the flow may have slowed, Virginia's New Mainstream is far from drying up.''
 
A Moderate Approach
Even if Virginia still had a plentiful amount of money in its treasury to spend, Mr. Wilder is not the kind of politician who would be searching far and wide to spend it. He has repeatedly said that his mark as a Governor would be made through careful, thoughtful stewardship, not flamboyance or big spending, and that if there was any future for him in national politics, it would flow from that approach and philosophy.
A veteran of 16 years in the state Senate, Mr. Wilder began his political career as a brash and confrontational legislator, always ready to take on the Establishment. His initial major move when he became one of the first blacks to serve in the General Assembly since Reconstruction was to demand that the Assembly strip the words ''darkey'' and ''massa'' from the official state song, ''Carry Me Back to Old Virginia.''
He did not prevail on that, although the song has since been sung at few official events and was on no program today.
Within a few years Mr. Wilder became less confrontational and eventually was one of the Assembly's most effective legislators.
When he decided to run for governor, he ran in the middle of the road. And most of his appointments so far have been mainstream, people with experience in government and politics, including a goodly number of women and blacks.
Also sworn in today was a new Lieutenant Governor, Donald S. Beyer Jr., an automobile dealer from Northern Virginia. The incumbent Attorney General, Mary Sue Terry, was sworn in for a second term. Both are Democrats.
Mr. Baliles, the departing Governor and also a Democrat, was not eligible under Virginia law to run for a consecutive term. Mr. Wilder had been serving as his Lieutenant Governor, having won that job in 1985 in an election that was the first solid sign that a new kind of politics was emerging in Virginia.

HEADLINE: Pastimes;
Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
Congress will have to deal with several bills concerning coins in the next few months. One will change the look of the coins. Another will abolish the cent in favor of a new coin valued at one dollar. Both bills are mired in controversy. The bill to change the design on the reverse side of the coins is supported by the American Numismatic Association and by many collectors. The Bill of Rights has been suggested as the theme of the new design, but there's one problem. With only five coins and 10 original rights the choice will be hard. Should a design glorifying the First Amendment's guarantee of a free press push aside the design proclaiming the Second Amendment's right to bear arms? A vote on that question could tie up Congress and lobbyists for eternity. 
The other bill proposes abolishing the cent under the argument that, with inflation, it has become next to worthless. In the cent's place, the United States Mint would be mandated to make a one-dollar coin, presumably one different from the unpopular Susan B. Anthony dollar.
Eighty-one years ago, Congress voted to change the design on the one-cent coin and caused quite a stir. Under the urging of President Theodore Roosevelt, the Indian-head cent was abolished and replaced by the Lincoln-head cent. But the new coin, first minted in August 1909, was the first bearing the portrait of a President. When this new penny was announced in February 1909, the protests began.
Newspapers took sides on the question with one major New York newpaper proclaiming that the Indian-head cent was just fine as a coin and there was no reason to change it. Readers differed or agreed. Some felt that honoring the aboriginal inhabitants of America was fitting. Others said that the copper color of the cent complemented the copper color of the American Indian. One reader thought that the cent was too low a denomination for President Lincoln, while another thought that changing the cent was a dishonor to Sarah Longacre, the model for the Indian head. Her father, James B. Longacre, was the coin's designer.
Other readers felt that the Lincoln-head cent commemorating the centennial of Lincoln's birth was an appropriate change. Lincoln, dead only 45 years, was still a cherished or reviled figure.
The largest objection to the new cent was that no President had ever been depicted on a coin before and the tradition had persisted for more than a century.
The Government of post-colonial America was vehemently anti-monarch - the people had seen enough of royal policy. George Washington decried efforts to make him king of the colonies and resisted all tries to have his face adorn any currency. (That tradition, like his limit of two-terms in office, endured until President Franklin D. Roosevelt was inuagurated for a fourth term in 1945.) The penny's design change was made. On Aug. 2,1909 the Philadelphia Mint issued the first Lincoln-head cents. Then another controversy arose. The designer, Victor D. Brenner, had placed his initials on the penny too prominently.
Rumors spread that the Treasury would recall the coins. The cents began selling for a premium and in New York City boys lined up at banks to buy a dollar's worth. The cents were sold two Lincoln-head cents for a nickle. But the Treasury changed the dies to eliminate the initials and the cents continued to pour forth. Today, the Lincoln-head cent and all its design variations is the most numerous U.S. coin ever minted, more than a quarter-trillion.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Overcoming Obstacles to a Civil-Rights Chronicle

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
In 1965, Henry Hampton, the executive producer of ''Eyes on the Prize,'' marched for civil rights in Selma, Ala. Today he works in a corner office piled high with books and papers, with a view of Shawmut Avenue, a thoroughfare in this city's South End that is, in his words, ''about the only integrated neighborhood in Boston.'' Over his desk is a somber portrait of William Butler Yeats; on one wall is a poster-sized drawing of a time line, with major civil-rights events from the 1950's to the 80's inked in by hand.
Mr. Hampton has just put the finishing touches on ''Eyes on the Prize II,'' the eight-hour second half of the critically acclaimed chronicle of the civil-rights movement that he conceived and produced for public television. The sequel, which, like the first, is narrated by Julian Bond, the civil-rights activist and longtime member of the Georgia Legislature, begins tomorrow night at 9 on the Public Broadcasting Service. It focuses on the more complicated years of the movement, 1965 to the mid-80's, and the story of its production underscores some of the lingering misunderstandings that caused problems for the movement itself at the time. Not the least of the hurdles Mr. Hampton had to overcome in completing the sequel, despite the praise heaped upon the original series, was financing - even from some of those who had contributed earlier. 
The initial half of the series, ''Eyes on the Prize,'' which focused on the years from 1955 to '65, was telecast in 1987. Walter Goodman, in his review in The New York Times, called it ''a moving documentary'' in which ''the nobility of America's civil-rights struggle comes through with the directness and strength of a spiritual.''
''Eyes on the Prize II,'' which begins with the passage of the Voting Rights Act and ends with the election of Harold Washington as Mayor of Chicago, examines a more complex period. The issues are less clear-cut and often more troubling, at least in the eyes of mainstream America, and events exploded amid dissent over how best to achieve real progress for black Americans.
The series discusses convulsive issues like the desegregation of the Boston schools in the mid-70's and the prison riots in Attica, N. Y., in 1971. It offers a look at the Black Panther Party, first as a political force in rural Alabama (where the panther was chosen to help illiterate voters distinguish the party's candidates from local Democrats and Republicans, who used roosters and elephants as party symbols) and then as a militant organization that became a source of fear in major cities. The series also examines attempts at local power-sharing, as in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school decentralization effort in Brooklyn, and the need for economic power as enunciated by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the final year of his life.
Mr. Hampton always envisioned the series as surveying the years through 1983 but chose to make two less massive projects by dividing the period at 1965. The first half, called ''Eyes One'' around the offices of Blackside Inc., the film production company Mr. Hampton founded in 1968, ''covered a period for which historians have had a chance to apply all the filters, and there is very little doubt about what was going on,'' Mr. Hampton said. From 1954 to '65, he added, the goal of nonviolent protests by blacks and whites was to outlaw the segregated society that prevailed in the South. Whites could readily understand what was wrong with the system.
''Eyes on the Prize II,'' on the other hand, deals with matters that are less straightforward. ''In 'Eyes Two,' we're where the East Germans are today,'' said Mr. Hampton, a sturdy, sunny 50-year-old in Brooks Brothers attire. Once the right to vote was in hand, black people had to be encouraged to vote. And there had to be black candidates, and black victories, and an electorate able to understand that not all things were possible even when a person it had chosen was in power. ''The issue wasn't separatism versus integration,'' Mr. Hampton said. ''The issue was that to participate in this country you have to have a base.''
The episodes in the sequel focus on the struggle of blacks to build a power base from which to shape the future. One segment examines the tensions felt by voters, black and white, who were confronted for the first time with the option of choosing a black mayor for a major city during the 1967 campaign of Carl B. Stokes Jr. in Cleveland.
''Don't vote for me because I am a Negro,'' Mr. Stokes is shown urging the congregation at a black church. ''But for God's sake, don't vote against me because I'm a Negro.''
The wider array of people and philosophies in the sequel took longer to research than those in ''Eyes I.'' Finding people who were willing to discuss the events after 1965 was often difficult.
''It was harder than some of the earlier films in the South,'' Mr. Hampton said, ''perhaps because they've resolved it in their heads down there, and it's further in the past.'' Among individuals who were approached for interviews but refused, he said, was former President Richard Nixon.
Despite the warm reception given the first series, Mr. Hampton, who spent eight years amassing enough money to produce it, found himself once again having to pry financial support out of corporate and private sources for the sequel. In part because of lingering controversy and skittishness about some of the issues addressed in ''Eyes on the Prize II,'' many of the potential investors he approached turned him down.
''We got $1 million from the Ford Foundation and $650,000 from the public stations, so I expected the rest to roll in,'' Mr. Hampton said. ''Wrong.''
Complicating the job, his production costs were twice as high this time. The first series cost $3 million to produce, but ''Eyes on the Prize II'' required $6.2 million.
''It's eight hours instead of six,'' Mr. Hampton explained. ''And our costs were artificially depressed the first time around, because I had people working for a lot less'' than standard industry wages.
He built a network of support by returning to some of the corporations that had helped him with ''Eyes on the Prize I.'' Through friends, he found others. Major underwriters for both halves of the series include the Lotus Development Corporation, a leading software manufacturer based in Cambridge, and the Ford Foundation. New underwriters include the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, the William Penn Foundation and the Melville Corporation, the Westchester-based owner of several national retail chains.
He was rejected by more than 100 companies. ''No one ever says, 'Malcolm X? No way!' '' Mr. Hampton said. ''The reality is, you never know why. There were some companies that said they'd like to sponsor us - but after the series was finished, so they could see it. It's a little like saying, 'I'd love to be pregnant. Can I see the baby first?' ''
Mr. Hampton said he did not target black-owned companies in particular for financial help. ''We really didn't go to them with a direct pitch,'' he said. ''We were looking for people who had the capacity to give at a certain level,'' namely about $350,000 each. ''That was a big contribution for a lot of companies who don't have big advertising budgets.''
The president and chief executive officer of Lotus, Jim Manzi, said his company helped to underwrite the series out of a policy of supporting programs that work to fight racism. It is of particular interest to him as well as other executives at Lotus, he said, ''given the history of Boston.''
Lotus provided $200,000 for the initial series and $300,000 for the sequel. ''The first one was so great that it was easy to fund the second,'' Mr. Manzi said. As for the content of ''Eyes on the Prize II,'' he added, ''We didn't think twice about it, but we understood that other people would. It's a much more controversial period to the extent that people remember it a whole lot more vividly and lived through it.''
In the end, only about 2 percent of the material gathered for ''Eyes on the Prize II'' became part of the finished product. Much of the rest has been compiled in ''Voices of Freedom,'' an oral history written by Mr. Hampton and Steve Fayer, the series's senior writer. The book is being published by Bantam to coincide with the telecast of ''Eyes on the Prize II.''
Mr. Hampton's own experience in the South inspired him to create a television series charting the civil-rights movement. ''It was great television,'' he says now. ''You have great characters and a big story. When I first got involved, there were cameras all over the place filming it. And it's still with us, while other movements have come and gone.''
After Selma, Mr. Hampton, a St. Louis native and a graduate of Washington University, returned to work in Boston as a spokesman for the Unitarian Universalist Church, a leading voice in the civil-rights movement. By 1968 he had formed Blackside, which now has a staff of 40 and has produced more than 40 documentaries and films. His next project is a series, also for public television, on the Depression.
''Eyes on the Prize II'' is a chronicle, Mr. Hampton observed, of a struggle that continues in America, and the series may serve as a bridge between movements and concerns that existed in the 1960's and 70's and those of the present.
The stalling of the civil-rights movement in the 1980's was ''one of the great crimes of our century,'' Mr. Hampton said. By the late 1970's, he added, people had come to believe that certain policies were needed to redress the effects of segregation, but the Reagan era changed that. ''The signal from the leadership was, let's go back,'' Mr. Hampton said. ''And so, this enormous opportunity gets deferred.'' Many of the issues, such as poverty and homelessness that preoccupy America today, Mr. Hampton said, were problems that the movement tried to eradicate but failed.
''The difference between then and now is the intensity you see in the films, compared with the vacant eyes you see now,'' Mr. Hampton said. ''I hope what happens is you get a sense of the breadth of the movement and the persistence of people to change the system. This may seem like a moment when people are retreating, but there's another wave coming. You have to both help create it and be ready to ride it when it comes.''

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1290 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
LEARNING TO TAKE CALIFORNIA SERIOUSLY

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
It is not true that there was no California architecture before Esther McCoy. But there was almost no writing about it, and that made all the difference, since before Esther McCoy began her career as an architectural historian almost no one took California seriously as a place where great buildings could be made. Esther McCoy discovered a California that was not just freeways and oranges but the place where the American dream fused more naturally, and more intensely, with the 20th-century's language of modernism than it did anywhere else. And she wrote about this combination, and about the architects who made it happen, with such dogged determination that her work gave birth to an entire realm of architectural history.
Esther McCoy died in the final days of 1989, at 85, in Santa Monica, where she had lived since the 1930's. There wasn't as much California when she arrived as there is now, but she perceived an extraordinary architectural legacy, some of which was still a-building in the 30's and virtually all of which was ignored back East: the stark, white buildings of Irving Gill, far warmer than they looked to be; the rich, gentle eclecticism of Bernard Maybeck, at once noble and mystical; the sumptuous villas of the brothers Charles and Henry Greene, which merged Japanese influences with the California bungalow; and the sleek, taut modernism of R. M. Schindler, Richard Neutra, Gregory Ain and so many others. 
These men were not unknown beyond the borders of California, but they surely had not received their due before Ms. McCoy wrote ''Five California Architects'' in 1960, the book that turned several of them into major figures of the 20th century. The book includes chapters on Gill, Maybeck, Schindler and the Greene brothers (the essay on the Greenes was contributed by Randall Makinson). It quickly went out of print, but it had the status of a rare volume among architectural historians until 1975, when it was brought back in a new edition (by Praeger).
Because California is so much the focus of our attention today, it is hard to imagine how radical the whole idea of taking California seriously was to an architectural historian in the 1950's. Yes, Charles and Ray Eames lived there, and Richard Neutra was well known, and Los Angeles had an unusual number of houses by Frank Lloyd Wright, but still, if you asked an Easterner to name an important man-made place in California in those days he would probably have answered ''Disneyland.'' Not even Californians took California all that seriously.
Esther McCoy did; she took everything seriously. She was not stern or prim in manner - she loved to laugh, to tell stories, and to communicate in her writing her love of what she saw - but she knew great architecture when she saw it, and she knew California was full of important things that no one back East was bothering about. When she wrote ''Five California Architects,'' it was with a sense of mission. And the mission succeeded beyond anyone's dreams. Not only did her writing serve as the first introduction to California architecture for an entire generation of scholars and critics, it also did much to create the climate that permitted California's remarkable architecture of the 1970's and 1980's to flower.
Esther McCoy was not a great stylist; her prose, like her personality, was blunt, not baroque. She saw things in a matter-of-fact way and she wrote about them in a matter-of-fact way. But sometimes her laserlike ability to cut to the essence of things could yield splendid phrase-making, as when she wrote that Irving Gill's Dodge House in Los Angeles ''was to bring concrete to the architectural importance of stone.'' Of unsympathetic alterations to Gill's Scripps House in La Jolla, she wrote with both irony and bluntness that the changes ''could not have been an easy task, for it requires a pneumatic drill to destroy a Gill building - and a lack of understanding of his work.'' Esther McCoy had none of the scholar's tendency to detach architecture from the rest of life; when she wrote about an architect she pulled together art history, sociology, economics and biography, and did so in a way that never made you feel that she was shifting gears. In her essay on Bernard Maybeck in ''Five California Architects,'' she manages to teach us something about the terrible financial stresses of architectural practice, no better at the turn of the century than now, and about the majesty of a kind, almost innocent, character who produced works of magical beauty and power.
That Esther McCoy would put Maybeck and Schindler together in the same book tells us something, too, for these architects could not have been more different: the one a romantic eclectic who designed mainly by intuition, the other a strong-willed modernist with roots in Viennese modernism and in the career of Frank Lloyd Wright. What they had in common, of course, was California, and by putting them together in a single volume Ms. McCoy was saying that she was more interested in what they both had to say about the nature of California as a place than in their separate ideologies.
Esther McCoy herself was sympathetic to the modern movement. It is where her beginnings were, from the days in the 1920's when, fresh from the University of Michigan, she did freelance editing in New York and traveled in the city's avant-garde literary circles and did research for Theodore Dreiser, to a period when she lived in Paris. When the Depression brought her back to the United States, she went first to Key West, where she wrote short stories and a novel, and then, in 1932, for what she expected would be only a single winter, to Los Angeles.
She never left. In 1940, she married Berkeley Tobey, who died in 1962, and during the war she worked as a draftsman at Douglas Aircraft. It was after that, she told Joseph Giovannini in an interview published in The Times five years ago, that she decided to go into architecture. But women were not encouraged in the profession then, and instead of studying for a degree, she took a job as a draftsman in the office of R. M. Schindler, where she worked from 1944 to 1947. After that she decided to put the two parts of her career, literature and architecture, together and begin writing about the buildings and the architects of California.
And thus began a stream of articles and books that continued until just before her death. Among its highlights, besides ''Five California Architects,'' were ''Richard Neutra,'' the first book-length study of that architect's work; ''Vienna to Los Angeles: Two Journeys,'' a look at the tense and competitive relationship between Neutra and Schindler; and ''The Second Generation,'' a study of later California modernists. Her career closed with writing that was more personal: a memoir, published in the quarterly Grand Street, and a catalogue essay for ''Blueprints for Modern Living: History and Legacy of the Case Study Houses,'' an exhibition that opened last November at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.
The exhibit traces the ambitious program of prototype modern houses in Los Angeles sponsored by the magazine Arts & Architecture between 1945 and 1966, which Esther McCoy was so much a part of that even this piece is as much a memoir as it is a work of architectural history. ''A magazine as flat as a tortilla and as sleek as a Bugatti with little advertising and no financial backing became the greatest force in the dissemination of information, architectural and cultural, about California,'' she wrote about how the Case Study program came to be, and while her similes could only have referred to the magazine, the rest of the sentence could really be about Esther McCoy herself.
