SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1618 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY: January 7-12

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Debt Ahead for UAL
 
The UAL Corporation had better learn to love debt. Either management and the employees will load the company with debt to buy it, or the board will undertake a buyback - mortgaging the company to pay some impatient stockholders a premium. The noisiest of these stockholders, Coniston Partners, threatens to unseat most of the board unless UAL coughs up a satisfactory payoff. Investors and arbitragers took a beating last October, when the collapse of a $300-a-share buyout plan sent the stock from the high 200's to the mid-160's. Stephen M. Wolf, the UAL chief executive, has warned that the buyback would drain the company of funds to buy more jets and maintain market share. Some analysts doubt the company would be much healthier if Mr. Wolf and the employees won control. 
 
Doubts on Farley's Filing
 
The woes of leverage, continued: William Farley's plans for creating the nation's largest textile company are looking as dim as his ambitions to become President. He took control of West Point-Pepperell Inc. last year, outbidding management with a $3 billion offer. For a part of his financing, he used some of the junkiest junk bonds Drexel Burnham Lambert could devise. Nine months later, he is still depending on his bankers to extend a billion-dollar bridge loan and keep his hopes for completing the purchase alive. Wall Street has such deep doubts about Mr. Farley's prospects that West Point-Pepperell shares are trading at more than $20 below his offering price. But then Mr. Farley's last Presidential campaign got no further than Iowa.
 
Pension Funds Pressure on G.M.
 
It was a rough week for the General Motors Corporation. Two of the nation's largest pension funds appeared fed up with the company's performance. The heads of the California and New York public employees pension funds asked G.M. directors for a broader role in choosing and setting goals for the next chairman and chief executive. The current boss, Roger B. Smith, is due to retire this August. Since the G.M. board has usually allowed chief executives to choose their own successors, analysts saw the pension funds' request as a slap at Mr. Smith. The funds own millions of G.M. shares, so unlike small investors, they can't easily bail out. The company issued a curt statement rejecting the funds' appeal. But a couple days later came broad cuts in expenses, with incentives for white-collar employees to retire early. Meanwhile, ticket sales for the movie Roger & Me were so strong that Warner Brothers expanded its distribution. The film contrasts Mr. Smith's reassuring pronouncements with scenes of laid-off auto workers being evicted from their homes in Flint, Mich.
 
Top Price for Tape Machine
 
Look for digital audio tape recorders to finally arrive in United Statesstores by mid-year - at more than twice the minimum price in Japan. Two Japanese manufacturers, the Sony Corporation and Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, plan to sell the machines. They were kept off the American market for three years because record companies feared their potential for copying compact disks and digital tapes. The record companies dropped their opposition after manufacturers agreed to restrict the machines' ability to copy the tapes, but not the disks. Matsushita, know for its Panasonic and Technics brands, announced a price of $1,200 to $1,300. In Tokyo, retailers in the glaring, neon-lit Akihabara electronics district already sell the digital recorders for about $500.
 
Campeau Buying Time
 
Robert Campeau has been forced from American retailing. The question is, how much more time will his departure buy from the Campeau Corporation's creditors and suppliers? The creditors agreed last week for Campeau, on the brink of bankruptcy, to pay for December merchandise. The payments insuring that shipments to Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and the rest of the company's 240 stores will continue for the time being. The retailing interests will be run by a new chief executive and a new board, with the majority of its members American. Mr. Campeau, a flamboyant Canadian real estate investor, took on $7 billion in debt in buying the stores. Some of that debt is now worth just a dime on the dollar.
 
Sotheby's Margins to Move
 
 Somehow, Sotheby's famous Van Gogh just can't stay sold. With the purchaser, Alan Bond, deep in financial trouble, ''Irises'' may be for looking for a buyer again. The art world toasted the auction price of $53.9 million in November 1987 as a record. But it turned out that Sotheby's had financed half the price, with the painting itself as collateral. Though Sotheby's says Mr. Bond is current on his loan, it has been extended twice. Now Sotheby's might be in the awkward position of having to treat the masterpiece like some used car that has ended up back on the lot. The company has issued a new rule: No more purchases on margin. Sotheby's has evidently decided that ''We tote the note'' is no motto for a distinguished auction gallery founded in 1744.
 
 
 
ECONOMY
 
Stalling on the Prime
 
The worse the banks do, the slower they become to lower the prime rate. The banks did finally lower it a half point last week, to 10 percent. Analysts had been predicting the move for weeks, as the economy weakened and the Federal Reserve eased credit. But bank earnings have been squeezed by problem loans to real estate developers and Third World nations. Troubles loom in some of their highly leveraged corporate deals; Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke said their consumer loans worry him as well. And for years, banks have had to pay higher rates on deposits. As a result, said Thomas H. Hanley, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, ''The banks are more reluctant to drop the prime directly in line with decreases in other short-term rates.''
 
Bond Defaults Head Higher
 
Corporate bond defaults are likely to mount in 1990. Ominously, the value of the defaults could approach the value of new junk bond issues. Richard Lehmann, president of the Bond Investors Association, predicts that about $15 billion in corporate bonds (mostly high-yield ''junk bonds'') will default this year, while only about $25 billion in new junk bonds will be issued. In 1989, $11.7 billion in corporate bonds defaulted - up 136 percent from 1988 - while $51 billion in junk bonds were issued, down 15 percent from 1988. The association, a nonprofit research group, keeps track of Wall Street's turkeys in the Defaulted Bonds Newsletter. ''All of these deals assumed capable management,'' Mr. Lehmann said. ''But some of these people are better at raising money than managing companies.''
 
An Inflationary Horizon
 
Economists predict renewed inflation in the wake of higher producer prices. And they say the Federal Reserve will be reluctant to ease credit further. The Producer Price Index rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December, or 4.8 percent for all of 1989 - the highest annual increase in eight years. Analysts said the producer price news contributed to a 71.46-point decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the steepest since a 190.58-point drop last October 13. Economists, who had predicted a five-tenths of 1 percent increase, couldn't blame cold December weather for the surprise. Even without figuring in food and energy costs, producer prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent. As Lacy Hunt, chief economist at Carroll McEntee & McGinley Inc. said, ''Inflation is going to be very significant this year.''
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Ailing Argentina
 
Argentinian stocks are losing value as rapidly as the currency. Prices on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange plunged an average of 53 percent on Monday, the first day the market was open this year. December inflation reached 40 percent, for a 1989 total of 4,923 percent. All President Menem's austerity plans, budget cuts and free-market medicine appear to be too little to rescue one of the world's sickest economies. Meanwhile, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has required banks to increase their reserves against Argentinian loans to at least 35 percent from 15 percent. Argentina has paid the banks no interest since 1988.
 
Tokyo's Quota Trick
 
Count meaningless but symbolic concessions as one of Japan's newest exports. The Japanese Government is expected to extend its ''voluntary'' quotas on automobile exports. But the Japanese automakers say the move will have no practical affect. Rising production at their American plants - more than 1.1million cars last year - has made them less dependent on exports. The export quota stands at 2.3 million cars, but Japanese automakers exported only 1.8 million to the United States through November last year. The United Automobile Workers want to count Japanese cars made in America under the quota. The crisp response from Japan's trade minister, Hikaru Matsunaga: ''Very unlikely.''
 
Moscow the Scrooge
 
The Soviet Union wants to end its charity for Eastern Europe. The Soviet-led trade bloc, Comecon, has supplied valuable Soviet oil and gas to Eastern Europe in return for shoddy manufactured goods of dubious worth. Next year, the Soviet Union wants Comecon to begin trading at real market prices in hard, convertible currencies (not rubles or zlotys). East Europeans generally live better than their Soviet neighbors, but the new trade standards would leave these former satellites with a $10 billion annual trade deficit. If the Soviet Union insists on Comecon trade at market prices in a year, said Jan Vanous, research director of the PlanEcon consulting firm, ''All hell will break loose.''

HEADLINE: WORLD MARKETS;
The Triple Demerits in Tokyo

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Rising interest rates, a declining yen and higher oil prices are undermining the usually buoyant Tokyo stock market, hurting the stocks of large companies and sending shivers through other markets around the world.
Analysts argue that the plunge of 1,399.10 points, or 3.6 percent, this year in the Nikkei 225-stock index is a correction in an overvalued market that had reached a record high, and does not have the smell of a bear market. As evidence they point to two broader stock indexes, both including smaller companies, have done better. One has declined only six-tenths of 1 percent and the other is up 3.9 percent this year. 
But if it is not a preface to a disaster, the Tokyo decline is a reminder that markets everywhere could be highly volatile this year, especially because they seem to be feeding off each other's ups and downs. Tokyo's plunge of 653.36 points on Friday helped pull the Dow Jones industrial average down 71.46 points and depressed markets in West Germany, Britain and elsewhere.
In addition, the hopes arising from the investment opportunites in the opening of Eastern Europe and the record highs hit in many markets this year may not stand up that well against unhappy developments in domestic economies and the surely bumpy road to real progress in the new Eastern bloc.
Whatever happens, some analysts expect the Tokyo market to be uncertain, if not weaker, as investors wait to see how the ruling Liberal Democratic Party fares in the Feb. 18 Parliamentary election. The jitters could also continue until the Bank of Japan makes it clear whether interest rates have hit their peak. This means more swoons even if there is nothing close to a crash, and these gyrations, as happened Friday, could pull other world markets with them.
''I am not saying a panic is setting in,'' said Yuichi Kohashi, executive vice president of Daiwa Securities American Inc. in New York. ''But an anxiety has been created.'' He said inflation worries are emerging with reports of jumps in prices for business services, including trucking and rent. This news and the rise in Japanese interest rates (the 10-year government bond reached 6.465 percent Friday, the highest since just before the October 1987 Wall Street crash) first hit the futures prices, then bonds and now the stock market.
Mr. Kohashi said the election is worrying the market and a setback for the Liberal Democrats would do more damage. But he plays down the influence of developments in the Soviet Union last week, arguing that they had more of an effect on the yen.
He also said the rise in small-company stocks is not as positive as it might look. Large investment funds suffered losses from their holdings in major companies and are switching to smaller companies to try to recoup. The size of their purchases can easily inflate the share price of smaller companies.
''It may take two or three months for investors to regain confidence in the market,'' Mr. Kohashi concluded.
The decline in the yen and the rise in oil prices, which both add to inflation, are the other main reasons for the collapse. ''These are the triple demerits,'' said John Ford of Rowe Price Fleming Inc. in London, adding in the jump in interst rates.
Mr. Ford sees some advantage in the decline. Because the market is so overvalued, he said, ''we are not distressed seeing it have a correction.'' But no correction is pleasant, he acknowledged. ''Its not particularly nice when markets are collapsing around you.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Beware The Lesser FSX Role

BYLINE: By MEL LEVINE; Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California, is a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and co-chairman of Rebuild America, a nonprofit group based in Washington.

 BODY:
The unfortunate truth about the FSX agreement to jointly develop a new Japanese fighter plane is that it was a compromise that ended up pleasing almost no one. The agreement was a contravention of free trade principles, a waste of resources and an inefficient method of meeting our defense needs. It may be that no permutation of the FSX agreement to transfer American technology abroad would have adequately addressed these central objections.
The FSX deal also vexed the Japanese defense industry, which wanted the full share of the Japanese Government's FSX contracts for itself. And it has irritated many in Congress and elsewhere who see in this deal the United States helping to expedite the development of yet another Japanese industry that will inevitably compete against our own companies. 
But while we argue about the wisdom of transferring some of our most advanced aviation technology to Japan, a much larger problem is emerging - our own growing reliance upon foreign technology. Accompanying this problem is the realization that the United States needs to find a way of insuring that technology developed in other countries also flows straight to America.
For most of this century, the United States, confident of its technological superiority and ability to maintain a comfortable lead over its competitors, felt little compunction about licensing products to foreign manufacturers. The F-16 technology that forms the basis of the FSX project is only the latest in a long history of American transfers of aerospace technology to Japan.
For future co-production agreements to avoid the acrimony surrounding the FSX, there must be some assurance that the technology flow will occasionally reverse itself and that the United States can benefit from research from abroad.
Carefully designed joint ventures can be a positive force and can result in precisely the kind of two-way technology flow the United States now requires. But the FSX is not that kind of two-way deal. A number of proposed international joint ventures may also pose an immediate risk to critical American industries.
Unless we begin to see some serious examples of the transfer of Japanese technology to the United States, we should reconsider the wisdom of future participation in such joint ventures.
The very fact that we must now insist on a two-way technology flow -and have grown so fearful about exporting our most advanced technology - reflects our weakening industrial position as a whole. American industry increasingly finds itself backed into an ''if you can't beat 'em, join 'em'' mentality. This pattern is reflected in such proposals as the suggested sale of Perkin-Elmer's stepper division - which manufactures the machines that make computer chips - to Japan's Nikon, the Boeing-Mitsubishi joint development plan for the 767X civilian transport plane, and the agreement for American semiconductor companies to manufacture chips for the Japanese high-definition televison and systems industry.
These deals symbolize the growing tendency of American companies to take a secondary position in international ventures. Over the long run, taking this secondary role will have profound negative implications for our industrial leadership, trade balance and standard of living. We increasingly find ourselves in a position in which there is often no alternative for an American company but to sell itself to the highest bidder (often foreign) or to remake itself with foreign cash.
We cannot permit the unlimited sale of vital high-technology assets to foreign interests. To deal with this problem in the urgent fashion it demands, we need to reform the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States - a Cabinet-level group that advises the President on foreign acquisitions - and give it more authority to block such sales when they threaten the survival of American industries critical to our economic future and our national security. But these are only near-term approaches. We have thus far spared ourselves the direct pain of a dwindling high-technology base by running up enormous balance of payments deficits to import the products we no longer make. The longer this continues, the more difficult it will be to rebuild our industrial infrastructure.
Ultimately, we need to find solutions to two key problems facing American industry: lack of access to patient capital, and a strategic economic vision. We need to reform capital gains to encourage long-term investment, extend the research and development tax credit, lower interest rates and increase savings. We also need to develop our most vital resource - our labor force - through vastly improved education and training.
It is clear that the old rules of comparative advantage no longer apply. Information and technological know-how cross national borders with relative ease, and the foreign targeting of key American industries distorts traditional market principles. In a global economy whose capacities and laws we barely understand, we can no longer act as if we have found the one formula for success. We must experiment boldly to find new ways of cooperation between industry and government.
The United States has maintained a comfortable industrial leadership position for so long, that it is not easy for us to adapt to the new realities of international competition. Only when we can put our own house in order will we be able to deal with our trading partners from a position of strength. Ultimately, this is the only way of averting future FSX-type controversies.

LENGTH: 1031 words

HEADLINE: TAKING THE FIELD;
A Battle for the Voters, and the 90's, Begins

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ELECTION 1990 is hardly uppermost in the minds of American voters. Non-presidential elections are often seen as mere housekeeping for democracy, and the stunning changes in Eastern Europe have overshadowed domestic politics.
But the parties are already obsessed with the November elections, which will have a fundamental effect on the politics of the 1990's. As of now, the 34 Senate contests are expected to yield no big partisan shift, and almost all of the 435 House seats are likely to be won, as usual, by incumbents. But the election of 36 governors and 6,257 state legislators will affect the contours of Congress for the rest of the decade. 
The new and re-elected state legislators and governors will help determine the composition of the House of Representatives of the 1990's, through the map-making exercise known as redistricting, which follows the Federal Census every 10 years.
This year will also see the emergence of a new dialogue, one absent many cold war era fears and anxieties; President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, after all, is getting approval ratings in American polls that most Washington politicians might envy. (Conservatives in the post-cold war era, page 24.)
Most off-year elections send some sort of message. In 1982 it was a thundering rebuke for Congressional Republicans who came up for re-election in the midst of recession. In 1990, the voters have much to comment upon; the world has changed significantly since most of them last went to the polls. The Pentagon is cutting its own budget, the Supreme Court has made abortion a more local issue, and a whole new crop of lawmakers is in the ethics spotlight.
''We are caught between the political dynamic of Reaganism and the emerging dynamic of the 90's, and it hasn't taken shape in a way that America really understands yet,'' said Michael McCurry, director of communications for the Democratic National Committee.
Democrats hope the voters are yearning for a more active government, one concerned with problems from crumbling highways to troubled schools. Republicans hope to keep control of the national political agenda, as they had for much of the 1980's, and campaign once again as the party of peace, prosperity and lower taxes.
Lee Atwater, the Republican National Chairman, offers a taste of campaign rhetoric to come. ''The fact of the matter is the President of the United States has not raised taxes,'' he said. ''And the fact is that Democrats talk about it all the time.'' Republicans hope 1990 is the first stage of a two-year assault on the Democratic fortress in Congress. They look back wistfully to the early Reagan years, when they controlled the Senate and had considerably more clout in the House than they do today.
The Senate, where the Democrats currently hold a 55-to-45 edge, seems by far the easier nut for Republicans to crack. Party leaders hope to pick up enough seats in 1990 to put them in striking distance of regaining control in 1992, when many freshman Democrats who were elected by narrow margins will be up for re-election.
Republicans have high hopes for races in Iowa, Rhode Island, Illinois and Michigan in which Republican House members are expected to challenge Democratic Senators. Senator John Breaux, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said he would be content with a successful holding action. ''If we keep what we have, we'll be in good shape for '92,'' he said.
Republican ambitions for the House are tempered by history. Ed Rollins, head of the National Republican Congressional Committee, noted that no sitting President's party has gained seats in the House in a midterm election since the Democrats did it in 1934 under Roosevelt. Moreover, the re-election rate in the House is about 98 percent, and Democrats currently outnumber Republicans 258 to 175. Still, Republican Party leaders say they hope to lay some groundwork this year for ending the Democrats' 36 years of dominance in the House.
''Obviously, the big opportunity will come in 1992,'' Mr. Rollins said. ''You've probably got 70 or 80 open seats that year with members retiring and the creation of new seats.'' The battles for those seats will be fought largely on terms set in the Congressional redistricting, which has customarily been used to further partisan goals. Democrats hold sway in 29 of the 37 states where both houses of the legislature are controlled by one party.
Demographic changes will make this new round of redistricting all the more contested. Population growth in the West and the South, particularly in California, Florida and Texas, will result in additional Sun Belt Congressional seats. The Northeast and Midwest, long considered part of the Democratic base, will lose about 18 seats, party officials estimate.
Gubernatorial races in California, Florida and Texas are nearly always hotly contested, and the stakes for redistricting will make them all the more so this year. The Georgia race will also be closely watched: former Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta is hoping to become the second black to be elected a governor. In Massachusetts, the woes of retiring Gov. Michael S. Dukakis have created new opportunities for Republicans.
 
No Presidential Coattails
President Bush currently is soaring in the public opinion polls, but Republicans say they learned from Ronald Reagan that the coattails of a popular President are not long. An Administration official said that the party hopes to use Mr. Bush for ''operational'' support -raising money and boosting volunteers' morale.
Few experts care to predict what issues will be important in November. ''The politics of this country has changed dramatically,'' said Ron Brown, the Democratic National Chairman. Not many had expected that support for legalized abortion, for example, would be a political plus in 1989. This year, who knows?
Some experts say the campaigns will reflect an increasing voter skepticism toward government. Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic polltaker, said, ''I think 1990 is going to be a year when a lot of incumbents are going to try to separate themselves from the institution, saying they're different from everything that's going on.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
China Seeks Respectability, But Painlessly

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
DENG XIAOPING is gambling again. The 85-year-old Chinese leader, who has proved an astute political oddsmaker, is betting that by ending martial law Beijing will reap economic and diplomatic benefits without risking further unrest.
Avoiding new turmoil is crucial, and the hope here is that foreigners will take the lifting of martial law, announced last week, more seriously than will the Chinese. It seems that the action is an effort to expunge some trappings of repression without ending the repression itself. 
China's leaders had hoped for a more enthusiastic response abroad. True, the Bush Administration agreed - on the very day of the announcement, although it said there was no connection - to allow World Bank loans for relief after earthquakes and other calamities. President Bush had earlier sent his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, on two missions to Beijing, and the Administration suggested that the lifting of martial law was a dividend. But Japan has said that it wants to see further liberalization before resuming negotiations on a $5 billion loan package. In Washington, Congress may well vote for new sanctions against China after convening later this month.
China's leaders had hoped for a more enthusiastic response abroad. Martial law and the bloody victory over the democracy movement last June carried with it tremendous costs. The Bush Administration's overtures notwithstanding, the Government has become a virtual pariah in the world. The sharp drop in tourism and foreign investment has hurt the economy and risks sparking further unrest. And the military presence during martial law deepened the hostility of many Chinese toward the Government.
Army troops remain in the capital, and the police have been ordered to intervene at the first sign of trouble. Unauthorized demonstrations are still illegal. On Tiananmen Square, even speaking loudly is an offense.
Until last May, the Communist Party might have gained some popular support with political liberalization, many Chinese intellectuals and foreign scholars say. While in Eastern Europe, Communist parties were generally reviled as Soviet-installed instruments of oppression and stagnation, the Chinese party still had a modest reservoir of good will based on its successes in the 1950's in reorganizing society and reviving the economy, as well as on the more recent economic boom of the early 1980's.
 
The Path Not Taken
Some young party officials here believe that when the leadership came to the crossroads last May and June, it could have chosen greater pluralism over violent repression. They say that if China had held elections, partly free, partly rigged, as in Taiwan and many developing countries, the Communist Party could have relied upon rural support to win.
But even these party members say that the Communists have so outraged the country over the last nine months that liberalization will be far more complex and dangerous than ever before. A famous pop singer, Hou Dejian, who has some protection because of his fame and Taiwanese origins, put it this way: ''In Eastern Europe, the regimes sacrificed one or two persons and protected the whole party. China was the opposite. China sacrificed the whole party and government to protect one or two persons.''
Economic pressures are crucial in this respect. A year ago, many Chinese were upset about inflation. Now inflation has been tamed, but unemployment and slow growth have emerged to make people more upset than ever.
Industrial output grew by only 6.8 percent in 1989, the Government announced last week, down from 17.7 percent growth the previous year. More alarming, most of the growth came early in the year; in the last quarter, industrial output grew only seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Because of a tight monetary policy, rising debts and a shortage of energy and raw materials, countless factories have been closed across the country - up to 8 percent of factories in some cities, the Government spokesman acknowledged. The Chinese people as a whole may not have seen their real standard of living drop, but they certainly have fallen far behind their expectations of continued improvement.
By late last year, the Government seemed to realize the political risk of further austerity, and monetary policy was sharply relaxed, though this may mean a resurgence of inflation later in 1990. The authorities also disclosed that all workers at state-owned enterprises will get a wage increase by the Chinese New Year holiday later this month.
It is not clear that the lifting of martial law will bring many of the expected economic benefits. Foreign business executives interviewed last week said that the move by itself made relatively little difference, and that economic prospects and the investment climate remain inauspicious. Tourism will improve, but is expected to remain subdued.
Most Chinese seem to believe that the party will try to consolidate its position through economic relaxation - a move intended to improve its popularity on pocketbook issues - while maintaining political controls that remain as strict as ever. But Chinese officials and foreign diplomats interviewed also maintain that hostility to the leadership is so great, particularly in cities and even within the party itself, that the hard-liners will be taking considerable risks if they try to rely on anything but the barrel of a gun.
Significantly, while the end of martial law brought no immediate economic benefits, it did ignite some minor political incidents. In several cases reported Thursday and Friday, people were hauled away from Tiananmen Square after shouting slogans or trying to present wreaths to honor the dead.
 
'When the Overthrow Will Come'
''Everybody is talking about when the overthrow will come,'' said a Government official. His own prediction is that it will take 10 years, but he acknowledged that his guess is unusually conservative. When asked, most people say two to five years will be enough. They do not so much forecast the end of socialism in China as simply a shift to a more moderate set of economic and political policies, probably under new Communist leaders. They see the changes coming either because of new street demonstrations or from a military coup or a power struggle within the Communist Party.
As the Government tries to heal the wounds of June and win a measure of support, it is stressing ''political study'' sessions intended to show that, as a huge billboard proclaims in the center of Beijing: ''Only socialism can save China. Only socialism can make China develop.''

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Finally, Amtrak Looks Like a Way To Run a Business

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
FOR most of its 19 years, Amtrak has been regarded as a kind of lost cause. Its trains were derided as unreliable, its service and food as primitive and its budget as a drain on the Federal treasury. But the national railroad appears, at last, to be moving in the right direction.
Revenues and service have shown a slow but substantial improvement. Passenger complaints are down. And the reliance on Federal money has steadily declined. Fares and other revenues now account for 72 cents of every dollar spent by Amtrak, up from only 40 cents in 1980. 
Last week, after Amtrak reported record income of $1.3 billion for 1989, W. Graham Claytor Jr., the system's president, even predicted that Amtrak might be able to cover all of its operating costs, something that no national railroad system in the world does now, by the year 2000.
Even critics of the railroad say they have been impressed. ''Three years ago, I would have said they never would have made it,'' said Stephen Moore, an economist with the Heritage Foundation, the conservative public policy institute that has opposed the Federal subsidies. ''I say, hats off to Mr. Claytor and other folks at Amtrak. They have really turned that railroad around.''
Amtrak, or the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, was created by Congress to take over the nation's failing passenger lines. Slowly, the managers of this patched-together network improved service, overhauled the reservation and ticketing system, advertised aggressively and undertook tough cost controls.
Indeed, Amtrak's major obstacle in recent years has been its inability to meet demand. While ridership in 1988 reached an all-time high of 21.5 million, gains have come slowly because the system is at or near capacity. Because the overworked fleet does not have enough cars and equipment, breakdowns are frequent.
While the Transportation Department tries to shape a new national transportation policy, Amtrak's success has given added credibility to those who say that trains must be part of any plan. Advocacy groups like the National Association of Railroad Passengers say the Federal Government needs to make a long-term commitment to passenger railroads and enable Amtrak to introduce new technology.
Over all, inter-city trains still account for only a small fraction, probably less than 5 percent, of the Amer ican transportation market.
But in some areas, trains play a much larger role. In the Northeast corridor, where Amtrak carries more than 11 million passengers annually - accounting for more than half of Amtrak's total ridership -trains are competitive, even essential. On many legs of the Washington-to-Boston corridor, flying is not even an alternative.
Mr. Claytor and others predict that Amtrak can become more competitive in other congested corridors, including some in California and the Midwest. With growing airport congestion, high-speed rail travel is seen as a sensible alternative on medium-distance routes, like those between Detroit and Chicago or Miami and Orlando. And while long-distance trains will never compete seriously with airplanes, they are potentially profitable. With improvements in service and equipment, some of Amtrak's most impressive gains in recent years have come on its overnight trains, especially popular with vacationers. First-class space on such trains is sold out months in advance of peak travel seasons.
At issue in the debate over transportation policy is the need for taxpayer dollars. If Mr. Claytor is going to see Amtrak break even by the year 2000, he says, he will need to hold down costs, including increasing demands from Amtrak workers, and count on Federal subsidies to cover anticipated operating losses. Last year, the Federal subsidy was $584 million.
More important, he said, he was counting on Congress to make investments in the equipment and technology needed to increase the speed and frequency of some trains and expand routes. At a minimum, he says, Amtrak needs $100 million a year in new investments, about half of which must come from Congress. He hopes to borrow the balance on the private market.
Last year, Congress granted Amtrak $80 million for capital spending, beyond its operating subsidy. In addition, the railroad privately financed about 100 new cars for routes in the Middle West.
Over the next decade, Mr. Claytor said he hopes to introduce new technology that will substantially improve service. One innovation will be ''tilt trains,'' which maintain speed and comfort on curves by leaning into them. By putting tilt trains, which are now operating in Canada and Spain, on the route between New York and Boston, for example, Amtrak hopes to reduce a trip that is now four hours and 20 minutes to less than three hours.
In addition, before the year 2000, Mr. Claytor also hopes that a train powered by magnetic levitation will be operating as a demonstration project on a short route. The technology, which is being tested in West Germany and Japan, enables a train to ride suspended on a magnetic cushion, about a half inch above an elevated magnetic track. It is then propelled at high speed by a traveling magnetic field created by current in the rail. Mr. Claytor's plans stop short of the high-speed technology of Japan's bullet trains or France's Train a Grande Vitesse, which approach 200 miles an hour. So far, the private sector is not convinced there is any return in such expensive technology, which costs more than $20 million a mile. And the Federal Government clearly cannot pay.
 
Less to Come
Those limits were pointedly stated last week by Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, who said that less rather than more Federal money would be available for transportation in coming years. Instead, he said, state and local governments are going to have to pay more.
Amtrak has already received support from state governments, including Michigan and Alabama, which are subsidizing operations and rebuilding roadbeds used by Amtrak.
Mr. Moore of the Heritage Foundation says the necessary limit on Federal subsidies also suggests another alternative - turning over at least some Amtrak routes to private enterprise, as conservative theorists have urged for years.
If Mr. Claytor and his colleagues at Amtrak have managed to do as well as they have, said Mr. Moore, ''imagine what Donald Trump could do with passenger service on the Northeast corridor.''
But for time being, Mr. Claytor is going to keep looking to his friends in Congress for continued support. That's where he can make use of his most effective argument: train routes that cross hundreds of Congressional districts.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
A Nation Tries to Decide How to Recall Martin Luther King

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
THE nation will honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. tomorrow, the holiday that marks his birth 61 years ago. But increasingly, the holiday is becoming a time when his admirers ponder not just the meaning of his life, but also the more delicate question of how best to carry on his work 22 years after his death.
This year, the celebration carries the burdens, passions and ambiguities of a work in progress. After a bitter battle over his memory and growing despair in the black communities whose aspirations he symbolized, Dr. King's legacy remains incomplete. 
The holiday symbolizes the civil rights era in the South and the man who more than anyone else is identified with its achievements. But many of his admirers see a legacy that is more complicated, including a focus on economic issues that was well ahead of its time.
Dr. King was honored in a week of ceremonies at the center that carries his name here and at the White House, where President Bush said, ''We have not finished the work of making Martin Luther King's dream a reality for each child in America: that one day they would live in a nation where they would be judged not by the color of their skin, but by the content of their character.''
 
Popular Misconceptions
But to some, the King now remembered is a sanitized version of the King who changed history. The Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker, senior pastor of the Canaan Baptist Church of Christ in Harlem and formerly the chief administrator of Dr. King's Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said all but lost in the popular notion of the man is his concern about economic inequality.
''When we left Birmingham, he said we would never make any major breakthroughs against racism until there was a fairer distribution of the wealth,'' Mr. Walker said. ''I contend anyone who is comfortable with the memory of Martin Luther King Jr. has missed his meaning and his message.'' Julian Bond, the civil rights figure who is now a visiting professor of African-American studies at Harvard, said: ''In some ways, we've smoothed Dr. King down. We don't remember King the critic of capitalism. We don't remember King the critic of imperialism. All we remember is the racial peacemaker, the black-and-white-together man.''
Some of the passions surrounding the man surround his holiday. White supremacist groups mark it with marches reviling him. In Arizona, conservatives led a petition drive that forced suspension of the King holiday, pending a popular vote in November.
But if the most visible controversies are caused by white opponents, the most painful may be among black supporters.
The civil rights leadership found itself in an ugly feud last summer when the Rev. Ralph Abernathy's autobiography repeated reports that Dr. King had extramarital affairs. Part of the furor reflected feelings of betrayal and disagreements with his account of the night before Dr. King's death. But some feel it also reflected the degree to which Dr. King's memory has become inviolate. Mr. Abernathy's charge that many of Dr. King's followers have become more attuned to preserving his name than perpetuating his work struck a note heard among blacks, often privately and seldom in public.
''I think we've become King-dependent,'' Mr. Bond said. ''We've invested so much hope in him or in a second coming of Martin Luther King that it becomes paralyzing.''
Adding to the complexity is the question of whether the tactics used against Bull Connor in Birmingham in the 1960's can be as successful today.
''We're not arguing the customer side of the lunch counter,'' said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, the head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. ''We're arguing the cash register side: not who can check into the hotel, but who has the means and who owns it. That's a far more complicated issue than where you sit on the bus.''
Still, this year the King holiday also brings renewed grounds for hope.
 
Example for the World
''Czechoslovakia and Rumania, Poland and Tiananmen Square - all of that is Dr. King's philosophy of nonviolent mass protest,'' said Mr. Walker. ''I fear the involuntary racism of America will not allow it to make the connection with the nonviolent mass protest of Dr. King because he was black.''
For others, the day is a time to reflect on the changes he brought to the nation and to rededicate themselves to his work.
''If not for Dr. King, I don't know what would have happened to the American South,'' said Representative John Lewis, an Atlanta Democrat who was an ally of Dr. King. ''We could have become like Northern Ireland, like Lebanon - not to the same degree, perhaps, but we would have been a much more divided region and a more divided nation.''
That does not make Dr. King sacrosanct, he said, but it makes him an extraordinary actor in American history, all the more so because he acted from no elected seat and with no power other than moral suasion.
''He was a man, a human being, flesh and blood,'' Mr. Lewis said, ''but he preached a message of hope and optimism that says to all of us that an individual can rise up and inspire an entire generation, an entire nation.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 24, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
If They've Won, Can Conservatives Still Be Important?

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
THE transformations sweeping Eastern Europe have reverberated through the institutes and offices, the meeting rooms and magazines that, for the past decade or so, have made up the most influential body of American political thought: conservatism. The echoes, in fact, are the sound of a victory chorus, even if the conservatives' detractors do not believe they should be the only ones to celebrate.
Naturally enough, conservatives believe that the extraordinary collapse of Communism in Europe has vindicated their most important beliefs about foreign policy. Or, as Burton Y. Pines, the vice president of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative public policy group in Washington, put it, ''We've won, and we won more extensively, more dramatically and more quickly than anybody could have imagined.'' 
In the conservatives' view, it was they and not apologetic liberals who bore the true message about the evils of Communism, a message that the people of the Soviet bloc are now for the first time free to proclaim themselves. For years these theorists argued that Communism was both threatening and bankrupt. If it is suddenly less threatening, they say, that is because of American wariness and military strength.
But what now? Has the agenda proclaimed by the coalition of forces that made up American conservatism lost its purpose now that its chief foreign policy enemy has been vanquished? Will the movement survive? And, if it does, what will be its issues in the future?
Perhaps the ultimate question is whether there is really something fundamental that sets American conservatism apart from other political philosophies. Put another way: is the movement, particularly in the powerful form it took in recent years, something permanent, or is it merely a phenomenon of an age when almost everybody sensed a common danger from the Soviet Union?
Some commentators have already seen what the essayist Charles Krauthammer has called ''the conservative crackup.'' The idea here is that the Soviet threat was the cement that held the movement together. Without it, the theory goes, it will disintegrate into a large number of factions.
 
Looking Within
The conservatives themselves agree that the time has come for introspection and re-evaluation. A few even concede that in some areas of American life, there may be no need for a specifically conservative agenda. In foreign policy, for example, some leaders on the right predict a return to the consensus they believe existed before the Vietnam War. Yet, with the many strains of conservatism no longer united by anti-Communism, it is difficult to see exactly what a unifying domestic agenda might be.
Some conservatives fervently believe that the movement has always been centered on national concerns, and if the foreign policy gap between East and West has narrowed, they will simply return to the domestic issues: government bureaucracy, the welfare state, the erosion of moral and educational standards.
But others are not sure that is possible. With the great icon, Ronald Reagan, no longer in office, and the Communist threat reduced, they see factionalism as not only possible but likely.
At the same time, the old liberal-conservative quarrel remains. If the conservatives have declared victory on the ideological battleground, others would like to deprive them of it. Some commentators, like Strobe Talbott of Time magazine, have argued that the collapse of the Soviet bloc is not at all the fruit of conservative policies but of Communism's inherent weaknesses.
Some contend that it was the cold-warriorism of the conservatives, their hawkish hostility to the Soviet Union, that gave rise to East-West tensions in the first place. And even those who blame the Soviets, rather than the Americans, for the cold war, refuse to give the conservatives credit for its end. Foreign policy, they say, has always been a good deal more bipartisan than the right admits.
The immediate response of some conservatives has been to taunt the liberals for being bad losers. ''Who, after all, has been most loudly proclaiming the superiority of capitalism?'' they ask. ''Who led the moral charge against the evident odiousness of Communism?''
Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the Reagan representative to the United Nations and perhaps that Administration's most influential foreign policy theorist, gives Mr. Reagan credit in two important areas.
''One was the confident reaffirmation of the case for free institutions,'' she said in an interview. ''And two, I think that the restoration of American military strength, occurring as it did with the stagnation of the Soviet economy, really dramatized and illustrated for Gorbachev the problems in that country of technology and the economic base.''
While celebrating Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms and his decision not to intervene in his neighbors' affairs, conservatives have been more cautious than liberals in assessing his prospects for success. Needless Concessions? Columnists like William Safire of The New York Times and William F. Buckley, publisher of the National Review, have warned about two things: making needless concessions to the Soviets in the hope of helping Gorbachev succeed in reforming the Communist system, and letting down the American military guard too hastily.
''The complacent community is inhaling every fresh dandelion within the Soviet empire as a reason to diminish our defense forces,'' Mr. Buckley wrote. ''But although it can be said that by all the evidence, Communism has failed, it can't yet be said that the aggressive potential of the Soviet Union has evaporated.''
And so the debate continues, but some conservatives say the issues are far more matters of nuance and degree than of fundamental difference. Some, like the columnist Patrick Buchanan, who have generally favored increased military spending, are already saying that the time has arrived to pare down military spending. It is a common misconception, conservatives like to argue, that they want a big Pentagon, no matter what. Saving money on the military would be a desirable ''peace dividend,'' they say, if the Soviet military threat has been genuinely reduced.
''The right in America is a mixture of very different strands,'' said Michael Joyce, president of the Bradley Foundation, a conservative group in Wisconsin. ''One thing that has been common to all of these factions -the Chicago School, the neo-conservatives, the National Review religious conservatives, the old South types - was a common revulsion of totalitarian regimes. So that to the extent that this great massive totalitarian system is in self-destruction, you could say that will accentuate the differences.''
Mr. Pines of the Heritage Foundation, by contrast, denies that anti-Communism was ever the real conservative cement.
''What created the conservative juggernaut were by and large domestic issues - abortion, falling standards, inflation, a stagnating economy and the growth of the bureaucracy,'' he said. ''There are going to be different parts of the movement thinking different things and having different priorities. But by and large if some of our energies are freed up to focus on the domestic arena, we're going to hold our coalition together.''

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Silicon Valley Is Changing Programs

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif.

 BODY:
SILICON VALLEY, where it once seemed growth had no limits, is in the midst of a midlife crisis. Faced with fierce Japanese competition and a market for personal computers that is growing more slowly than the industry's early visionaries predicted, high technology has lost some of its luster. If boom times are to return, the valley's engineers and entrepreneurs will have to find ways to make the personal computer cheaper, more powerful and portable enough to live up to its name.
Remember the predictions of the early 1980's? By now computers were supposed to be as ubiquitous as telephone answering machines and microwave ovens - the gadget that no one could do without. But except for those who needed a machine for word processing or spreadsheet calculations, the personal computer turned out to be an expensive toy. It was easier to keep track of household finances with a checkbook and to file recipes on three-by-five cards. 
Many companies tried to expand sales by catering to businesses and developing more powerful and expensive machines called work stations. But even that market became saturated more quickly than the optimists expected.
Apple Computer Inc. and Sun Microsystems Inc. both had disappointing years in 1989. Although neither company is losing money, it is clear that the 20 percent annual growth rates they once experienced are a thing of the past.
The slowdown in Silicon Valley mirrors a similar malaise for the nation's largest computer makers. Late last year, the chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, John Akers, gloomily predicted that growth in the industry as a whole would hover around 7 percent in the future.
One view from Wall Street suggests that the days of open-ended growth for American high technology are over for good. A Morgan Stanley economist, Stephen S. Roach, said that capital spending on information technology accounted for 40 percent of the growth of total spending on business equipment between the mid-1970's and the mid-1980's. But now that percentage is flat, even declining slightly last year. It seems that companies generally have all the computer equipment they need. At the same time foreign competition has greatly reduced domestic market share.
If the computer industry is to revitalize itself, it will have to come up with ways to appeal to people who have had no reason to buy a personal computer or who need enormous incentives to justify upgrading the systems they already have. There are reasons for optimism. The driving force of technology here, the ability to double every few years the number of transistors that can be squeezed onto a sliver of silicon, has shown no sign of pausing. The Intel Corporation introduced a microprocessor with more than a million transistors last year, a watershed indicating that desktop computers can soon match the complexity of the most powerful mainframes. The same is true for magnetic storage devices, also pioneered in Silicon Valley. I.B.M. researchers in San Jose said recently that they had succeeded in squeezing a billion bits of information onto a square inch of storage space.
At each of these technological plateaus new products and even new industries are made possible. While Japanese competitors continue to make inroads into the personal computer market, new Silicon Valley companies like Agilis Inc., the Poquet Computer Corporation, Momenta Inc. and the Go Corporation are all trying to redefine the personal computer. Go, for example, will soon introduce a portable notepad computer without a keyboard. Information will be written instead on an electronic pad. The idea behind such a machine is to open computing to a broader class of users, including those who don't type.
Agilis has an even more radical idea. Its mobile computer introduced last year is in constant communication with its home base via a radio link. Poquet and Atari are offering pocket-size computers that can run spreadsheet programs and other software that once required a desktop machine.
If these companies and others succeed they will likely transform computing in the next decade. The computer will no longer be chained to a desk. It will be something people have with them constantly, more like a watch or an appointment calendar.
As personal computers become more personal, few of them will actually be manufactured in Silicon Valley. State-of-the-art factories like those Steve Jobs created to build his Macintosh and Next computers are the exception today. Instead the valley is serving as a combined development laboratory, design center and corporate administration site. In a global economy manufacturing is relocated close to the markets it serves.
The advance of technology has meant the demise of the garage inventor, the heart of Silicon Valley's mythology. Computer design today is done seated at a powerful computer work station. But that hasn't ended the role of the individual designer. Powerful tools and custom computer chips permitted Sun Microsystems to build its new Sparcstation 1 work station with far fewer designers and more quickly than was possible with earlier models.
The challenge today for Silicon Valley is to see if it can reinvent itself once again.

LENGTH: 757 words

HEADLINE: Cold Warriors, From A to Z

 BODY:
Ever since Mikhail Gorbachev came to power in 1985, neoconservatives and other hard-liners have strained to find new rationales for old cold war animosities. It hasn't been easy. Mr. Gorbachev doesn't fit the mold of Soviet leaders with his political and economic reforms, his unilateral force reductions, his freeing of Eastern Europe, his willingness to reveal the lies of his predecessors and now his statement that a multiparty system in his own country would not be a ''tragedy.''
Even so, the hard-liners have persisted in their suspicions, looking for intellectual support wherever they could find it. Some of them now embrace the argument advanced by a writer known only as ''Z,'' in Daedalus, journal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and recently excerpted on the Op-Ed page. But in so doing, they commit two sins of omission. 
One is that, like Z, they oversimplify the likely paths to the future. The other is that they pay scant attention to Z's own policy recommendations.
The neocons and hard-liners have long felt that no Soviet leader could be trusted, and that Americans should not be duped into unilateral disarmament. When Mr. Gorbachev first spoke of reforms, they charged that he was all talk and no action. When he began to act, they insisted that more action was needed. When he delivered far more than anyone would have predicted, they found comfort within the Bush Administration and its early do-nothing policy self-described as ''status quo plus.''
Lawrence Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, talked about the turmoil Gorbachev policies were creating in Europe and seemed to pine over the loss of cold war stability and certainties. Robert Gates, the deputy national security adviser, argued in effect that Mr. Gorbachev wasn't worth helping because his reforms would fail and he'd be thrown out of office.
Secretary of State Baker scotched much of this talk by saying it was in America's interest to help Mr. Gorbachev succeed. And President Bush, after the Malta summit meeting, pledged to press ahead with arms control and Soviet-American trade to help Mr. Gorbachev ''keep going forward.''
That left the hard-liners groping for a new intellectual underpinning, a new line of attack. Some of them, at least, found it in the article by Z. Z argues that if Mr. Gorbachev's goal is to strengthen the Communist system through reform, he cannot succeed. The ''system cannot be restructured or reformed . . . On this score, Mr. Gorbachev is beyond our help'' . . . Helping him would only ''prolong the agony.''
If, rather, Mr. Gorbachev seeks gradually to transform his party dictatorship and command economy into a democracy and market economy, Z says he can't be believed. He ''clearly does not intend'' to liquidate Communist Party rule, asserts Z, and thus should not be helped to maintain it.
Thus, through this simple rhetorical device, Z defines away policy choice. Why isn't Mr. Gorbachev to be believed? Because, Z says, Soviet Communists would never relinquish power. But as he now illustrates anew in Lithuania, Mr. Gorbachev has already taken initiative after unimaginable initiative, weakening the party's power.
And even if he doesn't desire Western-style democracy and capitalism, perhaps he is searching. Perhaps he isn't even sure exactly what kind of system he wants and is mainly groping for what will work.
In any event, his actions matter far more than his supposed goals. And his actions offer the soundest test for Western support - whether he continues to allow, even encourage, political and economic freedoms in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. These are the very steps the West has demanded for 40 years. Hard-liners, neocons and Z skirt this issue. And they also duck the critical fact that the likely alternatives to Mr. Gorbachev would be far worse for Western interests.
Then, Z, unlike most hard-liners and neocons, seems to see that his analysis leads only to a policy dead end and alters course. Z writes that whatever the intentions of Mr. Gorbachev or his successors, the Communist regime is ''dwindling away,'' and here ''Western help could play a constructive role.''
Z then goes on to urge what Western liberals and moderates have been urging all along - arms control and cooperative arrangements to develop market structures and joint economic ventures in the Soviet Union. Thus, in the end, even Z seems to understand that there is no serious alternative to helping Mikhail Gorbachev. The neocons and hard-liners still miss the point.

HEADLINE: Who's Left, Who's Right in Post-Wall Europe?;
The Failed Experiment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a visitor from Britain, I am growing tired of the complacent tone that marks most reporting and comment on the remarkable events in Eastern Europe. Those who see those events as the final triumph of the American ideals of capitalism, democracy and freedom should pause to take a look, first, at what is really happening in those countries and, second, at whether ''democracy and freedom'' are really alive and kicking at home.
As for the triumph of capitalism, the widespread assumption that the people of Eastern Europe have embraced capitalism is fallacious. They have thrown off a repressive and totalitarian regime, which set a low premium on human dignity. No doubt this rejection will also include a rejection of the centrally planned economy. But as any European or Scandinavian social democrat or democratic socialist will tell you, an economic system that recognizes the importance of the market in appropriate spheres is a far cry from the free market utopia that is generally the American understanding of capitalism. It seems far more likely that Eastern Europe will follow the Western European or Scandinavian model than the American. 
As for whether the United States is today the best exemplar of democracy and freedom, you are right to observe (''Human Rights: Now the Hard Part,'' editorial, Dec. 30) that the recent struggle ''owes much to America's history and ideals.'' So indeed did the postwar international human rights movement, inspired by your Constitution's protections of fundamental rights and freedoms. But at the end of a dark decade for liberty and progressiveness at home, those values and ideals appear, regrettably, to have passed into American history.
Recent decisions of the Supreme Court retrenching on the hard-won gains of the civil rights movemment, threatening to remove a woman's reproductive autonomy, failing to guarantee respect for the private conduct of homosexual adults, would today inspire no United Nations Declaration or European Convention, other than as examples of the sorts of failures to guarantee fundamental freedoms to guard against.
A society in which the ''liberal'' label has become the pejorative ''L-word''; in which membership in the American Civil Liberties Union is used as a smear in a Presidential campaign, and in which lies and corruption in the highest places are widely tolerated, is a society sufficiently dislocated from its former commitment to make complacency about liberty unjustified and hypocritical.
Those in Eastern Europe and elsewhere who have courageously risked their lives to gain a say in how their countries should be run would surely not wish to choose as their model democratic society one in which less than half the electorate bothers to vote, while millions are consigned to the hopelessness of poverty, homelessness, drugs and crime. The idealistic mood in those countries would be appalled at the high level of toleration of outrageous suffering in this ''free and democratic'' nation. Where, they would ask, did it go wrong; how can democracy ever lead to that?
So, before rushing to celebrate the victory and vindication of the ''American experiment,'' Americans should take a closer look at their own society. Perhaps the best lesson they can offer the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe is to insure that the people there remain ever vigilant against the tragic ways in which such noble ideals and values can be corrupted.
 
MURRAY R. HUNT
 Somerville, Mass., Jan. 1, 1990

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Chronology Of Betrayal

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
This is the chronology of the American betrayal of the struggle for freedom in China. It is worth studying. There is still a chance to recover some of America's honor.
PUB-DATE: June 4, 1989:
June 20: President Bush orders some mild sanctions against China. He says any high-level contacts with the murderers of Beijing are suspended until they acknowledge the validity of the demonstrators' aspirations.
Early July: Exact date still secret. Mr. Bush sends a high-level mission to China but keeps that fact hidden.
July-November: More executions. New waves of arrests, closing in tighter on student leaders who had escaped; purging of officials who had shown any sympathy with them.
Nov. 30: Mr. Bush vetoes an act of Congress, passed without opposition in the House and Senate, to guarantee that Chinese students now in this country would not be forced to return to China as long as they were in danger.
Dec. 9: A top-level mission is sent publicly to Beijing. Warm exchanges of toasts with the men who ordered the murders. Administration refuses to say whether other secret missions were sent to China.
Dec. 10-24: Mr. Bush says some sanctions will be lifted. Brushes aside protests from Republican and Democratic members of Congress.
Administration makes it plain that it expects gestures from Chinese Communists before Congress reconvenes to try to override the President's veto.
Jan. 2-8, 1990: American organizations like the International League for Human Rights provide information detailing arrests and executions, which have continued since the June murders.
Chinese students say at least 10,000 demonstrators are still in jail, beg Mr. Bush to demand their release.
Chinese Communists denounce Eastern European revolutions, show even stronger determination not to loosen their own control.
Jan. 10: Chinese Communists, as predicted, announce lifting of martial law in Beijing - not in any other place where it was imposed publicly or secretly.
Many soldiers transferred to police force, which now numbers more than l.5 million in addition to army about twice that size. Laws allowing arrests without explanation, secret trials, executions, indefinite detention without trial, forced labor, press control, brutal student ''re-education'' camps - all still on the books and recently made even harsher.
Denunciation of ''lifting'' of martial law as meaningless cosmetic trick comes from all over the world. In Washington, the President orders steps to permit World Bank loans to Chinese Communists.
Jan. 11: Mr. Bush hails the Chinese Communists for taking a ''very sound step.'' Washington reports possible repeals of other sanctions. That is the chronology so far. In the last days of the 1980's the Bush Administration deserted the struggle for freedom in China. Whatever the reasons - outdated, stale geopolitics and Mr. Bush's misplaced confidence that he really ''knows'' China best -the Administration picked the wrong China, the China of the oppressors over the China of the oppressed.
In the first days of the 1990's it did something almost as bad - it made a fool of itself. It said that a contemptuous piece of cynical playacting by the murderers of Beijing was a step toward freedom.
Now here is a date for the future:
On Jan. 24, the day after it reconvenes, Congress will try to override Mr. Bush's veto of the bill to protect Chinese students in the United States.
This was always important, to help the students. Now it has taken on profound political significance.
An override would signal to the entire world that at least the legislative branch of the United States Government remains on the side of the freedom fighters of China. It would be an act of hope and loyalty for the Chinese and the freedom movements still struggling in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Override of a veto requires a two-thirds majority. The White House is working hard to persuade Republicans who voted for the bill to vote against an override.
Between today and the date of that vote, every American can get in touch with his or her representative and senator and urge them to vote against the veto and for the people of China.
This will give us all a chance to take part in the chronology of Chinese-American history and wipe away part of the stain.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By CARL SOMMERS

 BODY:

West German Youth Hostels
Q. My husband and I are planning a trip to West Germany in March and intend to stay in youth hostels. Has the recent influx of East Germans made it difficult to secure accommodations? - V. O., Springfield, Mass.
A. Many of the 537 hostels and guesthouses serving young people in West Germany are housing visitors and settlers from East Germany and other Eastern European countries, according to the country's hostel association. There is no list of which hostels take resettlers, the association said, as the decision to do so was made locally. However, most hostels and low-cost guesthouses that have been taking in Eastern Europeans have also set aside space for tourists. So it is a good idea to reserve early as space will be more limited than usual. The country code for telephoning West Germany is 49. 
The owner of a low-cost guesthouse in Hamburg (Jugendgastehaus, 100 Rennbornstrasse, 2000 Hamburg 74; 40-6511671) said he was reserving a quarter of his rooms for resettlers and leaving the rest for tourists.
In Nuremberg the guesthouse (Jugendgasthaus, 2 Auf der Burg, 8500 Nuremberg 1; 911-221024) is not saving rooms especially for tourists but will accept early reservations. In West Berlin, the youth hostel (48 Hermsdorfer Damm, 1000 Berlin 28; 30-4041610) and two guesthouses, Gasthaus Berlin (3 Luckstrasse, 1000 West Berlin; 30-8032034) and Gasthaus Wannsee (1 Badeweg, 1000 West Berlin 38; 30-8032034), are not taking in resettlers. However, the head of the youth hostel recommends making reservations as early as possible, as he expects a flood of visitors.
Information about West German youth hostels can be obtained from Deutsches Jugendherhbergwer, 8 Bismarckstrasse, 4930 Detmold 1; 5321-74010.
 
Art Deco Hotels in Miami
Q. I am interested in spending a week in the Art Deco district of Miami Beach this winter. Please provide information on renovated beachfront hotels in the area. - J. W., New York, N.Y.
A. The chief concentration of Art Deco hotels (among some 800 other buildings in the style) is in South Beach, on the southern tip of the island on which Miami is situated. There are several renovated Deco hotels along Ocean Drive, a milelong two-lane street along the beach. The hotel rates given here are for the least expensive rooms, which often do not have an ocean view. The mailing address of all the hotels is Miami, Fla. 33139.
The Avalon (700 Ocean Drive; 305-538-0133) has 61 rooms, starting at $75. The Majestic, a Deco hotel across the street, will finish renovation in mid-February and open under the same managment.
The Leslie (1244 Ocean Drive) and the Cardozo (1300 Ocean Drive) can be reached at 800-338-9076 or 305-534-2135). Both are managed by the Art Deco Hotels Group, as is the Cavalier (1320 Ocean Drive; 800-338-9076 or 305-531-6424). All have no more than 50 rooms. The Leslie's rooms start at $80, including breakfast, and the Cardozo's $95, no breakfast. Rooms at the Cavalier start at $95, with breakfast.
The Carlyle (1250 Ocean Drive), an outstanding Deco structure, is now an office building but has a restaurant, the Carlyle Grill (305-534-2135).
The Clevelander (1020 Ocean Drive; 305-531-3485) has 65 rooms starting at $50, plus an outdoor and indoor bar and a pool.
The Edison (960 Ocean Drive; 800-237-3522 or 305-531-0461) has 62 rooms starting at $75, a pool and two restaurants. A community center across the street blocks the view from the first and second floors.
Park Central (640 Ocean Drive; 305-538-1611) has 80 rooms starting at $75 and a restaurant.
The Waldorf Towers (860 Ocean Drive; 305-531-7684) has 45 rooms from $90 and a restaurant.
For an informed look at the local architecture, the Miami Design Preservation League (661 Washington Avenue; 305-672-2014) offers a 90-minute walking tour every Saturday at 10:30 A.M.; a $5 contribution is asked.
 
London Bucket Shops
Q. I used a bucket shop called the Late Traveler in the West End of London in 1979, specializing in last-minute flights out of England. I cannot find it. Do you know of similar shops? - R. B. F., Freehold, N.J.
A. London has several agencies, called bucket shops, that buy unused spaces on planes and travel packages and sell them to the public at a discount. The Late Traveler still exists, with its main branch in Croydon, at 78A High Street; telephone 686 0460. Its London office is called Dial A Flight, Hobbs Court, 2 Jacob Street, London SE1; 334 0995. The country code for England is 44 and the city code for London is 1. Other agencies specializing in plane tickets:
Trailfinders, 42-48 Earls Court Road, London W8; telephone 937 5400 (trans-Atlantic and European flights); 938 3366 (other flights); 938 3444 (first and business class).
S.T.A. Travel, 74 and 86 Old Brompton Road, London SW7, and 117 Euston Road, London NW1; 937 9971 (North American flights); 937 9921 (European); 937 9962 (other).
Orion Travel, Fifth Floor, Morley House, 320 Regent Street, London W1; 580 3751. Travel Bazaar, 221 Westbourne Park Road, London W11; 221 6095. The Air Travel Advisory Bureau (Morley House, 320 Regent Street, London W1; 636 5000) is a service that says it finds the cheapest flights available from bucket shops.
For more agencies that offer cheap flights, visitors to London can refer to the classified pages of the weekly magazine Time Out.
 
New Zealand Jewish Tour
Q. I hear there is a tour to New Zealand that covers Jewish history. Do you know anything about it? - M. S., New York, N.Y.
A. The American Jewish Congress organizes a 21-day tour called New Zealand: Jewish Discovery. The tour takes in much of the standard sites on the North and South Islands. However, the leader, Odeda Rosenthal, author of ''Not Strictly Kosher: Pioneer Jews in England,'' discusses the history of the Jewish population, which in New Zealand dates to 1840. Participants have Sabbath dinner at homes of Jewish Aucklanders and, for those who wish, attend synagogue there, and, in Wellington, they meet Shmuel Ovnat, Israel's Ambassador to New Zealand. The tour costs $3,690 a person in double occupancy, and includes economy-class air fare from New York, lodging and 31 meals, including full breakfast daily. Information: American Jewish Congress, Travel Department, 15 East 84th Street, New York, N.Y. 10028; 800-221-4694 or 212-879-4588.
