HEADLINE: SHOPPER'S WORLD;
An Array of Spices in Istanbul

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE; MARVINE HOWE, a reporter for the metropolitan desk of The Times, was a correspondent in Turkey.

 BODY:
IF you walk along the right bank of the Golden Horn through the maze of street vendors, porters and all kinds of vehicles, then turn south just opposite the Galata Bridge, you enter a world of pungent Oriental spices, medicinal herbs and essences, some very familiar, others quite unfathomable.
The grand 17th-century domed building on Eminonu Square is Istanbul's Spice Bazaar, called Misir Carsisi, which can mean either Egyptian market or corn market. The busy square has been a marketplace since the days of Venetian and Genoese traders, and at one time, corn was sold there. And during the Ottoman Empire, Egypt served as the main entrepot for goods from the East, which were then dispatched to Istanbul, seat of the imperial court. The bazaar was built in 1657 by the mother of Sultan Mehmet IV, Valide Sultan Turhan Hatice, founder of the handsome Yeni Cami, or New Mosque, nearby. Rents from the shops in the bazaar went toward financing the mosque.
Leaving the harsh glare and hubbub of the square and going into the Spice Bazaar is something like entering a vast cathedral. As you walk in the cool air of the central aisle you are enveloped in a soft, filtered light and a heady blend of fragrances. On either side are vaulted niches; you almost expect to see statues of saints instead of the brightly lighted shops. 
The Spice Bazaar is like some giant specialty store, where you can find all kinds of Turkish products that make wonderful gifts. Many visitors find the long L-shaped building easier to get around and far less exhausting than the legendary Covered Bazaar with its 4,000 shops.
Along the narrow corridors of the Spice Bazaar are mounds of dried apricots, pistachios, hazelnuts and almonds, selling for a fraction of their cost in the United States. Huge trays contain mild white cheeses, spicy sausages and honey-sweet lokum, the candy paste known as Turkish delight. Nonfood items include everything from basketware to gold jewelry.
Above all, this is the best place in town to find spices and herbs singly and in exotic combinations. In front of small numbered shops stand great bags of anise, cumin, saffron, cinnamon bark. Shelves are lined with bottles of hibiscus flower, sumac and rose-pepper as well as more familiar seasonings like ginger, rosemary, tarragon and thyme. Tucked away in dusty drawers or in ancient bottles are all kinds of mysterious plants for different ailments. In most of the tiny establishments, every inch of floor and wall space is used, and some products like branches of dried herbs and garlands of sponges dangle from the ceiling.
What seems to be the best seller these days is something called the Aphrodisiac of Sultans. This concoction has 41 spices and herbs including honey, nutmeg, cream of tartar, clove, cinnamon and saffron. People believe that besides its aphrodisiac qualities, it fortifies the blood, alleviates pain and protects against snake and insect bites. Some people eat it spread on bread like jam but taking it straight is advised for the best effect. A 12-ounce bottle costs between $2.10 and $3.15, at 1,908 Turkish liras to the dollar. (Inflation is running very high in Turkey, and prices are changing constantly.) Actually, the aphrodisiac is a popular version of a medicinal paste called Manisa Mesir Macunu, which can be found in some of the shops. This paste comes from Manisa, near Izmir, and dates to the early part of the 16th century. At that time, Suleyman the Magnificent, who later became sultan, was governor of Manisa. His mother, Hafsa Sultan, fell gravely ill, and the head of the Manisa Hospital put together a special paste of 41 herbs and spices that cured her. The sultan's mother proclaimed the miraculous paste should be distributed free to all who wanted it. From that time on, the paste, in small chunks like soft candy, has been distributed free from the Sultan's Mosque during the Mesir festival on the third or last Sunday in March.
Unlike in most Oriental markets, prices in the Spice Market are displayed on almost all goods. This practice seems to discourage bargaining - although it undoubtedly goes on. Shopkeepers sometimes offer free samples of spices to entice prospective clients.
At No. 7 Ayfer Kaur, spices and herbs are generally sold loose by weight. For example, 100 grams (about three and a half ounces) of paprika is priced at about 60 cents; 100 grams of curry, $1; 50 grams of oregano, 60 cents; 50 grams of vanilla sticks, $2.10; 100 grams of ginger powder, $2.10. A bottle of 300 grams of mixed herbs and spices for salad dressing costs $1.50; a spice mix to be used with fish is $2.10 for 100 grams. A gift package of eight small bottles of different condiments including mint, saffron, sumac, cumin black pepper, sweet pepper, rosemary and paprika sells for about $4.
No. 41 Erdal Bahrat, opened in 1927, is the oldest shop in the Spice Bazaar, according to its manager, who is generally known as Ali Bey. He says Turks buy mostly black and red pepper, mint, thyme, cumin and allspice, which are used in stuffed vegetable dishes. Also popular are orange-flower water and rose water, used in puddings. And much in demand are different herbs for tea; garden sage, supposed to be good for the digestion and nerves; linden flowers good for colds, and camomile flowers as a laxative.
Foreigners are partial to saffron, says Ali Bey, who warns that there are all kinds of saffron for all kinds of prices. Spanish saffron, which he does not carry, is weaker and cheaper than its Eastern counterparts. Indian saffron powder costs $1.10 for 100 grams, but the most highly prized saffron is the flower from Iran, 5 grams for $3.75.
In the back of the shop recently, amid large jars of medicinal plants and bottles of rose oil, paraffin and natural dyes, a group of Libyans were buying what looked like chunks of wood. Ali Bey explained that it was incense and they were taking it back to be burned in mosques.
Nearby is No. 51 Ucuzcular Spices and Food Company, which Dilaver Kadioglu says has been in his family for four generations. He sells spices, natural dyes, musks and oils as well as many medicinal plants and mysterious mixtures. One popular mix is called Bronchit, said to cure bronchitis and other respiratory ailments. It is made of nine spices and flowers including clove, cinnamon flower, jasmine flower and orange flower. There are also several concoctions, whose composition is a secret. One combination of natural fats and herb extracts is supposed to cure rheumatism.
About half of the market is devoted to spices and herbs. The other shops seem to deal on a small scale in almost everything found in the Covered Bazaar except carpets. Several shops display shoes and slippers made of good Turkish leather but generally lacking in flair. Other shops offer attractive soft leather handbags priced less than you would pay for plastic in the United States.
Some merchants specialize in household linens - towels and tablecloths of good Turkish cotton, wool blankets and embroidered mats and towels. Some carry children's clothing.
In one area, the bazaar has been invaded by high tech. Shelves are piled high with electronic calculators and stereo equipment. But better bargains can be had in discount stores in Manhattan.
For a quick snack, the busy shopper can always try one of the stand-up kebab bars in the market. But if there's time, Pandeli, upstairs in the Spice Bazaar, is a good spot for lunch. The upper rooms used to serve as the office of the cadi, or Islamic judge, until an earthquake left the place in ruins about 100 years ago, according to Christis Tsobanoglu, who is the manager of Pandeli.
''Istanbul is between Europe and Asia and has a temperate climate, so the cuisine is lighter and not so spicy as nearby cooking,'' Mr. Tsobanoglu says.
At Pandeli, as in most Turkish restaurants, a diner could probably be satisfied with just the meze, or hors d'oeuvres, and in fact many Turks stop at that point. You can start with chilled vine leaves stuffed with rice and onion, sauteed in olive oil and seasoned with fresh dill, mint and parsley, cinnamon and allspice, at $2.35. A must is the borek, crisp flaky pastry filled with white cheese and seasoned with chopped parsley, dill and nutmeg, for $1.60. As an entree, try sis kebap, grilled cubes of lamb or beef marinated in lemon juice, olive oil, thyme, pepper and grated onion, for $3.70. The entree specialty of the house is fresh swordfish marinated in lemon juice, olive oil, paprika and onion juice and grilled with bay leaves, green peppers and tomatoes, for $6.80 a serving.
Probably the best place to get to know the delights of Turkish cuisine and its panoply of spices and herbs is the Konyali Saray, inside Topkapi Palace. In the fourth court of the palace, behind the mosque, is the Konyali restaurant, looking out over the Bosphorus. At the entrance, there is a lineup of grand bottles containing spices and herbs used by the sultans and still gracing the fare in Topkapi.
NURETTIN DOGANBEY, who also manages the smaller - and even better - Konayli restaurant near the Sirkeci railway station, says that his cooks still use more than 50 different spices and herbs but points out that the Ottoman cooks used four times as many. ''McDonald's and television are changing Turkish tastes,'' he says.
Mr. Doganbey recounts how the Turkic nomads came from Central Asia, early in the 11th century, bringing with them spices and herbs accumulated from their travels in China, India and the Caucasus. In Anatolia, they found a wide variety of local spices and herbs and abundant fresh meat, fish and vegetables.
Under the Ottoman sultans, the use of fresh herbs and spices was developed into an art form, which spread to the villages. It is said that the common cook could tell by the taste of mint leaves on which side of the mountain they were grown, and would sometimes mix the sunny-side mint with the shady to get the right flavor.
Neset Eren, the author of ''The Delights of Turkish Cooking.'' (Redhouse Press), which is widely available in Turkey, says that Turkish cuisine is characterized by ''fresh herbs and discreet spices that don't overwhelm you.'' In the introduction to her book, she writes that her family home, on a hill overlooing the Bosporus, was headquarters of the Bektashi order of dervishes. She recalls the huge kitchen fireplace and the walls lined with shelves of countless jars of jams, herbs and spices and how at the age of 5, she used to go with the cooks to pick thyme, oregano, and dandelions on the hills around Istanbul.
She also tells the story of the Empress Eugenie, wife of Napoleon III, who visited Sultan Abdulaziz and fell in love with Topkapi Palace's specialty, eggplant puree. The sultan agreed to allow his chef to show the Empress's cook how to prepare the delicacy. But the Turkish chef refused to give his French colleague the recipe, saying, ''An imperial chef cooks with his feelings, his eyes, his nose.'' Today the delicate eggplant dish, hunkar begendi, meaning royalty liked it, has become a national favorite and is found on most menus.

HEADLINE: KASPAROV BEATS DEEP THOUGHT

BYLINE: By Brad Leithauser: Brad Leithauser is the author of the novel ''Hence,'' coming out in paperback in March from Penguin. He is on the editorial board of Book-of-the-Month Club.

 BODY:
IN A CROWDED AUDITORIUM, THE CHAMPION hunches over a chessboard. He is surrounded by cameramen. Taking refuge in himself, he pillows his jaw in his hands. He is thinking hard in order to make himself think harder. His opponent, also a champion, is some 300 miles away, pondering the next move, engaged in calculations on a scale too colossal for anyone in the audience to grasp.
The first champion, Gary Kasparov, is considered by many aficionados the greatest genius the game has seen. He became world champion by defeating his Soviet countryman Anatoly Karpov in the fall of 1985. Twenty-two at the time, Kasparov was the youngest person ever to gain the title.
The second champion, Deep Thought, is a good deal younger: roughly two years old. Deep Thought is a computer. It usually plays its games by telephone hookup. In the spring of 1989, it defeated all comers at the Sixth World Computer Chess Championship, held in Edmonton, Alberta. Deep Thought is, far and away, the fastest chess machine yet devised. 
The two-game match between the champions, which took place in New York City on Oct. 22, 1989, was designed to illuminate just where, at the highest levels, human chess and computer chess intersect. The mere existence of the match is, in a sense, a victory for the computer. Before the advent of Deep Thought, no machine had been developed that might challenge a human world champion. In the rapidly evolving relationship between people and their machines, this match is an acknowledgment of a new, and inherently short-lived, state - one of essential parity on the board.
On the day when computers begin to dominate the greatest human players - an inevitability - they will do so forever. If, taking an overview of the game, we regard the set of all human chess players as a single, collective organism, we see that this is a ''life form'' driven toward self-betterment: it ventures into new territory, tests and retests its hypotheses, pools its knowledge. But its rate of improvement simply cannot keep up with computers, whose progress is measured exponentially. In 1986, the fastest computer was looking at roughly 150,000 different chess positions per second. Deep Thought examines about 1,500,000. Machines that evaluate 10 million, even a hundred million positions per second may not be far off. Some computer scientists are now predicting that within another three to five years, machines will have ranged so far beyond our capabilities that a confrontation between human and computer world champions would be boringly one-sided.
ON THE DAY BEFORE THE MATCH, I GO OUT for coffee with a group of chess devotees that includes Murray Campbell and Feng-hsiung Hsu, two of the chief architects of Deep Thought. Although physically a study in contrasts - Campbell is lanky and neat, Hsu compact and disheveled - the two scientists have a lot in common. Campbell, who grew up in Alberta, Canada, is 32; Hsu, born in Taiwan, is 30. Both earned doctorates in computer science at Carnegie-Mellon in Pittsburgh, where Deep Thought is located, and both have recently become researchers at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, 40 miles outside New York City. They are working exclusively at the moment on chess computers.
They also share, on the eve of the match, a no-lose situation. Because Deep Thought is a decided underdog they needn't worry whether it will win or draw either game; two defeats, provided it plays solidly, would suit them just fine. Whatever happens, they are already looking ahead to a new machine, which they hope to develop within two or three years, and which Campbell predicts will represent a ''significant leap forward.'' Their primary worry is that some bug in the program will spring up, in poltergeist fashion, to make them appear ridiculous.
But the question remains - is even one draw feasible? Campbell sets the odds at 1 in 10. Because Deep Thought never gets discouraged, it can play marvelously tenacious chess when in trouble, often sneaking into an improbable draw - what Campbell calls its ''weasel phenomenon.'' Unlike the other members of the Deep Thought team, Campbell used to play competitive chess, which gives him a privileged insight into Deep Thought's ''behavior'' (Continued on Page 54) and enables him, through the machine, to attack far stronger opponents than he could on his own.
The business of predicting chess outcomes is greatly facilitated by an international rating scheme called the FIDE system, based upon performance in sanctioned tournaments. Deep Thought's rating would be approximately 2450-2500, which places it among the top 30 players in the country. Kasparov's rating, recently elevated to about 2800, is the highest in the history of ratings - he has exceeded even Bobby Fischer in his prime. Uncertainties arise, however, when a machine rather than a person is being evaluated. Deep Thought has achieved some signal victories, including one over the Danish veteran Bent Larsen, once a contender for world champion. But how much were these the product of intrinsic prowess, and how much of human jitteriness before a radically unfamiliar opponent? Of course Kasparov is not immune to nerves, either. There is nothing to say he won't find himself rattled by a machine adversary and play far below strength - in which case, Deep Thought could finesse the odds and seize a victory. ''I'll tell you one thing,'' says a member of our party: ''If Deep Thought wins the first game, there won't be a second game. Gary will refuse to play.''
The two-game match takes place at the New York Academy of Art, an unexpectedly appropriate site for a chess contest. Much of the artwork on display in the academy's auditorium depicts fragments of the human body: Here are drawings and sculptures of a hand, a torso, a head. The effect is a view of humanity as an assemblage of component parts - just the perspective fostered by the match. For we can see this encounter as a contest of mind versus mind, the two antagonists unburdened of bodily limitations. Chess has a physical side, naturally. At the championship level, mental demands are so exorbitant that only the fit of body are likely to stand up under them. Kasparov is an avid sportsman who enjoys tennis, soccer and long-distance swimming. Yet the game's physical dimension is something chess players are always working to overcome. (Continued on Page 58) It is a commonplace of chess literature that the advance toward mastery involves a process of neutralizing one's surroundings. The better the player, the less aware he'll be of his environment - a freedom rendered dramatically manifest whenever experts play multiple or blindfold games. Even a middling chess player may catch inklings of a state of mind in which the corporeal is transcended.
Ironically, this exalted state resembles the ''mind-set'' from which a computer commences play. It ''listens'' only to its own mathematical language of evaluation. It has no idea that the game involves actual pieces. In fact, it has no idea that it is playing a game. In many ways, Deep Thought looks like chess apotheosized: a show of skill enacted on a plane purified of such distractions as lighting and noise, mood and personality, victory and defeat.
Deep Thought may be a long shot, but going into the first game it has three sizable advantages. Under the terms of the match, photographers and camera crews will be allowed free reign during the first eight minutes, which obviously cannot disturb Deep Thought but may rattle Kasparov; the machine has been assigned White in Game One and Black in Game Two, and so will have the first move to begin with; and each side will be allowed only 90 minutes in all. Since this is a fraction of the time allotted in an ordinary tournament game, Kasparov might find such an irregularity unsettling.
The game begins; Kasparov hunches under the popping lights. He is a darkly good-looking man, the only child of a Jewish father, who died when the boy was 7, and an Armenian mother. His is a face that was made for brooding. Within moments he is very deep in thought.
In sharp contrast Hsu, who sits across from Kasparov, maintains a relaxed demeanor behind his computer keyboard. At this point, his job is largely secretarial: a matter of recording moves and serving as a liaison between Kasparov and Deep Thought. Concentration for Kasparov is not to be equated with immobility, and as time wears on he ranges through an impressive variety of gestures. He shrugs his shoulders, pops his knuckles, drums his fingers, scratches his forehead, chews his nails, clenches his jaw; and yet, for all this activity, the game unfolds quietly. What becomes evident after 18 or so moves to the best players - and there are a number of grandmasters present - can be seen by almost everyone a dozen moves later: Kasparov has wrested control of the game. Deep Thought - in the person of Hsu - resigns on the 53d move.
Before resting up for the second game, Kasparov briefly addresses the crowd upstairs. He is clearly in high spirits. His talk is exultant to the point of grandiosity. ''I can't visualize living with the knowledge that a computer is stronger than the human mind,'' he says; to challenge the machine is to ''protect the human race.''
ONE MIGHT SIMPLY ATTRIBUTE such remarks to the monomania of champions in almost any field; but this would fail to explain the sympathetic hearing they receive. Perhaps the deepest impression left by the first game is of the audience's partisan fervor. Deep Thought is disliked. Upstairs, where talking is permitted, its play is treated to scorn and condescension from the start. And as Kasparov begins to crush the machine, the crowd's contempt turns into catcalls, laughter, hoots of incredulous contempt. There is something both appealingly loyal and disturbingly delusive about this response. The simple truth is that Deep Thought could squelch all but a tiny handful of the chess fanatics assembled here. So why is the audience so worked up? In part, it's a matter of simple identification with a hero; people would feel many of the same tensions if Kasparov's opponent were a human being. But the match engages the spectator on another level as well, roping in even those few who (like some of the photographers) scarcely know how the pieces move. For everyone understands winning and losing.
Not that chess is like other games. Whoever wins at pinball or Asteroids or Nintendo has gained a qualified victory, one undermined by the certainty that it arises only through the machine's ''mercy.'' No one doubts that a pinball machine or video game could be constructed against which the human hand and eye would flounder. Chess is different. At present, it may provide the only activity in the world in which an all-out struggle between man and machine is a fair fight. In chess, the best human beings and the best machines possess capabilities both similar enough to allow meaningful competition and diverse enough to insure that the outcome is not a foregone conclusion. Their battle recalls Roman gladiatorial days, when a lively asymmetry was achieved by equipping one combatant with net and trident and the other with sword and shield.
The question the chessboard continually poses, for both man and machine, is a straightforward one: What is my strongest move? Yet if they pursue the same end, they go about it in radically divergent ways. Given the brain's relative slowness, a man can scrutinize no more than an infinitesimal fraction of the moves available at any juncture. In the typical case, his decision is bifurcated: He will first determine, by a somewhat mysterious process called intuition, a small number of plausible candidates for the optimal move - perhaps as few as two - and then study these possibilities at great depth, narrowing his choice from the few to the one. A machine like Deep Thought, conversely, will look at every possible move - however unlikely or even transparently inane many of these may be. This process of exhaustive investigation is called a ''brute force'' search, as opposed to an intuition-simulating ''selective'' search.
Partly because intuition has eluded machines, and partly because it represents an area of the psyche especially difficult to describe or categorize, many chess players have seen in it a final, impregnable defense against the incursions of the machine. Kasparov said as much a few years ago: ''If a computer can beat the world champion, the computer can read the best books in the world, can write the best plays, and can know everything about history and literature and people. That's impossible.'' About 10 years ago, when even the best computers were fodder to a grandmaster, a study was carried out in which many top international players estimated the proficiency that computers might eventually achieve. Despite variations in expertise, a consistent pattern emerged: respondents tended to envision computers reaching a level of play about 50 points below (Continued on Page 65) their own. Such results no doubt reflect a characteristic need among highly competitive people to assert their superiority. But they probably also reflect a heartfelt conviction that chess, when carried out at the highest and most rigorous levels, is so shaped by inexplicable promptings - by creative or mystical or artistic impulses - that a mere machine could never master it.
In fact, computer ratings have continued to go up. Each time computers have crossed a new threshold, various chess experts have speculated that some sort of natural ceiling had been reached and that without human intuition they could not climb much higher. But computers have steadily shown that mere acceleration may be a satisfactory substitute. The human realm - a realm supposedly inaccessible to machines - turns out to be more vulnerable than we thought. In years to come, the descendants of machines like Deep Thought will doubtless compel us to examine the nature and importance of human intuition. The rise of the chess computer conclusively demonstrates that at least for those tasks in which a narrowly defined objective is formulable (as in chess, where every goal is subordinate to checkmating your opponent), and in which all possible lines of behavior can be charted (every contingency in chess can be set out in a simple, if astronomically vast, diagram), intuition may be a useful but expendable tool. To be able to scan all possibilities on a chess board, you don't need to be smart in the usual sense. You can be dumb, in fact, provided you're fast - blindingly, electronically fast. Deep Thought makes us ask, What next? Which areas in our lives, in our ''history and literature and people,'' might prove accessible to the brute force of a monster number-cruncher?
 PLAYING WHITE IN THE second and final game, Kasparov lashes out fiercely. He plays a Queen's Gambit, in which White offers its queen's bishop pawn in exchange for a firm position on the board's center; and when Deep Thought accepts the pawn, Kasparov advances his king's pawn two spaces - an aggressive line. By the 10th move, with the game still theoretically in its preliminary stages, Kasparov has managed to do something to Deep Thought that no one has ever done: made it look silly. His forces are powerfully posted; Deep Thought has just gotten started. The game is essentially over before it has begun.
Kasparov handles a microphone with much the same assurance he brings to his chess moves; in his brief victory speech, he notes that the computer still has ''a lot to learn,'' including ''how to resign.'' His closing lines are graceful and ingratiating: ''When playing versus a human being there's energy going between us. Today I was puzzled because I felt no opponent, no energy - kind of like a black hole, into which my energy could disappear. But I discovered a new source of energy, from the audience to me, and I thank you very much for this enormous energy supply.''
In the next day or two, most newspaper accounts of the match will present an upbeat report on Deep Thought's performance - acknowledging Kasparov's easy triumph but predicting that in a few years' time the outcome may be different. On the night of the match, though, feelings are a good deal less sanguine - at least among those closest to the machines. Summing up the match, Campbell explains to a circle of journalists: ''This was a very clear demonstration of one of the weaknesses of the program. We'd seen glimpses of it before, but this was an exceptionally clear and well-conceived exhibit of Deep Thought's lack of long-range planning. It's a huge problem.''
After the match I talk with Monty Newborn, a professor of computer science at McGill University, and Hans Berliner of Carnegie-Mellon. One reads so frequently that computer science is still a discipline in its infancy that it comes as something of an illumination to talk with men who measure their research not in terms of months and years but of decades. Newborn is 51 and has been active in the field for 20 years. Berliner is 60. In addition to chess programming, he designed a backgammon-playing computer - which defeated the human world champion in 1979. These days, he is a designer of Hitech, after Deep Thought the world's strongest chess computer. Berliner probably has no peer in the world when it comes to a dual grasp of chess theory and of the technicalities of computer-chess programming - and tonight he comes away disheartened. He has long been an optimist about chess computers. When I met him, in 1986, he foresaw equality in five years.
Things look different tonight. ''I really expected to see Deep Thought get at least one draw,'' he admits, and adds that he certainly hadn't expected to see Kasparov win so effortlessly. Kasparov simply saw farther, ''much, much farther,'' than the machine. And while Berliner says he would still bet that a serious machine challenger will appear in three or four years, he recognizes that the existing hardware is limited, and he allows the possibility that man will ''still be master at the end of the century.''
I MEET KASPAROV AND his business manager, an Englishman named Andrew (Continued on Page 74) Page, for breakfast on the morning after the match. (Kasparov's business interests are large and, in the days of glasnost, growing. In addition to his substantial fees - the $10,000 he received for battling Deep Thought is said to be typical - he has endorsed a chess computer and Schweppes tonic water.) A first encounter with the world champion comes as something of a surprise. In view of the stereotype of the chess genius as an insular eccentric, he seems unexpectedly normal. One might even say disappointingly normal, since the notion dies hard that chess achievement of his magnitude is purchased only at the cost of a diminished aptitude for daily life. That a world chess champion could present himself as witty and engaging and intellectually broad - as Kasparov does - seems patently unfair.
''I am a man of many interests,'' he acknowledges. Last summer he gave an interview to Playboy in which he tossed out blistering condemnations of Soviet economic policy, social policy, the unreliability of the media and pre-glasnost mores (''Intellectual life was frozen, and sexual life, too''). Clearly proud of his openness, Kasparov relishes the chance to speak out broadly, and confesses that a future in politics ''may be inevitable.'' All the more curious, then, is his unwillingness to entertain hypothetical questions about his chess career. When I ask what he might have become if chess had never been invented, he counters with, ''But it was.'' What would have happened if he'd lost a sixth game to Karpov in their first encounter? ''But I didn't.'' And if the computer had defeated him yesterday? ''Oh, it couldn't.''
It seems peculiar that a man who makes his living by exploring unfollowed contingencies - roads not taken - should resist such hypotheticals, but Kasparov has strong feelings about Fate. ''I was fated to be world champion,'' he explains, with an odd but characteristic mixture of forcefulness and merriment. ''You ask would I eventually have become champion anyway, if I'd lost a sixth game to Karpov? But you see, I was fated not to lose a sixth game.'' The thought amuses him enormously.
Did the pressure ever get to him? Any trouble sleeping before a match? ''Andrew should answer that one,'' he replies, and calls across the table, ''Do I have trouble sleeping before a match?'' ''Oh, he has a problem sleeping all right,'' Andrew reports. ''Put him on a sofa for five minutes, or in a taxi, or in an armchair, and he falls asleep. It's a terrible problem.'' Both men laugh. They have every reason for feeling ebullient this morning. Yesterday's match has brought Kasparov more attention than any event since the last world championship. He's on the front page of every newspaper they've seen so far. He scans the articles with good-humored interest. One quotation, from Murray Campbell, particularly delights him: ''Deep Thought didn't get a chance to show what it can do.'' Kasparov reads this aloud. ''But that's exactly the point!'' he exclaims. ''I didn't let it. The highest art of the chess player lies in not allowing your opponent to show you what he can do.''
AT THE MOMENT , Kasparov reigns over the board as no one has for decades. Karpov, his predecessor as world champion, shared his crown with a ghost - that of the notoriously temperamental Bobby Fischer, from whom Karpov received it by default. None of the postwar champions who predated Fischer was ever more than first among equals. Looking back, one has to go a long way to find a suitable counterpart to Kasparov; looking forward, one may find none at all. At 26, he could plausibly hold his title for 10 or 15 more years - by which point even conservative computer scientists expect to see machines surpass the best human players. He reigns without peer, human or mechanical - a privilege that none of his successors may ever know.
The arrival of an unbeatable machine will hardly be a death knell to human players. The game will go on as before; there will still be human tournaments, flush with all the anguish and exultation of old. But psychology at the uppermost echelons will be irreversibly altered. Not even the world champion will be allowed a sense of untrammeled superiority. Kasparov is perhaps the last of a kind.
The new machines will represent triumphs of human doggedness and ingenuity, and we owe it to ourselves to acclaim their makers. But we also owe it to ourselves to grasp that within the transitional terrain we have now entered, where machines rapidly close in upon the human world champion, something inspiring is passing away. If we have reached the last world champion to whose name no asterisk is attached - the one who was champion of all and everything - it is heartening that this should prove to be Gary Kasparov. For he is a man who has not only climbed Everest but stood on its summit as though he belonged there.

HEADLINE: BLOOMING WHILE THE SUN WENT DOWN

BYLINE: By LEON BOTSTEIN; Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College, is the author of a forthcoming book on the social history of music in 19th-century Vienna.

 BODY:

THE JEWS OF VIENNA IN THE AGE OF FRANZ JOSEPH
By Robert S. Wistrich.
Illustrated. 696 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $79.
Americans and Western Europeans have been fascinated with the art and culture of Vienna for a decade, and there have been many books written about the old Hapsburg capital. But Robert Wistrich's exemplary scholarly analysis of the Viennese Jewish community in the 19th century is the first well-written, reliable study of its kind. It is devoid of the cloying sentimentality and tendentiousness that characterize most writings on Vienna and the Jews, and it provides a vital corrective to our understanding of the Viennese fin de siecle. Although the book closes with a sensitive discussion of how their Jewish identity influenced certain of the Viennese who were seminal in the development of 20th-century culture (Karl Kraus, Sigmund Freud, Arthur Schnitzler, Stefan Zweig and Joseph Roth), most of it is devoted to aspects of Viennese Jewish life that have been overlooked. 
At the outset, Mr. Wistrich, who teaches history at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, documents the stunning growth of Vienna's Jewish population. Between 1860 and 1910, primarily through migration from Bohemia, Moravia and Galicia, the number of Jews grew from 6,000 to over 175,000 - from just over 1 percent of the city's population to 9 percent. During this time the three leading Viennese rabbis - Isaac Noah Mannheimer, Adolf Jellinek and Moritz Gudemann - created and sustained a particular and quite Viennese synthesis of Jewish orthodoxy, secular Western learning and Austro-German patriotism. This accommodation set the tone for the posture of pride and patriotism assumed by most Viennese Jews towards the Hapsburg monarchy and Vienna. Socialism and Zionism caught the imaginations of some younger people at the turn of the century, but most Viennese Jews remained true Hapsburg loyalists, supporters of the crown and of the ideal of a multinational constitutional monarchy.
Within the Jewish community, the tremendous immigration from other parts of the empire and the rapid increase in the number of Jews who acquired wealth produced strains. The established community leadership would not democratize Jewish organizations to accommodate the new, mostly poor, immigrants. And the new rich did not sustain the historic tie between Jews and progressive politics. Thus, when strident popular anti-Semitism arose in the city's cultural and political life in the 1880's and 90's, the Jewish leadership had no influence or power in the new mass politics; it clung to its conservative, outdated brand of liberalism.
Mr. Wistrich gives elegant portraits of the crucial Jewish figures of the new Viennese politics at the turn of the century, including, of course, Theodor Herzl. Nathan Birnbaum was the gifted but eclectic and erratic Jewish politician who coined the term ''Zionism'' but later broke with Herzl, abandoning political Zionism to champion - as did Martin Buber and Joseph Roth - the Yiddish culture of the shtetl. Joseph Bloch was a maverick politician, journalist and Orthodox eastern European rabbi who challenged the official Jewish leadership and organized an aggressive strategy of self-help among middle-class Jews against the rising tide of Viennese anti-Semitism in the 80's. Bloch used the courts successfully to defeat slanderous misrepresentations of the Talmud by such Catholic leaders as the Rev. August Rohling and to fight recurrent accusations of Jewish ritual murder in parts of the empire.
Throughout ''The Jews of Vienna in the Age of Franz Joseph'' Mr. Wistrich places the history of this one group in the context of the history of Jews in all the German-speaking countries, and of contemporary economic and political changes in central Europe. In the last third of the century, Jews rose rapidly in commerce and culture. Those who played a leading role in Vienna had lived there relatively briefly; most of the key Jewish figures in the city in 1900 had not been born there. The profound acculturation and assimilation of Jews, and the striking assumption of leadership by Jews in the professions, the arts, journalism and science, despite powerful restrictive barriers, are tributes to the Jews and to the dynamism of the opportunity they encountered.
At the beginning of the 19th century, anti-Semitism was common among Viennese aristocrats, but a gradual process of Jewish emancipation was already under way. And throughout the century the multinational Hapsburg empire, more than any other continental European power, offered a paternalistic, if not benign, context in which both separatist Jewish culture and assimilation could flourish. However, by 1900 the triumph of radical social and political anti-Semitism (despite the overt resistance of the Emperor Franz Joseph), particularly among the middle classes in Vienna, reflected new economic and social pressures exacerbated by industrialization and the strident conflict of nationalities within the empire. Anti-Semitism emerged as a virulent racist prejudice, justified by a political ideology directed at eradicating the ills of capitalism, liberalism and modernity. The successful identification, in Viennese politics, of the Jews with these presumed sources of all social, moral and political evil provided an explosive political formula that would serve later as a model for the Nazis.
Mr. Wistrich's focus on the internal history of the highly diversified Jewish community enables him to reconstruct the attitudes of Jewish university students and to chronicle the evolution of various Jewish nationalist movements in Vienna before and after Zionism, particularly the first Jewish national fraternity, the Kadimah. He analyzes effectively the genesis of Herzl's Zionism from within the Viennese context. Although his sympathies for Zionism are clear, he is respectful of Jewish critics of Zionism. What is refreshing in his narrative is the absence of retrospective critical moralizing about assimilation and the remarkable participation of Jews in German culture. Assimilated Jewish aristocrats and intellectuals, even Jews who converted to Christianity, are presented with as much evenhandedness as those Viennese Jewish nationalists and traditionalist theologians whose mistrust of assimilation and acculturation as reliable defenses against prejudice seems to have been vindicated by the Holocaust.
''The Jews of Vienna in the Age of Franz Joseph'' is not merely a descriptive history of Viennese Jewry. It vindicates the centrality of Jewishness and anti-Semitism as dynamic and changing forces in the evolution of 19th-century Austro-German politics and culture. Czechs, Poles, Slovenes, Hungarians and Germans in the Hapsburg realm shared a scapegoat, the Jews, for their economic, political and cultural frustrations. Viennese Jews, in turn, whatever their psychological or social strategy toward the Jewish question, could never forget or avoid the issue.
Our current attraction to Vienna at the turn of the century - to its legendary mix of intellectual and esthetic radicalism, antiliberal pessimism and decadent behavior - may reflect only our fear that we too live in a culture in decline. Mr. Wistrich's book stimulates some different reflections.
As America and its large cities confront a growing ethnic diversity in which color remains the dominant basis for racial discrimination, we need to understand how Europe in the 19th century failed to deal successfully with its central racial prejudice, that against the Jews. The influence of anti-Semitism on social structure, political ideology and the history of ideas before 1914 was so central that anti-Semitism still retains a remarkable hold on the populations of central and Eastern Europe - even where there are no Jews left. The recent revolutionary political events there, including the explosion of nationalist sentiment - combined as they are with the call for freedom and democracy - should not obscure nationalism's nasty side.
This book reminds one that a century ago there were people in Vienna who idealized diaspora Jewry as the harbinger of a civilized world free of nationalistic strife, violence and racial prejudice. And it provides a framework in which to evaluate the dramatic shift in the international appraisal of Judaism and Zionism not only during the past century, but since the establishment of Israel in 1948. When Herzl proposed a Jewish state in 1896, some of the Viennese Jews worried that embracing Zionism would cost the Jews their diaspora heritage of spirituality, reason, humanism and cosmopolitanism that resulted from their having no homeland. The existence now of Jews as ordinary citizens of a modern Jewish nation, and the the rise of Israeli nationalism, throw a new light on that ideal; one might conceive nostalgia for it. The book can also alert us to a modern anti-Zionism that is no more than a thinly veiled variation of fin de siecle anti-Semitism.
And it speaks to people who are concerned with the issues of Jewish assimilation and identity in the United States. The large and successful Viennese Jewish community struggled with conflicting notions of Jewish identity - as a citizen with merely a different religion, a secular member of a separate nation and race, or an assimilated citizen with only a different ancestry. The modern quarrel among Jews about who is a Jew and whether assimilation is desirable or even possible can be compared usefully with the varieties of Jewish responses Mr. Wistrich chronicles for Vienna. It is clear that neither Herzl nor Karl Kraus (an extreme assimilationist and convert) nor the anti-Zionist religious Orthodox Jews of Vienna were right, in the light of history. The acculturated Viennese Jew who had contempt for the shtetl Jew from Galicia had no more claim to be on the side of historical progress than did the Orthodox Viennese Jew who regarded the leading Jewish figures of Viennese science, culture and art - such as Kraus, Arnold Schoenberg or Gustav Mahler - as self-deluded apostates.
Mr. Wistrich's poignant narrative reminds us that the struggle for civic equality, social acceptance and economic security by the Jews of 19th-century Vienna resulted, among other things, in a steady stream of diverse and unforgettable contributions to art, science and culture. The symbiosis of Jews and Austro-German culture in Vienna produced convincing exemplars of genuine cosmopolitanism and refined secular culture committed to the power of knowledge, the sanctity of art and language and the possibilities of universal tolerance and political equality. Two crucial personalities who came out of the Jewish population of Vienna - Freud and Ludwig Wittgenstein - were motivated, in part, by contradictions within the dominant liberal Viennese Jewish credo. They inspired much of our own century's engagement with the issues of meaning, language and truth. Even if the hopes implicit in the political and social struggle of the Jews of Vienna before 1914 were dashed finally by the violence of Nazism, Mr. Wistrich's book is a moving reminder of what high hopes they were.
 
'THE ISRAELITES ARE GOOD PATRIOTS'
 To the civil patriotism which had become the bedrock of post-emancipation Judaism throughout Europe, Austrian Jews added the dimension of unshakeable dynastic loyalty and devotion, which grew into a veritable cult. . . . This imperial patriotism was nourished from the pulpit, in the Jewish press, at public gatherings, and on commemorative occasions. The imperial-royal loyalty of the Jews stood moreover in sharp contrast to the centrifugal forces of Slavic nationalism and feudal particularism. Most significant of all, the civil religion of dynastic patriotism became a central feature in the defence strategy of the Jewish establishment, threatened as it was after 1880 by the new force of organized political anti-Semitism. . . . In 1882, when the Austrian anti-Semitic movement was celebrating its first Jew-baiting orgy, the Emperor had indeed declared to his Ministers: ''I will tolerate no Judenhetze [Jew-baiting] in my Empire.'' . . . Franz Joseph I increasingly appeared to Austrian Jews as their guardian angel, custodian, and patron saint. . . . By the 1880s it must be said that the darkening situation of Austrian Jews had begun to encourage a more positive view of the Habsburgs as uniquely benevolent custodians and patrons of Jewry, under whose blessed sceptre they had always enjoyed protection against medieval blood-libels, clerical fanaticism, and mob rule. Franz Joseph I now became, in Jewish eyes, an inheritor of this gracious, merciful, and benign Habsburg tradition, a monarch who outshone not only his illustrious predecessors but also all contemporary princely rulers of Europe in his respect for religious tolerance and justice.
 
From ''The Jews of Vienna in the Age of Franz Joseph.''

HEADLINE: A JOURNAL OF A PLAGUED LIFE

BYLINE: By PAT ROGERS; Pat Rogers, the DeBartolo Professor in the Liberal Arts at the University of South Florida, has edited a new abridgment of Daniel Defoe's ''Tour Through Great Britain.''

 BODY:

DANIEL DEFOE
His Life.
By Paula R. Backscheider.
Illustrated. 671 pp. Baltimore:
The Johns Hopkins University Press. $29.95.
Today biographers often know too much about their subjects, at least for their own comfort. The major figures of history have left abundant records of their being - in journals, letters or confessional statements in their art. So we admire one biographer for her tactful abridgment of this, another for his discreet avoidance of that, and a third for squeezing the whole of Henry James into four volumes. 
It is not like that with Daniel Defoe. He lived such a shifty subterranean life that many of the basic facts have still to be established. His letters are mostly confined to one period of his life and they never mention his best-known books, like ''Robinson Crusoe'' and ''Moll Flanders''; they are almost innocent of reference to his art. He left no journals and no profession of faith. His intimate being has to be reconstructed like a Dead Sea scroll. He wrote maybe 400 books and pamphlets, maybe 600 - but the retort ''who's counting?'' freezes on our lips, because the bibliographers are counting. The greatest debate in current Defoe scholarship concerns this very question of the scale and makeup of the canon. He is a great writer whose very oeuvre shifts before our gaze.
It was brave of Paula R. Backscheider, a professor of English at the University of Rochester, to take on the herculean task of a full new life. Brave but timely, for we have not had a serious chronological account of Defoe's career since the one by James Sutherland, originally published in 1937, though there have been popular versions and a large grab-bag of biographical materials, thematically organized, which John Robert Moore put out in 1956. Ms. Backscheider supplants both, as well as her three-decker Victorian predecessors, in the wealth of detail she has assembled and in her comprehensive grasp of the religious, political and economic setting. The density of her documentation is at first sight forbidding, but it is all there for a purpose. For the first time everything we know, or can reasonably surmise, about Defoe is presented in a single orderly sequence.
Of course there are still large gaps, and the story refuses to be altogether orderly, since Defoe lived such a jumbled life, with a literary output marked by syncopations and sudden backtracks. Bred for the ministry, he promptly turned himself into what the author calls a ''secular capitalist.'' He suddenly emerges as a member of the Duke of Monmouth's army at Sedgemoor (the last major battle fought on English soil, in 1685). It was of course the losing side, and Defoe barely escaped with a royal pardon - a fact that typically lay hidden until 20 years ago. He went into trade and engaged in a variety of more or less shady enterprises, from the wholesale hosiery business to farming civet cats (for perfume) to brick manufacture. Few professional writers have strayed very much beyond the printing trade or advertising or the learned professions. An occasional artist like Wallace Stevens or Charles Ives may have worked in an insurance office, but this is conventional beside Defoe's crazy venture into marine insurance during a time of naval warfare. The outcome was a succession of lawsuits, mostly revealing Defoe's sharp practices and mania for imprudent borrowing; ultimately bankruptcy followed, with a spell in the debtor's jail.
In all these matters Ms. Backscheider's treatment is exemplary. She has been able to add only a few details on the endless battles in the courts of Chancery and the Exchequer, but they are often telling. She tells us what hose-factors actually did, and how the brick-making business was affected by seasonal factors - hence the company's downfall at a time when Defoe was in prison (''Defoe's workers continued to lack supervision in the critical months between March and September when bricks were molded, dried, and heated and slaked in clamps and when pantiles were made from kneaded, sieved, and precipitated clay''). She has a remarkable hold on financial realities, and this comes in useful later when the complex machinations of the South Sea bubble entrap Defoe, like so many others. She fills out our understanding of Defoe as a land speculator - late in life he bought large estates near Colchester, with dreams of raising cattle and growing corn, but also (with his usual dispersed energy) of selling honey, oysters and anchovies.
Over all Ms. Backscheider has a clear sense of her subject. She sees him as one constantly beset by reversals: ''The most traumatic, influential experience of Defoe's life was not the pillory'' (where he arrived after his ironic book ''The Shortest Way With the Dissenters'') ''but his bankruptcy.'' But she also sees him as a courageous Protestant hero, and she does something to revive the unfashionable view that he was a prime intellectual architect of Britain's surge to colonial and economic power. His ''boringly mundane'' financial failure left its mark on all his work, but so did his sense of religious persecution as a dissenter. In only one area does she nod: she confuses printers and publishers in uncharacteristically slapdash fashion, and in one paragraph jumbles up all the crucial relationships between members of the book trade.
Elsewhere she is sure-footed and well primed, whether on Defoe's relations with the equally devious and secretive Robert Harley, a Tory politician who employed Defoe as his agent and spy, or on the impact of Defoe's dissenting education. There is no full literary assessment of major works like ''Moll Flanders'' or the ''Tour Through Great Britain'' - but Ms. Backscheider is, candidly, a smarter biographer than a critic, and anyway we have readings of these things elsewhere, almost to saturation. What she does give us is a searching study of a complex man, one that is coherent and credible for our times. Practically anyone can forge a shapely narrative out of a regular life and a tidy body of work. It is Paula Backscheider's considerable achievement to have made an enticing story out of a jerky and often obscure career.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Downtown Brooklyn;
Creating a Critical Mass at Metrotech

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
BY a curious quirk of timing in the mid-70's, Citibank found itself building the imposing Citicorp Center project at Lexington Avenue and East 53d Street when new office construction generally in Manhattan was tomb silent.
Entering the 1990's, the market generally is far healthier than it was then. But with much newly built space still unspoken for and with financial and other service firms leery about plunging into expensive building programs, the forecast is for a winding down in new office-construction starts in Manhattan this year and next.
And that may leave downtown Brooklyn in the countercyclical position that in the end benefited Citicorp Center in the 70's. For that neighborhood, in the cliche of the business, is in the process of ''taking off'' in new office construction. The bulk of the space in the buildings was spoken for before construction began, so this is not a case of speculative miscalculation. And the largest project of all, the Chase Financial Center, with 1.5 million square feet in two buildings, will be fully occupied by Chase itself. 
But the total effect, contrasted with the relative quiescence in Manhattan, will be to make Brooklyn the center of office construction in New York City in the early 90's. With excavation for the Chase buildings still about a month away, it may still be a year before the full impact of this concentration of new construction is apparent. By then, additional projects may be committed.
It is too early to say whether the leasing market will respond by taking new space in Brooklyn - at prices that are perhaps a third lower than Manhattan's. What is clear is that for the first time New York City is developing new space to compete for back-office operations of banks and financial firms with comparable space in northern New Jersey.
As Merrill Lynch & Company demonstrated last June in its decision to move 2,600 jobs to a new building on the site of the former Colgate-Palmolive soap factory in Jersey City, the Brooklyn alternative will not capture every major back-office tenant for New York City. But it has made the city more competitive.
On financial grounds, according to Michael P. Esposito, chief financial officer of Chase, the bank was ''cost neutral'' between New Jersey and New York City by the time it finished the negotiations that led it to choose Brooklyn. He also said that 40 percent of Chase's clerical staff already lives in Brooklyn.
The Brooklyn construction is all part of Metrotech, conceived ultimately as a 4.7-million-square-foot commercial, academic and high-technology office complex on a 10-block, 16-acre site. The tract lies between Jay Street and Flatbush Avenues on the west and east, and Tech Place and Willoughby Street on the north and south.
The office development is linked with the renovation and expansion of Polytechnic University, which is a partner of the developer, Forest City Ratner Companies. A major element in the university's building program, construction of a new library, is to begin in March. Lehrer McGovern Bovis Inc., is the Metrotech construction manager.
Forest City's 500,000-square-foot, 10-story, red-brick building for the Securities Industries Automation Corporation is about 60 percent complete. The tenant is leasing 350,000 square feet. Of the rest of the space, 80,000 square feet has been spoken for by a bank and a computer user, said Bruce Ratner, president of Forest City Ratner, although leases have not been concluded.
Foundation work has started next door on an 850,000-square-foot, 23-story headquarters building for the Brooklyn Union Gas Company. There, 400,000 square feet will be available for other tenants.
BROOKLYN enthusiasts have long contended that the borough's basic problem in attracting office tenants has been the lack of a ''critical mass'' of new construction. Now the mass is being created. But will it be enough?
Forest City believes that upgraded retail space is also required. Accordingly, it has contracted to buy the 10-year old Albee Square Mall, about three blocks from Metrotech on the Fulton Street Mall, to bring ''upscale retail'' operators into it, Mr. Ratner said. The mall has 155,000 square feet of space, of which all but 6,000 square feet is leased.
Lacking the critical mass, downtown Brooklyn has floundered. An example of that is the long postponed Renaissance Plaza, Alexander Muss & Company's name for the mixed-use hotel and office building it has tried for two years to start building on the site of a former municipal garage between Jay and Adams Streets.
Hilton Hotel is prepared to operate a 360-room hotel in the building, which William Tabler designed. But a major tenant for perhaps 250,000 square feet in the 600,000-square-foot office component is needed before construction can start. Two tenants came close to signing on - most recently the American Insurance Group - but then bowed out. ''I was like a bride left at the altar,'' said Joshua Muss, principal in Alexander Muss.
Now, with so much work proceeding on Metrotech, there is new interest, he said. ''I'm talking to 19 users who need 100,000 square feet or more,'' he said.
ALSO talking is Mr. Ratner, who was given a 50,000-square-foot city-owned site on Jay Street when Forest City yielded the Metrotech land that Chase bought, using favorable financing, for its operations center. On the Jay Street site, still occupied by city offices, Forest City is offering to build someone a one-million-square foot office building with 31 floors of 25,000 to 48,000 square feet. David Childs of Skidmore Owings & Merrill is the senior design partner.
Beyond that Metrotech has approved sites for an additional 1.4 million square feet of space.
If all this succeeds, no small debt will be owed to the Chase decision to come to Brooklyn. To bring it about, the city provided incentives of two types, as-of-right, or those that are available to any employer who decides to move from Manhattan to one of the other boroughs, and discretionary, or negotiated specifically for this move. The city estimated the total value of the incentive package over 25 years at $230 million.
The incentives include an as-of-right, 13-year total exemption on real estate taxes, phasing in to full taxes over the subsequent 10 years; a $10.9 million as-of-right savings on energy costs over 12 years; an as-of-right corporate-tax credit of $500 for each relocating employee; an exemption from sales taxes on the purchase of some equipment, for which Chase qualified because it is using industrial revenue bond financing, and a $15 million capital-budget contribution for site improvements. There also is a savings on energy through the Power Authority of the State of New York, estimated at $25 million.
CHASE is buying the land through the city's Industrial Development Agency, which will mean annual payments of $750,000 and a $7.5 million balloon payment in the 25th year, when Chase will acquire title.
New York City estimated the value of the as-of-right savings in these incentives at $137 million over 25 years, and of the additional state and city incentives at $68 million in the same period. The savings on energy through the Power Authority of the State of New York were estimated at $25 million.
The true benefits of building a new downtown office hub in Brooklyn are calculated not merely in dollars or even jobs, but also, it might be said, spiritually. Growth in an older, economically stagnant urban center redeems the aspirations and efforts of its community for a better future. Nevertheless, the city estimates that the Chase move will generate about $3.8 billion in economic activity over the 25-year period.

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
South Norwalk Waterfront Plan Moving

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
A MASTER PLAN to turn SoNo, the restored waterfront of the South Norwalk neighborhood, into one of Connecticut's prime tourist attractions is advancing with surprising brio in view of a recession-prone economy.
Last month final approvals were granted by Norwalk for the newest component - conversion of the vacant old City Hall on Main Street into what Robert Katz, its developer, describes as a ''mini-theme hotel.'' Now the hard part begins - arranging for $17 million in financing. The converted 16,500-square-foot City Hall will be called the Maritime Inn and be keyed to the atmosphere created by the $30 million Maritime Center a block away on Water Street overlooking the Norwalk River and harbor. It will house the lobby and registration desk, restaurant, bar, health club, kitchen and employee facilities. 
Its white-pillared entrance on Main Street will remain as a decorative artifact while a more impressive circular driveway and fountain will mark a new entrance around the corner on Marshall Street.
Behind the converted City Hall, an eight-story, 96-room hotel will rise. It will include a five-story atrium facing the water that will be soundproofed against the rattle of trains passing on the Danbury spur of Metro-North and three parking levels, one underground, that will accommodate 108 cars.
The doorman at the new entrance will be dressed as Long John Silver, with a live parrot on his shoulder.
''We want to accommodate tourists, families coming here for the weekend,'' said Mr. Katz, a Norwalk developer since 1950. ''We are not seeking business travelers, although they would be welcome.''
''We wholly support the project,'' said Rollo Gianannini, president of the 15-member City Council, ''because it will help draw people to Norwalk, help the Maritime Center and tie the area together with Washington Street.''
The Maritime Center, troubled by deficits in its first year, nonetheless attracted almost 400,000 people to its shark, fish and seal aquarium, marine and boating exhibits and educational exhibits. One block south is the Historic District on Washington Street, where eight years ago several abandoned 19th-century commercial buildings were remodeled into art galleries, boutiques, restaurants and condominiums. On weekends and holidays the area is clogged with visitors. Another element of the master plan is Maritime Square, a $70 million residential, office and restaurant complex on which construction by M. F. DiScala & Company, a local real estate concern, is to start early in 1990. It will back up to the new inn and front the Maritime Center at the end of Marshall Street.
The South Norwalk/Metro-North railroad station, three blocks from the inn, is scheduled for a $100 million expansion with a new station, housing, parking, theaters, restaurants and retail stores to be built by the Starrett Corporation of Manhattan.
''Once people park, they can walk everywhere,'' said Mr. Katz. He hopes to begin construction this spring and open 18 months later.
THE inn's 90 guest rooms, priced from $90 a night no matter how many people occupy what the developer calls suites (the range of prices has not been determined), will measure from 14 by 30 feet to 28 by 30 feet. Each will have two television sets and two bathrooms, one with a Jacuzzi, and sliding doors will separate its bedroom from the living room, which will have covertible sofas for children or guests as well as a refrigerator, sink and microwave oven.
In the larger rooms, there will be dining furniture and additional sleeping accommodations. Six penthouses will offer luxuries not yet worked out.
The architects are Valus and Carpenter Associates of Westport.
A second hotel, with 300 rooms, has been earmarked by the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, which controls the area, for a seven-acre parcel just north of the Maritime Center. It is for sale by the State Department of Transportation. ''This could be a good time to negotiate, with the market flat,'' said Mayor Frank J. Esposito. But the redevelopment agency estimates that a million square feet of new office space would be needed to support it.
The Fred F. French Realty Company of Manhattan has made a start in that direction by buying up 74,000 square feet of a block facing West Avenue at Reed Street, just west of the proposed hotel site. ''The city requires development of the entire block of 170,000 square feet,'' said Helmut Scholde, vice president. ''We are acquiring it gradually and intend to build about 340,000 square feet of offices.''
While the old City Hall is not the most prepossessing example of local architecture, Mr. Katz is abiding by the wishes of the Redevelopment Agency to preserve it. Built in 1912, it is one of 600 buildings, public art and oddments listed in the Norwalk Inventory of Historic Assets, a list that was drawn up by the local Historical Society in 1976 and that includes Stew Leonard's, the enormous supermarket-cum-funhouse on Route 1.
Next door to the inn is the Palace Theater, a vaudeville house built around 1916 and closed for decades. It is owned and operated by Palace Productions Center, a commercial television company whose president, Christopher Campbell, wanted to buy City Hall and expand into it. But Mr. Katz won out with a $1.2 million bid that the city accepted. He spent $1.7 million more on development costs. Now he is negotiating with Mr. Campbell to buy the theater and, he speculated, ''tie it in with the hotel, possibly as a conference center.''
Four existing hotels with 700 rooms in other parts Norwalk are not viewed as competition for Mr. Katz, but Thomas McConnell, manager of the hotel consulting division of Laventhal and Horwath, a Manhattan firm preparing a study of the district for Norwalk, said: ''Marketing an inn can be difficult. It's related to the ability to draw tourists.''
NORWALK officials have various opinions about what constitutes tourist attractions and recently gave Mort Walker, creator of the ''Beetle Bailey'' cartoon and founder of the Museum of Cartoon Art in Westchester, a mixed reception when he proposed moving his museum into a vacant building opposite the Maritime Center.
Mr. Katz views all this activity with enthusiasm but is concentrating on negotiating financing in a difficult time. ''The worst thing that could happen is the hotel doesn't get built,'' he said. ''I can't afford that.''

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Tin Pan Alley;
Rodgers & Hammerstein Is Moving to Broadway

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
THE cacophony of Tin Pin Alley has long been stilled, but enough of the music industry remains on Broadway to have lured the Rodgers & Hammerstein organization from Madison Avenue after four decades on the East Side.
The organization, which owns and licenses some of America's best-known musicals - ''The King and I,'' ''Sound of Music,'' ''Carousel'' and ''Oklahoma!'' among others - is scheduled to move this month into the Paramount Plaza Building at 1633 Broadway, between 50th and 51st Streets, one block north of the Brill Building, which used to be the center of music publishing.
Many music-related businesses had dispersed before the recent redevelopment of the blocks north of Times Square and others were displaced by demolition. But the industry is ''still largely between Times Square and Lincoln Center, although some of it is downtown,'' said Ken Sunshine, the manager of public relations for the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. Another music industry executive said that most music publishers could be found between 47th and 58th Streets. And a number of musical-instrument dealers are clustered on West 48th Street. 
''We looked all over the place,'' said Theodore S. Chapin, executive director of Rodgers & Hammerstein, ''but we kept going back to that corridor where the entertainment industry really is. Our business is focused on the theater and music. To be surrounded by it seemed to make sense.''
''Broadway is a community, a network, a small village,'' said Bert Fink, the director of special projects and public relations for Rodgers & Hammerstein. ''You run into people at the Edison Hotel coffee shop. You meet people on the elevator. You constantly run into business associates and friends. By being east of Fifth Avenue, we were on the other side of the moon.''
''From their new location, they can look out and see all the Broadway theaters,'' said Arthur H. Lerner, senior vice president and director of leasing for Helmsley-Spear, which represented Rodgers & Hammerstein in its search for new offices. ''Emotionally, and for every other reason, it's where they belong.''
Founded by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d in 1943, the organization controls the Rodgers and Hammerstein musicals, the major musicals by Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, some Hammerstein musicals (''Showboat,'' for example) and such other shows as Irving Berlin's ''Annie Get Your Gun.'' It licenses 3,000 productions a year, 600 of which are ''Oklahoma!'' It also has a music-publishing division and employs about 20 people in its Manhattan office.
At its founding, Rodgers & Hammerstein was at 1270 Sixth Avenue, at 51st Street, but a few years later moved to Madison in the lower 40's. Since 1960 it has occupied 4,500 square feet in 598 Madison Avenue, at 57th Street, paying a rent per square foot that Mr. Chapin said was in the low $40's. It has signed a 10-year-lease for 8,500 square feet on the 38th floor of Paramount Plaza, with a rent in the $30's, he said. There are few other, if any, music-related tenants in that skyscraper.
RODGERS & HAMMERSTEIN will sublet 2,500 square feet to the Really Useful Group P.L.C., of London, which owns the copyrights to the Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals ''Cats,'' ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' ''Starlight Express'' and ''Aspects of Love.'' John Whitney, the chief executive of the Really Useful Group, said that the choice of space had less to do with its Broadway address than with proximity to Rodgers & Hammerstein. ''I'm delighted we'll be joining them in an office that gives us the opportunity to have a dialogue without going through fax machines,'' he said.
That kind of closeness was the hallmark of the music business when it was much more centralized; when the Brill Building at 1619 Broadway, on the corner of 49th Street, was the 11-story embodiment of the songwriters' quarter called Tin Pan Alley.
Today, the 1650 Broadway building, at 51st Street, may the closest thing remaining to a vertical Tin Pan Alley or a Runyonesque hangout, a 12-story hive of small show-business offices. Among the tenants are Beaver Music, Creative Music Concepts, Dandy Dittys, Princess Music, Tiny Coots Music, Wazzie Music and We Three Music.
''It is probably the building in the area as far as Broadway-related corporations,'' said Steve Colavito, vice president of William Colavito, managing agent for 1650 Broadway. He said 90 percent of the tenants are involved in entertainment - music publishers and arrangers, talent agents and producers.
Unlike modern skyscrapers, 1650 Broadway has spaces as small as 350 square feet, for a two- to three-person office. Rents range from $25 to $28 a square foot, Mr. Colavito said. All told, there are some 100 tenants, from four to 10 on each floor.
''So many tenants in that building work closely with one another,'' Mr. Colavito said. ''They don't have to get on a train and go downtown. They just ring for the elevator and go two floors down.'' ''Despite all the advanced technology,'' said Mr. Sunshine, of ASCAP, ''it's still a people business, a human being writing music that needs to get published or recorded. The only way to do that is to meet somebody who can make it happen.''
Last summer, the Polygram record company moved its New York offices into 120,000 square feet at Worldwide Plaza on Eighth Avenue, between 49th and 50th Streets, five blocks from its old offices at 810 Seventh Avenue.
There, it is paying rent in the $30's, according to Peter E. Takiff, the executive vice president for administration. Polygram, owned by Philips N.V. of the Netherlands, has about 400 employees in mid-Manhattan.
''MY personal opinion is that we probably don't have to be in midtown,'' Mr. Takiff said, ''but there are advantages to being near other music businesses and law offices. I don't think our business would suffer if we weren't here. It's a matter of convenience.''
There is probably no better example of how the area has changed than the Brill Building itself. ''My guess,'' Mr. Takiff said, ''is that if you asked most record company employees under the age of 35 where the Brill Building is, they wouldn't know.''
''At one time, the Brill Building was nothing but music publishers,'' said Freddy Bienstock, president, chairman and chief executive officer of the Hudson Bay Music group of companies, the last major publisher left in the building. ''Songwriters would come to the 11th floor and make their way all the way down, peddling their songs, playing the piano.''
''When we took over the building in 1979, there were very few music publishers left,'' said David Gordon, vice president of Realty Group Ltd., managers of the Brill Building. ''A lot of the offices were used for undesirable businesses,'' he said, including the pornographic trade.
Mr. Bienstock said ''personal and sentimental'' reasons figured into his decision to stay in the Brill Building. ''My first and second employer had these premises,'' he said. ''I bought both of their businesses and remained in premises I'm familiar with.''
Economics also played a role. Thanks to a long lease, Mr. Bienstock pays $15 to $16 a square foot for about 6,000 square feet in the penthouse.
Hudson Bay, which also includes E. B. Marks and George M. Cohan Publishing, has shows like ''Cabaret,'' ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' ''Godspell'' and ''Company,'' as well as popular, jazz, classical and rock-and-roll titles.
Half of the Brill Building is occupied by the Sound One Corporation, a post-production sound studio for movies, specializing in sound effects, mixing, dubbing and even ''automatic dialogue replacement'' - the substitution of unoffensive words for profanity in movies that are to be broadcast on television.
On the ground floor is Colony Records, which has been there 21 years, specializing in out-of-print records and a 250,000-title sheet-music collection. (There is still a steady demand for ''Love Is Here to Stay,'' ''Cheek to Cheek'' and ''Blue Moon.'') ''As you look around and see everything coming down, this place stays here,'' said Norman Levy, the sheet-music buyer for Colony. ''People come in and say, 'We're glad you're here because no one else is around anymore.' This is the last remnant.''

GRAPHIC: Photos: Paramount Plaza on Broadway at 50th Street, rising over white Brill Building, center, once hub of Tin Pan Alley; Former office of Richard Rodgers being prepared for move. (The New York Times/Fred R. Conrad)
