HEADLINE: Mortgage Delinquencies Increasing

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
THE slump in the New York region's real estate market, now in its third year, is increasing the financial strain on homeowners, would-be sellers and lenders alike as delinquent mortgage loans and foreclosures spread across New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
More than 4 percent of the mortgage loans to individuals and families in New York City and its suburbs are now past due by at least two months, according to several studies. At those rates of delinquency, analysts say the region does not face anything close to the deep economic woes of Texas, Oklahoma, Colorado and other states around the Southwest, where more than 20 percent of the mortgage loans are delinquent and over 20,000 foreclosed homes are being sold off by the Federal Government.
But while few in the New York region are predicting problems of similar magnitude, experts say the rising number of problem loans offers little cause for comfort. The rate of mortgage delinquencies in the region has more than doubled since 1985, and now slightly surpasses the national average of 4 percent, according to the Office of Thrift Supervision, a Federal agency that supervises mortgage lenders. 
Home foreclosures, reported by the lending institutions, have also risen sharply. A check of legal documents filed by lenders with county clerks across the New York region as a first step in the process that sometimes leads to foreclosures indicates future problems.
Most disturbing, some experts say, is that problems in and around New York City have risen most dramatically over the last year.
''It would be an exaggeration to say the bottom is falling out of the market, but the rate of deterioriation in the New York region is not good news,'' said Eugene Sherman, chief economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board of New York.
The mortgage delinquencies provide an object lesson in what can happen after years of rapidly appreciating home values, when both borrowers and lenders come to assume that prices will continue to rise and that homeownership can be approached as a short-term investment.
Some of those now in arrears in their mortgage payments are people who bought homes, particularly condominiums, purely for investment purposes. Many became landlords, hoping that demand for rentals would be robust and rents would rise enough to cover their mortgage payments, upkeep, taxes and other costs. Instead, rents have risen little, if at all, and they are losing money on their investments.
Others ran into trouble because they stretched their budgets too far, often expecting that they would be able to sell at a profit after two or three years of rising prices. Some compounded their risks with hefty second mortgage or home equity loans, taking on too much debt to be supported if the underlying value of their property began to shrink, as it has in many cases.
LENDERS brought on some of the problems themselves and are paying the price for practices that real estate executives now say were too risky even in the heady real estate market of the mid-80's. Huge losses from nonperforming mortgage loans have already been reported by several banks and thrift institutions in the region, and analysts expect more fallout to come.
''People are hunkering down,'' said Michael J. Wexler, chief operating officer of the Related Companies, a real estate and financial services concern and former managing director of Chemical Bank. ''For the next few years, the days of excess in real estate lending are over.''
Many of the so-called ''no-documentation'' loans that were made to home buyers unwilling to provide proof of their employment or incomes are now showing up as delinquencies, and the lending practice is all but eliminated. Lenders who once quickly approved adjustible-rate mortgages to people whose income would cover the first, artificially low, phase of payments, but who might find themselves in a financial squeeze as the payments rose, are applying more stringent standards.
And in one of the most widespread shifts, banks and thrifts across the region are requiring that homeowners show evidence that they have sold their existing properties before they are granted mortgages for different homes. The change has come after hundreds of people found themselves paying off two mortgages because they were unable to find acceptable bids for the home they were trying to sell.
Many believe the troubled loans will become more commonplace. With some sellers unable to get as much for their homes as they would have a year ago, and thousands of householders paying adjustable-rate mortgages that have risen at hefty 6- or 12-month intervals, some lenders are making it more difficult to sell real estate by making it harder for would-be buyers to qualify for loans.
Indeed, lending executives say that in the region's sluggish market for houses, condominiums and cooperative apartments, which began a broad-based downturn after the October 1987 stock market collapse, may now be entering a period of new constraints as commercial banks and thrift institutions, jolted by a rash of soured loans, become more cautious in all forms of real estate lending.
''THE logic is inescapable that when you remove marginal buyers from the market it has a negative impact on sales,'' said Douglas Johnson, chief lending officer for the Dime Savings Bank of New York, one of the largest mortgage lenders in New York City and its suburbs.
Dime, like many other lenders, has tightened its requirements for lenders in recent months. Its changes have taken on a special urgency because it reported in December that it would have a fourth-quarter loss of $92 million, largely because of delinquencies and foreclosures in single-family home mortgages.
Other lenders, particularly those that had had been aggressively marketing mortgage loans in the suburbs, have reported similar problems. Midlantic Corporation, a major lender in New Jersey, said late in December that it had expected to be profitable in the fourth quarter but would add $75 million to a reserve against loan losses.
Citytrust Bancorp, a large real estate lender in Connecticut, which had earlier in the year added $40 million to its loan loss reserves, said its nonperforming real estate loans had risen by 45 percent in 12 months. Citytrust said that it expected a fourth-quarter loss, but it declined to predict how much it would be.
And in the starkest example of the problems faced by the region's real estate lenders, the City Federal Savings Bank, New Jersey's largest savings institution, was taken over in early December by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that is overseeing the Government's rescue of ailing thrifts across the nation.
Not all the problems at the thrifts and commercial banks have resulted from loans to individuals or families buying houses, condominiums or cooperative apartments. Some, like Midlantic, had financed office buildings, shopping malls and condominium projects, some of which ran into financial difficulties even before being put on the market for buyers or tenants.
And the lenders' problems extend beyond the New York City area. City Federal said some of its delinquent loans were to developers as far afield as Florida and Texas.
But analysts say the problems are as much a result of the sharp downturn in the New York region's market for homes as they are an outgrowth of lending to commercial developers or in distant real estate markets. And they say the problems have not ended.
''We haven't seen the half of it,'' said Lacey Shockley, a banking and thrift industry analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Bank and thrift industry executives ''tend to say three or four times that the problem is under control before it really is.''
The New York region's ''underlying economy has not yet stabilized, and we are going to see more problems,'' she added, saying that condominiums, particularly in suburban communities that have had intensive residential development, are likely to be the biggest problems for lenders.
One area that has been particularly hard hit by a surplus of condominiums is Fairfield County, where demand and prices hit a peak even before the stock market crash of 1987 and have been in a slump ever since. Hundreds of condominiums are on the market.
Robert D. Bundock, an appraiser in Stamford, said a typical two-bedroom condominium in a high-rise Stamford building has lost 19 percent of its value in four years. Although he declined to specify the building, he cited examples of typical selling prices of apartments with the same appraised value as $144,000 in 1986, $142,500 in 1987, $128,000 in 1988 and $117,000 last year.
Although he said demand and prices now appeared close to stabilizing, Mr. Bundock and other experts said such a steep decline in values seems certain to forebode continuing problems as those who lose their jobs or confront other economic hardship are unable to keep up their mortgage payments and find themselves unable to sell for close to what they paid for their homes.
TO be sure, the rising rate of delinquency and foreclosures is welcomed in some quarters. State officials in Connecticut announced this month that they had budgeted $50 million to buy the homes across the state at the lowest cut-rate prices they could negotiate and make them available in a special program for low- and middle-income first-time buyers.
Bargain hunters are also beginning to look to some of the banks and thrift institutions that have foreclosed properties to sell. At Dime, for example, officials are circulating a monthly list of homes that were in foreclosure and open for bids.
''We are not giving anything away, but we may price things moderately below the market,'' said Kenneth Borecki, vice president and director of owned real estate. He said the list currently includes 150 homes, including many New York City co-ops.
Hopeful buyers may also be encouraged by recent declines in interest rates, which have brought the average rate of a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage to slightly below 10 percent in the New York area, down more than a full point since the beginning of 1989. And most economists expect the rate to continue falling, albeit slightly, over the next six months.
But despite the incentives to buyers, the delinquent loans and foreclosures -and the resulting hardship on homeowners and lenders - are problems for the region that show no immediate signs of going away.
Federal agencies, which until now have been concentrating most of their resources on helping failing thrifts and preparing to sell off vast amounts of real estate in Texas, Arizona, Florida and elsewhere in the Sun Belt, are gearing up in the New York region.
''Our activity increased in the New York area last year, and from every indication, we have to expect it to be heavy in 1990,'' said Robert Cittadino, deputy regional director in the New York office of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's Division of Liquidation.
In one measure of the problem, the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York said 4.1 percent of the mortgage loans outstanding at the thrifts it supervises in New York State were at least 60 days past due at the end of the third quarter. That compared with a deliquency rate of 2.7 percent a year earlier.
In New Jersey, the analysis showed an even higher rate of mortgages over 60 days in arrears - 4.7 percent in the third quarter of 1989, up from 3 percent a year earlier.
Nationally, a study by the Office of Thrift Supervision found that the deliquency rates on home loans were 4 percent at the end of the third quarter, down from 4.8 percent a year earlier.
Mortgage loans that are past-due rarely lead to foreclosures because the borrowers, threatened with the loss of their entire investment, usually find buyers or other sources of financing before their properties are seized. Even when it occurs, foreclosure is usually a protracted legal process that takes months or years to complete.
NONETHELESS, foreclosures are on the rise. The Mortgage Bankers Association, a trade organization that analyzes thrifts, commercial banks and independent mortgage brokers, said foreclosures represented 0.83 percent of the residential real estate lending in New York State at the end of September, up from 0.49 percent a year earlier.
Foreclosures were a bigger problem in New Jersey, accounting for 0.89 percent of the real estate loans at the end of September, up from 0.67 percent a year earlier, the trade group said.
And in Connecticut, it was reported that foreclosures accounted for 0.32 percent of the lending at the end of September, up from 0.16 percent the year earlier.
One other indication of the expanding problem of loan delinquencies in the New York region comes from the county clerks, who record a legal document, filed by banks, thrifts or other mortgage lenders, when the mortgages are delinquent. The document, a lis pendens - Latin for ''notice of a pending suit'' - is typically filed when a loan is 90 days past due, and is used by lawyers as the first step in the lengthly process leading to foreclosure.
A spot check of county records shows that the number of such documents filed had risen sharply, particularly in the suburbs. On Long Island, Nassau County reported 2,478 filed in 1989, up from 1,576 in 1988, and Suffolk County said 3,530 were filed by Dec. 21, 1989, up from 2,451 in all of 1988.
In New Jersey, Hudson County said it had 823 lis pendens documents filed in 1989, up from 720 in 1988, and Morris County reported 643 of the filings in 1989, compared to 454 the year earlier.
Westchester County reported 965 of the filings thru Dec. 22, 1989, up from 805 for all of 1988. The increase was smaller in Manhattan, where there were 1,247 filings in 1989, compared to 1,140 in 1988.

HEADLINE: In Affluent Towns, The Working Poor Are Filling Shelters

BYLINE: By BARBARA LOECHER

 BODY:
WESTPORT, with its country clubs, marinas and million-dollar mansions, is not a town where you would expect to find a soup kitchen or a shelter for the homeless. Still, a few dozen people find their way every day to the Interfaith Housing Association's soup kitchen for a hot meal, and another 15 fill the nonprofit agency's shelter each night.
Many of these people are unemployed or retired. But a growing number are among the working poor. They hold clerical, custodial, restaurant or sales jobs in the community but do not earn enough to cover basic expenses.
Because they are employed, most do not qualify for Federal and state assistance. In communities like Westport, Greenwich and Fairfield in Fairfield County and Sharon and Salisbury in Litchfield County where the cost of living is high and rising faster than wages, the problems of the working poor stand out in high relief. 
Carol A. Femia, Commissioner of Social Services in Greenwich, a town better known as home to Wall Street executives and celebrities than to the poor, said: ''The number of people here who are eligible for welfare benefits is probably the same as it was a decade ago. It's a boom economy; there are jobs. The number of working poor, though, is much larger.''
There are no shelters or soup kitchens in Greenwich, but the town has a contract with a Stamford shelter to use a shelter and kitchen there. Greenwich also maintains a small cottage where homeless families can stay temporarily. Neighbor to Neighbor, a private nonprofit group, distributes food and clothing to those in need.
''We've seen a considerable increase in the number of households we are referring to Neighbor to Neighbor,'' Miss Femia said. ''It's our sense that the working poor are really suffering. Our housing costs are exorbitant; the cost of living here is high. These people might have jobs paying $10 an hour. Unless they have a second income, it's very tricky to pay rents here, which are in the $800- to $1,000-a-month range for one or two bedrooms.''
Along with the state's unemployment rate, the number of Connecticut residents receiving welfare benefits dropped to the lowest point of the decade in 1989. According to the State Department of Income Maintenance, 35,300 state residents were getting Aid to Families With Dependent Children last year, compared with a high of 45,800 in 1980. But in 1989 the number of Connecticut residents sleeping in shelters for the homeless reached a high of 18,400, according to the State Department of Human Resources. The department estimates that more than 20 percent of those people were employed.
''We've noticed we're getting more people who are working,'' said Pam Hyman, executive director of the Operation Hope shelter, soup kitchen and food bank in Fairfield. ''About half the men at our shelter work.''
An average of 30 people eat at the kitchen daily, and the 18-bed men's shelter is always full, she said.
 
Working but Homeless
One of those living at the shelter is 23-year-old Warren Richardson. Mr. Richardson, who was raised by his grandfather in Bridgeport, said he was forced to leave the house after his grandfather died. He said he lived in a friend's garage, did a stint in the Army and tried the Job Corps before he found the shelter seven months ago.
Since then he has been working full time at a McDonald's restaurant in Fairfield and studying graphic arts at Housatonic Community College in Bridgeport. With his earnings of $200 a week, he cannot afford an apartment in Fairfield, where most rents start at $800 a month. He said that he could find an apartment for $500 a month in Bridgeport but that if he lived there, he would have to pay to take the bus to work in Fairfield.
Evelyn Harris, a professor at the University of Connecticut at Stamford who last month organized a symposium on poverty in southern Connecticut, explained the seeming incongruity between decreasing unemployment and rising homelessness in the state by pointing out that most of the jobs created in Connecticut in the last decade were service jobs that pay less than $20,000 a year. At the same time, housing costs rose dramatically.
 
Programs in Wilton
In Wilton, where the average family of three earns more than $75,000 and apartments renting for $800 a month are scarce, the social services director, Suzanne Van Vechten, has only three clients who are eligible for welfare. Most of the people who stop at her office these days are the working poor.
''The people I think are most in need in Wilton and towns like Wilton are the ones doing unskilled jobs that don't pay a tremendous amount,'' Miss Van Vechten said. ''They're spending a very high percentage of their income on housing. We have various programs, including an energy-assistance program that's open to individuals earning $12,000 and below a year. What I'm finding, though, is that people with incomes just above the guidelines aren't eligible for help.''
In response, church and civic groups in Wilton have set up funds to assist those who are employed but still in need. The town officially has its own version of the state's heating-assistance program and a fund to cover medical expenses for those who have no insurance. Occasionally, Miss Van Vechten will tap a third fund to pay a month's rent for a tenant who might otherwise end up homeless. Wilton has no shelter and has to refer the homeless to shelters in Norwalk and Westport. The town does have a food pantry in Miss Van Vechten's office.
 
Help in Sharon
In Sharon, the Older Women's League is planning to open a food bank. The town already has a fund for residents who need emergency financial help. And Sharon Hospital has a contingency fund that covers certain medical expenses for those who cannot pay.
''It's easy to drive through this town and see nothing but the fancy houses, but it's a problem in these towns - poverty that people don't want to talk about,'' said Ella L. Clark, the social services director in Sharon. ''There's no affordable housing as yet in Sharon. I have 25 people who need fuel assistance and three more just applied, including a single mother who lives in an apartment where nearly all her income goes to rent. There are other people here who need surplus food.'' Sharon, a rural town in the northwestern corner of the state, is, like nearby Salisbury, a well-known second-home spot for affluent New Yorkers.
''I've asked virtually everyone I can think of whether they'd use the food bank the league is planning,'' said Miss Clark, who is a league member herself. ''They've said, 'Yes, because it doesen't have a means test.''' Like Miss Van Vechten and Miss Femia, Miss Clark says she is seeing an increasing number of people who need help but are not eligible for many benefit programs because they are employed.
 
Limits of Welfare
Even those who are eligible for benefits like Aid to Families With Dependent Children or Social Security need additional help, Miss Clark said. A family of three in Sharon is eligible for about $550 in A.F.D.C. benefits each month. This is supposed to cover housing, food, fuel, clothing and transportation, but the least expensive apartments in town rent for about $500.
In general, the federally financed A.F.D.C. program provides benefits that total just two-thirds of the amount the Government estimates that families need to live at the poverty level. According to the Federal Government's definition, the poverty level for a family of three in Connecticut is $10,060 annually. A.F.D.C. benefits to a family of three in Sharon total $6,564 a year. Welfare benefits did not keep pace with inflation through the 1970's and were cut back significantly during the Reagan Administration. Welfare benefits are now pegged to the inflation rate, but the Government has limited increases to 6 percent annually.
While local governments and religious and civic groups are trying to fill the gap, there are limits to what they can do.
 
The Housing Problem
''I think housing is the main problem,'' the Salisbury social services director, Barbara Tobias, said. Salisbury Family Services, a private group, has long provided townspeople with financial assistance, and the privately endowed Bissell Fund helps low- and middle-income residents with medical expenses. There are 25 subsidized housing units for low- and mid-income people in Salisbury, some renting for as little as $200 a month. But there is a long waiting list.
People who would otherwise end up spending most of their income on market-rate housing have little choice but to live with another family or two in a house or apartment, Mrs. Tobias said.
''A lot end up moving back in with their parents,'' she said. ''We've had two people do that in the last month. There are parents with their daughter or son, and their children, in one household. Homes built for four people house seven to nine.''
The situation is much the same in southwestern Connecticut.
 
Doubling Up
''People double up, or triple up, or leave town'' for places where housing costs are at least slightly lower, said Miss Femia, the Greenwich Social Services Commissioner. ''That's one reason it's so hard for Greenwich employers to find employees.'' There are 800 subsidized housing units in Greenwich, but Miss Femia said that the town would have to double that number to meet the need over the next decade.
Connecticut businesses have complained for several years that they were having problems attracting and retaining entry-level workers. In areas like Fairfield County, they point out, there is little housing that someone earning a receptionist's salary can afford.
The State Department of Economic Development is concerned about the long-term consequences, including possible corporate relocation outside Connecticut. Commissioner Stephen B. Heintz said his department may recommend formation of state and corporate partnerships, which would be responsible for finding ways to lower home financing costs and for investigating variations on typical single-family home ownership, like co-housing.
To make things somewhat easier for low-income tenants, the state started offering welfare recipients an additional $50-a-month rent subsidy this year. The subsidy, however, is available only to those who spend more than 50 percent of their benefits on rent.
 
Rental Assistance
A rental-assistance program the state introduced several years ago is further reaching. Under the program - patterned after the Federal Section 8 rental-assistance plan - eligible tenants pay one-third of their income for rent. The state pays participating landlords the difference between that amount and the landlord's actual charge. To qualify for the program, a family of three in Fairfield, for example, could earn up to $20,800 a year.
The state offered more than 1,200 households rental assistance through the program last year and plans to offer it to another 360 shortly. But there are far more than 360 families on waiting lists for the program and its federally financed counterpart.
The state should make affordable housing a top priority, municipal social service workers agree. But it should also increase benefits and extend them to the working poor, they say. A family of three is eligible for $600 a year in state energy assistance, they point out, only if it earns less than $20,124 a year.
''The income limits are outrageously low,'' said the Rev. Peter Powell, director of the Westport shelter and soup kitchen.
 
Fallacy of Work
Before there is widespread support for more extensive social welfare programs, there may have to be fundamental changes in the way people think about poverty and employment, said Claudette Bieulieu, a spokeswoman for the Department of Income Maintenance. The notion that a job is everyone's ticket out of poverty, she said, has always been a basic assumption behind the country's social welfare policy.
''There certainly is evidence that merely having a job is no guarantee against poverty,'' Miss Bieulieu said. ''But our welfare programs don't provide a long continuum of support. You're either on welfare or you get a job and you're on your own.''

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Encouraging a Healthy Life Style Is Just Good Business

BYLINE: By Robert W. Figlerski; Robert W. Figlerski is executive director of the Hofstra Health Dome in Hempstead.

 BODY:
A COOLING economy in Long Island is not the only challenge facing Nassau and Suffolk County employers. The rising cost of health insurance has become a serious drain on revenues and makes it increasingly difficult for companies to grow and compete in a chilly economic climate.
In 1987, increases in the costs of providing health insurance to employees were an average of 7.9 percent over those same costs in 1986. In 1988, increases in health care costs soared at an average pace of 20 percent, and 1989's average increase will be about 25 percent. Looking at companies on an individual basis, increases of 35 to 40 percent are not uncommon. 
Controlling health care costs has become an uphill battle, particularly for small to mid-sized employers.
Increases in health insurance premiums are taking place throughout the insurance industry, making it difficult for a company to switch to an insurance carrier offering lower rates. Even if an employer found an insurance carrier offering lower rates, insurance companies won't guarantee a rate for more than a year.
Small to mid-size businesses are working at an even bigger disadvantage to secure lower rates since they usually pay 10 to 40 percent more than a large employer, and insurance companies are less interested in insuring small groups.
However, these increases should not come as too much of a surprise, since major health studies have concluded we are in poor shape, our children are in worse shape, and our life styles are to blame. The following are a few examples:
* Approximately 26 percent of the adult population is overweight. Overweight workers are 50 percent more likely to have medical claims that exceed $5,000 in a year, and 29 percent more likely to miss more than a week of work each year.
%
* Sedentary employees spend 30 percent more time in the hospital and call in sick more often than those who exercise.
* Most people who have high blood pressure don't know it. Fortunately, if they are made aware of it, most cases of high blood pressure can be controlled by changes in exercise habits and diet.
* The fat content of the average American diet is 100 percent above the recommended level, which is one reason the United States has one of the highest rates of heart disease of any industrialized country.
For many years, companies have assumed the habit of paying for medical costs after the fact and viewed screening and life-style programs as nice things to do for the employees, but not really relevant to the bottom line. Employers are now looking to life-style programs as a method of containing costs.
Because of rising health care costs, the business community is beginning to warm up to lifestyle programs. At a recent business meeting of the Long Island Forum for Technology, the chairman, Fenimore Fisher, commented, ''These types of programs are long overdue. The business community needs to recognize these health programs are an investment in their company, not a cost.''
Life style, or wellness, programs are based on the premise that employees who control their risk factors not only are more productive, but have less need to use costly medical services. This helps the employer maintain a better medical utilization profile, improves employee morale, decreases absenteeism, and boosts productivity.
One survey of company-supported exercise programs documented the effects on the bottom line and found:
* A drop of 50 percent in average absenteeism among program participants compared to the prior year.
* A 20 percent decrease in average disability days.
* A 48 percent reduction in the medical costs of employees who exercised compared to those that did not.
However, wellness is more than making a corporate fitness center available to employees. While staying active is a key to staying healthy, it's not the only important component of a lifestyle program.
Smoking, obesity, stress, diet and lack of awareness of potential health problems are driving medical utilization, and therefore premiums, through the roof. Until people begin taking better care of themselves, the rising costs of health care will not be controlled.
For example, an employer sponsored health screening program provides an opportunity for employees to detect problems like high cholesterol or blood pressure before they turn into more serious health problems, which bring with them tremendous costs in the forms of medical claims and lost productivity.
Dr. Stanley Shannies, president of the Long Island Heart Council, believes organized efforts of these kind are long overdue. ''The stage has been set for the health and business community to start working together to help Long Islanders reduce their health risks due to life-style habits,'' he said. ''Well-organized life-style programs can only have a positive impact on all those involved.''
In terms of the bottom line, Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Indiana research found that every $1 invested in a life-style program returned $1.45 in medical claims savings. It has also been established that employees who participate in life-style programs are hospitalized less than other employees and their medical costs increase at a much slower rate.
In addition, when factors like absenteeism are assessed, significant decreases have been found which translates to more productivity. It is estimated that for every 1 percent decrease in absenteeism, a company's profits increase 1 percent.
The time has come for the business community to actively promote the health and well-being of their employees through education and life-style programs. It has become good business sense to help employees stay healthy as a way of controlling rapidly escalating health care costs and protecting the bottom line.

LENGTH: 670 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
L.I.R.R. Should Recognize Long Beach's Ties to New York

BYLINE: By Arnold Gumowitz is chairman of the Association for a Better Long Beach.

 BODY:
IF you are one of those individuals who derive pleasure in life from swimming against the tide, it's hard to think of a better place to do it than Long Beach.
Sprawled across the sands of the Atlantic shoreline like a sunbathing stretch of homes, shops and boardwalk, Long Beach is the only city in New York State which is situated entirely on a barrier beach island. With Reynolds Channel to the north, and the Atlantic Ocean to the south, there is plenty of opportunity for residents to choose the tide best suited to their own stroke.
In Long Beach, people are swimming against the tide in less literal fashion as well. While Long Island, once considered a vast bedroom community for New York City, has been changing its employment focus, Long Beach still maintains economic ties with its urban cousin to the west. 
Like childhood friends going their separate ways, Long Island and New York City have been gradually growing apart. Between 1980 and 1988 the number of jobs on Long Island grew by 25 percent. More than 200,000 people still commute to work in New York City every day, but a vastly larger number of residents, 1.1 million, now earn their living at home on Long Island.
This unexpected change recently forced the Long Island Rail Road to amend its capital improvement program started in 1982. Under this program, the L.I.R.R. planned to meet what it anticipated would be an expanding demand for its commuter services. But the commuter demand leveled off as business and industry grew with the sudden expansion of Long Island's economy during the mid 1980's. With an expanding local economy, more people found work closer to home.
The same boom that boosted Long Island's economic future turned into a bust for the railroad's expansion program. It recently became apparent that there would not be enough new commuters to justify the capital improvement plans adopted 7 years ago. Most of the people going to work on Long Island no longer need the L.I.R.R. to get there. The Dashing Dans of years ago are now concerned about traffic congestion rather than train schedules.
But in Long Beach the tide is still flowing toward New York City, at least during the morning rush hours. Nearly 5,000 people commute from the Long Beach station to New York every day. Many more take their cars over the Loop Parkway and catch the train at other stations, where they can find more convenient service. That's a lot of people going to New York each day from a relatively small city.
So the railroad is still very important to the commuters of Long Beach, and, consequently, those commuters should be important to the rail road. That's why they feel justified in asking the L.I.R.R. to rearrange the existing service to make it more convenient for the people who are most interested in using it.
In this case, the improved service ought to take the form of an express train. The typical train of eight cars holds just under 1,000 people, so there is certainly enough demand generated from Long Beach to fill one express leaving for New York in the morning and returning at night. Because we are looking to rearrange service, rather than place additional demands on the system, it should be possible for the schedule to be made up so that such an express train would take the place of two local trains. This two-for-one swap would be a small price to pay for better service.
A new president is taking the throttle at the L.I.R.R. at a time when the railroad has to contend with increasing competition for riders. Specialized service would be a highly effective marketing tool for encouraging new riders to start with and current riders to stay with the L.I.R.R.
Long Beach is not the only part of Long Island that deserves such service. Many towns on Long Island could support express trains, and the L.I.R.R. should be actively looking to establish special service wherever demand and scheduling considerations make it feasible. As a station at the end of the line, Long Beach would be a good place to start.

LENGTH: 1885 words

HEADLINE: To Mr. Floria: Words of Advice

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
EVERY New Jersey governor takes office as the head of a different state. New problems constantly demand different solutions and innovative approaches to deal with economic cycles, a changing population, shifting employment patterns and, lately, global changes that present new challenges and opportunities.
James J. Florio, the Democrat who will become New Jersey's 49th governor on Tuesday, will have to deal with an economic downturn after seven years of rapid growth. Although that will have a chilling effect on his ability to offer new programs that require increased spending, problems persist, change and grow, as well as demand attention.
In a series of interviews, several people outside government who deal with these changes were asked for their thoughts on the challenges that face New Jersey in the immediate future. 
New Jersey's cities require changes in the state's tax system and its reliance on local property taxes if they are ever going to be able to rejoin the economic mainstream, Mr. Roper said.
''We must make building in the inner cities less costly,'' he said. ''And if we do that, it will have an impact on a whole range of social-welfare needs.''
He said revitalized inner cities could provide the financial resources needed to improve urban education. Mr. Roper added, however, that money was not the total answer.
''After 10 years of increased state funding, we still are not providing inner-city youngsters with the skills to compete,'' he said. ''We need the intellectual creativity to define new solutions and new approaches to urban education.''
Along with the new programs must come dedicated and creative managers to make them work, Mr. Roper said, adding that job training and skills development are sorely needed by a work force caught in the shift from a manufacturing economy to one based on services and communications.
''The question we must answer,'' he said, ''is how do we make the most of job training programs to prepare people to move out of manufacturing and participate more effectively in the information and service sectors?''
Mr. Florio has recognized that need and given his Commerce and Labor Commissioners the task of coordinating and condensing the dozens of job-training programs.
Providing affordable housing for the poor and for those forced out of their homes by the excessively high cost of housing, Mr. Roper said, is another pressing need. ''In addition to the poor and moderately poor,'' he said, ''we must also provide for those young married couples buying their first home, the people moving out of their family home for the first time and those who have fallen on hard times and can no longer afford to pay their mortgage or rents.''
Mr. Roper said the state had made a good start in revitalizing some downtown areas in the cities, but said: ''We have not focused enough on reviving the neighborhoods abutting these downtown areas. The people living in these neighborhoods are out of the economic mainstream and worry most about crime and illness, and if we fail to begin to address this problem, it will be inexcusable.''
New Jersey colleges and universities will have to deal with declining high school graduation classes through most of the 90's, Dr. Donaldson said. He added that the schools had to devise programs to meet the needs of more minority students; nontraditional students, whose higher education was interrupted and are returning to the classrooms, and graduate students.
''We will be into the 21st century before we see a high school graduating class as large as the one that graduated in 1988,'' Dr. Donaldson said. That will require schools to do a better job of persuading those students who intend to go out of state that New Jersey colleges and universities ''are every bit as good, or better, than the schools they are thinking of attending.''
The high dropout rate among minority students in high school, he said, is a pattern that is being repeated in New Jersey colleges and universities and requires ''some new strategies to retain our black and Hispanic students.''
''It's not just good social public policy to help our minority students stay in school, but sheer economic necessity that says we must expand our management pool, and the urban minority population has got to help fill that need,'' he said.
The nontraditional and graduate students also have to be prepared and made aware of their importance as potential business managers and engineers who are sorely needed if the state's economy is to continue to develop, Dr. Donaldson said.
He said Fairleigh Dickinson, whose physical plant was largely built in the 1960's, and other institutions had pressing needs to work on their buildings. ''During periods of high inflation, not much maintenance was done, and now we're paying the price,'' he said. ''We must renovate existing facilities and build new ones.''
One possible source of the needed capital, he said, is the business community. In recent years, partnerships between corporations and the state's colleges and universities have grown, as business looks to the schools to provide highly trained workers.
''They've got to continue to invest in our universities, not only to help us do a better job of retaining and teaching students, but to build new facilities,'' Dr. Donaldson said. ''They will derive a direct benefit from a stronger economy.''
He said the schools also had to acquaint their students with international issues. ''We are more and more being caught up in a global economy,'' he said. ''And our students are relatively unsophisticated about the world.''
Mr. Stanton said he believed that the inflated value of real estate had harmed the New Jersey economy and made banks and savings institutions very cautious in considering new loans.
''The value of real estate pretty much got way ahead of itself,'' he said. ''People began to think that a 10 to 12 percent annual growth in the value of their property was a God-given right.''
The leveling of the trend has shaken confidence somewhat and left the real-estate market with a large inventory, Mr. Stanton said, adding, ''It looks like we're in for another difficult year.'' The loss of confidence and the banks' cautious attitude also forecast some earnings problems for banks, he said.
Another troubling prospect, he said, is Mr. Florio's plan to appoint an environmental prosecutor. ''We already have a situation where people sue over perceived environmental threats at the drop of a hat, and this is hurting our economic development,'' he said.
''The oil spill at the Exxon refinery in Linden is an example,'' Mr. Stanton added. ''The state already has impaneled a grand jury just because of the accident.
''I'm worried about the proposed prosecutor because a prosecutor's only job is to 'get' people. From an economic standpoint, creating such a post would be overkill.''
A member of the commission overseeing Liberty State Park, Mr. Stanton said half the agency's budget went to pay legal fees fighting suits to stop the development of the park. ''We won every case, but it's costly,'' he said. ''I recognize that the new governor promised to appoint an environmental prosecutor during his campaign, but it won't be good for our economic climate.''
Mr. Stanton said the economic slowdown was not affecting New Jersey as hard as its neighbors, New York and Pennsylvania. Unemployment is still low, but there is a perception that the state economy has some stresses and that to meet them Mr. Florio will have to consider raising taxes. ''He may have to bite that bullet, and the sooner the better,'' Mr. Stanton said. ''If there is a central theme to improving our protection of the environment,'' Mr. Moore said, ''it's better growth management. This could lead to solving a lot of other problems.''
By creating buffer zones around water resources and streams, the amount of pollution that runs into the waterways and eventually forms slicks of debris along the ocean beachfront could be reduced, he said, adding:
''Non-point source pollution is generated primarily by runoff into streams and waterways. And maximizing the natural environment by preventing development in buffer zones around our waterways will protect against the problem.
Mr. Moore suggested that ocean pollution could be reduced by mapping and repairing the storm-water system and equipping it with devices to trap debris before the water pours into the ocean and that parking lots and highways should also be equipped to prevent debris from entering the storm drains.
Reducing vehicular travel in the most densely populated state also would improve air quality, Mr. Moore said. ''Instead of allowing people to spread out all over the landscape, development should be encouraged where it reduces the number of miles people travel between their homes and where they work and shop,'' he said.
He also said the state should resist pressure on the Department of Environmental Protection to speed up or reduce its examinations of development that might harm the environment. ''For many types of licenses, there is already a 90-day time limit for D.E.P. action,'' he said. ''If people weren't always trying to beat the system, things would go smoothly. But they are always seeking variances from local zoning boards and exceptions to state regulations, and that takes time.''
The major problems facing New Jersey and the nation, Dr. Bergen said, are health care and its cost.
''It's rapidly becoming an overwhelming problem, and industries and business find they must compete in a global economy and they no longer sustain the increased health-care costs for their employees,'' he said. ''And the state is finding it difficult to provide care for the medically indigent and the unemployed. The price tag is just getting out of hand.
''We're hearing nationally that there are 38 million people who have no access to health care because they are poor, do piecework or work for small companies that are not required to provide health insurance.''
Dr. Bergen said he believed that the problems were rapidly approaching a breaking point and that it would probably require all the parts of the health care system, providers, patients and payers, to join in devising controls on costs and assurances of quality.
He said the public would have to be on guard to make sure that institutions and physicians did not sacrifice quality.
Dr. Bergen said he agreed with the incoming Attorney General, Robert J. Del Tufo, and Mr. Florio that drug abuse is the major health problem in the state. ''And closely connected with that, of course, is the problem of AIDS,'' he added. ''Individual drug abusers make up our major AIDS population, and they are spreading the disease to other members of their community and outside the community.''
The treatment of AIDS, with its growing number of patients and new treatments that can prolong lives, also increases health costs, he said, adding:
''We must develop out-of-hospital techniques for some of these patients, ambulatory care or hospice care, and not lock up all of our beds with AIDS patients. We must continue to pursue a course of educating the public on how AIDS is transmitted. And we have to make sure it gets across in school, when talking about drug abuse and sex education.''

HEADLINE: Turnpike Seen as Metaphor for America

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
POSING for newspaper photos on a small hill overlooking the New Jersey Turnpike here, a Rutgers University professor turned to a colleague standing beside him.
''I always expect to see a gun sticking out a window,'' said Prof. Angus Kress Gillespie, gesturing toward the Turnpike Authority headquarters, which rise on a knoll above the toll plaza at Exit 9 and the authority's heliport.
''That's because you're afraid of authority,'' the colleague, Prof. Michael Aaron Rockland, said. The two professors of American studies have written ''Looking for America on the New Jersey Turnpike,'' poking fun at the authority and holding that the quintessential New Jersey highway is so bad it's good. They also see the superhighway as a metaphor for America in many ways. ''The turnpike represents a number of American ideas and values,'' they wrote. ''Built as economically as possible, with virtually no attention to esthetics, the turnpike is the embodiment of American pragmatism and of the triumph of function over form. Offering its patrons virtually no amenities and with an exclusively bottom-line approach to management, the turnpike is an unabashed shrine to American materialism.'' 
While giving credit to the authority, which they compare to a paramilitary organization, for efficiency, the writers accuse the authority of making the collection of revenue its top priority and courtesy to the public last. They contend that the agency's ''virtual political and economic independence'' has created an arrogance that ''has trickled down to turnpike employes on every level, including, most notably, some of the state police who patrol the turnpike.''
The book includes a Kafkaesque tale that explains Dr. Gillespie's wariness. A motorist was arrested, and convicted, for taking pictures of an accident caused by a trooper. The writers contend that the turnpike regulations, posted in fine print at entrances where they are virtually impossible to read, can be interpreted to mean that no pictures can be taken on the turnpike, or even of the road.
The authority responds that the professors have misread the law, which is aimed at keeping people, for their own safety, from walking on the roadway and that, with the authority's permission, photos can be taken on the road by professional photographers for publication, even in books like ''Looking for America.'' The 219-page book, however, features drawings.
Nonetheless, Dr. Gillespie said, he still is a bit apprehensive when posing for newspaper pictures against a turnpike background, despite a growing number of requests since the book was published in November. The Rutgers University Press, in New Brunswick, has started a second printing, after an initial run of 5,000. The book's price is $18.95.
Newspapers in New Jersey, as well as The Philadelphia Inquirer and The News Leader in Richmond, where Dr. Gillespie went to high school, have published articles on the book, and ''The 11th Hour'' on WNET-TV featured it.
The book's success has prompted the writers, longtime friends, to continue their friendly banter. The calm Dr. Gillespie, 47 years old, presents a tie, sweater and blazer to the frenetic Dr. Rockland, 54, the chairman of the department, who favors jeans, turtleneck sweater and leather jacket.
In an interview near Exit 9 and in Dr. Rockland's office, they acknowledged that the ''redneck law-and-order type'' Professor Gillespie and the ''knee-jerk liberal'' Professor Rockland, as they call each other, had different views about the turnpike.
Dr. Gillespie tended to find what the turnpike did well; Dr. Rockland tended to be critical. They divided the writing of the chapters, mercilessly rewrote each other's efforts and continued to ''thrash'' things out over two years.
Dr. Gillespie, a specialist in folklore, said he thought up the idea for the book as a graduate student while reading about the Brooklyn Bridge as artifact with cultural implications.
''I can't say there's one moment when it hit me, like Paul on the road to Damascus,'' he said. ''It was just a big artifact that kind of invited explanation.''
Although he began research in 1979, he put off writing the book until Dr. Rockland joined him.
The title comes from a line from the 1968 Simon and Garfunkel song ''America,'' about a young traveler who is ''empty and aching'' and doesn't know why, ''Countin' the cars on the New Jersey Turnpike/And they've all come to look for America.''
As much as that song captures the alienation of America in the late 60's, other songs the authors cite touch other values, from the expansiveness and freedom of the 50's in Chuck Berry's ''You Can't Catch Me'' to the spiritual malaise of the 80's, as expressed in Bruce Springsteen's ''State Trooper.''
That ambiguity runs through the book deliberately, said Dr. Rockland, who was born in the Bronx.
''That's our premise, I think, that this thing is so powerful it attracts us and repels us,'' he said. ''Not alternately, but simultaneously.''
They write that for residents the turnpike is the ''most important common experience,'' the ''source of what it means to be a New Jerseyan,'' who can appreciate its efficiency but despise it as ''a source of New Jersey's negative image.''
For out-of-staters, it is one of the ''central experiences of the East Coast,'' evoking ''powerful images of dense traffic combined with an industrial landscape and chemically fouled air.''
Although rural and somewhat nondescript in the south, the turnpike takes its identity from the northern, industrialized 35-mile section, a stretch so overwhelming in its ''world class ugliness,'' the authors wrote, that it has become synonymous with the entire highway in the consciousness of most people. Especially overwhelming for the authors is the Newark Airport area, inspiring them to write:
''With Newark Airport on one side, Port Elizabeth on the other; with the flames of the refineries and huge tank farms of petroleum; with planes roaring in one after another, so close one is sure a Lockheed Tri-Star is going to land on the roof of one's automobile; with the giant cranes of the container shipping port seeming to stalk across the land on their long legs like Martian war machines in 'War of the Worlds' - one is impressed almost to speechlessness by the sheer, raw power of this technological landscape. Hideous, yes. But theater that rivals anything on Broadway ten miles to the northeast.''
A spokesman for the authority, Gordon Hector, said he had ordered 12 copies for officials of the authority. His reading of the book, Mr. Hector said, was that it was ''fair and even-handed.'' Aside from saying that the professors had misread the regulation on taking photos, he said he would not rebut the book, adding, ''We certainly are not going to shoot them.''

HEADLINE: JAPAN STILL WARY OF LOANS TO CHINA

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Despite the lifting of martial law in Beijing last week, Government officials say Japan is not prepared to resume talks on arranging $5.6 billion in loans suspended after the Chinese crackdown in Tiananmen Square in June.
Sounding a similar cautionary note, Japanese businessmen who welcomed the suspension of martial law, which took effect in Beijing on Wednesday, also said in interviews that they would be slow to resume a high level of investment activity in China because of concern about the country's political stability.
As the biggest donor of economic assistance to China, Japan has reacted cautiously to its neighbor in recent months, frequently reminding the United States and other countries that it was not in their interest to impose heavy sanctions on Beijing.
At a New Year's news conference, for instance, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu reiterated Japan's position that sanctions would only reinforce a feeling of defensiveness in China, perhaps driving it into the Soviet Union's camp or making it dangerously mistrustful of other countries in Asia. 
 
Opposes Isolation of China
''To isolate China will not be good for world peace and stability,'' Mr. Kaifu said. Apparently mindful of public outrage over the crackdown last year, he said he hoped that China would ''carry out the consolidation of its environment in a way easily understandable to the West.''
Mr. Kaifu said that Japan intended to renew the aid it had frozen after Beijing imposed repressive measures last year, but that talks on the matter would probably not come until the spring.
Japanese officials said they still intended to send back a Chinese man who is charged with hijacking an Air China plane on Dec. 16 and forcing it to fly to Fukuoka, in southern Japan.
The hijacking suspect, identified as Zhang Zhenhai, asserts that he took part in the demonstrations in Tiananmen Square. He has said he will appeal in Japanese courts for permission to seek political asylum in Japan.
 
Suspect Claims Political Status
Lawyers from the Fukuoka Bar Association's human rights committee have said Mr. Zhang argues that he is a political refugee. But the Japanese Government said it understood that he was charged with embezzlement in China and was free on bail when he committed the hijacking.
''Even if Zhang was involved in June's pro-democracy demonstration, resorting to inhuman methods like hijacking can never be pardoned,'' said Mayumi Moriyama, the Chief Cabinet Secretary.
Mr. Zhang was transferred to Tokyo this week from a hospital near the airport. He was injured when someone pushed him out of the plane and onto the tarmac at the airport in Fukuoka after the hijacking.
The centerpiece of Japanese aid to China was a $3.3 billion loan program that is near completion, although most of the projects were unfinished when they were frozen in June. Japan has resumed many of them since August.
 
Talks, but No Pledges So Far
Future aid for China, including a $5.6 billion program announced in 1988 by Noboru Takeshita when he was Prime Minister, remains suspended. That program is to run from 1990 to 1995.
In the last week, Japan has announced that it will step up discussions of general economic matters with China by sending a high-level aid official to Beijing after the visit here this month of the head of the Chinese State Planning Commission, Zou Jiahua.
Prime Minister Kaifu also has decided to send Koichiro Matsuura, director general of the Foreign Ministry's Economic Cooperation Bureau, to Beijing next week. Mr. Matsuura has been traveling with Mr. Kaifu in Europe, where he announced an aid program for Poland and Hungary this week.
But a Foreign Ministry spokesman said those talks would not necessarily lead to the resumption of aid to China. He said only that officials wanted to learn about Chinese plans, including measures to liberalize its economy.
''A simple visit by the director general does not mean the start of extending yen loans,'' said Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry spokesman.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Amid the Jealousies, a Suspicion That the U.N. Works

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA

 BODY:
''A dangerous place'' - that was how Daniel Patrick Moynihan described the United Nations when he served there as the United States representative in the mid-1970's, a time of ferocious East-West rivalry.
Thomas R. Pickering, who now holds the job, likes to call it a ''useful place,'' and this view was widely echoed as the 44th General Assembly concluded business last month.
Infused with what the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Vladimir F. Petrovsky, called ''the spirit of superpower detente and cooperation,'' this year's Assembly approved an unparalleled volume of international ''legislation'' with the potential to change the way the world works.
Among other things, it agreed to ban fishing with immense nets that sweep great areas of the ocean free of marine life; to draft a treaty to stabilize the world climate; to set up a world action program to fight drug trafficking, and to extend human rights guarantees to children. 
The Security Council has turned its attention toward seeking peace in Cambodia after coaxing Namibia toward independence, beginning a peacekeeping operation in Central America, and prodding Arab League mediators to cobble together another fragile peace accord in Lebanon.
Yet when the Academic Council on the United Nations System brought academics and diplomats together here on Jan. 5-7 to examine the future of the United Nations, the discussion centered more on the difficulties faced by the organization than on its potential.
 
A North-South Split
Despite the easing of East-West tensions, the effectiveness of the United Nations as a forum for global agreement remains impaired by a widening North-South split between industrialized and developing nations, and by growing doubts about Washington's interest in multilateral action.
Echoes of the North-South split were audible during the Assembly's difficult debates on the environment and drugs, when developing countries tried to barter their support for promises of economic aid.
And in Ottawa, Mexico's deputy representative, Olga Pellicer, argued that the issues that industrialized countries want the United Nations to emphasize - drugs, the environment, terrorism and refugees - are of greatest concern to rich countries.
Poorer nations struggling to bring their economic difficulties to center stage at the United Nations are blocked by the United States, which believes that development springs from domestic policies, not international action.
Ahmed Osman, a retired Egyptian diplomat, said that while the group of developing countries that consider themselves nonaligned might appear irrelevant at a time of eased tensions between the Washington and Moscow, the third world must keep its agenda before the world community to insure its survival.
John Trent, a professor of political science at Ottawa University, said that the third world is forced to raise its voice to avoid becoming ''marginalized'' as Western countries refocus their aid and attention on Eastern Europe and new technologies reduce the demand for poor countries' raw materials.
But Assistant Secretary General James O. C. Jonah expressed doubt that the conflict over agendas could be resolved easily. ''Why should the United States change its attitude when Eastern Europe is accepting the market economy as the motor of development?'' he asked.
 
Envying the 5 Powers
During the General Assembly session, the third world's assertiveness killed British proposals to give the Security Council a role in the fight against drug trafficking and to simplify discussions of economic and social issues.
The defeat of the drug proposal showed that the developing world is bent on blocking any expansion of the Security Council, and thus the power of the five countries with permanent seats and veto power - Britain, China, France, the United States and the Soviet Union.
The defeat of the second item demonstrated the third world's impatience with demands for cost-cutting and for greater efficency, goals that Humphrey A. Asobie, a professor at the University of Nigeria, dismissed as ''a Western concept.''
It is not just the poor countries that are jealous of the permanent Security Council members. As Canada's deputy representative, Phillipe Kirsch, observed, detente allows the five to work together for peace, but also arouses fear they will form a directorate to run the United Nations. Indignation at U.S. At the General Assembly, as well as at the Ottawa conference, the liveliest debate came over United States attitudes toward the United Nations.
The Bush Administration's blunt threat to resort again to withholding funds even though it already owes the United Nations more than $500 million, killed an Arab effort to win recognition of the Palestine Liberation Organization as a state by the last General Assembly.
But at the Ottawa meeting, Washington's threat was seen both as an attempt to extend the nation's Security Council veto into the General Assembly, and as a sign that the United States remains uncomfortable with the give and take of multilateral diplomacy.
Jane Becker, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State in the Bureau for International Organization Affairs, argued that the United Nations is in ''a transitional phase,'' becoming more relevant and gaining support from the United States Congress.
But if the P.L.O. seeks to join the World Health Organization again in April, or Vice President Dan Quayle pursues the repeal of a 1975 General Assembly resolution equating Zionism with racism, some believe that another bout of American withholding could be seen again this year.

HEADLINE: THE U.S. AND PANAMA;
New Government Starts To Put Panama on Track

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Slowly, sometimes painfully, the new civilian Government here has begun grappling with the problems of getting post-Noriega Panama up and running again.
There are already some success stories.
In the three and a half weeks since President Guillermo Endara was sworn in, hours after an American invasion force ended the six-year rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, basic municipal services have been restored, and many schools and banks are preparing to reopen.
On Monday, Mr. Endara is expected to meet his first full, on-time payroll, issuing salary checks to more than 100,000 Government employees. 
In the capital and many outlying areas, garbage collectors have resumed regular pickups, many of them driving trucks repaired with the help of American troops. Street lamps and traffic lights, scores of which were shot out in the fighting, have been fixed.
 
Sewers Still Need Work
Telephone service, water and electricity have been restored ''pretty much to pre-conflict levels,'' a American military adviser said, although the sewer system, parts of which were apparently sabotaged, still needs work.
Airports are struggling back toward normalcy. On Saturday, the runway of a local airstrip known as Paitilla - the scene of a fierce firefight Dec. 20 between Navy commandos and Panamanian troops - was finally cleared of debris, including General Noriega's damaged private jet, which was carried away by an American helicopter.
But despite the progress, President Endara, a 52-year-old lawyer who had never held public office before, presides over a largely untested group of leaders who have not had nearly enough time to begin to free themselves of dependence on the United States for armed protection, financial aid and technical advice.
On Saturday, the newly appointed American Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, said the remaining 20,000 American troops in Panama would be withdrawn either to their bases here or to the United States as soon as possible, ''hopefully in a matter of weeks.'' Seven thousand troops have returned to the United States so far.
But Panamanian officials say they cannot possibly attend to the country's most pressing needs without a continuing American military presence, certainly for many months to come.
 
'We Need Their Help'
''There's a very strong desire, not only in the Government but among Panamanians generally, to keep the troops here much longer than the U.S. wants,'' Louis Martinz, a senior Endara aide, said today. ''We need their help simply because we can't do everything at once.''
Many ordinary Panamanians also seem haunted by the fear that without the troops in the streets, diehard Noriega loyalists might someday try to strike back with terrorist tactics.
In the last week, 300 civil-affairs advisers from the American military -half of them reservists, all under the supervision of American Embassy and the civilian Agency for International Development - have begun answering requests from such ministries as Health, Education, Public Works and the new police agency known as the Public Forces for suggestions on how to solve specific problems and reorganize their bureaucracies.
Another area in which the Americans are expected to be generous with their advice is in the formation of a new, corruption-free criminal justice system.
With an avalanche of Panamanian charges expected against scores of former Noriega loyalists, the courts will be especially busy. The Supreme Court, which was packed with the general's appointees, has already begun work with a new cast of justices.
 
Criminal Inquiries Begin
Although no indictments have been issued yet, in the last week the Attorney General, Rogelio Cruz, announced that criminal investigations had begun into the activities of many former Noriega loyalists, both military men and civilians.
Over the weekend, the new Comptroller General, Ruben Dario Carles, disclosed that while going through documents left behind by his predecessor, he discovered evidence of what appeared to be a $36.5 million slush fund set aside for the personal needs of the eight civilian Presidents who served under either General Noriega or his predecessor, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera.
''All of these investigations are going to take a long time,'' Mr. Martinz said. ''We haven't had access to government documents in 21 years.''
Others doubt the process will be that time-consuming.
''Basically, we know who all the corrupt people are,'' said I. Roberto Eisenmann Jr., publisher and editor in chief of the daily La Prensa. ''This is a very small country; everybody knew who was in what business and how much they were making. Typically, a lot of overnight millionaires were connected to a major here or a colonel there.''
 
Rooting Out the Untrustworthy
Apart from the task of investigating past corruption, Mr. Endara must also balance the task of rooting out untrustworthy holdovers from the old regime without crippling the staffs of the various ministries in the process.
The Endara Government's biggest single problem is building a police force capable of maintaining public order, guarding the Panama Canal and keeping the country free of drug traffickers - while at the same time remaining fully answerable to the civilian authorities.
The new Government's continuing reliance on American troops is a direct consequence of the fact that when General Noriega's 15,000-member Panamanian Defense Forces collapsed in defeat, the country was left not only without an army, but without customs and immigration authorities; a municipal, port and transit police; a presidential guard; a coast guard, and even a forestry police.
So far, the newly formed Public Force, a 1,000-member police agency composed of former Noriega troops, is keeping order in the streets by patrolling jointly with American combat units. The only ones on their own are 150 traffic police officers posted at intersections.
Panamanians are vigorously debating the ultimate size and duties of the Public Force, whose long-term reliability worries many people.
Some officials have expressed concern that if Panama follows the recommendations of American officials to endow the force with specialized anti-narcotics-trafficking powers, it could someday become powerful enough to threaten the civilian Government.
But Mr. Endara's First Vice Preident, Ricardo Arias Calderon, whose office supervises the Public Force, said he was confident that the new Government would be able to keep the police on a short leash.
''They will always be fully under the financial control of the Comptroller General's office,'' he said.
As for hiring former Noriega soldiers, officials say there was no way around it if Panama was to move quickly to build its own force; there was no time to train new personnel.
At the same time, the Government is facing intense pressure from Panama's business leaders, who are fearful of labor problems ahead unless there is quick assistance from the United States to ''jump start'' commercial activity, mainly in financial services and retail industry, the traditional mainstays of the Panamanian ecomomy.
Many of the hundreds of merchants whose inventories were stripped by looters warn that officials must move quickly to persuade Washington to give Panama millions of dollars in relief money to help put commerce back on its feet.
''Six thousand unemployed workers is one thing in a dictatorship,'' said a shoe manufacturer whose 375 employees were thrown out of work by the looting that occurred during the fighting. ''It's a whole other story in a democracy.''

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Scoring Political Points On Social Security Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Despite Republican claims, Federal taxes over all were not cut in the Reagan-Bush years. But Democrats have failed to persuade voters of that, or to call attention to the way the mix of taxes has changed.
That is mostly what is behind Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security payroll tax.
The New York Democrat has already succeeded in scoring political points by embarrassing President Bush, forcing the White House to express disapproval of a plan that would cut workers' taxes by more than $60 billion in the next two years. That, from a President who has made opposition to higher taxes the cornerstone of his political philosophy. 
And Senator Moynihan, who offered his plan just before New Year's Day and then left for Africa on a trip for the Foreign Relations Committee, has also managed to generate an unusual amount of debate on two points that he and some other Democrats have been harping on without much notice for years.
The first is that in the last decade lower income taxes were offset by higher Social Security taxes. The proportion of Federal taxes paid now is just under 20 percent of the gross national product, the same as at the beginning of the last decade.
Income taxes were sharply reduced. The top rate in the 1980's fell to 28 percent from 70 percent, providing a boon to the wealthy and some tax relief for the middle class and the working poor.
But at the same time, payroll taxes went way up. As of Jan. 1, workers and their employers are each paying 7.65 percent, 6.2 percent for retirement under Social Security and 1.45 percent for Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. The tax is paid on the first $51,300 earned. At the beginning of the decade, the payroll rate was 6.13 percent on the first $29,700 of income.
Nearly three-quarters of all Americans now pay more in payroll taxes than they do in income taxes. In the view of many Democrats, that is an abomination. Income taxes increase the more a taxpayer earns. Social Security taxes, on the other hand, are paid at the same rate by all workers, and those making $500,000 a year pay no more than those making $51,300. This year, the maximum payroll tax will total $3,924.45.
Senator Moynihan's other point is that the growing surplus of Social Security revenue, which will exceed $250 billion by the year 2000, is being used to mask the deficit in the Government's operating budget rather than to guarantee pension benefits for today's workers when they retire.
In the current fiscal year, the Government is taking in $65 billion more in Social Security taxes than it is paying out in benefits. If it were not for the Social Security surplus, the deficit, by the Bush Administration's accounting, would be more than half again what it says it is, about $165 billion instead of $100 billion. The main reason the overall deficit has fallen in recent years is not so much that spending has been cut, but that Social Security taxes have been increased.
Using Social Security revenue in effect for day-to-day government expenses, Mr. Moynihan says, is a perversion of the reason a schedule of rising payroll taxes was set in 1983. The Senator was a key member of a Presidential commission that established the new rates.
The theory behind the new rates, he says, was to allow money to be invested in productive ventures, thus promoting economic growth and producing the revenue needed for retirement benefits in the next century.
Mr. Moynihan says that since that is not being done, the only reasonable action is to cut the Social Security tax rate. He would reduce it this year to 6.06 percent (7.51 percent with Medicare), where it was in 1989, and reduce it further in 1991 to 5.1 percent (6.55 percent with Medicare). So far, only a few conservative Republicans and no Democrats have embraced the proposal. But tax cuts are so popular that lawmakers may feel compelled to vote for the plan if Mr. Moynihan presses his case.
Democratic leaders are hoping he will not do so. They are glorying in the political mileage the Senator is getting, but deep down they think the last thing the country needs is a tax cut of any kind.
''The Moynihan proposal reflects our frustration,'' said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader. But like the other leaders in the House and the Senate, he said he was unwilling to make a commitment.
