HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Flavors of Capitalism

BYLINE: By Nicholas Wade

 BODY:
Free trade is best, everyone agrees, but what should the United States do when its partners distort trade by closing their markets or targeting special industries for support? The answer is a subject of hot debate, as demonstrated anew in a study group commissioned by the Twentieth Century Fund, a New York research foundation. The group divided so sharply it issued two reports, one favoring traditional free trade, the other calling for revision of trade policy.
The focus of the debate is that the United States doesn't seem to be as good at making things as it once was. Japan's pre-eminence in cars, consumer electronics and some semiconductors is one visible symptom. The decline in America's export of high-technology goods is another. To most economists, the cause lies almost entirely in the overall weaknesses of the U.S. economy, like the high Federal deficit and low savings rate. 
''We have problems, but they are not made in Tokyo or Brussels: they are made here,'' said Herbert Stein, the economist who spoke for the free traders. ''We reject the notion that the United States should embark upon an industrial policy, meaning Government should select industries that need particular support.''
Clyde Prestowitz, a former trade negotiator with Japan, replied that when countries like Japan and Korea target particular industries for government support it is impossible to have open markets. The U.S. regularly complains that these practices are unfair, but the accusations cause only friction, not freer trade. Better to accept, says Mr. Prestowitz, that other countries regard the possession of certain industries as a national necessity, like the Europeans with Airbus, and to manage trade in such targeted sectors by agreement.
Free traders reject managed or ''results-oriented'' trade because the results are rarely as expected. U.S. sugar policy costs consumers more than $1 billion a year. The import quotas demanded by the U.S. auto industry only induced Honda, Toyota and Nissan to transfer production to the United States, and to switch to luxury cars instead of ''econoboxes.'' Better to agree on rules for open trading rather than try to fix the results.
But the hands-off approach, say the trade policy revisionists, is fatal when Japan targets an industry and drives out American companies. It matters a lot, they say, whether the U.S. is a maker of wood chips - or computer chips. Even after the U.S. has put its economic house in order, it will still face the fact that Japan practices a different flavor of capitalism, which gives its companies special advantages over their American competitors.
The free traders, in their Twentieth Century Fund report, concede that Japan's brilliant record of growth has been ''accompanied by a pervasive system of managed trade'' and that Japan has reduced its trade barriers only under intense foreign pressure. But Japan's targeting of high technology is unlikely to relegate the U.S. to second-class industrial status, the free traders say. The revisionists reply that the U.S. cannot let its economic future be ''dictated by the narrow and chauvinistic trade and industrial policies of other countries.''
What is society to do when even an expert group like this splits down the middle? Surely it should heed the advice of economists, almost all of whom back the free traders, by investing more, and having Government overspend less. But even economists might concede a little disquiet when whole industries, like consumer electronics or semiconductor equipment, seem headed for oblivion. Just in case their prescriptions prove insufficient, maybe the problems of particular industries are also a fit subject for government concern. NICHOLAS WADE

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Lift Manufacturing Ban on Phone Companies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''How to Rewire America'' (editorial, Jan. 1) raises the question of whether or not it is time to remove restrictions against the entry of telephone companies into cable television, as a means of making it economically feasible for them to hook up every home with fiber-optic cable. You might have added that local cable companies are deregulated and ought therefore not be protected from competition - provided that competitors are assured of free and fair access to such phone company networks.
We should also examine the other legal restraints on telephone companies to exploit modern telecommunications technology. The one that seems to me ripest for elimination is the ban, six years old Jan. 1, on manufacture of communications equipment by Bell operating companies. 
The prohibition made sense as long as the American Telephone & Telegraph Company was a single national telephone monopoly because that enabled it to monopolize equipment manufacture as well. But now manufacturing is highly competitive; and A.T.& T.'s local telephone business is in the hands of seven regional companies, no one of which offers a captive market sufficient to permit it to dominate the manufacturing business.
The danger remains that the local Bell companies would buy equipment from their manufacturing affiliates at inflated prices, hoping to pass costs on to captive customers. But the Federal Communications Commission and state regulatory agencies can hold these transfer prices to cost plus a reasonable return. The regulators would also have open-market competitive prices against which to test interaffiliate transfers.
Meanwhile, the manufacturing prohibition confronts the telephone companies with the threat of a contempt citation if ever they cross the boundary from research and development, in which they are very heavily engaged, to manufacturing. To a scientist or engineer that distinction is arbitrary: the essence of innovation is the play of information and ideas between basic research and marketing.
For example, one of the companies, Nynex, entered a partnership in 1986 with Citicorp and RCA for development of an inexpensive terminal to give telephone users electronic access to information services like directory listings, bill paying, banking and shopping by phone, but Nynex had to drop out because it could not cooperate consistently with the manufacturing prohibition. While big business users have all those capabilities available to them through their own computers and switches, the telephone company has the greatest incentive to make them available to all its subscribers.
The prohibition on manufacturing no longer serves its antitrust purpose; now, I think, it does more harm than good.
 
ALFRED E. KAHN
 Ithaca, N.Y., Jan. 2, 1990
The writer retired as the Robert Julius Thorne Professor of political economy at Cornell University.

HEADLINE: New Parks Commissioner Has Opportunity to Do a Lot of Good

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Cheers for Elizabeth F. Gotbaum, New York City's new Parks Commissioner, the first woman to hold this office (news article, Dec. 28). She could become the most important official in Mayor David N. Dinkins's administration, but it will require courage to review the imperatives that came from City Hall during the last decade, to question the directives that will come from City Hall in the years ahead and to place the public needs of the 1990's before special interests. The commissioner's stature would be measured by her willingness to ask hard questions. 
The last decade in the city's parks was marked by an obsession with massive, multimillion-dollar construction projects. By comparison, only a pittance was spent on maintaining the grounds. This, coupled with the past administration's view of recreation as theatrical entertainment, further threatened our parks.
In Prospect Park, an outdoor theater rushed to completion at spectacular cost, has vilified the landscape with the ugliest structure ever built. Now, a needless $22 million redesign of the nearby Grand Army Plaza is in the works, and the administrator talks dangerously of building another Wollman Rink, this time on a hilltop.
In Central Park, the department has been striving to enlarge theater offerings, first on a pier on Belvedere Lake, defeated by public outcry, and now with a high-tech, airport-style stage on the Mall, temporarily shelved by protest from every community planning board. The Parks Department persists and is prepared to spend millions for Broadway theatrical entertainment in the park.
The new commissioner is fortunate to have former commissioner Gordon Davis as adviser; she can find no better guide than his great 1980 park policy statement, which closed Central Park to Christo's fantasy of gates. But Mr. Davis is also respons-ible for advancing the policy he termed ''load shedding,'' a disavowal of responsibility and ceding of management to concessionaires, heavily subsidized, invited to take over sections of the park.
In Central Park, the Administrator proclaims the need for a restaurant at the Harlem Meer, unprecedented in the park's history, a banquet-catering hall, whose enlarged size is dictated by the need of the concessionaires for profits. Restaurants will no more eliminate drugs, the excuse here, than they will revive dwindling attendance at the Metropolitan Museum's Lehman Wing, over which another restaurant is to be built. Central Park has never been so threatened.
The new commissioner's urgent task is to appoint, as first deputy, a professionally trained horticulturist and to work with him or her to make our parks labor intensive. This would stand in contrast to the high point of the past parks administration, dedicating a new five-borough motor pool on Randalls Island.
Mrs. Gotbaum has a rare opportunity. The Parks Department is one city agency that can hire large numbers of the unemployed and the unskilled for maintenance and modest capital projects. They are always with us, otherwise without prospect of meaningful work.
 
ROBERT M. MAKLA
 New York, Jan. 3, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Baltics + Z - F.S.R.

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To their credit, the unreconstructed roundheels of The New York Times editorial pages gave extended space recently to an anonymous hard-line analysis, signed ''Z,'' that has caused a fearsome fluttering in the dovecotes.
Z argues that Mr. Gorbachev's announced plan for reforming the Communist system while retaining central control is hopeless; consequently, whatever the West does to help him postpone the day of free markets and a multiparty system only prolongs the agony of the exit from Communism.
Keep the pressure on, is Z's import; economic desperation causes political movement. I would add that our State Department mantra of ''stability,'' its go-slow admonitions to radicals and Mr. Bush's unstinting offer of economic aid to Moscow -untied to systemic change - help only those roll-with-the-punch totalitarians who will cling to as much power as they can. 
My Times colleagues' response: Since Gorbachev's rise, ''hard-liners have strained to find new rationales for old cold war animosities.'' Ad whominem? At me and him. Psycho-hangups aside, we hard-liners are said to ''duck the critical fact that the likely alternatives to Mr. Gorbachev would be far worse for Western interests.''
Revivified accommodationists, so wrong for so long about our policy of stressing the Soviet system, find what they consider a contradiction. They discover in Z's analysis ''what Western liberals and moderates have been urging all along - arms control and cooperative arrangements to develop market structures and joint economic ventures . . .''
Wrong. To soft-liners, arms control means a hurry-up strategic missile treaty, which would save the Russians vast sums while retaining their superpower threat; to hard-liners, arms control means first getting Soviet troops and tanks out of Eastern Europe, so that an end to occupation is not linked to Mr. Gorbachev's shaky personal fortunes.
Here is another difference between softs and hards: freedom for the Baltic peoples.
I have a large Bernese Mountain dog who bounds in out of the snow to lie on her back, paws splayed in every direction, in hopes of getting her belly scratched. This is the current State Department position on Baltic independence.
For 50 years, the U.S. has refused to acknowledge the Hitler-Stalin deal that forced Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia into becoming ''Soviet Socialist Republics.'' Nine U.S. Presidents have supported their independence-asserting legations in Washington.
With freedom now imminent, the Balts hear our State Department spokesman say their status is a Soviet ''internal matter.'' Why couldn't we cut the hand-wringing and say instead:
''The United States reasserts its longstanding recognition of Baltic independence. We applaud the peaceful but resolute way the Baltic peoples have recently demonstrated their desire for freedom.
''As these three countries gain their freedom in fact, we are prepared to join with the Soviet Union and European nations to create a Baltic Convertible Currency Zone. We will encourage a private economy capable of replacing the command system, speeding the day of a convertible ruble and the opening of Soviet markets.''
Such a targeted approach is a far cry from the tell-us-what-you-want, we-won't-rock-your-boat offer of trade by the eager Mr. Bush at Malta. One way requires genuine change; the other permits cosmetic change.
Here's the beauty part: Centrifugal agitation is now causing Mr. Gorbachev to rethink his insistence on one-party monopoly. He doesn't need tacit understanding from freedom-seekers; he needs a shove. Only then can he continue to play the man in the middle.
That's why some hard-liners here for the past year have been focusing on the Baltic states as the testing ground for real Soviet change. The freeing of six states of the empire has been breathtaking, but Baltic unrest reaches across what Moscow considers its border.
Mr. Gorbachev went to Lithuania to act against his words: in waggling a finger against inevitable separatism, he plunged ahead to ''I see no tragedy in a multiparty system.''
What brought about this high-wire flip-flop on the essence of one-party control - gentle accommodation by the Balts? Just the opposite.
Only unrelenting pressure from inside and out, accompanied by Red Army refusal to back political power with firepower, can change the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics into a less militarist F.S.R. - a Federation of Soviet Republics. While soft-liners are struck dumb with delight, hard-liners will keep pressing.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
A Needed Revolution

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
On the anniversary of Martin Luther King's birthday, those who have grown complacent about the racial situation in America can find plenty of evidence - if they'll look - that his work is not finished, and nowhere less so than in education.
As only one example, a state survey shows that 58 percent of black high school seniors in Maryland, compared with 76 percent of whites, plan to pursue higher education. But 22 percent of black male seniors intend to join the military, as against only 9 percent of whites.
Americans do not have to be liberal do-gooders to worry about that, because it vitally concerns their economic future. In the 1990's, only 2 of 10 new entrants in the American work force will be white males. Therefore, as Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, put it:
''If we are to compete effectively in the world economy, we need minority and poor youngsters to produce, rather than become dependent on us or shoot at us.'' 
Nor is it the problem, as all too many white Americans - some in positions of authority - seem to think, that minority students either can't or don't want to learn.
Evidence of their capacities was the only good news in a recent study made public by the Secretary of Education, Lauro F. Cavazos. It showed that the reading and writing skills of all American students -white or black - were ''dreadfully inadequate,'' requiring ''a revolution in teaching and learning.''
Black and Hispanic pupils, however, showed strong improvement in reading skills; white students made no such gains. Even so, 17-year-old whites remained about 20 points above minority youths in the study conducted by the National Assessment of Educational Progress. That suggests how far the education system has to go to achieve satisfactory performance for all.
It's not true, either - despite the ritual belief of many skeptical Americans - that funds spent on compensatory education programs for minority students are a waste of taxpayers' money. Officials of the assessment board said that older students had benefited considerably from preschool education programs like Head Start. One reason black and Hispanic students displayed greater gains than whites, in fact, was that many of the former had more directly benefited from such compensatory programs.
Nevertheless, ''a glaring gap between minority and non-minority educational achievement'' remains, another national study reported, because too many minority students ''still attend schools that are both separate and unequal.''
Again, that is, or should be, everybody's concern; as Shirley McBray, the study director, pointed out:
''Nearly one-quarter of all Americans are minority and by 2020 [only 30 years from now], at least one-third of the nation will be non-white.''
That study, financed by the Carnegie Corporation, was conducted over two years, at a cost of $1.2 million, by a project of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The many recommendations it made contradict another popular myth - that compensatory programs only benefit minorities. That might be the case with one proposal, to revise curriculums to reflect the culture of minorities; but most of the report's proposals clearly would benefit pupils of all races - nutrition assistance to the poor, for example, reduced class sizes, an extended school year, summer residencies on college campuses to improve older pupils' math and science skills and school aid for all children from welfare families.
Putting all these programs fully into effect, it was estimated in the report, would cost about $27 billion a year. Such substantial investment need not be out of the question, despite the deficit and those who share President Bush's opposition to new taxes. John E. Jacob, the president of the Urban League, for example, has called for a $50 billion program to train minority workers, with the money to come from no-longer-needed military expenditures.
It won't be easy, even with the cold war a bad memory, to wrest that kind of money away from the Pentagon and from fossilized Cold Warriors in Congress and the Administration. But what price bombers and missiles if, as Mr. Jacob properly warned:
''America will become a second-rate power unless we undertake . . . to insure that our neglected minority population gets the education, housing, health care and job skills . . . to help America compete successfully in a global economy.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 781 words

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Housing Project Poses Quandary: Is It Affordable?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
It was, Mayor Edward I. Koch declared at City Hall, ''probably the single most important announcement in the last five years made here in this room.''
Let's hope not. Nearly three years later, the significance of that showcase agreement by leading developers to build, at no profit, 1,000 apartments for middle-income families is affirmation of how difficult it is to get some things done in New York.
Even if the agreement survives a review by Mr. Koch's successor, Mayor David N. Dinkins, the number of apartments has been reduced, they will be affordable to fewer moderate-income families and they could require more than double the subsidy officials had anticipated. 
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has just recommended that the project be re-evaluated because ''the costs involved and the degree of risk are inordinately high'' and the prices now appear to be beyond the grasp of many less affluent middle-income buyers.
In 1984, Mr. Koch asked developers how the city could stimulate production of affordable housing without government subsidies. In response, the real-estate industry agreed to build 3,000 apartments at no profit if the city would streamline cumbersome regulations.
The city made strides. But the developers finally concluded that the housing could not be built unless the city helped pay for it.
In 1987, Mr. Koch announced the agreement to build the first apartments on 10 acres at Tibbett Avenue and West 230th Street in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. The city would sell the land to a Real Estate Board of New York subsidiary for $1 an acre. The city would pay a $15,000 to $25,000 subsidy per apartment to make them affordable to families with gross incomes ranging from $25,000 to about $50,000. Tibbett Gardens was to have been a prototype for at least 2,000 additional apartments sponsored by the board. Instead, it may have become an embarrassment.
The latest proposal, scaled back by the Board of Estimate, is to sell 75 apartments at market prices to defray costs on 675 subsidized apartments. Those are expected to be sold for from $64,000 for a studio to $128,000 for a three-bedroom to buyers whose income can range as high as $60,840.
The relatively small condominium apartments would be built for about $120,000 each -roughly the cost of the most expensive city-sponsored apartment renovations. The original $25,000 city subsidy is expected to balloon to about $50,000 - in part, because of legal challenges, inflation and the expense of complying with handicapped-access and other requirements, but primarily because of borrowing costs. (In comparison, subsidies for a Harlem project by the New York City Partnership, a nonprofit consortium, which hired a private developer, averaged $25,000 per apartment.) Slow sales could increase interest costs. If the city fails to recoup its loans, Elinor B. Bachrach, a deputy state comptroller, warns the subsidy could average as much as $90,000 per apartment.
Mr. Dinkins is torn. He voted for Tibbett Gardens. He has labored to reassure the business community that he is neither profligate nor against development. To revamp the project might mean years of delay, which could prove fatal. It would fuel opposition by advocates for more affordable housing and by the site's northwest Bronx neighbors, some of whom fear congestion and prefer that the land be reserved for an educational complex rather than for middle-income residents, or worse.
''There are people on my side of the issue who don't want those black and brown faces anywhere nearby,'' says Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President. ''That bothers me. But that's not going to affect my decision that this is a crummy site for housing and a poor way to use scarce housing dollars.''
Steven Spinola, the Real Estate Board president, is hopeful. He said the board has already invested $1 million in time and money out of self-interest: developers' stake in the city could be jeopardized if middle-income families cannot find some place to live. The city itself has spent about $3.5 million, he said.
Mr. Spinola said construction could begin immediately if the city's Housing Development Corporation and Citibank agree on financing. He predicted that all the apartments would be sold in four years. But he acknowledged that if the board tiptoes into a second project, this one in Queens, it would proceed differently.
Three years ago, Mr. Spinola figured that Tibbett Gardens would ''demonstrate what it is going to take to build affordable housing in the city.'' He was right. Now the city must weigh the need, the symbolism and the expense and decide whether this is one housing project it can still afford.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: Panel Stresses Productivity In Budget Fight

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
New York City should increase the productivity of municipal workers by using more one-officer police cars, closing underused firehouses and introducing one-worker garbage trucks among other measures, a private budget-monitoring group urged in a report released yesterday.
In its report on the state of city services, the group, the Citizens Budget Commission, called on Mayor David N. Dinkins and other city officials to balance the city's budget not by relying entirely on tax increases and service cuts but by improving efficiency.
''We're in a period,'' said the group's president, Raymond D. Horton, a Columbia University professor, ''when the economy is going south and also at a period when the sheer dependence of so many New Yorkers on the city for not just food, clothing and shelter but a variety of things from preventing child abuse to treating AIDS is enormous.''
 
'A Huge Bureaucracy'
''So if the entire budget-balancing process rests on the citizenry in the form of taxes and service cuts, that's really sticking it to them,'' he added. ''There's a huge bureaucracy that has to contribute, too.'' 
The report comes as city officials have warned that the city must close a budget gap of $400 million in the rest of the fiscal year that ends June 30 and faces a projected gap of more than $1 billion in the next fiscal year. Mr. Dinkins has already ordered all city agencies to prepare cuts to help close the current gap.
The Mayor's press secretary, Albert Scardino, said last night that Mr. Dinkins's position is that ''there will likely be a significant need for new tax revenues'' in the next fiscal year. But until the state prepares its new budget, no specific plans for new taxes can be made by the city, Mr. Scardino said. ''There is no way to know what they might be and where they might come from.''
At the same time, the Mayor and his first deputy, Norman Steisel, have indicated that they are open to a thorough review of how the city goes about providing services in an effort to make it perform more effectively. As Sanitation Commissioner in the Koch administration, Mr. Steisel presided over a major productivity gain, the introduction of two-worker garbage trucks, replacing three-member crews.
Mr. Steisel said he was not sure that one-worker garbage trucks, which are used in some cities, could be easily used in New York. But he said he had not yet fully reviewed the report and would not dismiss any of its suggestions ''out of hand.''
 
'A Helpful Indicator'
''We need to do a thoughtful analysis and make a judgment about whether they are workable,'' he said of the suggestions. ''The fact that they're used in other cities is a helpful indicator, but all it is is an indicator. One has to look at the unique circumstances here and decide whether you can go forward in our city at this time.''
He said whatever was done would follow ''discussion and cooperation with our labor groups.''
Many of the report's suggestions, including one-officer police patrol cars, have been discussed for years and never put into effect because they were deemed impractical, inappropriate or politically difficult by prior administrations. The strong reaction of municipal workers' unions to the report's recommendations makes it clear that they would resist some of the proposed changes.
For example, Mr. Steisel and the new Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown, have said use of one-officer patrol cars must be studied seriously.
But Phil Caruso, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the main police union, issued a statement saying it has long opposed one-officer patrol cars for safety reasons, although the Police Department uses them now in highway units and for some guard-duty assignments.
''If the geniuses at the Citizens Budget Commission think such procedures would be safe, let them ride in police cars by themselves,'' Mr. Caruso said.
 
A Succinct Reaction
Edward Ostrowksi, president of the sanitation workers union, was even more succinct in his reaction to the suggestion of one-worker garbage trucks. ''I think it's time for a no-man Citizens Budget Commission,'' he said.
In addition to recommending that underused firehouses be closed, the report called on the city to shift more emergency and rescue duties from the police to firefighters and to press the State Legislature to repeal a 1938 law requiring that fire companies be staffed at the same levels day and night.
Louis Sforza, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said the staffing suggestion would ''play Russian roulette with the lives of the people of New York City'' and ''borders on insanity.''
But Mr. Horton of the budget commssion, which is financed mostly by the city's business community, said difficult fiscal times called for new initiatives, in the same way that the two-worker garbage truck was introduced in the early 1980's, when the city was still recovering from its fiscal crisis of the mid-70's. He said that in the last two years, for the first time since use of the two-worker trucks began, the efficiency of garbage collection as measured by the city's own index had declined.
The index compares hours worked and tons collected against predetermined standards, and in the 1987-89 period it fell to 95.2 percent from 97.3 percent, indicating that the city may have achieved all the gains it can from the two-worker trucks and now needs to begin using one-worker trucks, Mr. Horton said.
 
Looking for Opportunities
Mr. Steisel said that ''as with many services, there may be advances in technologies that allow you to do even more productivity.'' He said one-worker trucks were now used in other cities ''in back alleys, with cart collection.''
''My sense is you may be able to find such opportunities in New York City, but I'm not sure they're as extensive as the report would suggest,'' he said.
Noting the city's severe jail overcowding problems, the report said the city should ''make much wider use of alternatives to incarceration,'' including more flexible bail requirements, work-release programs and drug and alcohol treatment programs for addicts. Mr. Dinkins called for expanded opportunities for drug treatment as a major theme in his campaign but has not yet made clear how much he thinks the city should do or how it would pay for the programs.
The report also called on the Police Department to transfer more officers from administrative jobs to direct law-enforcement positions, by adding civilians if necessary, and to assign more officers to foot patrol instead of patrol cars.

HEADLINE: Rage Over a Gas Pipeline Appears to Cool in Connecticut

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHERMAN, Conn., Jan. 10

 BODY:
When Hank Dutton moved to this rural, one-stoplight town two decades ago to start a 20-acre hobby farm, he never figured on sharing his prized back pasture with a 24-inch-wide natural-gas pipeline.
''I don't think the cows are going to like this,'' he said.
Such complaints, usually less understated, have been common for the last three years among the 2,600 residents of this northern Fairfield County town, the planned entry point in Connecticut for a $583 million, 369-mile underground pipeline from Iroquois, Ontario, to South Commack, L.I.
But as the pipeline plans progress in the complicated approval process, the fervor of opponents appears to be fading. ''People have been at this for so long that time has taken its toll,'' said Gary B. Davis, spokesman for the Iroquois Gas Transmission System, a consortium of Canadian and United States natural-gas utilities planning the pipeline. 
 
Remark About Arthur Miller
Opponents of the pipeline here and throughout southwestern Connecticut believe that much of the most vigorous anti-pipeline activity - angry town meetings, fund-raising rallies and ''Stop the Pipe'' T-shirt sales - has diminished because of a 1987 rerouting away from Litchfield County and the more affluent towns of Salisbury, Roxbury and Washington.
Many are still rankled by a remark that Mr. Davis made last year about how Iroquois was no longer bothered by telephone calls from the playwright Arthur Miller, who lives in Roxbury.
''There are a lot of people in those towns who have a lot of money and can make a lot of noise,'' said John Duncan, a computer programming manager whose colonial-style house in Sherman lies about 500 feet from the pipeline's route. Opponents also cite the wooing by Iroquois of local politicians and residents. The company has announced plans to buy $10 million worth of land in New York and Connecticut, which it will lease to municipalities and private groups for use as parks.
 
'Making an Effort'
But Iroquois officials say the company is merely being a good neighbor. They said the route was shifted from Roxbury for economic reasons, not because of Mr. Miller. They also note that they have held frequent meetings in each of the eight Connecticut towns now in the pipeline's path in an effort to allay fears about the effect on the environment.
Opponents fear a natural-gas pipeline could leak into the ground water or explode.
''I don't think anybody has gone 180 degrees,'' Mr. Davis said. ''But many of them would have to say that we're making an effort to address their concerns and provide information.''
The pipeline, a connection off the huge Trans-Canada pipeline, was announced in 1986. It crosses the United States-Canadian border at Waddington, N.Y., zigzags through upstate New York and enters Sherman from Dutchess County, N.Y.
From Sherman, which was added to the route in 1987, the pipeline will burrow to New Milford in Litchfield County, into Brookfield, Newtown, Monroe, Shelton and Stratford in Fairfield County and then into Milford in New Haven County before running under the Long Island Sound to the Long Island Lighting Company's Northport station in Huntington. Then it would be buried along a Lilco right of way to the South Commack substation.
 
Awaiting Approval
The pipeline has received state approval in New York, even though such approval was not necessary; the Federal Government has sole legal jurisdiction over interstate pipelines. Iroquois is negotiating rights of way with property owners in New York.
But in Connecticut and New York the project still must receive final approval from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Army Corps of Engineers, which have held several public hearings over the last four years, including four in Danbury and Albany last week.
Iroquois officials are confident of approval but are concerned that Connecticut may challenge Federal jurisdiction over the pipeline and delay, if not stop, the project. It has been criticized by virtually every state politician, including Gov. William A. O'Neill, on environmental and economic grounds.
The pipeline would take a year to build; the company expects the project to be approved by the end of this year and completed by the end of 1991.
''We will be in operation as scheduled,'' Mr. Davis said.
 
'Big Bucks Talking Here'
The grass-roots opposition in Connecticut, though less strident than it once was, remains troublesome to Iroquois.
At a public hearing this week, about 100 people criticized Federal officials. ''This is a real joke!'' yelled Lola Shumlin, a Sherman resident. ''You don't care if you hurt these residents, because it's big bucks talking here.''
''There is still a lot of battle left in most of us,'' Mr. Dutton added.
But more common are moderate assessments like those of Sherman's First Selectman, Kenneth F. Grant. ''Nobody wants it in their backdoor yard,'' he said. ''But if we're going to have it, then we want to have it where we want and in a manner we want.''
Opponents contend that the project will ruin valuable farmland, wetlands and natural areas, as well as several golf courses and parks. They also believe that the economic need for the pipeline has not been established.
 
Need for Gas Is Questioned
''We're not opposed to gas,'' said Karen Ann Hayward, a consultant for the Housatonic Valley Association in Cornwall Bridge. ''We're opposed to how this project is totally disregarding the environment, particularly if there is no need for it - and the need has not been shown.''
Iroquois officials have argued that natural gas is needed because it is less polluting and more available than oil, on which the region is now heavily dependent. The pipeline would carry 125 million cubic feet of gas daily to New York City and Long Island and 144 million cubic feet a day to Connecticut customers.
In all, 576 million cubic feet of gas would be carried daily on the entire pipeline, enough to generate three times as much power as would have been created by the Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island, which was mothballed last year. Gas would also be provided to Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New Hampshire and New Jersey.
Iroquois officials said a recent increase in oil prices and a shortage of natural gas in the Northeast in the last few months should be enough evidence of the region's need for additional supplies.
''The issue is violation - many of these people believe they are being violated by this proposal,'' Mr. Davis said. ''They do not believe that the benefits to the entire region outweigh their concern for their community.''

HEADLINE: Florio Plans An Assault On Poverty In the Cities

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Governor-elect James J. Florio envisions an aggressive administration that will experiment with new approaches to protecting the environment and begin an assault on urban poverty.
Mr. Florio says he plans to use Camden, one of the poorest cities in the nation, as his first test of a partnership between business and government to help children and the unemployed.
''If you can bring Camden back you can bring any place back,'' Mr. Florio said as he spooned a lunch of vegetable soup out of a paper cup in his transition office. ''The key to our national success in the past was the perception that we all had opportunity. We have got to create opportunity.'' 
 
Sharp Drop in Revenues
New Jersey is a particularly good laboratory for experimenting with new approaches to urban problems, aides to Mr. Florio said, because its cities are small, making up 10 percent of the population. Modest programs in small cities, they said, can produce more visible results than in a huge, troubled metropolis like New York or Detroit.
But standing in the way of Mr. Florio's initiatives is a budget crisis that will demand action soon after Mr. Florio takes office tomorrow. With revenues dropping sharply, Mr. Florio may have to cut $500 million in services or raise that amount in taxes this fiscal year, politicians here say.
Nonetheless, in interviews last week, Mr. Florio and top members of his staff sketched their vision for a Democratic administration dedicated to solving social problems, a kind of ''post-Reagan activism,'' they said, after eight years of Republican leadership under Gov. Thomas H. Kean.
Although most of Mr. Florio's plans are still taking shape, and many may not be introduced until well into the administration, aides to Mr. Florio said their goal is to experiment with new approaches to some of the nation's most intractable problems, including a crackdown on environmental polluters, expansion of recycling, controls on overdevelopment and improvement of a health-care system that leaves more than one million New Jerseyans uninsured.
Tomorrow, Mr. Florio plans to call for a special session of the Legislature on Jan. 22 to announce his plans to reduce automobile insurance rates.
But perhaps his top long-term priority, Mr. Florio said, will be an ambitious assault on urban poverty in which he plans to enlist the help of businesses to train workers, improve education and expand social services for people left behind by the economic boom of the 1980's.
''We in government don't have the money to do all we would like to do,'' said Steven P. Perskie, who will serve as Mr. Florio's chief of staff. ''But now you can go to business and say, here, on your bottom line, is the reason for helping with drug treatment, with day care, with job training. Not out of altruism, but because it makes good business sense.''
Given industry's desperate need for new workers in this mostly suburban state and the high unemployment in cities, Mr. Florio said he hoped to bring the poor into the work force by creating partnerships between government and industry, as well as new programs in the schools.
Mr. Florio said he would start this approach in Camden, where infant mortality is the highest in the nation and government attempts at revitalization have failed for 30 years. Mr. Florio represented Camden in his 15 years as a Congressman.
What makes this kind of government possible at a time of budget constraints, Mr. Florio argues, is that economic forces now require businesses to search for solutions to the state's most serious social problems and to look to government for help.
''The time is right,'' Mr. Florio said. ''There has never been a time that I can remember when there has been more parallelism between private-sector concerns and the concerns of the public. I see a partnership approach with government acting as a catalyst.''
 
A Year of Crisis
But talk of saving the cities seems starry-eyed to many New Jersey politicians, who see 1990 as a year of crisis for Mr. Florio. Unless he overcomes budget, tax and insurance problems, they say, he will have neither the money nor the political support to pursue lofty goals.
Although Mr. Florio said during the campaign that he did not foresee a need for new taxes, budget specialists in the Legislature say state revenues may be running $500 million short in a $12 billion budget for this fiscal year, which ends on June 30.
Mr. Florio and his aides have refused to talk about their budget plans, but hints from top Democrats suggest that the new Governor may propose an increase in the income tax. He is expected to disclose his fiscal plans in a budget message before March 15.
Making matters more complex for the new administration, a major State Supreme Court decision is expected in the next few months that may require the state to change the way it funds public schools, at a cost of hundreds of millions to the state. Also, legislators feel growing rage from voters over rising property taxes.
 
Reliance on Property Taxes
Together, the budget problems, the court decision and the property taxes may well turn 1990 into the year when Mr. Florio proposes major tax reform, an idea that has been discussed here for years.
Mr. Florio and other Democrats have long been critical of New Jersey's reliance on property taxes to raise revenue, a system they say discriminates against cities. But Republicans and others oppose increasing the income tax, saying such a shift would stifle economic growth.
In the interview last week, Mr. Florio, 52 years old, conveyed a striking contrast, both in style and philosophy, to his predecessor.
Mr. Kean was, above all, a popular Governor, who used his buoyant personality to convery a feeling of hope about the state. In an interview he was as likely to chat about children and offer whimsical anecdotes as to discuss legislation crossing his desk.
Mr. Florio, on the other hand, possesses a passion for public policy and far less patience for small talk.
To friends, colleagues and assistants, Mr. Florio, the author of the nation's Superfund law that provides Federal funds to clean toxic-waste sites, is known for his remarkable command of detail and a thirst for information about social problems and their possible solutions.
''My husband is the only man I know who can talk passionately about sludge,'' his wife, Lucinda, said last year during the campaign.
Mr. Kean's top priority was to encourage business growth. Mr. Florio says the greatest problems facing the state now are byproducts of the economic boom that business alone cannot cure: the urban poor, clogged highways, increasingly endangered natural resources, and industries like insurance and health care that he believes need tighter regulation.
Since 1982, more than 600,000 jobs have been created in New Jersey, reducing unemployment to nearly 4 percent statewide and less in some areas. But businesses in those areas badly need qualified workers, while many residents of the nearby cities, which were left out of the economic good times, remain out of work.
 
Improved Prenatal Care
The new administration's plan to attack poverty is likely to be presented to the public as initiatives for children. Florio aides said they hoped to involve businesses in programs to improve prenatal care, to provide day care for working mothers, and to create transportation to bring inner-city workers to suburban jobs.
Mr. Florio said he will also propose legislation to expand health-insurance policies to cover drug abuse, and to encourage businesses to add drug-treatment programs.
Concerning the environment, Mr. Florio said he envisioned incentives for industries to reduce production of harmful wastes, and to have state government and public authorities use recycled products. He also said he expected to appoint an ''environmental prosecutor'' to crack down on polluters in highly publicized cases.
''In the history of government in this country the states have been laboratories,'' Mr. Perskie, the chief of staff, said. ''We are going to be a laboratory for a new set of approaches. The ones that work will be exportable.''

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
'Jonquil,' the 3d Play in a Saga of Black History

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
With harshness as well as equanimity, Charles Fuller's ''Jonquil'' reveals the obstacles to full emancipation in the South immediately after the Civil War. Through a voting rights episode in a small South Carolina community, the author views the Reconstruction period as one of the uglier chapters in the nation's history. ''Jonquil,'' the third play in Mr. Fuller's projected five-play series about black Americans in the second half of the 19th century, opened Saturday at the Negro Ensemble Company.
In common with ''Sally'' and ''Prince,'' the two plays that preceded it, ''Jonquil'' is not yet a finished work. A tentativeness in some of the characterizations and in Douglas Turner Ward's production lessens Mr. Fuller's argument. But for the first time in this ambitious cycle, the author tellingly dramatizes a complex situation and has a narrative strong enough to carry the play to a tragic conclusion. 
Though ''Jonquil'' makes passing reference to the earlier plays, especially in regard to the absent character of Prince Logan, a charismatic black soldier in the Union Army, the play stands on its own as a portrait of a section of the South totally unable to face its defeat and to discontinue a dehumanizing way of life. The theatergoer need not have seen the first plays in order to follow this one.
At the center is the character named Calvin (Charles Weldon), who is embarking on what he envisions as a political career. Calvin is willfully trying to transform himself into a leader of men. His primary asset appears to be the absence of any others challenging him for that position. In the course of the play, he grows as a candidate for state office, and he also sees the error of his pragmatic ways. Cowardly when his wife, Sally, is attacked by members of the Ku Klux Klan, he is gradually swept into taking a stand.
His allies include a loose assembly of rebels and passivists, from Graham Brown as a man who believes that only by arming themelves can blacks begin to achieve their rights, to Samuel L. Jackson, who has his mind entirely on the concept of owning property. As in the earlier plays, the author sees economics as a root concern, with blacks demanding equal pay as they did when they served in the army. In the case of ''Jonquil,'' they also claim the right to vote, and that claim sends them into violent collision with whites.
Mr. Fuller's white characters include a judge (William Mooney) whose paternalism barely conceals his racism and an apparently well-meaning carpetbagger (Tracy Griswold) with his own ambiguous attitude toward questions of brotherhood. Although some of the minor characters, black and white, become simplistic, these two and others have shadings that make their reactions unpredictable.
The symbolic center is intended to be the title character. Jonquil (Cynthia Bond) is one aspect of the play that needs strengthening. She is blind, but she hears with a mystical intensity. It is she, for example, who can testify with the most certainty about the identity of the hooded assailants who humiliated her friend Sally. Jonquil remains in the background. Whenever she is given prominence, she becomes the embodiment of Mr. Fuller's premise, which is that progress can only come through unity.
The comprehensive title of this cycle is ''We,'' a word that the illiterate Jonquil uses in the objective case, as in ''Folks are always forgetting what they do to we.'' Led by Jonquil as concerned conscience, the ''we'' will presumably consolidate their protest in the next play in the series.
Even as ''Jonquil'' is the sturdiest of the plays to date, the production is schematic. Charles McClennahan's unfurnished setting is only a step from a workshop. Several of the actors, including Mr. Weldon, still seem to be adjusting themselves to the demands of the play. Iris Little (as Sally), Mr. Mooney, Mr. Brown and, particularly, Ms. Bond are more insightful about delineating characters.
Because of its intelligent perspective on American history, ''Jonquil'' reminds one of Mr. Fuller's early play ''The Brownsville Raid.'' It is a sign that, as it proceeds, ''We'' is advancing.
 
'We' as an Object

HEADLINE: Companies

 BODY:
A bank syndicate extended a deadline for Campeau's retailing operations. The American and Japanese banks, which are owed $2.34 billion, gave Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores until Friday to provide assurances that the nine department store chains they own are solvent, banking and retailing executives said. The banks' decision came after Federated and Allied said they hoped to name a new American chief executive with a merchandising background some time this week. Despite the four-day extension, financial and retailing executives said they expected Campeau to file for bankruptcy protection sometime this week. [Page A1.] 
Sears, Roebuck may have stemmed its decline. Some analysts say the nation's largest retailer will eventually become the turnaround story of retailing in the 1990's. [D1.]
 
International Report
U.S. foundations and research groups are playing an active role in shaping Eastern Europe's transition to free markets. This involvement has become quite evident, with the Hudson Institute even helping to draw an economic action plan for the next Hungarian Government. [D1.]
Western Europe's economy is growing at a faster pace, and some economists predict that growth there will exceed that of the U.S. in the 1990's. [D1.]
General Motors and Suzuki have agreed to set up production plants in Hungary. [D8]
Hong Kong companies are expanding overseas. The move abroad comes as the territory prepares for the return of Beijing's rule in 1997. But Hong Kong executives say there are business reasons as well as political ones for the move. [D8.]
The Belzberg family of Canada offered to buy Koor Industries, a troubled Israeli concern, for $130 million. [D2.]
 
The Economy
Airlines have been quietly giving large companies a break. They are waiving restrictions on discount fares for travel agencies with big corporate clients, industry experts say. [D1.]
The Internal Revenue Service is taking action to prevent misconduct by its senior employees. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
Negotiations for the rights to ''Monday Night Football'' are expected to be hotly contested, with CBS and Fox likely to challenge ABC, which has owned the television rights for 20 years. [D6.]
Newspapers are feeling the pinch from the troubles in the retailing industry as many department stores tighten their advertising budgets. [D6.]
At least 10 new publishing houses have been started in the last two years, despite the consolidation in the industry. [D6.]
Hollywood is unlikely to change how it does business, even though Art Buchwald won a court victory against Paramount Pictures over the story rights to ''Coming to America.'' [D6.]
Is Miles Drentell for real? The agency boss in the ABC television series ''thirtysomething'' has stirred a debate in the advertising community about whether Miles is representative of industry executives. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Europe Taking a Lead in Growth

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The benefits already flowing from the European Community's continuing effort to create a single market by 1992 and the changes in Eastern Europe are prompting economists to predict that Western Europe's economic growth will exceed that of the United States in the 1990's.
For much of the 1980's, the fast-growing American economy was the envy of Western Europeans, who seemed to think that the high unemployment and sluggish growth plaguing most of their nations were insurmountable problems.
No longer. Last year, the economy of all Western European nations outpaced that of the United States. It grew 3.5 percent, while the United States economy grew about 3 percent. 
Economists expect growth in Western Europe to continue to outpace that in the United States for at least two years and possibly much longer. While annual growth in the United States is widely expected to average 2.5 percent in the 1990's, many economists expect Western Europe to grow by 3 to 3.5 percent a year.
 
'A Locomotive Role'
''It's very important for the world economy and the United States that Europe in conjunction with Japan should exhibit stronger economic growth,'' said George A. Magnus, chief international economist at Warburg Securities in London. ''To a degree, Europe is fulfilling a locomotive role as the U.S. economy slows down.''
With the 12 nations of the European Community moving ahead with their program to create a barrier-free common market by 1992 and with Eastern Europe moving toward democracy and market-based economies, there is a palpable excitement in Europe - a feeling that the Age of Europe may be dawning.
''There's a lot of dynamism in Europe,'' said Norbert A. Walter, chief economist at Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest bank. ''Nineteen ninety-two and the Eastern Europe reforms have created the perception around the globe that Europe is on the move, that there is a renaissance in Europe.''
For a couple of years there have been signs that optimism is replacing the pessimism that had long gripped Europe. But with unemployment in Europe remaining high and inflation inching upward, many economists still feared that the expansion would lose steam.
About the only major nation where that has happened is Britain, whose Government's use of high interest rates to combat an inflation rate of 7.7 percent has brought growth nearly to a standstill.
With West Germany and other major European countries maintaining a relatively tight monetary policy, most economists are now cautiously optimistic that inflation, which hit a plateau in the second half of last year, will remain under control. Annual inflation in the European Community could average 4 percent between 1990 and 1995, down from 5.4 percent last year, said Paul Cockle, chief European economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, the economic consulting firm.
Reflecting the cheerful new outlook, economists have managed to find a virtue in Western Europe's high unemployment rate, which has been falling only slowly. The rate -now about 9 percent - means Western Europe does not face the kinds of limits on growth confronting the United States, where unemployment is 5.3 percent, they say.
In a turnaround from just a year ago, some economists say it is possible that unemployment could fall to 6 or 7 percent by the mid-1990's. But any sizable reduction will require sustained economic growth of 3 to 4 percent, they say.
 
Boom in Capital Spending
One big reason for the current optimism is the capital-spending boom that has been under way in the European Community for several years. ''By helping to make sure that demand does not outstrip supply, the buoyant investment is an important factor in a continued noninflationary expansion,'' said David A. Currie, an economist at the London Business School.
While the spending boom has been slowing, it shows no signs of petering out. ''We had expected a greater moderation than there has been,'' Mr. Cockle said.
This spending, economists say, is being fueled by a combination of excitement and fear that the 1992 program has created.
Some companies are spending heavily to exploit the opportunities for expansion that they think the single market will offer them. Others are doing so to defend themselves against the increased competition they expect.
Investment in machinery and equipment has been growing at 9 percent annually in West Germany, even more in France and more than 20 percent in Spain and Portugal, Dr. Walter of Deutsche Bank noted.
 
Money From Outside
Heavy investment from companies based outside the community is one big reason this growth is so strong. ''Enticed by both the opportunities and the fears that outsiders may be prevented from exploiting them, companies from outside the European Community - especially the Japanese, the Swedes, the Finns and the Australians - are continuing to pour money into the community,'' said Martin Waldenstrom, president of Booz Allen Acquisition Services, a unit of Booz Allen & Hamilton, the consulting firm.
Mr. Waldenstrom, who recently completed a study for the European Community, said American direct investment in the community, which soared in the mid-1980's, has declined since its peak in 1987.
The European Commission, the community's executive branch, estimated earlier that the 1992 program could add as much as one percentage point to the community's medium-term economic growth.
The surprise is that the rise has come so soon. Given the heavy capital spending, some economists now say that 1992 has already added a total of two to three percentage points over the last three years to the European Community's economic growth and that the total extra growth from the 1992 program could exceed the commission's prediction.
 
'Clear Change' in Behavior
''There has been a clear change in European economic behavior,'' Robert Z. Lawrence, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said of the new optimism.
While it may be too early to pronounce Communism dead in Eastern Europe, the widespread hope is that the leadership role that Western Europe would play in rebuilding Eastern Europe will take up where 1992 leaves off in keeping Western Europe's expansion rolling along.
West Germany, already the economic locomotive of Western Europe (its gross national product represents 25 percent of the European Community's), is expected to reap the greatest benefit from any rebuilding of Eastern Europe. Mr. Walter predicted that the portion of West Germany's exports going to Eastern European countries could soar to 15 percent of its total within 10 years, from 5 percent now.
While such forecasts may be too optimistic, the flood of immigrants from the East is already giving a boost to West Germany's economy. The influx of 1.3 million ethnic Germans from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union in the last three years is adding one-quarter to three-quarters of a percentage point to West Germany's gross national product, economists figure.
 
Help for Labor Shortage
Most of the immigrants are younger people who are in their prime spending years and who can help alleviate the shortage of skilled workers in West German industry. In addition, it is already clear that the immigration will force the Government to increase social spending to house the new arrivals.
To keep West Germany's inflation, now about 3 percent, under control, the Bundesbank, the country's central bank, is expected to continue to pursue its tight monetary policy. But economists do not expect it to slow the economy much. They note that besides the stimulus from the immigration, a sizable tax cut went into effect on Jan. 1.
With many economists expecting this tight monetary policy and looser fiscal policy to continue well into the 1990's, the result could be a higher value for the West German mark and an increase in imports that would stimulate the economies of West Germany's trading partners.
''What the capitalist economies could never persuade the West Germans to do, the demise of Communism is achieving - a more expansive policy,'' said Mr. Lawrence of Brookings. Implications for the U.S. What does all this mean for the United States?
Exports to Western Europe will undoubtedly continue to rise. A surge in such exports - to an estimated $100 billion last year from $61.6 billion in 1986 - has largely eliminated America's trade deficit with Western Europe.
Most economists note that this amount of exports is still tiny compared with the size of the $5 trillion American economy, and will not spell the difference between growth and recession.
The growing attractiveness of Europe - both East and West - as a place to invest could pose some threats to the United States. For one thing, the United States may find it increasingly difficult to attract the foreign capital it needs to finance its big trade and budget deficits.
 
'Pressure on the Dollar'
As a result, ''it may end up putting a lot of downward pressure on the dollar,'' said Charles R. Bean, an economist at the London School of Economics. That, he said, could translate into higher inflation and a drop in the standard of living for Americans.
If disarmament continues, reducing the importance of United States military power, American influence in the world could continue to slip because of its weakening economic muscle. The back seat America seems to be taking in the West's response to the events in Eastern Europe reflects this decline, political analysts and economists say.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
U.S. Foundations Seek an East Bloc Role

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 13

 BODY:
American foundations and research groups are playing an active role in shaping Eastern Europe's transition to free markets, even helping to draw up an economic action plan for the next Hungarian Government.
The involvement was quite evident here over the last few days as the Hudson Institute, a staunch advocate of free markets, held the first gathering of a self-designated ''blue-ribbon commission'' of prominent Hungarians and Westerners. The panel is preparing detailed economic proposals for the Hungarian Government that will come to power after the March 25 parliamentary election.
Publication of the plan, covering such things as private ownership, labor law, taxes, social welfare, inflation and foreign exchange rates, is scheduled for early April. 
The Hudson project highlights a change in the overseas role of private American groups. Rarely in the past were they so openly active in trying to shape other countries; rather, they stayed in the background, financing research and other support work.
 
Evolutionary Catalysts
Taking note of the change, Kevin F. F. Quigley, an executive of the Pew Charitable Trusts, said the foundations had been given ''a historic opportunity to be catalysts in the evolution of Eastern Europe toward the values that we favor.''
Pew, which dispenses $140 million a year in grants, mostly for health and education projects in the United States, is just getting involved in Eastern Europe. Mr. Quigley came here to consider Hudson's Hungarian commission as a candidate for Pew funds.
The Ford Foundation, the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the George Soros Foundation, among others, are already dispensing money to such beneficiaries as Polish farmers and people organizing political parties.
The Hudson commission's mixture of prominent Westerners and Hungarians is intended to make its plan hard to resist for the next Government. That, at least, is the strategy of the organizers, a group of Hungarian politicians, the Hudson Institute and Paul Marar, an intermediary who brought them together. Mr. Marar, a Hungarian-born economist who fled his homeland as a young man in 1956, is now a specialist on Hungary at Indiana University.
 
No Credibility Now
''This is a bipartisan effort for a Government that will take office without having given the details of economic transformation much thought,'' Mr. Marar said. ''Right now there is no credibility within Hungary. The old Government is discredited, and the new political parties have no track record yet.''
Indiana University is sharing the cost of the Hungarian project with Hudson and another research organization, the East-West Forum. They have spent $150,000 so far.
More than two dozen Hungarians flew to Indianapolis from Budapest for the five days of sessions that ended Friday at Hudson's headquarters, a refurbished hilltop mansion. They included not only politicians, but also economists, educators, political scientists, even former Communist Party members.
Such well-known Westerners as Pierre S. du Pont 4th, the former Governor of Delaware, and Sir Alan A. Walters, a former economic adviser to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, urged a rapid transition to free markets, perhaps in less than five years. But the Hungarians mostly resisted, arguing that too hasty a transformation could bring high unemployment, inflation and hardship.
 
Social Welfare State
''We think more in terms of Western Europe's social welfare state model,'' said Elemer Hankiss, a political sociologist at the Hungarian Academy of Sciences. He was among more than 100 people trying to develop recommendations for the 19-member commission.
At one working group session, Bruce Chapman, a Hudson official who is a former director of the United States Census Bureau, argued against a Hungarian proposal for a labor law modeled after those in Scandinavian countries, with their numerous protections for workers.
Mr. Chapman said that until Hungary builds up enough wealth to afford such benefits, it would be more appropriate to model the labor law after those in Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea and slowly work up to Scandinavia.
Some issues came up repeatedly during the five days, although none were resolved. One was whether to continue Hungary's present tax holidays for foreign investment, or perhaps extend tax breaks to Hungarian entrepreneurs.
 
Inflation Dangers
Another was how quickly to make Hungary's currency, the forint, convertible to Western currencies, a process likely to result in steep devaluations and inflation if done too quickly. The working group dealing with this issue recommended three years, a deadline considered too ambitious and painful by others.
And there was considerable sympathy for a proposal that would keep big state enterprises, particularly manufacturing operations, in state hands while they were converted into operations efficient and profitable enough to command good prices from private buyers, foreign and Hungarian.
The new Government, in effect, would be responsible for the layoffs, plant closings and other measures intended to achieve efficiency.
The thought of imposing such hardships is one reason Hungarian politicians are turning to free-market advocates in the United States and Western Europe for support. That the Hungarians could not go only to Americans illustrates the decline of this country's influence. The Hudson Institute found that it had to enlist numerous Western Europeans, on the theory that they will be the main source of much-needed financial aid and foreign investment. Thus their endorsement is required to get the Hungarian public to accept the commission's transition plan.
 
Next Time in Brussels
So while the first gathering was held in this heartland American city, the next one will be in Brussels late this month, with Europeans playing the major role.
''It is useful for us to have this broad spectrum,'' said Geza Jeszenszky, an historian at Karl Marx University in Budapest and a leader of the Democratic Forum Party. ''Foreign capital is not possible without foreigners telling us what they require to come here.''
If the Democratic Forum, whose constituency is mostly those operating small businesses, does as well in the March election as many polls say it will, then Mr. Jeszenszky might emerge as the foreign minister in the new Government.
But a majority of the Hungarians here this week are members of or sympathize with the Free Democratic Party, whose constituency is mostly the wealthiest Hungarians. A leader of this party is Marton Tardos, an economist at the Hungarian Academy of Sciences who is a co-chairman of the Hudson commission, along with Sylvia Ostry, former head of the Economic Council of Canada.
''The future Government of Hungary can't cope with the hardships of transition to free markets,'' he said. ''We have to design a program to do this, and that is best done with the support of experts from the major free-market countries.''

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Are True Profits Falling or Rising?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
CORPORATE profits are in decline. Company after company is reporting sinking net income and the trend seems certain to continue, given the weak economy. But there are several ways to measure profitability and some show American business to be in not such bad shape.
Profitability is a tricky, subjective concept. Two economists, or two executives, can draw different conclusions from the same mass of numbers. Examine income alone and the total is clearly running below last year's level by more than 10 percent, a decline spotlighted by the companies themselves in quarterly earnings reports. 
But if income is considered the return on the money invested in factories, offices and equipment, the picture brightens. Although the 1989 return is not yet calculated, it was probably close to the level of the two previous years for manufacturing and service companies, says John Musgrave, a Commerce Department economist.
That resilient showing reflects the efficiencies that many companies have achieved in the 1980's, through factory closings, work force reductions, automation and overseas investments. ''We have definitely lowered our break-even point,'' said Richard W. Kopcke, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, who studies profitability.
The Federal Reserve and Commerce, in assessing profitability, often include in income an item that business executives think of as an onerous cost: the interest payments on ballooning corporate debt. For Mr. Kopcke and most business executives, a loan to a company provides capital to buy a machine, just as selling stock does. The disagreement is how to classify the interest payments. Mr. Kopcke and some other economists contend the payments, like dividends, should be counted as payouts from profits.
Viewed this way, profits have not declined since last year, although they have not risen either. Before taxes and including interest payments, income for the nation's nonfinancial companies remained at about $375 billion through the third quarter. This steady flow of wealth helps to explain why the nation's economic expansion has lasted for more than seven years.
Nevertheless, labeling interest payments as profits obscures the conflict in the American system between shareholders, who own a company, and creditors, who are outsiders. It does not, for example, end the nightmare at the heavily indebted Campeau Corporation. Nor does it help the nation's stockholders who blame interest payments for the sharp decline in profits, endangering stock values.
With the economy weak and consumers holding back, companies have had difficulty raising prices. That means that rising costs can squeeze profits and this has happened, but mostly because of interest payments. Other costs have hardly budged as a percentage of revenue.
Out of every dollar of revenue in the third quarter last year, interest payments consumed 5.2 cents, compared with 4.6 cents in 1988 and 3.6 cents in 1983, at the start of the economic expansion, Commerce says. Labor costs, by comparison, took 66.6 cents from the sales dollar in the third quarter, only slightly above the 1983 proportion of 66.2 cents. Corporate income taxes, sales taxes and the depreciation of buildings and equipment all take about the same today from each dollar as they did in 1983. Profits, on the other hand, fell in the third quarter to 4.5 cents, from 5.2 cents in 1988 and 5.6 cents in 1983. (The high point was 6.9 cents in 1984.) Aside from whether interest payments are profits or costs, another issue is how to value a company's capital investment in buildings and equipment. Mr. Kopcke and Mr. Musgrave, among others, favor valuing assets at current replacement cost; that is, the cost today of replacing, say, a three-year-old truck. While that might be $50,000, most companies carry the truck on their books at its original cost, say $25,000. The result is that a trucking company with 10 such vehicles and $25,000 in annual net income would report a 10 percent return on investment, while Mr. Kopcke would call it 5 percent.
''If executives are forced to keep marking up the value of their capital, they are more likely to acknowledge a slipping rate of return and to seek efficiencies,'' he said.
Many executives say they do keep an informal tally of replacement costs, and that is evident. Using a broad definition of pretax income - one that includes interest payments as well as various adjustments to remove fluke profits - Mr. Kopcke finds that the rate of return on the replacement cost of capital has risen steadily in the 1980's, to 8.1 percent in 1988 and probably a similar figure last year.
This return is up from 4.5 percent or less in the early 1980's and is the highest rate since 1973, although still a far cry from the 11 to 14.5 percent returns of the 1960's. Studies by other economists have produced similar results.
''The good news is that the rate of return has held up close to 8 percent despite the weakening economy,'' Mr. Kopcke said. And the bad news is that after energetic cost-cutting and modernization during seven years of economic expansion, American business got its rate of return back only to the early 1970's level - and now might once again lose ground.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Investors Relish Bet Against Japan

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AMERICAN investors may buy Japanese cars, but they don't like Japanese stocks.
That fact became obvious again on Friday, when the latest way for American investors to bet against Japan became available. It amounts to a put option, of an unusual variety, on the Nikkei 225, the most prominent of the Japanese stock indexes.
The security was the most active issue trading on the American Stock Exchange, with volume of 3.2 million warrants, as the securities are called. In the initial public offering, underwriters led by Goldman Sachs & Company sold at least six million warrants, and are likely to end up selling another 900,000. 
The timing could not have been better from a marketing standpoint, coming on the heels of a sharp fall on Friday in the Nikkei 225, which tumbled 1.7 percent, or 653.36 points, to 37,516.77. Higher interest rates played a role in the drop, which left the index down 3.6 percent so far in 1990.
But that decline will do the buyers of the new security no good at all. Under the rules of the security, if on Jan. 3, 1993, the Nikkei is below Friday's level of 37,516.77, the holder can cash in the warrants. The lower the index, the higher the amount the holder will receive.
The warrants are issued by the Kingdom of Denmark, in a move to raise money that seems virtually certain to confuse investors. Denmark promises to make the payments, and it is collecting the $4.05 a warrant, less underwriting discounts, that investors paid for them.
As stock prices slid in the United States on Friday, the bearishness on Japan seemed to grow. The first trade of the warrants was at $4.125, an instant profit for those who sold after buying at the offering. By the end of the day, the price rose to $5.
To calculate the value of the warrant at expiration, one takes the Nikkei average then, and divides it by 145.325, the value of the dollar in yen on Friday, and then by five. Then that figure is subtracted from $51.63. Thus the absolute most a warrant owner could collect would be $51.63, and that is if the Nikkei fell to zero. The value of the warrant is not affected by what happens to the dollar relative to the yen.
If someone who bought a warrant for $5 holds it until it matures on Jan. 3, 1993, he makes a profit if the Nikkei average then is trading below 33,883.65, or 9.7 percent below current levels. That is a fairly hefty premium, particularly considering that the Japanese market has not had a down year in more than a decade.
The Kingdon of Denmark is not, as it happens, necessarily bullish on Japan. Goldman, which designed the warrant, has come up with a way for Denmark to pass on the market risks to Goldman, which in turn has hedged itself in ways it will not describe. A Goldman official concedes, however, that the brokerage firm's own hedge is imperfect.
There are ways for American investors to bet on the Japanese market going up, like buying American Depository Receipts of shares in Japanese companies, many of which are traded in this country, or by purchasing shares in mutual funds that invest heavily or, in the case of the Japan Fund, exclusively in Japan.
But there is no way to place a leveraged bet in favor of the Japanese market similar to the way the new warrants make a bet against it possible. No doubt if brokers perceived a demand for such a product, it would be created. The fact that it hasn't been is a testament to a continued American bearishness on Japanese stocks.
There is nothing new about that sentiment, and the bearishness is not hard to understand. Japanese valuations were excessive, by American standards, throughout the 1980's, a fact that did not stop prices from rising. The dividend yield on the Japanese stocks in the Financial Times-Actuaries world index now averages 47-hundredths of 1 percent, meaning that if an investor spent $1,000 on Japanese stocks, he or she could expect to collect dividends of $4.70 each year.
By contrast, the dividend yield on American stocks in the Financial Times-Actuaries index is 3.4 percent, a return that is a bit below historical averages, although not nearly as low as in 1987, when the figure dropped below 3 percent, a period when, in retrospect, American stock prices were wildly overvalued. To get a 3 percent yield in Japan, without raising dividends, Japanese stock prices would have to fall 84 percent. Even if dividends in Japan tripled, it would take a 50 percent fall in stock prices to get a 3 percent yield. The American bearishness on Japan has been easy to understand, but it has seldom been profitable in many years.
Still, in 1989, for the first time since 1982, American stocks did perform better than Japanese ones, and for the first two weeks of this year, Japan ranked last of the 24 countries in the Financial Times-Actuaries indexes. Perhaps the bears will finally be right.
