HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Hong Kong Extending Its Reach

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
After enjoying extremely rapid growth in this territory, many large Hong Kong companies are looking abroad to find new sources of profits. But instead of going north to China, as they used to, many are reaching far in other directions.
In December alone, New World Hotel (Holdings) Ltd. completed its $540 million purchase of Ramada Inns, the American hotel chain, and Jardine Matheson Holdings acquired a United States insurance concern, the Financial Guardian Group, for an amount that local reports have estimated at about $70 million.
In the past, large local companies expanded mainly in Hong Kong, feeding off an exuberant local economy. The move abroad is partly the result of a natural transition for family-run companies that have built their empires so large that there is no longer room for them in Hong Kong. 
But it also comes at a time when this British territory of 5.7 million people prepares to revert to Chinese rule in 1997. There are rising political uncertainties over China and fears of further and greater instabilities, especially after the upheavals that have taken place in Eastern Europe.
 
New Sources of Earnings
China's retrenchment program already is stunting growth on the mainland and the economy in Hong Kong has slowed as well. While Hong Kong's giant companies are by no means abandoning their home, they say that they must look overseas, as many other corporations in Asia are doing, for new sources of earnings.
''Asian companies are diversifying for a variety of reasons,'' said Stephen A. Orlins, president of Shearson Lehman Hutton Asia Holdings Ltd. in Hong Kong. ''Hong Kong companies are diversifying for very much the same reasons, plus the reason of 1997.''
The flow abroad may lead to a more mature and diversified economy for Hong Kong, less dependent on the Chinese market that now sustains it. Nearly one-third of Hong Kong's total trade was with China for the first 10 months of last year, and stock prices of Hong Kong companies fluctuate on news from China.
Hong Kong's expansion overseas has been growing for the last few years, but interest and activity in investing abroad has blossomed in the last year or two. At least a dozen more companies are considering a move abroad, OCBC Securities (Hong Kong) Ltd. reports.
 
Closely Watched Ship Owner
Among them is Sir Y. K. Pao, the industrialist and shipowner who is one of the most closely watched and richest Hong Kong investors. He has made a variety of foreign acquisitions, including the purchase of Omni Hotels in the United States in 1988.
In another highly publicized deal, Semi-Tech Microelectronics (Far East) Ltd., bought the Singer Sewing Machine Company for $269 million in April 1989.
Like many corporate giants, New World Hotels, one of the largest hotel developers in the territory, is reaching out to both Asia and the United States and at the same time expanding in Hong Kong. This summer, it opened two deluxe hotels here, and they have already become popular meeting spots for well-to-do Hong Kong Chinese.
''We make money from Hong Kong,'' said Henry K. S. Cheng, managing director of New World. ''But if we want to expand, how can we do it?
''We must go out of Hong Kong, and our aim is to establish an international chain of hotels based in Hong Kong,'' he said in an interview, explaining why the company bought Ramada.
 
Political Risks a Factor
New World is mindful of the economic and political strains in China, where it has hotel interests. ''If I told you that absolutely no political factors entered into it, that would not be a fair statement,'' Mr. Cheng said. ''But we have to go overseas anyway. The political risk just makes us move quicker.''
The largest deals have been property- or hotel-related, but analysts say that is to be expected, because it is easier to evaluate the risk in buying real estate or a hotel chain if it is the company's specialty, and real estate has always been a popular purchase among Hong Kong corporations.
Michael E. J. Sadak, a managing director of mergers and acquisitions at Chase Manhattan Asia Ltd., said many Hong Kong companies have relatively little debt on their balance sheets. This gives them capacity to borrow, if need be, to finance overseas acquisitions.
''Many of them have been family-oriented, well known in Hong Kong, but relatively unknown in the international market,'' Mr. Sadak said. ''One challenge they face is to raise their international profile, so they are viewed in the proper light.''
 
Outflow of Personal Capital
As more and more Hong Kong people move overseas, there has been greater speculation that a good deal of capital is going with them. While the Government has no way of tracking capital flight, economists and financial officials agree that there is probably a significant outflow.
''You can't put a figure on it,'' said Joseph C. K. Yam, Deputy Secretary for Monetary Affairs in Hong Kong. ''But it would be unrealistic to say that residents haven't moved capital overseas.''
He and other economists, however, say there is no indication that corporate capital is part of the exodus. Even if there is a flight of capital from local companies, it is rarely from divestment, and it is essentially matched by an inflow of investment from foreigners, they say.
Among several reasons they cite for this is the lack of pressure on the exchange rate between the Hong Kong dollar and the United States dollar, to which the local currency is pegged. The rate of exchange hovers steadily around 7.8 Hong Kong dollars to the dollar.
''A lot of Hong Kong companies are investing overseas, partly to diversify, partly for political reasons,'' said K. C. Kwok, senior economist at the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. ''But the capital flight is not particularly serious.''
 
Significant Local Investments
Moreover, a significant amount of capital continues to be invested in Hong Kong, and the differences of opinion over the risk and opportunity that the territory presents are highlighted by the recent decisions of two top businessmen, Sir Y. K. and Li Kashing.
Both bid last year on Hong Kong's first cable television license, and the Government asked both to increase their bids. Sir Y. K. envisioned combining the system with a larger telephone and telecommunications system that might be built within the next decade to help enhance Hong Kong as a communications base, and he raised his bid to $640 million.
Mr. Li, whose company, Hutchison Whampoa, already is part owner of a communications satellite that is to be launched on a Chinese rocket, indicated the investment was already expensive and bowed out.

HEADLINE: David Wells MacEachron, 66, Ex-Leader of the Japan Society

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
David W. MacEachron, who retired last year as president of the Japan Society after leading the nonprofit group for 15 years, died of colon cancer on Saturday at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 66 years old.
Mr. MacEachron was successively executive director and president of the organization, which advances understanding between the United States and Japan. Despite his worsening illness, he remained an active adviser to the society's board at Japan House, at 333 East 47th Street. 
He was a staunch advocate of liberalized trade, of close American-Japanese economic cooperation, and of the nations' joint repudiation of any effort to achieve dual dominance of other economies. He stressed the latter belief in his recently completed autobiography, which, his son, Daniel, said, he wrote for his family and friends.
Mr. MacEachron (pronounced Mac-KEK-ron) increased the Japan Society's endowment by about $20 million and its role as the main conduit for American awareness of Japanese culture, economics and politics with film festivals, stage performances, art exhibits and conferences.
 
Served in the Navy
David Wells MacEachron was born in Grinnell, Iowa, to parents who had been Congregational missionaries in China. He grew up in Oberlin, Ohio, and Des Moines, and earned a bachelor's degree in philosophy at Yale. He also earned a master's degree in public administration and a doctorate in economics from Harvard. In World War II, he served in the Navy's Pacific Fleet on a submarine assigned primarily to rescuing downed American pilots.
After the war, his assignments included stints in Paris for the Marshall Plan, in Washington for the Bureau of the Budget and in New York where, from 1962 to 1974, he was successively program director and vice president of the Council on Foreign Relations. In later years, he was increasingly concerned about ecological dangers and overpopulation.
Surviving are his wife, the former Frances DePuydt, the Mayor of Hastings-on-Hudson for nearly eight years; his son, Daniel N., of New Canaan, Conn.; two daughters, Susan Patrick of Manhattan, and Laura O'Callaghan of Baltimore; two brothers, Lendrum, of St. Paul, and John, of Glendale, Calif., and two granddaughters.
A memorial service will be held at the Japan Society on Thursday at 4:30 P.M.

HEADLINE: After Months of Unsubtle Hints, Cuomo to Seek a Hold on Tax Cut

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 15

 BODY:
After months of dropping all-but-delicate hints, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on Tuesday will formally recommend suspending the next phase of the state's income-tax cut, aides to the Governor said today.
That phase, the last of the four-year tax-cut plan, was to take effect in October.
The Governor's recommendation will be listed in the budget Mr. Coumo is to present to the Legislature on Tuesday. If adopted, the proposal would freeze the top tax rate at the current 7.875 percent, instead of allowing it to drop as planned by half a percentage point. $2 Billion Gap in Budget Freezing the rate would provide the state $400 million in the fiscal year that starts on April 1. For that year, the state is facing a budget gap estimated at almost $2 billion. In the next fiscal year, the freeze would provide the state far more money, an estimated $1.3 billion. 
Aides to the Governor said Mr. Cuomo would argue in his proposal that the state's financial situation was too grave to sustain an additional tax cut.
''You can't keep cutting taxes when all your revenues are going south,'' an administration official said. ''We need to have some stability. The only practical prudent way to do that, in our opinion, is by re-examining the tax cut.''
Just last week, the administration estimated that the state would end the current fiscal year, which runs through March 31, with a shortfall of almost $700 million. That is almost three times earlier estimates.
 
Fuse for Debate
Budget Director Dall W. Forsythe attributed the growing gap to lower-than-expected tax collections in several areas.
Since the spring, Mr. Cuomo has hinted dozens of times that he favored deferring the next phase of the tax cut. But he has always stopped just short of endorsing the idea, maintaining that he had not made up his mind. Even after the budget was complete and much of it was in print, the Governor insisted last week that he did not know what he would recommend.
The formal proposal on Tuesday is likely to touch off months of debate and demonstrations. Business groups have pledged to fight any proposal to tamper with the cut, and labor and social-service groups have vowed to fight for a deferral.
Last year, when the financial problems were also severe, Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, Democrat of Brooklyn, favored a delay in the cut, a suggestion Mr. Cuomo rejected. Mr. Miller is expected to support Mr. Cuomo's call for suspending the cut this year.
The State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., has said he will oppose changes in the cut.
The battle, which appears to be forming along party lines, is expected to be particularly fervid because this year is an election year for the Governor and all 211 legislators.
The legal deadline for putting a budget in place is April 1, but in recent years that limit has frequently been ignored.
Under the plan approved by the Governor and the Legislature in 1987, the top tax rate has already dropped, from 9 percent to 7.5 percent. Because the last cut took effect toward the end of last year, the effective tax rate for 1989 was 7.875 percent.
 
To Freeze '89 Rate
In the last phase, the top rate is now scheduled to drop, to 7 percent, in the fall. That would yield an effective rate for the year of 7.375 percent and a top rate of 7 percent for 1991.
Aides to Mr. Cuomo said today that they would propose legislation to freeze the top rate at 7.875 percent. ''What you would do is keep the 1989 tax rate,'' one aide said.
The next phase would save taxpayers from a few dollars to several hundred dollars, depending on their incomes. Some taxpayers would actually pay more if the cut was put into effect. That is because the number of brackets is supposed to drop, to two from five, a change that would place some lower-income taxpayers into a higher bracket.
 
Likelihood of Stopgaps
The budget that the Governor presents on Tuesday is expected to rely heavily on the revenues that a delay the tax cut would generate two years from now. That means that the budget for the next fiscal year is likely to include many stopgap measures that depend on one-time revenue sources like refinancings and reserve funds.
It also means that if the Legislature rejects Mr. Cuomo's call to freeze the tax rate, his budget proposal will have to be substantially rewritten. That is because many stopgap measures could not be justified in the next fiscal year, if the state treasury was not likely to be replenished in the year after that.
In recommending a freeze, the Governor is in part following the advice of his council of economic advisers, which suggested last month that the cut be deferred. But the Governor's advisers, who include some of the most prominent executives in the state, explicitly recommended that the cut be delayed for a limited period of just ''one or two years.''
Administration officials said the Governor was not recommending a limited deferral, because such a proposal would simply create new problems in a year or two.

HEADLINE: Riverside Journal;
New Reign For Queen Of Hotels In West?

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVERSIDE, Calif.

 BODY:
Riverside gave the world the navel orange, but not even the fruit has defined this locality like the Mission Inn, the gaudy, sprawling hotel created by Frank Augustus Miller, an entrepreneur.
With its ornate beamed rooms, great courtyards with curved gables, campaniles, mosaics and stained glass windows, the inn has been host to the prominent from near and far since the turn of the century.
The Nixons were married there and spent their wedding night there in June 1940, as did the Reagans nearly 12 years later. Theodore Roosevelt was one of the earliest guests, overnighting on May 7, 1903. 
Now, after years of decay, decline and bankruptcies, the grand old hotel, shuttered and fenced off since 1985, is coming back to life under its latest owner. The owner is a reluctant one, the Chemical Bank of New York.
The bank seized the property after the Carley Capital Group, a Wisconsin-based syndicator, collapsed in 1988 just before it was to conclude restoration on the Mission Inn and reopen it as an Omni hotel.
The bank decided to throw in extra money and finish the restoration.
The huge complex is abuzz with jackhammers and drills. The furnishings are arriving for a reopening in the fall, two years late. It is the ultimate fixer-upper, 320,000 square feet of rooms, corridors, catwalks, loggias, alcoves and pergolas, with 750 doors and 450 windows that had to be replaced or repaired.
Reopening cannot come too soon for Riverside, a city of about 200,000 people 60 miles east of Los Angeles. The big Spanish mission-style structure is the centerpiece of a 700-acre downtown project.
''It is the centerpiece of our whole downtown redevelopment, physically, architecturally, economically and culturally,'' said Margueretta S. Gulati, director of Riverside's development department. ''It is the thing Riverside is known for nationally. It is a magnet for other development in the area. It will bring people back downtown.''
The inn is the kind of thing only the early California entrepreneurs could bring off. Frank Miller traveled the world and brought back ideas for expanding the inn over three decades, building four wings, each more spectacular than the last. No two rooms are the same. The styles evoke medieval castles, Spanish missions, Moorish palaces, Gothic cathedrals.
The Court of the Birds has fountains and a pool. The Music Room is a dark cavern with great oak beams. Then there are the St. Francis of Assisi chapel, with an 18-foot-tall gold leaf altar, four Tiffany windows and three Tiffany mosaics; the International Rotunda, with its spiral staircase and grand arches, and an octagonal wedding suite under a tall dome on the roof with splendid views of the San Bernardino Mountains.
Old-timers recall the parties, weddings and New Year's parties. A long slow decline started after Miller's death in 1935. The coup de grace was the Carley collapse.
The Chemical Bank, holder of $27.3 million in mortgages, consulted with the city; the New York bankers decided that they would lose less by finishing the inn - and they pumped in $9 million more.
As an inducement to the Chemical, says Ralph J. Megna, the inn's project manager for the Riverside development department, the city forgave part of a loan for seismic reinforcement. The hotel is situated very near the San Andreas fault.
The city has put together a $4.7 million financing package and built a 524-car garage to be leased to the new owner of the Mission Inn at below-market rates for three years.
The inn, designated a National Historic Landmark in 1977, will include a museum for Miller's Asian and European art.
The hope is that the inn will regain its status as a winter resort - a ''destination'' hotel, a place where people go to be there, not just to bed down for the night. The Chemical Bank is looking for a buyer. The bank is taking written bids with a minimum bid of $28 million.
But will vacationers will find downtown Riverside a congenial destination? Indeed, the city already has a less desirable regular guest: smog and auto fumes that drift in from Los Angeles and are trapped here between two mountain ranges. The thick, soupy haze can last for weeks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mission Inn in Riverside, Calif., is being restored and is to reopen in the fall. (NYT/Bart Bartholomew)

LENGTH: 979 words

HEADLINE: Amtrak Presses Northeast Strategy, But Riders and Rivals Seem Unfazed

BYLINE: By PHILIP S. GUTIS

 BODY:
With Amtrak nearing profitability, its managers are looking to several areas to push the railroad into the black, and one of their best hopes is the market now dominated by the Washington-to-New York air shuttles.
But the express Metroliner service between New York's Pennsylvania Station and Union Station in Washington, which Amtrak officials recently increased with that goal in mind, is off to a slow start.
On a recent morning, Metroliner 203, scheduled to make the 225-mile trip in 2 hours 37 minutes, carried only 24 passengers in its five cars. A more typical load, Amtrak officials said, is 40 to 50 people. But even with those numbers, the new express service would remain a money loser, although one that Amtrak appears willing to endure. 
By calling its express trains ''the civilized shuttle,'' Amtrak is taking a sharp marketing jab at the popular but crowded shuttle flights operated by the Pan Am Corporation and the Trump Organization. And strategies like that seem to be paying off.
 
Encouraging Financial Report
Last week, the railroad announced that in 1989 it had covered 72 percent of its operating expenses with revenue, a feat that was all but inconceivable only five years ago. Reporting record revenues of $1.3 billion for 1989, the railroad's chairman, W. Graham Claytor Jr., predicted Amtrak might be able to completely covers its costs by the year 2000.
Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, now carries about a million passengers between New York and Washington, about a third of the number who travel by air between the cities. Its goal, said Ira Silverman, Amtrak's director of route marketing, is to increase ridership by another 500,000.
''To be realistic, unless we some day have the equivalent of the European bullet trains, there is always going to be a market for the two shuttles that exist,'' said Mr. Silverman, ''but we clearly think that we can continue to increase our market share.''
Officials of the shuttle companies are politely derisive of Amtrak's ambition.
''We are the biggest competitor that Amtrak has, and we don't pay any attention to them,'' said Bruce Noble, president of the Trump Shuttle. ''I am no more worried about Amtrak as a competitor than I am about cars, buses or boats.''
 
Suburban Passengers Cited
Pamela Hanlon, a spokeswoman for Pan Am, said, ''We question the number of passengers who would be in Manhattan that early in the morning to take the Amtrak express service and how many would wish to end their trip back in Manhattan at the end of the day.'' She added that most air shuttle passengers ''live in suburban areas and find that the airport is more convenient.''
Amtrak's best hope for winning converts is the Metroliner, the reserved-seat train that celebrated its 20th birthday last year. Although he would not disclose actual ridership numbers, Mr. Silverman said the Metroliner accounted for most of Amtrak's growth in the New York-Washington market.
To better sell the Metroliner to time-conscious business travelers, Amtrak started an express train in 1987 from Washington to New York that made the trip in 2 hours 40 minutes. Last October, Amtrak added three additional express trains.
Amtrak has also begun serving Philadelphia's suburbs with Metroliner service that starts in Downington, Pa., at 6:10 A.M. and arrives in Washington by 8:37 A.M. Another nonstop express train from Baltimore to New York was also started.
Mr. Silverman acknowledged that the new routes have had a slow start, with average loads of about 40 passengers. To be profitable, he said, the trains need double that number.
 
'I Hate Trains'
But even with the recent 20 percent jump in prices for shuttle flights, to $119 from $99, many travelers interviewed recently at La Guardia Airport said they were devoted air passengers. A one-way Metroliner ticket costs $74, with an upgrade to the club service that includes wider seats and a meal, available for $43 extra.
''I hate trains; they're outmoded,'' said Barbara Winer, a consultant who flies monthly between New York and Washington for political projects. ''It would take me more time to go to Penn Station, which is filthy and full of homeless people.''
Some shuttle passengers said they would prefer to travel by train but were persuaded to fly by the added amenities at the shuttle terminals, including free champagne and snacks, vacation discounts and facsimile machines.
The largest lure, however, appeared to be the benefits airlines provide to those who accumulate flight miles. ''I got caught up in competing for the frequent flier miles,'' said Andrea Black, a television producer who flies weekly.
Arthur Messinger, a food executive, said of Pan Am's benefits, ''It's all the goodies and free vacations that got me.''
While gaining converts to the Metroliner may be difficult, Amtrak officials say they expect the service to grow slowly and are prepared to wait.
 
'Civil, the Genteel Way'
It could be a long wait. Most people interviewed on a recent 7:30 A.M. express train said they were not first-time Metroliner travelers. Generally, they said they used the train because they lived it Manhattan and found it easier to get to Pennsylvania Station than La Guardia Airport in Queens.
Gordon Ohlsson, a publishing executive from Washington who owns an apartment in Manhattan, said, ''The train is much more convenient; no taxis, no airport hassles and I get a lot more room.''
Some passengers also said they found the train service more reliable. ''If all goes right, certainly the plane is faster,'' said Chris Amundsen, an economist. ''But that happens so rarely.''
But it was David Bork, a management consultant from Aspen, Colo., who offered Amtrak its best hope. Sounding as though he were reading from an advertising script, he said trains were ''civil, the genteel way to travel.''

HEADLINE: Senator's Troubles Test Minnesotans' Tolerance

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In a state that likes to think of its politics as especially clean and genteel, Minnesota Democrats see special opportunities in Senator David Durenberger's problems.
The Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party dominates the state and the Congressional delegation but has been unable to reclaim the two Senate seats it lost to the Republicans in the same year, 1978.
Mr. Durenberger, a liberal Republican elected that year to fill out the term of the late Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, has enjoyed one of the highest popularity ratings of any Minnesota officeholder. He won a third Senate term in 1988 by trouncing Mr. Humphrey's son, Hubert H. (Skip) Humphrey, the current Attorney General. The other Republican seat, held by Rudy Boschwitz, is up for election this year and Mr. Boschwitz is heavily favored to win. 
But over the past two months, Mr. Durenberger has found himself under increasing attack by the Minnesota press about issues that he thought had been laid to rest in the campaign: an unusual, lucrative book publishing arrangement and bills for questionable travel expenses.
While Minnesotans will forgive much in their politicians, there are limits. His constituents stood by Mr. Durenberger when his marital and family problems were front-page news five years ago, but now politicians of both parties say state voters are more troubled by allegations that paint him as part of a pattern of abuse of privilege and power in Washington.
 
'A Minnesota Ethos'
''In Minnesota there is less of a liklihood that people will say, 'O.K., that's just politics,' '' said Mayor Don Frazier of Minneapolis, himself a former Democratic member of Congress.
Jim Rogers, the host of a public affairs show on WCCO radio in Minneapolis, noted that of the listeners who telephoned when Senator Durenberger was the guest in late December, most ''were pretty tough on him, but in a particularly Minnesotan way.'' He said there is ''a Minnesota ethos - politics here are cleaner, more honest, less ego-ridden; we expect our people here to be very high caliber.''
David M. Jennings, a Republican political analyst and former Speaker of the Minnesota House, said this of the state's political character: ''Independent voters here are so fierce and so proud that if they've gone down the ballot and found they've voted for too many candidates in the same party, they'll vote for the other party just to balance it off.'' He added of Mr. Durenberger that ''part of his charm is that he doesn't toe the Republican line.''
Still, the Senator's political future has been the main topic each week on a widely viewed local public affairs television program. The Mankato Free Press, which endorsed him in 1988, called for his resignation; Mr. Durenberger himself raised eyebrows and hackles in both parties by appearing to blame his lawyers and former aides for ''sloppy legal work'' on the financial activities for which the Senate Ethics Committee is now investigating him. To many Minnesotans, the Senator's statements smacked of disloyalty.
Mr. Durenberger said that the quotations about ''sloppy legal work'' in a front-page article in The Minneapolis Star Tribune did not accurately reflect his repeated statements in the interview with the newspaper, and that he was fully responsible for what brought him before the committee.
The committee, which began its investigation in September 1988, is trying to determine if a book publishing arrangement Mr. Durenberger had in 1985 and 1986 was intended to evade Senate limits on speaking fees. The committee is also trying to find out if he violated Senate rules by arranging speaking engagements in Boston that would pay for trips he made there for personal reasons.
 
Real Estate Partnership
In addition, the committee is looking into newly emerging questions about a 1983-87 real estate partnership that enabled him to bill the Senate for lodging in a Minneapolis condominium of which he was part owner.
Bill Luther, the assistant majority leader in the Democratic-Farmer-Labor-controlled Minnesota State Senate, said the the condominium and the flap over comments about aides helped crystalize an issue that simply wasn't ''developed at the time of the 1988 election.''
''It's not dissimilar to Watergate and George McGovern's unsuccessful Presidential effort in 1972,'' he said. ''George McGovern didn't win that election, but that didn't make Watergate any less a travesty.''
Mr. Jennings, the political analyst, called the the news reporting of current developments overheated and unfair, but he said there was no question that Mr. Durenberger had a serious problem.
''What people believe is that the book deal stinks, that the condo deal is bad,'' he said. ''There is a perception that he has done something wrong. What he needs to do is be on the attack so that the headline says 'Durenberger Apologizes,' or 'Durenberger Denies,' or 'Durenberger Fights Back.' ''
 
Strategy Down the Tubes
The most immediate casualty is the campaign strategy that the Republicans had hoped to use in the 1990 elections to unseat the two-term Democratic Governor, Rudy Perpich, and regain control of the House.
Half a dozen Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party members have been accused of ethical misconduct, and Republicans had hoped they could exploit that issue, as well as raise questions about Mr. Perpich's political ties to a wealthy Minnesotan whose ailing savings and loan institution has been taken over by the Government.
Mr. Durenberger has apologized to his constituents for ''mistakes and lapses in judgment,'' saying that while he believed his activities were permissible under Senate rules, he was wrong to have undertaken them and that he now knows they seemed improper. He has promised a full accounting of the real estate partnership and any tax or economic benefits he derived from it.
He expects to appear before the Ethics Committee early in February and hopes the panel will make a decision on his case by the end of that month.
A lawyer himself, and an authority on the complex subject of health policy, Mr. Durenberger has had trouble convincing critics at home that he did not know the particulars of his own financial transactions and cannot make the information available because he doesn't have it.
 
More Than Apologies, He Says
''To the general public, it's not credible at all, but to those of us who know him it's very credible,'' said Tom Horner, a former Durenberger chief of staff who heads a public relations firm. ''He's the absent-minded professor who can discuss the galaxy but doesn't know where he parked the car.''
In his Minneapolis office at the end of the week, fuming over the ''drip, drip, drip,'' of negative publicity, Mr. Durenberger acknowledged that he was on the defensive and that repairing his reputation and credibility will need more than apologies. On Friday morning, he said, his priest called him aside to tell him, ''The thing that's dripping on you is vagueness.''
''It's killing me, the inability to respond to the condo thing,'' the Senator said. ''It's like a claw around my neck.'' He said he hoped to have all the information available shortly. ''Yes, I'm choking on vagueness,'' he said.
He dismissed any notion of resigning. ''There's not another person in the state who could have beat Skip Humphrey,'' he said, ''And I'll be darned if I'm going to let his cronies beat me now.''
What hurts, he said, is the knowledge that he has disappointed people in Minnesota, let them down. ''It means I've got to earn back that good feeling.'' How does one earn back a good feeling? ''I can't think as much about how to win it back now because I've first got to convince people that I'm really not a bad guy.''

HEADLINE: Study for War Changes With Europe

BYLINE: By BERNARD E. TRAINOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
As the faculty of the Naval War College at Newport, R.I., sat in a conference room puzzling over what changes are needed in their curriculum to respond to the dramatic events unfolding in Eastern Europe, 50 generals and admirals from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were playing an annual war game next door.
For the senior NATO officers, it was business as usual. In their eyes the enemy threat was undiminished as they sought last week to defeat a hypothetical Soviet attack on Norway.
One British officer watching the scene said, ''When military men don't know what to do, they do what they know.'' 
But for the senior officers who serve as instructors at the nation's top-level military schools, teaching what they know is no longer enough. For more than 40 years, like the participants in the war game, they have prepared to deal with Soviet aggression. Now they find that threat is growing more ambiguous by the day and say that war games portraying the Soviet Union as the aggressor are increasingly irrelevant.
 
'The Threat Is Uncertainty'
''The threat is no longer the Russians,'' said Capt. John H. Heidt of the Navy school. ''The threat is uncertainty.''
Robin Pirie, the head of the college's strategic studies group, agreed and said, ''Developing a course of instruction in the face of such dramatic changes is like trying to paint a moving train.''
The Army, Navy and Air Force each have war colleges and the Defense Department sponsors two more that specialize in economics and resource management as well as high-level strategy.
The colleges play a major role in developing strategic thinkers and prospective generals and admirals for the armed forces. More than a thousand of the services' brightest officers are selected each year to attend nine-month courses at the colleges.
Most students are experienced officers in the grade of commander in the Navy or lieutenant colonel in the other services who will go on to important command and staff assignments. The courses at all five colleges stress military theory and the principles of national security. Through seminars, war games and research, the students formulate strategies and set up military forces to carry them out.
 
Quick Change After Stability
Until the events of the past year, the students wrestled with problems largely concerning a threat from the Soviet Union like the one addressed in the NATO war game at Newport. The problems differed little from those faced by officers attending the schools a decade ago, but this academic year all that has been changing as the Berlin Wall came tumbling down and the Warsaw Pact was unraveling.
Vice Adm. John Baldwin, the head the National Defense University, which consists of the National War College and the Industrial College of the Armed Forces, said nobody in the military or the academic world foresaw the sudden upheaval in Eastern Europe. Its effect upon military thinking in the colleges is still unclear.
''While the principles underlying national security remain the same,'' he said, ''what that means in practice is by no means clear.''
The events in Europe and the military's role in the war against drugs have stimulated sharp discussions among the students, and the prospect of a reduced military budget has already raised questions about the services' roles and what they might be called on to do.
''The Russians are 'out' and the third world is 'in' '' said Lieut. Col. Paul Pugh, a marine who is a student at the Naval War College. ''In a changing world, each of us wants his own service to be out front with innovative thinking.''
 
'No School Solution'
Col. Roy Stafford, the academic dean of the National War College, said the students know that ''there is no school solution to the new challenges and that their views are just as valid as those of the faculty,''
Col. Don Lundy of the Army War College in Carlisle, Pa., said, ''Everyone accepts the fact that the old way of thinking is on its way out, but what happens in Europe now?''
''With the rebirth of nationalism in the East, are we going back to 1912 and an endless round of territorial disputes?'' he asked. ''How much of a threat will that be to U.S. interests? What sort of military do we need for the coming decade? What is the ideal balance between active duty forces and reserves for both NATO and third world contingencies, including the drug war?''
The colonel said war colleges must integrate thinking about these issues into their curriculums for the current and coming year.
 
New Approaches Are Varied
With the exception of the Air War College in Montgomery, Ala., whose commander, Lieut. Gen. Charles G. Boyd, said the college's curriculum is driven by ''enduring concepts'' unrelated to current events, academic deans at the schools are considering a variety of changes for the next academic year, which begins this summer.
The National War College believes the best way to deal with uncertainty is to ask the budding strategists in the school to decide the kind of world the United States wants to see 10 years from now and to work back from that on the ways of making it a reality while at the same time providing a hedge against unpredictable events.
The Naval War College takes a different approach. Capt. Betsy Wylie, the academic dean, said the future is too uncertain to be definitive.
''It is like driving in a fog,'' she said.''Your high beams will only blind you. It is better to creep along on your lows so you can see where you are going.''
William Turcotte, the head of the school's strategy branch, said this means the college sees the current situation as an interim one: ''It is much too early to say how things will play out. In the meantime, the students should confine their thinking to what is happening, not what they think will happen. Maintaining a strong and balanced military force has gotten us to where we are, and we should not go off on flights of fancy before the dust settles.''
Another faculty member said, ''We know we will have smaller armed forces, but we want the students to think about what those forces will look like and do.''
The colleges admit they were unprepared for the rush of events in Europe, as well as being equally unprepared to address the role of the military in the war on drugs, a role that was not even considered by the colleges during the Reagan Administration.
As part as President Bush's anti-drug campaign, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney recently increased the role of the armed forces, but there are no drug enforcement experts on any of the faculties.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS SAID TO LAG IN SCHOOL SPENDING

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The United States spends relatively less on elementary and secondary education than do 13 other industrial countries, according to a report made public today.
The report, compiled by the Economic Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research organization, also criticized assertions by President Bush that the nation ''lavishes unsurpassed resources on schooling.''
The Education Department said it disagreed with the report's findings and that officials were preparing a detailed response. 
The paper, ''Shortchanging Education,'' said that only Australia and Ireland invest less on elementary and secondary education, relative to the size of their economies, than the United States does.
 
Other Countries' 'Average'
Sweden, Austria, Switzerland, Norway, Belgium, Denmark, Japan, Canada, West Germany, France, the Netherlands, Britain and Italy all invest more, said the nonprofit institute, which receives its major financing from labor organizations.
''If the U.S. were to increase spending for primary and secondary school up to the 'average' level found in the other 15 countries, we would need to raise spending by over $20 billion annually,'' the report read.
M. Edith Rasell, who wrote the report, said the results were based on widely accepted data published by the Federal Government and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
 
Three-Way Tie for Second
The report acknowledged that the United States ''spends comparatively more than other countries on higher education.'' But Ms. Rasell said that ''when expenditues on all levels of education - pre-primary, primary, secondary and post-secondary - are calculated, the United States is in a three-way tie for second place among the countries studied.''
The Education Department has estimated that total education spending by state, local and Federal governments will total $353 billion this year. By that measure, Sweden spends a larger share of national income on education than the United States, and Canada and the Netherlands spend equivalent amounts.
But when spending on higher education is removed from comparative data, the report said that ''the relative position of U.S. spending falls from a three-way tie for second highest in spending to close to the bottom of the group of 16 industrial nations.''
The statistics show that the United States spent 4.1 percent of its national income on elementary and secondary education in 1985, while the average abroad was 4.6 percent. Sweden spent 7 percent, followed by Austria at 5.9 percent, Switzerland at 5.8 percent, Norway at 5.3 percent, Belgium at 4.9 percent and Denmark and Japan at 4.8 percent. Canada spent 4.7 percent, West Germany and France, 4.6 percent, the Netherlands and United Kingdom, 4.5 percent and Italy, 4.2 percent.
Counting higher education as well, spending as a percentage of national income was Sweden, 7.6 percent; The United States, Canada and the Netherlands, 6.8 percent; Japan, 6.5 percent; Norway, 6.3 percent; Belgium, 6.1 percent; Denmark and Ireland, 68 percent; France, 5.9 percent; Austria, 5.8 percent; Australia, 5.5 percent; Britain, 5.2 percent; Switzerland, 5.1 percent; Italy, 4.8 percent and West Germany, 4.6 percent.
The institute's report noted assertions by President Bush at last year's meeting of the nation's governors to discuss education that the country ''lavishes unsurpassed resources on schooling,'' and therefore, ''Our focus must no longer be on resources - it must be on results.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Memories: Too Short

 BODY:
An unusual cooperative venture with the apt name of U.S. Memories has failed to raise the necessary funds from American computer companies to go into the business of making memory chips. A major opportunity to guard against future pressure from Japanese competitors thus seems to have been frittered away.
The idea of U.S. Memories began four years ago when American computer companies found only 10 percent of their memory chips were coming from U.S. sources, the rest mostly from Japan. The danger of such dependence is that Japanese chip makers could acquire control of the market, and favor Japanese computer companies with the latest chips and lowest prices. 
I.B.M. offered to license to U.S. Memories its technology for making the next generation of memory chips, those carrying four megabits of information. U.S. Memories has sought to raise $500 million from other computer companies to put the new chip into production.
But the supposed beneficiaries are no longer so worried. Twelve months ago, one-megabit memory chips were in short supply. Now they are abundant. Times are tough and few computer makers wish to spend now to avert a possible future shortage. Companies like Apple Computer say they have secured their own supply with long-term contracts. They may have correctly judged their situation - or may be mortgaging their future to Japanese suppliers.
But without alternative sources of supply, memory chips will surely again grow scarce and expensive, unless other companies can produce the next generation of chips in copious amounts. Without U.S. Memories, Japanese companies will be free to cut production and raise prices again. ''It's a textbook strategy. These guys are masters of the game, and the U.S. industry is playing into their hands,'' says Wilfred Corrigan, chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association.
Japanese computer companies are members of industrial conglomerates and enjoy Tokyo's support in indirect ways. U.S. Memories was an effort to match some of these advantages. Had it succeeded, it might have become a model for similar consortiums on other technologies, like flat screens.
The failed attempt leaves the U.S. semiconductor industry with no other visible strategy for stemming its decline. The decline affects other industries that depend on access to the latest chips, like computers and telecommunications. ''This isn't the demise of the industry, but the trend is very disturbing,'' says Sanford Kane, the former I.B.M. executive who heads U.S. Memories. ''As the industry moves along the trend it becomes a second-class industry, and the U.S. economy with it.''
The industry tried to help itself and failed. Washington paid no attention. Though an expression of concern might have helped U.S. Memories get off the ground, the Bush Administration summarily dismissed a recent blue-ribbon report warning that the semiconductor industry is in trouble.
Mr. Kane and I.B.M. have done their imaginative best. The failure of U.S. Memories is the failure of grasshoppers like Sun Microsystems and Apple Computer to remember that winter follows summer, and the failure of the Administration to notice that the foundation of some critical industries is slowly crumbling.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Auditors Not to Blame For Thrifts Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, I strongly disagree with the view in ''The Lapses by Lincoln's Auditors'' (Business Day, Dec. 28) that auditing rules didn't keep pace with change in the savings and loan industry.
The major causes of the savings and loan crisis are well known: an interest rate squeeze, a downturn in oil, gas and agriculture, and a deregulatory climate that encouraged greater risk taking and sought to downplay savings and loan problems. 
The accounting profession consistently urged caution in the face of regulatory proposals that would weaken accounting discipline applicable to savings and loan institutions. As early as 1981, we warned against allowing them to defer losses from asset sales. Later, we objected to proposals to defer recognition of bad debt losses and other devices to create equity artificially for the thrifts.
Moreover, as I testified before the House Banking Committee last February, my organization provided guidance to savings and loan auditors through the 1980's. Since January 1983, we issued 33 pieces of audit guidance applicable to thrifts. We continue to provide guidance as Congress and the regulators seek to resolve the crisis.
 
PHILIP B. CHENOK
New York, Jan. 2, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Americans Still Trade Real Estate for Beads

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Fifth Column,'' Peter Passell's Economic Scene column on foreign investment and our trade deficit (Business Day, Dec. 20), makes light of the major issue. The primary concern is not that we are spending instead of saving. The number of jobs in the ever-increasing service economy is no better a measure of economic vitality than to claim the baby isn't sick because it doesn't have a fever.
Rather, what we must focus on, and change, is that we are financing our purchase of depreciable foreign merchandise (cars, videocameras, sneakers, clothing, beverages, small appliances to name a few) with the sale of appreciable assets, such as United States real estate and corporations.
Long after our Sri Lankan socks and Swedish Volvos have gone to the landfill and scrap yard, foreign investors with savvy will still be collecting even more rent and ringing up continuing corporate profits.
Intelligent people don't lay the blame solely to Japan, either. Until we collectively realize that we're trading equity for consumables, there doesn't seem any hope for change on the horizon.
 
D. SCHMIDT
Avon, Conn., Dec. 27, 1989

HEADLINE: U.S. Can Help Soviet Private Entrepreneurs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is understandable that William Safire finds the ''Z'' article in the winter issue of Daedalus important (column, Jan. 4), because it affirms his skeptical reading of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It is less clear why you gave the article such prominence, excerpting it on the same Op-Ed page. The article's main conclusion is a warmed-over version of the arguments used to justify the Bush Administration's early reluctance to support perestroika and glasnost: that the Soviet Union is, after all, still a Communist system, and any outside aid will simply help prolong that system's life. 
Z reaches this conclusion by positing unbridgeable gaps between Bolshevism and democracy and between command and market economies, and by putting forward a crude cold-war image of the Communist Party. He argues that reform (''soft Communism'') is impossible because Soviet institutions, and particularly the Communist Party, are incapable of introducing true reform.
The party in this view is incapable of reform because it will ineluctably seek to maintain its role in the system. How does Z explain the significant numbers of reform Communists, including the radical group of deputies in the Supreme Soviet, who seek to reduce the role of the party and create a multiparty system? It is not at all inconceivable that in the next few years this wing could come to dominate party decision-making bodies, as has happened in the Communist parties of the Baltic republics.
While it is true that the measures adopted so far are inadequate to achieve either democracy or marketization, it is too soon to say they will not be expanded in the absence of total collapse. Mr. Gorbachev is not basing his reforms, as Z states, on structures programmed for ''hard'' Communism. The new Congress of People's Deputies and Supreme Soviet are unlike any previous Soviet political institutions and have shown considerable assertiveness - particularly in rejecting appointees for government posts and in sending back for revision draft laws that it considered too conservative. Ultimately, this too undermines the role of the party in setting policy.
Z concludes that United States assistance to President Gorbachev would be counterproductive; it would only ''prolong the agony'' and delay the inevitable collapse of the system, though he makes an exception for aid for ''parallel structures in a private sector . . . to promote economic and, eventually, political pluralism.'' This point is well taken, though by confining the discussion to free economic zones, Z ignores another option: to open a major program to assist the thousands of new Soviet private enterprises called cooperatives.
While mostly confined to the service sector and small-scale production, a few large state enterprises have been privatized and turned into cooperatives. These enterprises face severe problems in technological modernization and access to supplies, mostly because economic reform has stalled in other areas. The United States Government could provide incentives for American companies to create joint ventures with cooperatives and help modernize them. The United States could also support management training programs for Soviet private entrepreneurs.
These and other steps would increase the vitality of what has already become the most dynamic sector of the Soviet economy and help push the Soviets along the path of reform.
 
DARRELL SLIDER
Durham, N.C., Jan. 4, 1990
 The writer is Carnegie Fellow at Duke University's East-West Center.

HEADLINE: To Help New Democracies, Cut Aid to Israel, 4 Others

BYLINE: By Bob Dole; Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, is the Senate minority leader.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It's always a little risky to predict history's verdict on contemporary events. But even from today's sometimes shortsighted perspective, it is safe to declare 1989 as one of the watershed years of the 20th century - the year in which Communism collapsed and the long dormancy of freedom suddenly and dramatically blossomed in places from Poland to Panama.
In fact, events have been moving so fast that, in some ways, we're all playing catch-up in our own analyses and policy prescriptions. A little caution makes great sense in such a volatile environment. 
But this much is already clear: We do have an enormous opportunity to consolidate and expand freedom's gains and, at the same time, to enhance America's security and economic potential.
If the new democracies and free market economies fail, the long-term cost to America and to the cause of freedom will be enormous. But if they succeed, it will mean that the United States could enjoy increased security, reduced defense budgets and armament levels and expanded markets for our exports and our ingenuity. Simply put, there is no better investment we can make in America in 1990 than finding ways to support the new democracies.
That's the good news. The bad news is that supporting freedom is not free. It will cost bucks - big bucks. And we must find those bucks within the constraints of our own crushing budget deficits and a foreign aid budget that is already stretched to the breaking point.
We may be able to increase marginally our overall foreign aid expenditures. But the reality is that we are not going to have much more foreign aid money in the next few years, at least until the so-called peace dividend kicks in (if it ever materializes).
The immediate answer must include reallocation of what we are spending on foreign aid now.
Let me make this point clear: I am certainly not suggesting abandoning or short-changing our long-time friends around the world. They remain very important to us, and their needs are just as real and pressing as those of the new democracies.
What I am suggesting is to re-examine some of the huge aid programs in a few countries - the so-called earmarked countries - that take most of our current aid budget. Right now, the big five - Israel, Egypt, the Philippines, Turkey and Pakistan - receive more than two-thirds of our foreign aid.
Does it make sense, at this historic moment, to provide these countries practically all of our aid at the cost of foreclosing dramatically promising new aid initiatives in Eastern Europe or other important countries? What about, for example, those Latin American nations in the front lines in the war against drugs?
Consider this simple fact: A 5 percent cut in current aid programs for the big five would provide about $330 million - enough to respond to the needs of new democracies such as Poland, Hungary, Panama and countless needy countries that under current allocations will receive not one penny of American aid.
Perhaps an even larger across-the-board cut and reallocation would be warranted, as the democratic revolution gains momentum. That would represent a better balancing of our limited resources with our changing priorities.
No doubt, these proposed reallocations will raise a hue and cry. But can't we convince our friends who would ''lose'' a tiny amount of their aid how much it is in their interest, too, to help insure against the failure of new democracies and free-market economies?
Can't those pressure groups that have turned some of our foreign aid programs virtually into ''entitlement programs'' realize that making some minor adjustments in aid allocations can simultaneously serve the countries of their special interest, and serve America?
And can't my colleagues in Congress, who have forced the President to swallow a few huge earmarked aid programs, stand up to domestic political pressure and resist the temptation to politicize foreign aid? Can't they instead support an amended foreign aid strategy that more completely serves the national interest?
Even despite Congressionally mandated aid programs, the President has the authority to make the small reallocations of foreign aid that I believe are warranted. I encourage him to consider seriously making those reallocations now. I stand ready to work hard to insure that the Congress and the American public will back him up.
To me, it boils down to this: Are big gains for freedom worth a small cut in a few huge foreign aid programs? I say yes.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: A Storybook Development With an Uncertain Ending

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 15

 BODY:
When Federal regulators seized control of New Jersey's largest savings institution last month, one of the troubled properties that came with it was Port Liberte, a storybook development of sumptuous town houses rising above lazy canals on the cluttered waterfront here.
To bank officials, Port Liberte is just one of the risky real-estate ventures that lured lenders across the country into debt way over their heads, setting off the savings and loan crisis. But to developers and investors, Port Liberte is one of the most ambitious projects attempted in the metropolitan region, a bold but sobering symbol of what can happen when unharnessed ambition exceeds reality.
Conceived in the financially optimistic days of the mid-1980's, this immense project on the Hudson River 4,000 feet west of the Statue of Liberty is floundering amid the region's economic slowdown.
Cost overruns and delays caused by the complexity of its design combined with an inability to close sales in 1989 to create a cash crisis for Port Liberte; with less than a fifth of the proposed 1,690 houses and apartments built, its developer ran out of money and halted construction. Most of the stores that were planned have not opened. The promised restaurant has not served a meal. 
 
'Buying Into a Dream'
Port Liberte's developer, Paul W. Bucha, says he is confident he will find overseas investors to pay off the project's $158 million debt and see it through to completion. Failing that, regulators may choose to foreclose, selling what has been built to the highest bidder, who could then push on. Or they could invest the $20 million to $30 million needed to complete Port Liberte's first phase of 363 homes, now 15 months behind schedule, and then sell the bank's interest.
The project's future is no more uncertain than when Port Liberte was proposed in 1980.
''What it will take is due diligence, a certain amount of creativity and buying into a dream,'' said Mr. Bucha, the president of Port Liberte Partners, a international group of designers, architects and builders. ''And let's not kid anybody. It is a dream.'' The first glimpse of Port Liberte is a surprise. It is taller and more striking than anything within a mile, except for the Statue of Liberty rising gracefully above its rooflines.
This is the epitome of the new Hudson River waterfront, the showiest of the projects being built along the 18 miles of old railroads and piers from here north to the George Washington Bridge. A few hundred feet south, the old waterfront survives on a pier where cars are shredded into scrap.
What has been completed is substantial. The first section of winding canals is open, and a few sailboats are tied up at backyard docks. There are 37 town houses and 326 apartments in various stages of completion; 189 homes are occupied.
The architecture is a subtle blend of Mediterranean village and Dutch streetscape. Some town houses sold for more than $750,000. Dual-level apartments on the upper floors of the larger buildings offer sweeping views of the New York Harbor and the lights of Manhattan.
''It's one of the most fascinating and interesting projects ever done around New York,'' said Steven G. Rockmore, chairman of Gilbert Charles Beylen, a real-estate marketing company in New York. ''The unfortunate part of it is that it's in Jersey City.''
Not just Jersey City, but a corner far from everything except the river. There are other waterfront projects here, but they are nearer established neighborhoods and PATH trains to Manhattan.
Many real-estate professionals admire the pluck of Port Liberte's developers, though they say only foreigners unfamiliar with the psychological barriers separating New Jersey from New York would have undertaken so extravagant a venture here.
 
'A Vision in Mind'
''They had a vision in mind,'' Mr. Rockmore said, ''a vision that was so grandiose, so ambitious, that the reality of where they were doing it got lost.''
The developers expected to sell heavily to New Yorkers. But New Jerseyans, most of them professionals, bought 85 percent of the first 303 homes sold or under contract. New Yorkers bought just 10 percent, and foreigners the rest.
An unexpected obstacle was the Wall Street decline that began with the October 1987 crash and has resulted in 16,000 layoffs in the financial services industry. Wall Street was to have been a major source of buyers.
''It got a little out of sync with the market,'' said Richard Schlott, president of Schlott Realtors, one of New Jersey's largest real-estate companies.
 
Out of Step
The project was out of step in other ways. Daring to be different in concept and design, the developers were unable to find craftsmen skilled enough to translate the plan into reality.
Expensive canals, for example, had to be built before sales could begin in earnest; the project was based on them. At first the developers tried to build the canal bulkheads with concrete piles, but they glanced off sunken barges and other fill and set crooked. Later, steel piles were used, but the developers had lost time and money.
Forty-seven floor plans, four different types of roofs and intricate interior woodwork further complicated the job, pushing costs up and completion dates back until the project was more than a year behind schedule and millions over budget.
Still, the concept gained acceptance. Patricia and Otto Lowe were among the first buyers, putting a down payment on their waterfront town house before anything was built. They sold their six-bedroom house in Short Hills and moved to Jersey City in May 1987. Mr. Lowe, a vice president at Kidder, Peabody & Company in lower Manhattan, now takes Port Liberte's ferry to and from work, 15 minutes each way.
 
A New Way of Life
For the Lowes it is a new way of life, a kind of suburb-by-the-sea. Mrs. Lowe is taking sailing lessons and the family has bought a 13-foot rubber Zodiac, the kind of motorized raft used by the explorer Jacques Cousteau.
''At first Otto said, 'If I miss the ferry you might be able to whip me across the river,' '' Mrs. Lowe said. ''I said, 'You're crazy.' '' So far, she has not had to try.
Though they continue to shop in Short Hills, about half an hour away, and return there to play tennis, the Lowes say they have not been disappointed with life at Port Liberte. ''In the summer we sit outside every single night,'' Mrs. Lowe said. ''We don't watch TV. We watch the lights come on in the city.''
For Robert Shifman, a retired manufacturer, Port Liberte represents the best of all worlds. An avid sailor who lived for years up and down the East Coast aboard his 39-foot cutter, ''Mon Liberte,'' he bought a $209,000 one-bedroom condominium and a $60,000 boat slip just below his third-floor window.
 
In Dark Moments, Pit Liberte
''The best part of Port Liberte is the character of the development, which I describe as a joining of London, Amsterdam and Venice,'' Mr. Shifman said. ''The worst part of it, unfortunately, is the delay in construction.''
Residents say they are tired of the dirt and noise and they are disappointed that the ferry does not run on weekends. In darker moments, a few refer to the project as Pit Liberte.
But the disappointment is nothing compared with the frustration and anger that residents said they felt in December when Port Liberte's primary lender, City Federal Savings Bank, was taken over by the Federal Government and news reports tied the bank's problems to Port Liberte.
''On the day we heard about it, naturally we felt discouraged,'' said Harvard G. Gordon, who with his wife, Dorothy, moved from Short Hills to Port Liberte in 1987. The Gordons have not panicked by trying to sell right away, but some people have. Twenty-two homes are up for resale.
 
'We'd Probably Take a Loss'
''The major problem we're worried about is our investment,'' said Mr. Gordon, who owns a factory in Brooklyn. ''If we were forced to sell right now, we'd probably take a loss.''
Last fall, CityFed Financial Corporation of Somerset, N.J., the parent company of City Federal, reported a net loss of $223.7 million for the third quarter of 1989. Bank officials attributed it to bad real-estate loans, lower bond portfolio values and operational losses. Less than a month later, Federal regulators seized the bank. It was the second largest savings institution taken over by the Government.
Of City Federal's loss, less than a quarter, or $52.7 million, concerned Port Liberte. Apartments were under contract, but buyers had the right to back out if their homes were not completed within nine months, and many did. Because the sales were not completed, the developer did not have the money to pay off the loan.
To finance Port Liberte, City Federal had formed a consortium of 15 financial institutions, including two others that also ended up taken over by the Government. City Federal and two other institutions also formed a partnership that holds a 50 percent equity interest in the project.
 
Heroic Sense of Optimism
City Federal played the lead role in administering a revolving line of credit - much like a home equity loan - in which money advanced for construction was repaid and loaned again. It totaled nearly $160 million.
Last March the loan expired and had to be renegotiated. In the meantime, the bank refused to give out any more money. Unable to pay its contractors, the developer shut down construction. Contracts of sale could not be closed, and some 113 sales remain in limbo.
Last summer the bank ordered a fair market appraisal on Port Liberte that pegged its value at $88 million, far below the $158 million the developers owed. The bank declared the $52.7 million loss on the basis of the preliminary results of the appraisal.
Mr. Bucha, the developer, is a Medal of Honor winner with a heroic sense of optimism that some of his rivals say borders on recklessness. In spite of all the bad news, he believes the permits he has to build 1,690 homes and the record of more than 400 sales before some buyers backed out will attract a new lender.
 
'I'm Fairly Confident'
He said he is negotiating with Sung Mo Chung, the head of Elite Company, a South Korean construction concern which owns office buildings in Seoul, to complete the first phase and take over the rest of Port Liberte.
Perhaps because prices are so high and so many buyers are well-established, Port Liberte residents seem to be taking the problems in stride.
''I'm fairly confident the project will be completed,'' said Mr. Shifman, a homeowners' association leader. ''So far there's been absolutely no panic. If you doubt that, try to pick up a bargain here now. I don't think you can.''

HEADLINE: Florio's Bright and Loyal Inner Circle

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The top advisers James J. Florio will bring with him when he is sworn in as governor of New Jersey on Tuesday are known for having many of the same traits as their boss: intelligence, loyalty, liberal instincts and reputations as tough political operatives.
All from New Jersey, many with degrees from Ivy League schools, the people known as the Florio team helped execute a nearly mistake-free campaign last fall, one that Democrats lauded and Republicans called one of the dirtiest in state history.
In the 10 weeks since Mr. Florio was elected by a landslide, they have rarely appeared in public as they engineered the takeover of the only statewide elective office, with its hundreds of appointees and its overwhelming control of a $12 billion government.
Mr. Florio, who describes his first love as making policy, and practicing politics as a price that must be paid, is expected to centralize the top decision-making in the governor's office, to give his top advisers unusual political influence and power. 
 
Devotion and Discretion
His inner circle includes a former Superior Court judge, a lawyer who worked in the campaigns of Mr. Florio and Senator Bill Bradley, a former social worker, a former journalist, and a university professor who studied the failures of Federal social programs in the 1960's and 70's.
What the Florio insiders share are years of experience with Mr. Florio in which they proved their devotion, discretion and intelligence, politicians here say. His aides say that after proving their loyalty to him, they are given a good deal of freedom to express their ideas and can count on his loyalty in return. Nonetheless, they say Mr. Florio insists on maintaining tight control of all major policy decisions.
''Generally, they are politically savvy, politically capable people who have proven themselves in various political wars,'' said Alan Rosenthal, the director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. ''I think they are more adept at politics than they are at policy.''
The group includes Steven P. Perskie, a 45-year-old former judge who will serve as Mr. Florio's chief of staff; Douglas Berman, 37, who has been named state treasurer; Brenda J. Bacon, 39, who will serve as head of the Office of Management and Planning, and Jon Shure, 38, a former reporter for The Record of Hackensack, who has been named director of communications.
 
Professor As Policy Director
In addition, Carl Van Horn, 39, a professor of political science and associate director of Rutgers University's Eagleton Institute, is expected to be a major contributor to Florio's policy initiatives as director of policy. Gregory Lawler, a member of Mr. Florio's Washington staff, is expected to play an important role in shaping legislative initiatives like Mr. Florio's plans for bringing down the high price of automobile insurance in the state.
Some leading members of the new administration say there was some jockeying between Mr. Perskie and Mr. Berman for the lead role under Mr. Florio. Although Mr. Perskie took what was probably the most powerful position among Mr. Florio's aides, Mr. Berman's appointment as treasurer gives him direct involvement in all budget and tax issues, central concerns to an administration facing a growing budget deficit and the possibility of changing the state tax structure.
Mr. Perskie, a graduate of Yale and the University of Pennsylvania Law School, served with Mr. Florio in the State Assembly in the 1970's and gained a reputation for a sharp intellect and keen political instinct as Senate majority leader and chairman of the Judiciary Committee. Among his duties, officials say, will be working with the Legislature.
Mr. Berman, a graduate of Yale and Columbia University Law School, had worked in two of Senator Bradley's Senate campaigns before taking over the Florio election effort last year.
 
Health Care and Federal Failures
Ms. Bacon, a graduate of the Hampton Institute and the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, began her career as a social worker and served as president of a health care consulting firm and as a Camden County Freeholder. She has a particular interest in health-care issues and in changing the way the state delivers social services. Aides say Mr. Florio often calls on Ms. Bacon to help him thrash out policy decisions.
Mr. Van Horn, who attended the University of Pittsburgh and received his Ph.D. from Ohio State University, has written extensively on the failures of Federal programs for the long-term unemployed in the 1960's and 70's, devised in Washington and implemented by the states.

HEADLINE: Housing Police Ask Merger With New York Force

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
The head of the union that represents New York City housing police officers called yesterday for a merger of that force with the city's Police Department.
''It's better for the City of New York,'' said Jack Jordan, president of the Housing Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. ''It's better for our members. It's better for the tenants and it will save money. So we say, let's do it.'' 
Though both housing and city officers take the same entrance examinations and attend the Police Academy, are appointed from the same list and are paid the same, some housing officers have complained that city officers have greater opportunities for different types of assignments and are viewed as having greater prestige.
At the same time, some city officers have expressed concern that, under a merger, they might get housing-patrol or other assignments they do not want.
 
Transit Union Agrees
Mayor David N. Dinkins said afterward that merging the separate city, transit and housing police forces would be ''one of the first things'' the city's new Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown, would study after he takes office on Monday. He said Mr. Brown would then ''make recommendations to me about whether a merger makes sense.''
A little later, Ron Reale, the president of the Transit Police Benevolent Association, said he agreed with Mr. Jordan. ''Only through the merger of the three uniformed police services will we be able to accomplish the mission of providing better service to the people of New York,'' Mr. Reale said in a statement.
Joe Mancini, a spokesman for the city's Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said the union would have no immediate comment on the proposal.
The question of a police merger, long a controversial subject, has been raised again recently, with advocates contending that it could result in more effective, efficient and economical operations. Some critics, however, assert that a unification of departments could lead to the subordination of those needs now met by the transit and housing police forces and a dimunition of some services.
Val Coleman, a spokesman for the city's Housing Authority, said yesterday that Louis Raiford Jr., the chief of the housing police, was concerned that a merger might ''siphon off'' certain police services now provided to tenants, like foot patrols on project grounds and patrols inside buildings.
 
'Lateral Transfers' Also Favored
The city's police force has nearly 26,000 members, the transit force, 3,600, and the housing force, 2,100.
Speaking at a news conference outsisde City Hall, Mr. Jordan said that a survey of his members showed that ''the sentiment for a merger is overwhelming.'' If there is no merger, he said, then his members favored a system of ''lateral transfers'' that would make it possible for officers from one department to voluntarily transfer to another.
Mr. Jordan said it was unfair to force a person who wants to join one department to go to another. He said that while some housing officers would, if they could, transfer to the city department, some city officers might prefer to be assigned to work in housing projects. He asserted there had been no shortage of candidates for housing police jobs when there was a separate selection process.
The city's Housing Authority now receives millions of dollars in Federal funds that are used for housing security purposes, and housing officials, in the past, have expressed concern that a merger might result in a loss of at least some of that money. But Mr. Jordan said that the problem could be worked out without any loss of money.
