HEADLINE: Men at 65: New Findings On Well-Being

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
THE secret of emotional health among older men is not a successful career, a happy marriage or a stable childhood, new findings suggest. It lies instead in an ability to handle life's blows without passivity, blame or bitterness.
The findings, which contradict widely held theories about the importance of early life for emotional well-being in adulthood, are among recent conclusions of a study of 173 men who have been scrutinized at five-year intervals since they graduated from Harvard in the early 1940's.
The project, known as the Grant study after the W. T. Grant Foundation, which initially supported it, is one of a handful that have intensively assessed people at regular intervals through their adult years. Such studies are particularly valuable for the understanding of psychological development because they allow researchers to see what factors matter, for better or worse, later in life. 
The researchers defined emotional health at 65 as the ''clear ability to play and to work and to love,'' and a feeling of satisfaction with life.
These were among their findings:
* Pragmatism and dependability are particularly important.
* Many factors in early life, even devastating problems in childhood, had virtually no effect on well-being at 65.
* Being close to one's siblings at college age was strongly linked to emotional health at 65.
* Severe depression earlier in life caused problems that persisted.
* Traits that were important at college age, like the ability to make friends easily, were unimportant later in life.
The latest data were collected by George E. Vaillant, a psychiatrist at Dartmouth Medical School. He and his wife, Caroline O. Vaillant, a social worker, reported the findings in an article in the January issue of The American Journal of Psychiatry. In 1977 Dr. Vaillant published a book, ''Adaptation to Life'' (Little, Brown), based on findings of how the men fared at the age of 47.
The men hardly represent a cross-section of Americans. All were Harvard undergraduates, white, and in good mental and physical health when selected. The researchers say that by avoiding complicating factors like sex, economic status and race, they were able to focus on more subtle forces that propel one person forward while another lags.
One of the most surprising results, Dr. Vaillant said, was that having been close to one's brothers and sisters at college age strongly predicted emotional well-being in adulthood - far more strongly, for example, than having had a good marriage or successful career. Those who were only children or who said they were distant from their siblings at college age fared poorly at 65 compared with those who had at least one close brother or sister.
Before age 50, the most powerful predictors of adult mental health were an emotionally close home life as a child and parents who encouraged trust and initiative. But by 65 those factors faded in significance, and closeness to siblings in childhood ''became as powerful a predictor of later-life adjustment'' as three other factors taken together: family closeness, good relations with parents and the absence of emotional problems in childhood. Dr. Vaillant said researchers could only guess at the reasons. ''It's intriguing, a sleeper variable that didn't show up as important until the men reached 65,'' said Dr. Vaillant. ''I would guess that those who were close early in life had the seeds of a good relationship late in life.''
At the age of 47, the quality of relationships with siblings was not an important factor; having a good marriage and enjoyable job were more strongly related with life satisfaction and emotional health. But in the decade before retirement age, neither mattered as much as did having been close to a sibling earlier in life.
 
'Lots of Surprises'
By and large, those most satisfied at 47 were still happy at 65. But ''there were lots of surprises,'' said Dr. Vaillant. Poor health or alcoholism in that 18-year span set some men back; those with ''strong stoicism'' at 47 were doing well at 65.
The researchers found little evidence that several factors long assumed to be important in lifelong psychological development had much effect on well-being at 65. They included being poor or orphaned in childhood, having parents who divorced (or who were happily married) and having emotional problems in childhood or college.
For instance, of the 204 men in the original group, 13 felt troubled enough during college to have seen a psychiatrist. But by the age of 65 these men fared no worse than the rest of the group.
''In the long run, people are extraordinarily adaptable,'' Dr. Vaillant said. ''Given enough time, people recover and change; a half-century perspective shows that time heals.''
One of the most devastating experiences over the course of life was a severe depression, Dr. Vaillant found. Of the 204 men, 21 had such a depression at some point between the ages of 21 and 50. In the latest study, 15 of the 21 were chronically ill or had died.
''I expected that the men in the study would be better-adapted and protected than most,'' Dr. Vaillant said. ''If they got depressed, it would pass with little lasting effect. But depression led to a greater global disruption of life than any other single factor.''
 
Buffers Against Depression
Having close family relations may have been a buffer against depression, since the researchers found that having had a ''bleak childhood'' predicted depression later in life. But not all of those who had a difficult childhood became depressed. And for those who escaped depression, bad times in childhood seemed to have little long-term effect.
Only 7 percent of those who did well at 65 had not been close to a brother or sister, Dr. Vaillant said. Of the 21 men who became seriously depressed at some point in their lives, 12 were only children or said they were estranged from their siblings by college age.
Whether they were only children or were distant from brothers and sisters, he said, ''the effects of the isolation seem to be the same in later life.'' Psychoanalytic theories of depression hold that emotional warmth early in life, whether with parents or siblings, can be a buffer against depression later.
One of the most potent predictors of well-being at 65 was the ability to handle emotional crisis maturely. Immature reactions included becoming bitter or prejudiced, collecting injustices, feigning cheerfulness and chronically complaining without allowing anyone to help.
The best way to handle emotional crisis, the study found, is to control the first impulse and give a more measured response. ''It's having the capacity to hold a conflict or impulse in consciousness without acting on it,'' Dr. Vaillant said. ''You can acknowledge the clouds, but also see the silver lining.''
Two lifelong traits, pragmatism and dependability, also emerged as particularly important to emotional health at 65 - more so than being clever in analytic work or having a creative flair.
Those who in college had been seen as being good at practical organization in their course work, rather than as having a theoretical, speculative or scholarly bent, were among the healthiest in mind at retirement age, the study found. So were those who as college sophomores were rated by a psychiatrist as ''steady, stable, dependable, thorough, sincere and trustworthy.''
On the other hand, traits that seemed important for psychological adjustment in college mattered less and less over the years. Among these were spontaneity and the ability to make friends easily.
By 65, being pragmatic and well-organized was the trait that most strongly predicted well-being. ''It's another way of measuring perseverance,'' Dr. Vaillant said. ''At this age, perseverance is more important than whether you can run the bases fast.''

HEADLINE: Human Genes Turn Plants Into Factories For Medicines

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE

 BODY:
SCIENTISTS are inserting human genes into plants and turning the plants into miniature factories that can produce large quantities of useful human proteins.
They have grown tobacco plants that produce antibodies; potatoes that make serum albumin, a human blood protein widely used in surgery; and rape plants that make enkephalin, a painkiller produced in the human brain. And a California biotechnology company is planning to market a sun screen containing human melanin, a natural skin pigment, that will be grown in tobacco.
The researchers hope to use plants to make a wide range of human hormones, growth factors, enzymes and immune system cells, said Dr. Andrew Hiatt, a molecular biologist at the Research Institute of Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, Calif., who grew the antibody-making plants.
While many scientists applaud such experiments, critics say there are risks that need to be addressed. Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends and a frequent critic of biotechnology, said that ''turning living creatures into chemical factories'' has obvious benefits, but that ''the environmental and ethical implications have not been explored.'' 
''If the plants are raised outdoors and the new genes get into the wild gene pool,'' he said, ''it could have a potentially destabilizing effect on the ecological system. They are performing processes not performed in nature.'' Advocates of such experiments say these criticisms are probably exaggerated but agree that they need to be explored.
The usual way of manufacturing proteins is to insert human genes into bacteria, yeast or animal cells. These techniques are a big improvement over previous methods, which required painstaking extraction of proteins from vast amounts of animal tissue. But genetically altered plants can produce much more of these useful proteins at far less cost, scientists say.
''We can put just about any molecule that has therapeutic value into plants,'' Dr. Hiatt said.
Yeast and bacteria need to be carefully tended, said Don Cooksey, a plant pathologist at the University of California at Riverside. Animal cells in suspension and mouse-human hybrid cells are tricky and expensive to maintain.
But plants generally take care of themselves, Dr. Cooksey said. They convert sunlight, water and soil nutrients into food. Some plants, like tobacco, potatoes and petunias, can be grown from single plant cells; seeds are not required. Genes can be transferred into plant cells with relative ease. There is even a ''gene gun'' that shoots DNA into leaves.
For some human molecules, plants offer a biochemical advantage over simpler organisms, said Robert Erwin, president of the Biosource Genetics Corporation of Vacaville, Calif. Plant cells, which are every bit as complicated as human cells, tend to assemble human proteins in their proper configurations; bacteria and yeast do not.
But the most important advantage, the scientists said, is that plants can be grown by the acre and can thus produce vast quantities of a useful protein. Some proteins, like human growth hormone, may never be needed in large amounts. But if large amounts would be useful, Dr. Hiatt said, ''plants are the way to go.''
For example, he said, other Scripps scientists are testing an antibody intended to combat lung cancer. Over the course of treatment, each patient requires about a gram of antibody. If the therapy is successful, Dr. Hiatt said, 100,000 people a year would need the antibody, making plants an economical route of production.
 
Tobacco's Advantage
Scientists have developed two strategies for inserting human genes into plants, one permanent and one temporary. Dr. Hiatt took the permanent route. His experiment, reported in November, began by manipulating an immune cell that produces a particular antibody. Previous efforts to insert a complete immune cell into tobacco plants had failed; Dr. Hiatt found that he had to extract from the cells the the two genes needed to make an antibody, a light chain gene and heavy chain gene.
The genes were inserted into a soil bacterium that passed them into tobacco leaf fragments. Next Dr. Hiatt exploited tobacco's ability to grow entire new plants from single cells. He chose tobacco cells that had taken up human genes and grew two kinds of plants: those with heavy chain genes and those with light.
Then he crossed the adult plants sexually. As the plants combined their genes, some received both a heavy and a light chain gene. Thus endowed with a complete set of genetic instructions, they began assembling complete human antibodies in abundance.
But there was an immediate problem, Dr. Hiatt said. The antibodies were released into the plant cell's fluid interior, where enzymes chewed them up as fast as they were made.
To avoid this fate, Dr. Hiatt attached protein from a mouse to the human antibody genes. This attachment protects the antibody from the hostile enzymes and guides it to a cell membrane where the assembly of the antibody is completed and is then secreted. If the plants are grown in liquid, they will secrete the protein into it; from there the protein can be extracted.
A Dutch company, Mogen, used a similar technique to produce serum albumin in potatoes. And a Belgian company, Plant Genetic Systems, introduced the brain protein enkephalin into rape plants.
The second strategy, pursued by Biosource Genetics, temporarily introduces human genes into adult plants. The company has developed a technique in which a new gene is carried into plant cells by an RNA molecule that multiplies and spreads itself and the foreign gene to neighboring cells. Within days, the entire plant is producing human protein.
The RNA degrades with time, said Mr. Erwin, the Biosource president, and the foreign gene is never passed on to subsequent generations. The plants are harvested and ground up, and the desired protein is extracted.
 
Genetic Sun Screens
The company's first commercial product is human melanin, which is produced in a variety of plant cells. Several pounds of pure melanin have been sold to a joint venture of William H. Rorer Inc. and Advanced Polymer Systems that plans to market a sun screen.
Conventional sun screens contain a chemical compound that both absorbs and scatters the ultraviolet light that causes sunburn, said Dr. Miles Chedekel, a research scientist at Biosource Genetics. Human melanin is better at scattering ultraviolet rays, he said, and offers more protection. The melanin is incorporated into microscopic sponges that are applied as a cream. Rorer and Advanced Polymer Systems are working on sun screens that will deflect all the ultraviolet light.
Mr. Erwin said his company was also using tobacco plants to produce interleukin-2, an anti-cancer agent derived from the human immune system. He recently met with Gov. James G. Martin of North Carolina to discuss conducting outdoor tests in that state's tobacco fields.
These technologies, the scientists said, can also be used to produce hard-to-synthesize drugs inside plants. For example, eincristine, a cancer drug, is now extracted at high expense from the periwinkle plant. Dr. Hiatt said the gene for eincristine could be inserted into tobacco cells, which are easy to manipulate, to produce the cancer drug more cheaply.
Finally, the technology is being used to give plants new genes that will protect them from plant diseases. It should be possible, researchers say, to give plants antibodies derived from animals that will neutralize many bacteria, viruses and funguses.
 
Permanent Gene Transfer
 
The two genes that produce a desired human antibody are isolated. One is called the light chain, the other the heavy chain. Each is inserted into rings of DNA called plasmids. The plasmids are placed in bacteria.
 
The bacteria are added to tobacco leaf fragments and transfer the plasmid to plant cells. Some cells integrate the heavy or the light chain into their own DNA.
 
Plants are cloned from the leaf fragments. Some carry either light or heavy genes.
 
The plants that carry either light or heavy genes are grown to maturity and crossed. Some of their offspring receive both genes and combine them so they can produce the functioning antibody.

HEADLINE: Chase Profit Off in Period; Loss for Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, parent of the Chase Manhattan Bank, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter profits fell 36.4 percent and that it had a loss for the year.
Chase said earnings in the last quarter of 1989 fell to $175 million, or $1.47 a share, from $275 million, or $2.93 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.
The nation's second-largest bank holding company after Citicorp reported a loss of $665 million for the year in contrast to net income of $1.06 billion, or $11.55 a share, a year earlier.
 
Problems With Latin Loans
Chase attributed the weak showing in both periods to difficulties with its Latin American loans. 
Separately, the First Chicago Corporation, the largest banking company in the Midwest, said earnings were down 10.5 percent in the fourth quarter and 30 percent for the year, also reflecting in part moves to reduce exposure to third world debt.
Last week, J. P. Morgan & Company also reported sharply lower profits for the last quarter of 1989 and a loss for the year. Its $1.27 billion yearly loss included a $2 billion provision for losses on loans to developing nations in the third quarter.
Yesterday, Chase stock rose 37.5 cents, to $32.125, in very heavy trading, of nearly 1.7 million shares. Chase declined to speculate on the market's move,, but Cheryl Swaim, a banking analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, said that ''people were expecting disappointing earnings, and that they were pretty much in line with those expectations.''
Chase said profits fell in the final quarter of 1989 because Brazil had made practically no interest payments in the period. Brazil suspended payments in February, 1987, the bank said, but then brought itself up to date in the final quarter of 1988 with a $365 million payment, thus distorting figures for the two fourth quarters.
The bank attributed the 1989 loss largely to nearly $1.3 billion in special third-quarter charges, including new loan-loss reserves of $1.15 billion to cover possible losses on loans to the developing countries, mainly Brazil, Argentina, Mexico and Venezuela.
 
No Addition to Loan Reserves
Chase reported increases in fourth-quarter income from consumer banking, investment banking and from trading.
The provision for possible loan losses was $130 million in the fourth quarter compared with $300 million in the period a year earlier. In the 1988 period, Chase said it had added $200 million to reserves for possible loan losses in the developing world. No provision for developing countries was made in the fourth quarter of 1989.
For the full year, the loan-loss provision totaled $1.7 billion, including $1.3 billion for developing countries and $47 million for problem real estate in Arizona.
Chase said it also wrote off $463 million in loans in the fourth quarter, including $336 million in loans to the developing nations. Argentinian borrowers accounted for $165 million of that amount, or about half. It said it had written off $181 million in loans in the comparable period the year before.
Loans written off for the year, Chase said, amounted to $1.2 billion, including $91 million for real estate in Arizona, $706 million to developing countries and another $152 million to Argentine borrowers.
In addition to the $1.15 billion in reserves added in the third quarter, Chase said it wrote off $126 million last year for bad real estate at the Chase Bank of Arizona and $38 million to leave the securities business, mostly in London.
Interest income fell in the fourth quarter to $761 million, from $1.13 billion the year before, it said, and also for the year, dropping to $3.15 billion, from $3.4 billion.
Chase said it had collected $100 million in interest payments from loans to Brazil last year, mainly in the first half, but another $97 million in interest payments was not received, including $14 million due in the fourth quarter of 1989.
Argentina, Chase said, continued to be in arrears on its interest payments, reducing fourth-quarter interest income by $17 million and by $74 million for the year.
 
First Chicago Down
 
By The Associated Press
The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $122.9 million, or $1.77 a share, down from $137.3 million, or $2.07 a share, in the same quarter in 1988.
The company said its operating income, however, rose 4.2 percent, to $115 million, from $110.4 million in the corresponding 1988 period.
The Chicago bank's income for 1989 totaled $358.7 million, or $5.10 a share, compared with $513.1 million, or $8.20 a share, in 1988.
Full-year operating income was up 8 percent, to $451.2 million, or $6.56 a share, from $417.3 million, or $6.57 a share.
The company's stock slipped 25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, to $35.125. with 283,300 shares changing hands.
First Chicago said its allowance for credit losses was $1.28 billion at the end of the year, compared with $1.4 billion at the end of the third quarter and $1.31 billion at the end of 1988.
Its provision for credit losses rose to $75 million in the fourth quarter from $50 million the year earlier. Total net charge-offs were $199 million, up from $128 million in 1988.
First Chicago's exposure to Third World debt was reduced by about $350 million in the fourth quarter, to around $1.3 billion.

HEADLINE: Where Savings Crisis Hits Hard

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 11

 BODY:
This overbuilt city, only a few years ago an illustration of solid growth in the West, has now become a clear example of the difficulty the Government faces in selling the vast real estate holdings it has acquired in the savings and loan crisis.
Colorado Springs boomed during much of the last decade, helped by Pentagon spending and the arrival of big electronics companies. But after a three-year economic slowdown that left developers unable to sell or rent many homes, office buildings and shopping centers, three of the four local savings and loan institutions failed and were seized by the Government last year. Out-of-state savings institutions that had lent heavily here were also battered by foreclosures, and some fell into insolvency.
 
A Distressed Market
The result was to dump into the Government's lap a huge inventory of repossessed property. If the Government is to resolve the savings and loan situation quickly and without further inflating the bailout's costs, currently estimated at $160 billion, it will have to succeed in selling the property in Colorado Springs and in similarly distressed cities, mostly in the West and Southwest, with a minimum of delay and at market prices. 
Colorado, along with Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, New Mexico and Arkansas, has been formally designated in the bailout legislation for savings institutions as a distressed real estate market, and Colorado Springs has the largest concentration of foreclosed properties in the state.
Officials of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency set up last summer to sell the assets of most failed savings institutions, concede their task is daunting at best. Among the biggest problems here and elsewhere are the sheer quantity of the properties to be sold, an inability to find enough tenants to make buildings attractive to buyers, the difficulty for potential buyers to find financing in places where surviving financial institutions have become more conservative, and competition from other Federal agencies also trying to dispose of troubled properties.
Complicating the situation, real estate executives here say, are ethics rules that prevent certain developers whose losses have already cost the Government money from helping to manage or sell the properties.
The quantity of property to be sold in this city alone is staggering. Resolution Trust has listed 156 single-family homes for sale in this city of 280,000 people hard by the eastern slope of the Rockies, 70 miles south of Denver.
The agency has put up for sale 162 condominiums, 10 apartment buildings with four units or less, 15 larger apartment buildings and 31 residential lots. There are 17 office buildings for sale, 8 strip malls and other retail locations, a warehouse, a movie theater and assorted other properties, not to mention thousands of acres of undeveloped land. Altogether, the agency owns at least 40 percent of the land of Colorado Springs.
 
Value Sharply Reduced
The list grows almost daily, and the trust corporation has not yet made a thorough appraisal of all the properties in its hands. Local real estate executives and economists say the property was once worth as much as $1 billion, although its market value today is probably no more than half that, meaning the bailout could cost taxpayers up to $500 million just in this one city.
The quantity of property is just one of the Government's problems. From a standing start, the trust agency will have to learn the intricacies of the real estate businesses, become intimately acquainted with market conditions in this community and others. It will also have to set up a system for hiring and policing the private brokers and property managers who will handle much of the day-to-day sales work and upkeep.
The agency will have to balance pressure to act quickly with pressure not to dump property on the market at fire-sale prices. It will have to cope with a host of practical problems, like a nationwide shortage of appraisers, needed to assess the fair market value of the holdings and help set prices. And it will have to accomplish all this without creating a cumbersome bureaucracy that will drive prospective buyers away.
 
'One Day at a Time'
''We're going to have to go from being a Rube Goldberg-type operation to being a well-oiled machine,'' said Anthony Scalzi, the regional director for Resolution Trust in Denver. ''The only way to approach this job is like a recovering alcoholic -one day at a time.''
The decline in real estate prices here seems to be leveling off. Brokers say prices are sufficiently low to attract a fair number of buyers, especially for completed homes in nice neighborhoods, and the Government has made modest progress in selling the most attractive of its residential properties.
Brent P. Spaulding, a broker with Premier Inc. working on behalf of the Government, has sold 32 of 56 town houses in the Brandy Glass development since last fall. But the prices he can get, around $60,000 for two-bedroom, 1,300-square-foot units, are $30,000 less than the developer was asking three years ago, and Mr. Spaulding said the Government was losing up to $20,000 on each unit he sold.
''I 100 percent believe we've already seen property values in this market hit bottom,'' Mr. Spaulding said. ''But with the savings and loan crisis, it just means we're going to stay at those prices for longer.''
 
Still a Tough Sell
Even at the depressed prices, both residential and commercial real estate remains a tough sell here. Brokers like Mr. Spaulding are competing not only with other properties controlled by Resolution Trust but also with homes repossessed by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Veterans Administration and other Federal agencies. Those agencies have foreclosed on thousands of properties in the area on which they held mortgages or mortgage guarantees.
Moreover, Mr. Spaulding said, investors interested in purchasing properties have been unable to get financing because the pool of available credit has shrunk since the failure of the city's three major savings and loan institutions. They are now being operated by the Government.
In addition, many properties, both residential and commercial, will prove difficult or impossible to sell at anything approaching market price, brokers said. Some properties are not fully built, or have deteriorated.
 
Beautiful View, No Tenants
One of the biggest problems facing the trust agency is leasing out enough space in office and apartment buildings to permit a buyer to generate sufficient cash flow to make a purchase attractive. The agency recently took over Union Pointe, a new 40,000-square-foot office building in Colorado Springs with a stunning view of the Rockies, but not a single tenant.
''If it's vacant, we can't sell it,'' Mr. Scalzi of Resolution Trust said.
Brokers said much of the undeveloped land would also be nearly impossible to sell. The biggest chunk in the Government's possession is the 25,000-acre Banning-Lewis Ranch, which runs along the eastern edge of the city. The land, purchased several years ago by a speculator named Frank Aries with $230 million borrowed from the Western Savings and Loan Association of Phoenix, was repossessed by Western last year, just after the institution was seized by Federal regulators.
Mr. Scalzi said the Government, under terms of the bailout bill, must use the private sector as much as possible in managing and selling its properties. But real estate executives, most of whom are eager to get that business, say the agency will be restricted in whom it can employ because of ethics guidelines that ban contract awards to any company that has been involved in a major foreclosure or has caused a significant loss to the Government. In Colorado Springs, that encompasses virtually every major developer. The Government says it is simply trying to avoid doing business with the same people who caused the problems.
 
A 'Neighborhood Business'
''The R.T.C. needs local companies because real estate is a local, neighborhood business,'' said Stephen M. Schuck, who as one of the area's largest developers has had his share of failed projects in recent years. ''There's no reason we should be disqualified, but it appears that we will be.''
Some developers also worry that the trust agency, under pressure to sell properties quickly and facing a lack of knowledgeable appraisers, will cut prices further, driving down the entire market. They say that even if the agency can find enough appraisers, it will be difficult to judge the true value of a property in a hypersensitive market where sales are relatively infrequent.
By law, the Government cannot sell any of the property in Colorado for less than 95 percent of its fair market value because the state is formally designated in the bailout bill as having a distressed real estate market. But even Government officials acknowledge that fair market value is a moving target and can be determined only by a good appraiser and knowledgeable local brokers.
Just a few years ago it would have been inconceivable to almost anyone in Colorado Springs that the city would become a symbol of a huge real estate debacle. After growing steadily for several decades, the local economy in the early 1980's seemed on the verge of a boom. The city was successful in persuading major electronics companies like the Hewlett-Packard Company and Texas Instruments Inc. to put big operations here.
Home to the Air Force Academy and Fort Carson, a large Army base, the city had long relied heavily on military spending. Colorado Springs became the home of a major testing center for the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program and was designated as the site of a new military space command. Suddenly, the city was one of the fastest-growing in the nation and one of the most attractive markets for developers.
Housing developments, office buildings, retail space and other projects were built with abandon, anticipating consistently strong growth.
 
Lenders Had Sharp Growth
The three biggest local savings institutions, freed to plunge into real estate by deregulation in the early 1980's, financed most of the building, often lending 100 percent of the cost of a project in return for a share of the profits. The institutions all grew rapidly; the largest, the American Federal Savings and Loan of Colorado Springs, more than doubled in asset size between 1983 and 1988, to $830 million, and eventually had 60 percent of its loan portfolio in construction loans.
But then the city was struck by layoffs in the electronics business, cuts in military spending plans and the fallout from the depressed oil prices that struck at Denver and cities in the Southwest. Suddenly there was no demand for new office space, buyers for houses became scarce, defaults started mounting and the financial health of the savings institutions deteriorated rapidly.
Federal regulators seized American Federal and the two other institutions, Otero Savings and the First Federal Savings and Loan of Colorado Springs, last winter. The Government formally put American Federal and Otero Savings up for sale this month.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Health Insurers' Changing Role

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
HEALTH-INSURANCE executives say their business has changed radically in the last two years in the nation's struggle with double-digit growth in medical spending. Many insurers say their traditional work of assuming risks has been eclipsed by services to help their customers' health dollars go further.
''We are not an insurance company, we are a managed-care company,'' said John P. Cole, executive vice president of the Lincoln National Corporation, a medium-sized insurer based in Fort Wayne, Ind. Its business now, he said, is negotiating on behalf of employer groups to get discounts from doctors and hospitals and to eliminate unnecessary medical procedures. 
Demand from employers for ''managed care'' services has surged. They range from insurer-operated health maintenance organizations and discount networks of doctors and hospitals to requiring advance approval by an insurer for a hospital admission. And in some particularly expensive cases, like organ transplants or cancer, the insurer may assign a nurse or social worker to review the cost-effectiveness of care.
People in the industry say the number of Americans still covered by traditional fee-for-service insurance - which pays medical charges, no questions asked - declined again sharply in 1989.
For example, only 22 percent of the 11 million people covered for health benefits through the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, based in Hartford, are still eligible for traditional care, compared with 64 percent in 1988, said Charles T. Bell, senior vice president for employee benefits with Aetna. ''Our basic strategy is to suggest to our customers that we convert to these managed-care plans,'' Mr. Bell said.
The insurance companies say their charges for traditional fee-for-service policies caught up with inflation in health costs in 1989, after losses in the previous two years or so. But some insurers are still losing money in managed care. The start-up expenses of organizing networks of doctors and hospitals, checking on credentials and monitoring performance are higher than in traditional fee-for-service health insurance, said Anthony J. Gajda, a principal in New York with Mercer Meidinger Hansen, a benefits consulting firm.
Aetna, for example, said it lost money on its managed-care business in 1989. But Francis L. Onofrio, an Aetna spokesman, said the managed-care line is expected to break even this year and be profitable in 1991.
Ronald E. Hunt, a vice president with the Nationwide Life Insurance Company, said the company, based in Columbus, Ohio, now requires ''pre-certification before hospital confinement on virtually 100 percent of our business.'' Nationwide, which had $350 million in group life and health premiums in 1989, is setting up discount networks in Midwestern and Southern cities.
Indeed, 93 percent of the 1,915 employers recently surveyed by A. Foster Higgins & Company, a benefits consulting firm, said they offer employees the chance to join an H.M.O. or another type of discount network. The employees typically pay out less than for traditional coverage, to induce them to join. Meanwhile, the doctors in the networks have financial incentives to avoid unnecessary medical procedures. John Erb, a managing consultant with Foster Higgins in New York, said a growing number of businesses with fewer than 500 employees had begun to offer managed-care systems, which larger companies have long used.
The number of employees choosing managed-care deals is growing rapidly. The latest survey of 1,665 employers by the Health Industry Association of America, an insurer trade group, found that only 28 percent of employees still had traditional coverage in 1988, compared with 41 percent in 1987.
''The commercial insurers are convinced that managed care is the future of their business,'' said John J. Gable, a research manager with the association of 200 health insurers, which cover 90 million people.
The same trend was reported by the nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations, which have 74 million subscribers. Gary Meade, a managed-care executive with national Blue Cross and Blue Shield in Chicago, said the movement toward H.M.O.'s and discount networks was accelerating. Managed-care systems now cover half the Blue Cross enrollees, compared with only 25 percent two years ago.
About $150 billion of the $600 billion that Americans spend on health care is handled by insurance companies, according to Government statistics. Only about half the companies' business is now ''real,'' or traditional, insurance, said Louise M. Firth, a vice president in Cambridge, Mass., with Arthur D. Little Inc., the management consultants. ''The other half is benefits under administration, including claims processing for self-insured employers,'' she said.
Many large insurance brokers, meanwhile, have developed benefit-consulting services to replace dwindling revenue from commissions as traditional insurance sales have declined.

HEADLINE: Mexico and Banks Said To Close Financing Gap

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Mexico and its bankers have agreed on how to cover the $300 million shortfall in their landmark deal under which most of the banks involved will reduce the value of the country's existing debt by 35 percent, according to bank and Mexican officials.
At the same time, the Bank Advisory Committee, led by Citibank of New York, is hoping to get Canadian banks to sign off this week on a $1.2 billion bridge loan that is the other last detail of the deal to be worked out. One reluctant British bank, Lloyds Bank, agreed to the bridge loan providing interim financing last week. The brige loan, by providing financing to the Mexicans earlier in the year, allows some of the guarantees involved in the proposal to be offered earlier. 
Both actions reflect the difficulty of tying up all the loose ends in this deal, which will be the first completed under the Bush Administration's debt strategy known as the Brady plan, named for Treasury Secretatry Nicholas F. Brady. If the deal is finally completed early next month in Mexico, as now planned, the conclusion will come 11 months after Mr. Brady first disclosed the new debt strategy and 10 months after Mexico and its bankers began negotiations.
 
Initial Outline in July
The initial outline of the deal was announced in July and involved the reduction of debt. The Mexicans are inviting the advisory committee members and the chairmen of the banks involved to Mexico for the signing ceremony, officials said.
The $300 million gap in the financing is a shortfall in the money necessary to provide the guarantees or what bankers call enhancements for the debt plan covering $48 billion of medium- and long-term Mexican debt.
The details of the method of covering the $300 million financing gap have become an issue because of a dispute in the United States Treasury and suggestions from Treasury officials and others that American taxpayers might be tapped to cover the gap. Officials from Mexico and the banks involved in the negotiations and the Treasury said, however, that this was not the case.
Under the overall debt plan, the bankers could chose debt reduction, either by lowering the principal on existing loans or accepting lower interest payments at a fixed 6.25 percent. Both reductions equal about a 35 percent reduction in the value of the existing loans. A third option allowed banks to choose to make new loans equal to 25 percent of their current exposure.
 
Mexican Guarantees
The Mexicans are to provide guarantees for both the principal and interest to be paid. They will buy zero-coupon Treasury bonds to guarantee the principal of the new bonds that are swapped for the old loans and will set up a revolving fund to cover the interest payments for up to 18 months. If all the interest payments are made by Mexico, the fund is rolled over for another 18 months.
The Mexican Government has $7 billion for these guarantees, which turned out to be $300 million short because more banks than expected chose to do principal reduction and fewer banks than expected chose to make new loans. The $7 billion includes money from Mexico, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Japanese Government.
Under the proposal the banks and Mexico have worked out to cover this gap, the Mexican Government will come up with as much as $100 million from its reserves. In addition, the money put in the fund to cover the interest payments will be cut by up to $200 million. The interest earned while the money is in the fund will make up the $200 million gap.
The question of a subsidy from the taxpayers arose when the Treasury separately decided what interest rate and price to offer on the zero-coupon bonds used to back the principal payments on the bonds that are traded for the old loans. Some Treasury officials suggested that a below-market price for these represented a subsidy from taxpayers to cover the $300 million financing gap. A zero-coupon bond is sold at a large discount to its face value because it pays no interest until its maturity. The higher the yield, the less that has to be paid for the face value of the bond. 7.925% Interest Rate The interest rate is 8.05 percent and there is a Treasury fee of 0.125 percent, which lowers the rate to 7.925 percent. This is about one-quarter of a percentage point above what the yield is on 30-year zero-coupon bonds in the market. Some in Treasury had argued that the Mexicans should get this lower rate, which would mean they would have to pay more for their zero-coupon bonds, thereby aggravating the lingering financing problems with the debt package.
Louis Crandall, the chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates in New York, said there is an ''institutional distortion'' in the zero-coupon bond market at 30 years that created the lower yield. In addition, he said, this market is very small, amounting to a total face value of $45 million and a value today of around $5 million.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Broadly Lower; Dow Off 19.84

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks fell broadly yesterday in slow trading as many investors observed the Martin Luther King Day holiday.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.84 points, to 2,669.37, as declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances, 1,091 to 395. On Friday, the Dow tumbled 71.46 points, its biggest drop since the indicator plummeted 190.58 points on Oct. 13.
Turnover on the Big Board shrank to 140.6 million shares, from 183.9 million on Friday because of the Federal and bank holiday. Government securities markets were closed and corporate bond trading was light. 
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.93 points, to 337, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.61 points, to 186.71.
Traders said that some of the market's decline might have been attributed to the fact that Greg Smith, investment strategist at Prudential-Bache Securities, suggested his firm's clients increase the cash portion of their portfolios to 30 percent, from 15 percent, and that stocks be decreased to 35 percent, from 50 percent.
''There is concern that interest rates are not coming down and that the differential in interest rates between the United States and the rest of the world is narrowing, making it more difficult to attract more capital from overseas,'' Mr. Smith said in a telephone interview. ''There is also worry about inflation, and the earnings outlook is poor. In short, it looks like rough going for the first half of this year.''
 
J.P. Morgan Down
Among individual issues, J.P. Morgan dropped 2 1/8, to 38 1/8. Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said he had lowered his earnings estimate to $4.10 a share, from $4.35 a share, and his rating on the bank to below average near-term, from neutral.
Rorer soared 13 3/4, to 63, and was the biggest point gainer. Its 27.9 percentage change was the largest on the Big Board as more than 2.6 million shares were traded. Rorer said it was negotiating a deal in which an unidentified drug company would acquire about 68 percent of its outstanding common shares. Rorer has valued the transaction at $73 a share, or $2.3 billion.
Desoto fell 1 7/8, to 41. The company, which has offered its United States consumer paint business for sale, said other domestic paint manufacturers were the most likely buyers.
Symbol Technologies showed the largest percentage decline, falling 5, to 10 1/2. The company told an analysts meeting that it expected 1989 earnings to come in at about 5 cents a share. Most analysts had expected earnings in the mid-20-cent range.
Sea Containers plummeted 7 1/4, or 11.1 percent, to 59 1/2, and was one of the biggest net losers on the Big Board. Temple Holdings Ltd., jointly owned by Stena A.B. of Sweden and Tiphook P.L.C. of Britain, said Stena had offered to buy Sea Containers' Sealink British Ferries unit for $430 million and 838,098 Sea Containers shares. Analysts said that investors, speculating that Sea Containers would might agree to the Temple offer and give up its plan to buy back shares, took profits while they could.
 
Philip Morris Is Most Active
Philip Morris, which announced several executive appointments, was the most-active stock, falling 5/8, to 38 1/8, on a volume of 3.3 million shares.
Other active blue chips included Chase Manhattan, up 3/8, to 32 1/8; General Electric, off 1/2, to 62 5/8; A.T.&T., off 5/8, to 42 5/8; Merck, down 1 7/8, to 73 1/4, and Eastman Kodak, off 3/4, to 40 1/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index dropped 3.65 points, to 368.58, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index declined 3.08 points, to 436.64.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
'Junk Bond' Prices Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The long-awaited bankruptcy filing by two of the Campeau Corporation's primary subsidiaries had little effect on prices in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market yesterday.
Market participants said that bids on most outstanding debt issues of the Allied Stores Corporation and Federated Department Stores Inc., the Campeau units that sought bankruptcy protection in Cincinnati, fell early in the day, then recovered and by late in the session were little changed.
Trading was limited in the high-yield markets and in other fixed-income markets because of holidays in the United States and Japan. What little trading there was, however, suggested that investors were concerned about higher interest rates. 
 
'Hard to Find Trading'
The Treasury securities markets here were closed for the holiday for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., although futures contracts on Treasury securities were traded on the commodities exchanges.
''It is very hard to find trading in anything right now,'' said Kingman Penniman, an analyst who follows the high-yield market for McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei.
''The market took the Campeau news the way it should have, since it has already been built into prices,'' he said. ''The impact of this filing took place in September and October.''
In Europe, the only cash market for Treasury securities that was open yesterday, investors furthered the slide in Goverment notes and bonds by selling securities.
At the close of trading in Europe, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds were offered at a price of 99 7/32, down by 9/32, to yield 8.19 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 99 18/32, down by 5/32, to yield 8.08 percent.
 
Selling in Chicago
Selling pressure was also evident in trading in the futures market in Chicago, despite a further slide in stock prices.
''The bond market should have benefited from a flight to quality out of the stock market, but that was not the case at all,'' said Richard L. Sandor, an executive vice president in charge of the fixed-income department at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
At the close of trading yesterday at the Chicago Board of Trade, the March Treasury bond contract closed at a price of 96 19/32, down by 13/32 on the day. The March contract for 10-year notes fell by 15/32, to 98 15/ 32.
''The 10-year future was hit harder than the long bond,'' Mr. Sandor noted. ''That is a recognition that interest rates in Japan and around the world are headed higher.''
Ten-year Treasury note issues may be more vulnerable to shifts in foreign interest rates because most governments outside the United States do not issue securities with maturities longer than 10 years.

HEADLINE: CUOMO PROPOSES AUSTERITY BUDGET WITH MORE TAXES

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Saying that ''there is a huge gap between what we want to spend and what we can afford to spend,'' Gov. Mario M. Cuomo presented an austere budget today that would increase state spending by the lowest rate in more than a decade and would force cuts in dozens of state programs.
The Governor recommended that the last phase of New York's tax cut plan be suspended, a move that would provide the state with $400 million in the coming fiscal year. He also proposed that the state raise more than $800 million in increased fees and taxes, bringing his total tax proposal to more than $1 billion.
Among the tax increases he recommended are a new 6 percent tax on out-of-state telephone calls and an increase of 5 cents a pack in the state's cigarette tax, now at 33 cents a pack.
 
Praise and Criticism
As soon as the Governor's $31 billion budget plan was released, state lawmakers mobilized along partisan lines. 
The Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, offered reserved praise for the Cuomo proposal, saying that ''parameters of the budget are something I can support.''
In contrast, the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I., attacked the proposal.
''The Governor has proposed a budget that increases the rate at which state spending is growing and looks to raise revenues to the tune of $1.5 billion,'' he said. ''I do not agree with the Governor's proposed deferral of the next phase of the income tax cut, nor am I receptive to the additional new taxes and fees he has proposed.''
In his budget proposal, the Governor barely managed to live up to a pledge he made last week to keep the spending increase below the inflation rate. The Governor projected that the inflation rate for the state, a figure that is rarely used and difficult to calculate, would be 4.5 percent for the fiscal year that starts April 1. His budget would raise spending by 4.49 percent, down from the 5 percent increase estimated for the current budget year.
But Mr. Cuomo's estimated 4.49 percent increase applies only to the state's general fund, which is made up of most state tax revenues. For the state's total budget, which includes billions of dollars in Federal aid as well as capital funds and specially earmarked taxes, the rate of increase would be 9.3 percent. Under Mr. Cuomo's proposal total state spending would rise to $51 billion.
The Governor's budget contains a significant spending increase for drug treatment and enforcement, $188 billion, and includes start-up funds for two drug treatment ''campuses'' to house 1,000 addicts each. It also contains $13 million to begin a new health-insurance program for children.
But outside of the drug and children's insurance programs, both of which were featured prominently in the Governor's State of the State address two weeks ago, few state programs would receive significant increases, and many would suffer cuts.
Aid to private colleges in the state, for example, would be cut by almost $11 million. The state's I H New York tourist promotion program would be cut by $2 million, and aid to local governments to run sewage treatment plants would decline by $24 million.
 
Programs for the Poor
Programs for the poor would be cut, too, under the Governor's proposal. Mr. Cuomo recommended limiting some welfare recipients deemed employable to six months of benefits, for a saving of $9 million. And he asked the Legislature to impose limits on the number of visits that Medicaid recipients can make to a doctor - to save the state $24 million. The Governor tried to impose such limits administratively last year, but they have been tied up in the courts.
In his budget presentation this morning, Mr. Cuomo dealt only with the broad outlines of his budget, glossing over the specific taxes or spending cuts he was proposing.
Even in his broad sketch, Mr. Cuomo painted a grim picture of the state's situation, saying New York was entering a period of declining tax revenues while social problems, like AIDS and drug use, were growing. And he warned that state tax collections, which have been lagging, could be even lower than predicted in the budget, necessitating further cuts.
''If we meet this challenge, as I fully expect we will, we will be stronger than we ever were,'' he said. ''But if we fail to meet the challenge, then, frankly, challenge can become crisis.''
 
Bracing for Tough Fight
Mr. Cuomo appeared to be bracing for a long and bruising fight with the Legislature, which traditionally adds several hundred million dollars to the Governor's budget to increase education aid and finance local projects.
In the budget season, it is common for legislators to accuse the Governor of stinginess and profligacy. But this year Mr. Cuomo pledged to expose what he said was lawmakers' hypocrisy. ''Every year I get $5 billion in requests from legislators,'' Mr. Cuomo said. This year, he said, he will make public whatever requests he gets.
''I'm not going to play that game,'' he said.
One of the few areas to receive a substantial increase in the Governor's budget is prisons. Predicting that the number of inmates in the state would grow by more than 8,000 over the next year, Mr. Cuomo proposed constructing 5,300 new beds in annexes attached to existing prisons. The cost of the prison expansion would be $282 million.
For New York City, which is suffering from tremendous budget problems of its own, Mr. Cuomo's proposed budget offered little comfort. Some of the Governor's recommendations, like the limits on Medicaid, would provide savings for the city, which picks up part of the cost of the program. But other proposals, like reductions in aid to local cultural organizations, are likely to cost the city money.
 
'Difficult Times'
In a carefully worded statement, Mayor David N. Dinkins avoided complaints but said the Governor's budget clearly reflected ''difficult times.''
In his education aid proposal, the Governor offered a $240 million increase, to roughly $8.7 billion. While educators in New York City and throughout the state called the proposal, which is traditionally raised by the Legislature, too low, Mr. Dinkins said he was pleased Mr. Cuomo was trying to direct more education aid to the city. Under the Governor's proposal, almost half the increase in aid would go to the city's schools.
Mr. Cuomo today proposed only a vague plan to deal with the state's financial difficulties for the current fiscal year, which ends on March 31. The state's budget director, Dall W. Forsythe, has estimated that the state will end the year with a $700 million budget gap. To make up half that gap, Mr. Cuomo recommended using reserve funds and other existing resources. The rest he proposed to borrow by issuing short-term notes that the state would have to pay back within the year.
The Cuomo administration had projected a budget gap for the coming fiscal year of about $2 billion, and today the Governor put the figure even higher. He said he had closed the gap with almost $1 billion in new or increased taxes, $1 billion in nonrecurring or ''one shot'' revenues and several hundred million dollars in spending cuts.
 
Taxes on Businesses
Several of the new taxes Mr. Cuomo recommended would fall on businesses. One of those is a 2 percent tax on ''S corporations'' that have tried to save money by paying personal income taxes rather than corporate taxes. This tax would raise an estimated $175 million this year.
The tax on out-of-state telephone calls would also be borne heavily by corporations, and today business leaders began what promises to be a long campaign against the tax.
''We are deeply disturbed about an excise tax on telecommunications,'' said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry. ''Such a tax would seriously undermine New York City's position as a headquarters city and financial service center.''
As expected, the Governor's budget relies heavily on nonrecurring revenues. Those include revenues from state authority reserves that would be transferred to the state treasury and money that would be saved by refinancing some of the state's debt. Mr. Cuomo also proposed changing the way the state's contribution to its workers' pension fund is calculated to save $122 million this year.
Mr. Cuomo said using the one-shot revenues could be justified only if the Legislature goes along with his effort to suspend the last phase of the tax cut. Suspending the tax cut would, the Governor argued, provide enough recurring revenues later to make up for the ''one shots.''
Under the tax cut scheduled to go into effect in October, the state's highest income tax rate would drop to 7 percent from 7.5 percent, for an effective rate for the year of 7.375 percent. Mr. Cuomo proposed today that the income tax rate be frozen at the effective rate for 1989, which was 7.875 percent.

HEADLINE: Talks on Bank to Aid the East Bloc End in Dispute

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 16

 BODY:
An East-West meeting on establishing a development bank to help Eastern Europe's troubled economies ended today with some dispute over whether the bank's lending should be limited to only the private sector.
Officials said most of the 27 Western nations and 7 Eastern European nations represented at the two-day meeting agreed that the bank should have about $12 billion in capital and should channel most of its funds to Eastern Europe's private sector to assist that region in moving from Communism to market economies.
Nevertheless, Jacques Attali, the French official who chaired the meeting, said that many issues still remained to be resolved, even though he expressed the hope that the bank would be operating by the end of the year. Some officials said that goal was optimistic. 
Once established, the bank could administer the largest program of aid to Eastern Europe - surpassing the $5 billion committed to the region so far according to estimates -and become one of the largest regional assistance programs since the Marshall Plan. Private-Sector Loans Only? One of the most divisive issues to emerge at the meeting was whether the bank's loans should go only to the private sector or whether they should also be allowed to go to state-owned companies or to government infrastructure projects.
Participants in the meetings said the United States and Britian argued strenuously in favor of limiting the loans to the private sector. Some participants said they feared that if the money were made available to governments to improve roads and other infrastructure, almost all of the bank's money could end up being used that way.
But several Eastern European officials objected to limiting the loans to the private sector. ''It is not easy to go very quickly from an economy of state-owned enterprises to develop a private sector,'' said Joseph Tosovsky, chairman of Czechoslovakia's Central Bank. ''If the bank offers money only to private-sector companies, then we might be left out of it.''
''Other countries would like to promote entrepreneurship as well,'' he said. ''But they realize there are difficulties in promoting it.''
 
Moscow's Eligibility Debated
Mr. Attali, expressing the French position, suggested that money might go to state-owned companies in sectors where there was competition.
Finance ministry and foreign ministry officials at the meeting said the bank, expected to called the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Eastern Europe, would channel money to Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, East Germany, Rumania and Bulgaria. But there was considerable debate about whether the Soviet Union should be able to receive money from the bank.
Some participants said the United States had expressed reservations in informal meetings about Soviet membership and whether the Soviet Union should be able to receive loans from the bank. The European Community has offered a plan under which France, West Germany, Italy, Britain, the United States, Japan and the Soviet Union would each have an 8.5 percent stake in the bank, with the remaining shares distributed among other countries.
''There is a broad consensus that the Soviet Union should be allowed to join'' to help shape the bank's policies, said a Western European finance ministry official. But the official said there was far less consensus on whether the Soviet Union should be allowed to receive loans. Many participants have suggested allowing loans only to countries that have free elections and a multiparty system. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has opposed ending the Communist Party's dominant role in Soviet society.
 
Criteria for Borrowing
Mr. Attali, a senior aide to President Francois Mitterrand, said the participants hoped to sign the articles setting up the bank in Paris in March. He said that among the issues to be worked out were the total capitalization of the bank, what shares each of the 34 member countries would hold and where the bank would be based.
''There are no major difficulties in all this,'' Mr. Attali said. ''Everything has to be done to help these countries make the transition to a competitive economy and to develop their private sector.''
Mr. Attali said the representatives from the 34 nations had set up three working groups to resolve many of the issues under debate. Those groups are to meet in Paris on Jan. 30, and then hold a large drafting meeting in Paris March 10 and 11. Mr. Attali said he hoped the founding articles could be signed later in March.
He said the working groups would discuss the criteria for borrowing, such as whether undertaking economic revisions would be a condition. The groups are also to seek to resolve whether money would be loaned at market rates or below-market rates and where the bank should be situated.
Mr. Attali said that several nations had suggested capitalizing the bank at $18 billion, while others called for $6 billion. He said the majority supported capitalization of $12 billion, with the 34 nations paying in $3.6 billion for a reserve fund.
David E. Mulford, the United States Undersecretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, declined to discuss the meeting after it ended.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
State Dept. Endorses Dole's Call For More Flexibility in Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The State Department today endorsed a call by Senator Bob Dole to give the Administration greater flexibility in allocating foreign aid. But it stopped short of saying, as the Senate Republican leader did, that some money now designated for Israel, Egypt and other large aid recipients should be redirected to Eastern Europe and Panama.
''This is aimed at the system, not at any country,'' said Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman. ''We want to be able to conduct foreign policy with flexibility in order to be able to respond to new developments in the world.'' 
In an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times today, Mr. Dole wrote bluntly about the need to re-examine the strained foreign aid budget, in which Congress has earmarked more than two-thirds of $15 billion for five countries - Israel, Egypt, Turkey, Pakistan and the Philippines. Mr. Dole said this leaves little money for Eastern Europe and Panama or for Latin American countries fighting the war against drugs.
 
Discussed It With Baker
Miss Tutwiler said Mr. Dole had discussed his views with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and that department officials would be meeting soon to discuss the matter with the Congressional leadership.
At the White House, Marlin Fitzwater, the spokesman, said the Administration had long been concerned about limits imposed on Presidential flexibility through Congressional earmarking of money for specific programs. But Mr. Fitzwater said the Administration had not encouraged Mr. Dole to make his proposal and had ''some problems'' with Mr. Dole's suggestions.
Mr. Fitzwater sought in particular to avoid any suggestion that the Administration was considering cuts in aid to Israel or Egypt. ''I wouldn't want to comment on any specific country and their need,'' he said.
Assistance to Israel and Egypt makes up more than a third of the foreign aid budget and is a pillar of United States policy on the Middle East. The amounts - Israel gets $3 billion in military and economic aid and Egypt $2.1 billion - have been linked and virtually unchanged over the last five years.
 
Political Alarm Bells
Although Mr. Dole did not single out Israel and Egypt for cuts greater than the cuts for the three other countries, his comments touched off political alarm bells on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers in both parties regard Israel's foreign aid allotment as virtually sacrosanct. In comments to reporters today, Mr. Dole said his suggestion envisioned cuts in all Congressionally earmarked country programs, not just those of the ''big five'' countries.
Mr. Dole said that he met with President Bush at the White House today on another matter and that the President had told him he had read the Op-Ed article and ''appreciated it.''
Caught between limited resources and philanthropic instincts, Congress is preparing a re-examination of foreign aid programs, but most lawmakers are unwilling to deal with a choice as stark as the one Mr. Dole has presented.
''I think Mr. Dole deserves credit for putting his finger on the lack of resources, but his approach is only one way to get to the problem,'' said Representative Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East.
 
Other Approaches Suggested
Mr. Hamilton said other approaches would include shifts from the Pentagon budget or reductions in foreign military assistance for countries that have not yet spent their allocations. Another possibility, he said, was redesigning the current approach to debt relief.
Mr. Hamilton noted that Israel receives about $1.2 billion a year in economic aid, most of which is immediately used to repay the United States for past loans. ''I don't put that forward as a position to advocate, but to suggest that there are other ways,'' he said, adding that he expects Congress to support additonal money for both Eastern Europe and Panama this year.
While Mr. Hamilton said he would continue to support current levels of aid for Israel and other countries that receive large assistance, he and other lawmakers agreed that the major aid recipients would come under close scrutiny by Congress this year to justify their funding levels. Representative Vin Weber, a conservative Republican from Minnesota and a member of the House Appropriations Committee, said that if anything, the Israeli Government might be able to make a case for additional aid to cope with the huge influx of new Soviet and Eastern European immigrants.
Representative David Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, said a reshuffling of foreign aid as Mr. Dole has suggested would at best provide a one-year solution to the problem.
 
Figures Not Discussed
''It's a major undertaking that is going to need the sustained support of the American people,'' Mr. Obey said, ''and anybody who thinks you are going to get that support by telling the American people you are going to take it out of domestic spending is an absolute political idiot.''
At this point few lawmakers are willing to attach figures to the amount of aid required for Eastern Europe or Panama, let alone predict how much Congress can ultimately approve.
The American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the chief lobby for Israel on Capitol Hill, said in a statement today that while it shared Mr. Dole's concern about providing assistance to emerging democracies this should be done by increasing foreign aid over all.
''We believe it should not be at the expense of other vital U.S. policy objectives,'' the lobbying group said. ''We should not hurt our existing, vulnerable democratic allies in the process of helping potential democracies. Instead we should look toward strengthing the tools of diplomacy by increasing the foreign assistance account.''
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the Senate Armed Services Committee have scheduled a series of hearings shortly after Congress returns on Jan. 23 to examine the changing military and foreign aid needs in view of the reduced Soviet threat in Eastern Europe.

HEADLINE: Noriega's Party Wants a Role Again

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's Government may be history, but his civilian political party - at least part of it, anyway - is still around. In fact, four members of the party faithful emerged from seclusion today and announced that they had decided to become the loyal opposition.
The officials of the Democratic Revolutionary Party, who included Mario Rognoni, a former Noriega Commerce Minister, also used the occasion to put a great deal of discreet distance between themselves and General Noriega, who is in a Miami jail awaiting trial on drug-trafficking charges.
''Whatever the accusations against the general, that is a problem that has to be solved in the courts in the United States,'' said Mr. Rognoni, who was briefly detained by American troops in the first week of the invasion that toppled the Noriega Government last month. ''Yet that is his problem and that is a different situation.'' 
But, Mr. Rognoni added, ''we feel comfortable that he will come out innocent because most of the accusations against him are political.''
 
U.S. Troops Accused
''The challenge that we have now is to start our role in the new democracy without any armed forces ruling or advising us on political decisions,'' Mr. Rognoni said, standing in desolate, sweltering party offices that he and his colleagues said had been ransacked by American troops.
Mr. Rognoni, who appeared with the party's secretary general, Darisnel Espina, the second secretary, Pedro Pereira, and Ruben Dario Murgas, former head of the Government-run radio, also praised Panama's ''new democracy,'' declared himself and his colleagues to be utterly opposed to all forms of political persecution, conceded that the ruling party had made numerous mistakes that had alienated ''the masses,'' and dismissed the new Endara Government as a corrupt appendage of the Pentagon whose highest officials might yet find themselves formally charged with corruption.
''We have been looking at write-ups in the American press linking some officers of this Government to wrongdoing in different cases, including the laundering of money,'' Mr. Rognoni said. He was alluding to unconfirmed reports last week that a former law partner of President Guillermo Endara handled drug profits for clients and that a brother of Second Vice President Guillermo Ford was associated with a Miami accountant who laundered millions of dollars for the Medellin drug cartel.
 
'Not the Party of Crooks'
''We believe that when the Government of Panama goes in a true fashion after everybody who has done something wrong, they will have to jail more of their own people and more people from the independent ranks than people from the P.R.D.,'' Mr. Rognoni said, using the Spanish initials of the party, which was founded by General Noriega's predecessor, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera.
''That's because,'' he said, ''the P.R.D. in the majority of the cases were honest, come from middle and lower classes - and we were not involved in the wrongdong.
''In the end, the Panamanian people and the world will know the truth -that the P.R.D. is not the party of crooks or a party of violent people or anti-American people.''
The four officals asserted that the Endara Government bore main responsibility for the American invasion, which Mr. Espino said had resulted in unparalleled death and destruction as well as the looting of the party's offices.
 
U.S. Held Responsible
''The gringos came here and stole our computers, our files, everything, and removed all of it illegally from Panama,'' Mr. Espino said.
Mr. Rognoni added, ''We hold the U.S. responsible not only for the damage done by the invasion, but the damage done through the last two years with economic sanctions, with harassment, with pressure in the international finance centers.''
''We will accept the authority of the new Government the minute the United States armed forces leave Panama,'' Mr. Rognoni said. ''Right now, we believe that the Government is being run by the Southern Command and by the Pentagon.''
