HEADLINE: Colonel Held in Salvador Ordered Killings of Jesuits, Cristiani Says

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 16

 BODY:
President Alfredo Cristiani said today that a colonel arrested in the killing of six Jesuit priests had ordered the slayings and that two lieutenants had named him in their confessions.
The President said that United States-trained investigators had not found any evidence that more senior officers were involved in the killing or an attempted cover-up. He said he did not expect any more arrests in the case.
''I think most of it is covered,'' he said in an interview at the Presidential House, where he has been living since guerrillas attacked his private home at the start of an offensive in November. 
Asked if there was any evidence of a conspiracy that included others besides the colonel and seven other officers and soldiers arrested in the case, Mr. Cristiani said, ''Up until now there is no reason to believe anything had gone beyond what it is.''
 
An Appeal to the Rebels
In the 40-minute interview, President Cristiani noted the desperate economic crisis facing the country and repeated an appeal to the guerrillas to resume negotiations, which they broke off before launching the November offensive.
For the first time the President stated that the leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Fronts held the key to his ambitious economic restructuring program. A major goal of the guerrillas' November offensive was to force the rightist Government to concede that its success and El Salvador's future were tied to in large measure to them.
Asked whether the economy was clearly in deep trouble, he said, ''That's an understatement.''
''Obviously the F.M.L.N. violence is a factor in the economic recovery of the country,'' he said.
The interview, one of several he gave to American newspapers and television networks, seemed intended to improve El Salvador's image in anticipation of a debate in the United States Congress on aid to the country.
 
Ninth Suspect Sought
The President appeared more relaxed and confident than at any other time since the slaying of the Jesuits along with their housekeeper and her daughter on Nov. 16.
The interviews all expanded on Mr. Cristiani's announcement on Saturday of the arrest of the colonel, Guillermo Alfredo Benavides, three more junior officers and four soldiers for the Jesuit killings. The eight were turned over to judicial authorities today in preparation for their likely indictment before a civilian court. President Cristiani said a ninth suspect, a soldier, deserted last month and is being sought.
Colonel Benavides, the commander of El Salvador's military school, is the highest-ranking officer arrested for human rights abuses in the country's decade-long civil war, in which many abuses have been attributed to the armed forces and death squads linked to the military and the governing party.
Until today, President Cristiani had not described the role the colonel is accused of in the slaying of the Jesuits, who were prominent advocates of a negotiated solution to the civil war.
 
Motive Called Unclear
Referring to Colonel Benavides, President Cristiani said ''two lieutentants testified that they did receive the order from him,'' adding that a third lieutenant said he had been ordered by the colonel to accompany them.
President Cristiani said the motive for the killings remained unclear. He said he thought the killings stemmed from a feeling shared by many in the army that the Jesuits were helping the rebels.
''These guys could have felt that they were part of the offensive,'' he said in suggesting the killers' motive.
Mr. Cristiani's view contrasted with that of diplomats and human rights monitors, who contend that the priests were killed by right-wing extremists eager to destabilize the eight-month-old Cristiani administration. Some of those also dispute Mr. Cristiani's assertion of where the orders originated, contending that they had to come from someone higher than any of those arrested. They note that Colonel Benavides has not been previously linked to human rights abuses and that he was not known to be prominent among the army's extremists.
''Benavides is the scapegoat,'' said a Latin American diplomat. ''He's the one whose taking responsibility. But there was a top man who knew about it and ordered it.''
 
A 'Historic' Precedent
In the interview, President Cristiani seemed to leave open the possibility that others could have been involved or aware of the killings but suggested that the interrogation of Colonel Benavides had provided no leads. ''Maybe he did talk to other people, but he's denying everything,'' the President said.
But President Cristiani said this should not overshadow what some here are calling the historic precedent set by the arrest of Colonel Benavides. The President said he thought it would begin to show the military, long a state within a state, that its traditional immunity from prosecution has begun to end.
''Obviously you cannot change things from one day to the other,'' he said. ''So it's a matter of pushing on the one hand, but also accepting that this is a process and that new possibilities will arise in the future.''
President Cristiani said he had received support for the decision to prosecute the Colonel Benavides from the high command, most of whom are classmates of the colonel. In the past, the officers have steadfastly defended each other from all accusations.
''We think the high-ranking officers understand why this has to be done,'' he said. ''They understand that the law is above any person and that nobody will be above the law.''
Mr. Cristiani acknowledged some concern about the reaction of junior officers, especially in the Atlacatl Battalion, the crack unit to which most of the arrested soldiers belong. ''I'm sure there's a lot of anxiety there,'' he said. ''Anything like this will create some expectations, some anxiety.''
But he said he had no sense that there was enough dissatifaction to provoke a coup.

HEADLINE: Robert Campeau's Special Genius

 BODY:
Any corporate executive can figure out how to file for bankruptcy when the bottom drops out of the business. It took the special genius of Robert Campeau, chairman of the Campeau Corporation, to figure out how to bankrupt more than 250 profitable department stores. The dramatic jolt to Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, Jordan Marsh and the other proud stores reflects his overreaching grasp and oversized ego. 
But the importance of this spectacle to the public is easily exaggerated. A few customers might be inconvenienced. Some suppliers will be hurt, probably only temporarily. Otherwise, the big losers are investors, grown-ups, who loaned money to Mr. Campeau with full recognition of the risks. The rest of the public has little at stake.
The Campeau Corporation racked up more than $7 billion of debt buying up hundreds of department stores. It overpaid. The stores' profits cannot cover the interest payments on the mammoth debt. Mr. Campeau's creditors demanded relief. Bankruptcy does not mean closing the stores. They are, by contrast with other retailers that have recently folded, well run and profitable. They will remain open, but under court supervision until the creditors sort out the losses. In all likelihood, stores like Bloomingdale's will be sold. The new owners might lay off workers and alter policies. But if cutbacks occur, it is because they make sense and would have happened anyway. The valuable parts of the fallen empire will survive, with or without Mr. Campeau.
The grotesque Campeau failure has crystallized criticism of leveraged buyouts - the purchase of entire companies with borrowed money. Such sweeping indictments are premature. Research shows that L.B.O.'s in the early 1980's probably increased productivity, helping the economy. Managers operating under enormous debt worked hard to cut costs. Preliminary evidence from the late 80's is less encouraging. Recent L.B.O.'s benefited the target companies' shareholders, who received high takeover prices. But most of these gains seem to have come at the expense of bondholders, creditors and employees.
Whatever the final verdict on L.B.O.'s, the Campeau fiasco does highlight an important flaw in the corporate tax code. It is cheaper for businesses to borrow money than to raise it by issuing stock. This advantage encourages plungers like Mr. Campeau to buy healthy companies with borrowed money even if the reorganization doesn't add a dime to the nation's output of goods and services. As a plunger winds up paying less tax, the rest of the nation pays more.
The Bush Administration is well aware of this tax bias and is working on corrections. There are possible solutions, but they will cause tax revenues to fall and, thereby, the Federal deficit to rise. Unless it is willing to propose offsetting tax hikes, the Treasury will be unable to solve the problem.
L.B.O.'s are risky. That means some will succeed; many will fail. The Campeau failure, no matter how spectacular, does not prove that the bad outweighs the good. There will be some innocent victims, but the overwhelming losses will be borne by people who knew what they were getting into. If the nation can stop subsidizing such speculation with tax breaks, there will be little reason for the typical shopper, or voter, to feel any real concern.

HEADLINE: Mr. Dole Milks a Miniature Cow

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole has never been shy about sounding a clanging alarm in the middle of policy debate. He did so again on the Op-Ed page yesterday. Mr. Dole urged that foreign aid funds be shifted from favored clients like Israel and Egypt to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, and to other countries where freedom has ''suddenly and dramatically blossomed.''
Mr. Dole's idea, which found cautious approval in the State Department and raised hackles among friends of Israel, is sure to provoke controversy. He is quite right to say that duty and self-interest oblige America to help people struggling to eradicate tyranny, whether in Poland or Panama. He's also right that there's nothing sacrosanct about the present foreign aid list. 
It's the next part of Mr. Dole's argument that fails: He suggests that the money can only be found in the foreign aid budget. Foreign aid accounts for less than $15 billion of total Federal spending of $1 trillion plus. Mr. Dole is right to want to nourish new democracies, but why does he limit himself to such a tiny cow?
The Senator's response is that there is no ''new'' money. The budget is already hemmed in by massive deficits. Further, he says, Eastern Europe can't wait for a ''peace dividend'' that may never materialize. He thus asks President Bush to make modest reallocations in foreign aid already appropriated and asks Congress to take a careful, across-the-board look at requests for next year - especially for the big five: Israel, Egypt, the Philippines, Turkey and Pakistan.
Mr. Dole doesn't differentiate among the needs of the five countries, but that will surely be necessary. Egypt's requirements, for example, may have diminished now that Cairo is no longer isolated in the Arab world. President Cory Aquino of the Philippines might make a case for even more aid to fight the guerrillas and sustain her economy.
The question of Israel is the trickiest, diplomatically and politically. Israel receives $3 billion, more than a fifth of all foreign aid. Would reduced aid speed the Middle East peace talks? Mr. Dole and others in Congress are fed up with Prime Minister Shamir's glacial pace. But reducing aid could cause Mr. Shamir to dig in his heels and rally Israelis behind him.
These tactical considerations aside, the fundamental flaw with Mr. Dole's plan is that it aims too low. The reduced Soviet threat and slowdown in nuclear modernization provide compelling opportunities for prompt savings. A few military exercises canceled, a few procurements deferred - pretty soon, as Everett Dirksen once said, you're talking about real money. Enough, surely, to make a difference in the places where Mr. Dole rightly wants to make a difference.

HEADLINE: The Reagan Boom - Greatest Ever

BYLINE: By Martin Anderson; Martin Anderson, a senior fellow of the Hoover Institution, at Stanford University, was an adviser to Ronald Reagan.

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Almost everyone knows that the greatest depression the U.S. ever had was in the 1930's. It was known as the Great Depression, and its infamy merits a separate section in economics textbooks. But what was its counterpart? When did our greatest economic expansion occur?
We just had it. And it is still expanding, setting new records with each passing month. 
We don't know whether historians will call it the Great Expansion of the 1980's or Reagan's Great Expansion, but we do know from official economic statistics that the seven year period from 1982 to 1989 was the greatest, consistent burst of economic activity ever seen in the U.S. In fact, it was the greatest economic expansion the world has ever seen - in any country, at any time.
The two key measures that mark a depression or expansion are jobs and production. Let's look at the records that were set. Creation of jobs. From November 1982, when President Ronald Reagan's new economic program was beginning to take effect, to November 1989, 18.7 million new jobs were created. It was a world record: Never before had so many jobs been created during a comparable time period. The new jobs covered the entire spectrum of work, and more than half of them paid more than $20,000 a year. As total employment grew to 119.5 million, the rate of unemployment fell to slightly over 5 percent, the lowest level in 15 years. Creation of wealth.
The amount of wealth produced during this seven year period was stupendous - some $30 trillion worth of goods and services. Again, it was a world record. Never before had so much wealth been produced during a comparable period. According to a recent study, net asset values - including stocks, bonds and real estate - went up by more than $5 trillion between 1982 and 1989, an increase of roughly 50 percent.
There are other important measures. Steady economic growth. As we begin the decade of the 1990's, we are in our 86th straight month of economic growth - a new record for peacetime, five months longer than the wartime growth of World War II and only 23 months short of the wartime record set during the Vietnam War in the 1960's. Most experts now predict that it will last right through 1990, and perhaps beyond.
Income tax rates, interest rates and inflation.
Under President Reagan, top personal income tax rates were lowered dramatically, from 70 percent to 28 percent. This policy change was the prime force behind the record breaking economic expansion. Interest rates and inflation also fell sharply and, so far, have stayed comfortably low - a further indication of the power and pervasiveness of Mr. Reagan's economic policies. The stock market. Perhaps the key indicator of an economy's booms and busts is the stock market, the bottom line economic report card. And here the record has been striking. During the period from 1970 to 1982, the stock market barely moved. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks inched up about 35 percent during that entire period. But starting in late 1982, just as Reaganomics began to work, the stock market took off like a giant skyrocket. Since then, the Standard & Poor's index has soared, reaching a record high of 360, almost triple what it was in 1982.
There were other consequences of the expansion. Annual Federal spending on public housing and welfare, and on Social Security, Medicare and health all increased by billions of dollars. The poverty rate has fallen steadily since 1983.
When you add up the record of the Reagan years, and the first year of President Bush - during which he has faithfully continued Mr. Reagan's economic policies - the conclusion is clear, inescapable and stunning. We have just witnessed America's Great Expansion.
The Reagan economic expansion was not perfect and we will never have one that is. The Federal budget deficits were too high and still are, too many Federal regulations lay unreformed and the trade deficit is worrisome.
In fact, the Reagan expansion may not have been the best economic expansion in history, for every economic expansion must be judged by many criteria. But if we look at the sheer size and immensity of it, at its scope and power, then it cannot be denied that it was the greatest.
The full impact of the powerful economic recovery that President Reagan launched during the 1980s is still unfolding.
Mr. Reagan's expansion provided the financial resources to allow the U.S. to build up the combat capability of its defense forces and to begin blazing the new trail for a protective missile system. This, in turn, convinced the Soviet rulers they could never defeat the U.S., and today the Soviet Union and the U.S. are busily engaged in nuclear disarmament as peace breaks out in country after country throughout the world.
Equally important, it proved beyond doubt to all (except perhaps for a handful of left-wing faculty members in our best universities) that capitalism is superior to Socialism and Communism. Our economy is the guiding beacon for all those countries that are ripping apart the ruthless collectivist regimes that ruined the lives of their people for so long.
One thing the Marxists got right: Economics is a powerful determining factor of history. But Marxists never dreamed it would be the economics of Ronald Reagan and all those capitalists that would prevail in the end.

HEADLINE: New York Region and the Budget: School-Aid Proposal Is Big Change

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Like most aspects of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget, the line items that most affect New York City and its suburbs are what Assembly Speaker Mel Miller called ho-hum - neither greatly enhanced nor greatly diminished from last year's appropriations.
Under Mr. Cuomo's budget, the state's discretionary revenue sharing with local governments would stay static at just under $1 billion for the fourth consecutive year. Although New York City would receive $535 million of that amount, as it did in the current fiscal year, the money would provide Mayor David N. Dinkins with little relief for the city's budget deficit.
Local governments in Westchester and on Long Island can expect scant increases in a number of programs important to those areas. For instance, the Governor proposed no increase in local highway assistance, a $24 million cut in aid for sewage operation and maintenance and a $5.4 million cut in grants to arts and cultural organizations. 
The city would seem to benefit, however, from a proposed change in the state's school aid formula and from increased funds for Medicaid, foster care, AIDS and welfare programs.
The new school financing formula, proposed last year by a state task force known as the Salerno Commission, would compensate schools for the higher cost of education in the city, would direct aid to schools with high populations of at-risk students and would begin to base state money partly on student enrollment. Currently, student attendance is the primary criterion in spending for schools, and the New York City system has suffered because of its truancy problem. The new formula is subject to legislative approval.
 
Battle Along Geographic Lines
While the school aid formula would benefit the city's schools, it would cost school systems in suburban areas like Long Island and Westchester County, where attendance usually is high and enrollment is declining in some communities.
That difference sets the scene for a political battle along geographic lines, Members of both the Democratic-controlled Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate, as well as educators in both city and suburban school systems, predicted that the new formula would face problems unless money can be found to wipe out the losses that would be realized by suburban schools.
''I think the Governor is trying to inject the Salerno formula into state aid in a way that favors New York City, and I think we have to take a look at that,'' said the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I.
Mr. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, said that to make the new formula successful, ''What you really need is a year of a lot of money because you can't rob Peter to pay Paul.'' He added, ''It doesn't work in a political system.''
 
Lack of New Money
Nobody in Albany would mistake fiscal 1991 as a year of a lot of money. The increase in education aid proposed by Mr. Cuomo is $240 million in a total education budget of $8.7 billion, or 2.8 percent. Under the new formula, New York City would receive $116 million, or 48 percent, of the increase.
City officials, who have long complained that New York City schools do not get their fair share of the state's education dollar, tempered their enthusiasm for the formula by expressing disappointment at the lack of new money in the budget.
''Given that an increase of only $240 million is too low to meet anyone's needs,'' said the city's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, ''what is significant is his recommendation that close to 50 percent go to New York City, a major improvement over last year, when the Governor proposed that the city school system receive only about a third of the state aid-to-education increase.''
 
Dinkins Sees Causes for Concern
Although Mr. Dinkins said it appeared that the increase in the city's share of the state budget would be less than the rate of inflation, he said the impact on the city was not so bad as it could have been. But Mr. Dinkins, who is expected to testify before a joint meeting of the Assembly and Senate budget committees on Feb. 6., said he would lobby for more aid.
Mr. Dinkins said at a news conference at City Hall that he and his advisers need more time to study the Governor's budget but that he spotted several causes for concern during his first review of the document.
He questioned whether the Governor's proposed efforts at Medicaid cost control, which the state estimates will save the city $115 million, would simply increase the burden on public hospitals operated by the city. And he questioned Mr. Cuomo's proposal that the city assume the more than $20 million cost of financing associate degree programs at John Jay College and New York City Technical College, both units of the City University of New York.
Other proposals in Mr. Cuomo's budget pose what Mr. Miller called ''a two-edged sword'' for the city. By increasing state appropriations for a variety of Medicaid reimbursements, foster care and welfare initiatives, Mr. Cuomo would fatten programs with large constituencies in New York City. But he also would increase the short-term burden on the city budget, which must match state and Federal contributions to those programs by mandatory formulas.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
About Education

BYLINE: By Fred M. Hechinger

 BODY:
Education research too often ignores the people it claims to serve -the children and teachers. So says J. Myron Atkin, a professor of education and teacher of science at Stanford University, where he was dean of the Graduate School of Education from 1979 to 1986.
When teachers are denied major roles in research, he writes in Phi Delta Kappan magazine, they ''are taught, once again, that worthwhile innovation comes from outside the schools.'' Professor Atkin complains that scholarship about education often does not realize that ''certain knowledge is available only to people who work within a system and try to change it.'' 
''Not much progress in education is likely to take place unless teachers become agents in the improvement of their own practice,'' he contends in the November issue of the magazine. What is frequently lacking, he finds, is a setting in which teachers can regularly exchange ideas.
''Teachers are at best peripheral to the conduct of educational research,'' he says, and as a result, many teachers and principals are convinced that ''educational research is irrelevant, wrong-headed, or both.''
Of course, he adds, research is essential. Teachers need new knowledge to cope with tough problems. He cites examples: teachers want to know how students can learn better, how children can teach other children, how educational progress can best be judged, and how various subjects relate to one another.
But, Professor Atkin says, because many researchers have never taught elementary and high school students, they tend to view schools as places to test their theories. He calls for a better balance between theory and practice.
Elaborating on his ideas in a telephone interview, he said that unless teachers are given a more active role in educational research, the ''message to them is that they are merely supposed to implement what other people have devised.''
On the bright side, he said, he sees a trend toward case studies written by teachers, which could become ''springboards for further research.''
Professor Atkin's background qualifies him as an informed critic. Born in New York, he graduated from City College with a major in chemistry and did graduate work in science education at New York University. He taught elementary and high school science in Great Neck, L.I., and was a teacher and administrator at the University of Illinois for 24 years before moving to Stanford.
Together with Donald Kennedy, the university's president, he began the study of Stanford and the schools, now called the Stanford/schools collaborative, which brought university faculty and researchers together with teachers and administrators in six surrounding school districts. He recently published a book, ''Improving Science Education through Local Alliances,'' based on a study of ties between schools and industries, universities, science museums, government libraries and the armed forces. The study is financed by the Carnegie Corporation of New York.
Professor Atkin says that assigning a passive role to teachers while others determine what should be researched is particularly damaging when school reforms are supposed to give teachers greater power and responsibility over what and how they teach.
Currently, he says, research findings, and therefore proposals for change, come primarily from people outside the schools - university-based experts in sociology, psychology, anthropology and economics.
Why? Largely, Professor Atkin believes, because schools of education think this boosts scholarly image.
He does not exclude his own university from such criticism. ''That's how Stanford's school of education made its fame,'' he said. As an example of a trend that began in the 1960's, he recalls that Stanford, like many other major universities, ''dropped its programs in science and mathematics education (for teachers) altogether so that the institution could hire political scientists, economists, and sociologists.''
Many of them, he said, are first-rate scholars, but ''they don't see the day-to-day problems of the teachers.''
In recent years, Professor Atkin found some encouraging attempts to bridge the gap between researchers and practitioners. ''Because some professors wanted their ideas to have greater impact, they began to work more closely with teachers and to spend longer periods of time in schools,'' he found. They realize that ''the teacher seems to be helping to market the professor's ideas.''
Professor Atkin expects some fundamental changes. The unions and subject-oriented professional groups like the National Council of Teachers of English and similar groups in mathematics and science are using their power to give teachers a place on the research front. This, he says, is crucial because unless teachers play a greater role in identifying the obstacles to progress, school reform will not gain momentum.

LENGTH: 1328 words

HEADLINE: For Every Five Young Women, Six Young Men

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
SOCIAL myth: There are not enough young men for all the young women looking for boyfriends or husbands.
Social reality: Single men in their 20's outnumber single women of the same age by more than a 6-to-5 ratio. For an entire generation born after the baby boom's peak in 1957, it is the men, not the women, who face a shortage of spouses.
From Greenwich Village nightclubs to Malibu beaches, women in their early and mid-20's repeat a common refrain: too few men and too many rivals for their affections. But on softball fields and in bars from New York to California, young men sound a different tune: not enough women and too much competition from older, more affluent men. The numbers say the young men may have a point. The Census Bureau estimates there are about 2.3 million more unmarried men in their 20's than women the same age in the United States. Altogether there are about 19.9 million men and 20.4 million women, although some sociologists believe that the Census Bureau misses many single young men because they move frequently. 
The end of the baby boom has shifted the odds even further in favor of young women, because bridegrooms are typically older than their brides. Since the number of births in the United States fell by an average of 1.7 percent a year from 1957 to 1975 - from 4.3 million to 3.1 million - the men born in any given year outnumber women born in most of the following years, so that younger women are in even shorter supply.
The result is frustration for many young men. ''Sometimes I'm lonely,'' said a 27-year-old associate at a major New York law firm who has been searching for a girlfriend for the last two and a half years and who, like other young men interviewed, asked not to be identified.
''We are competing against these 30- and 40-year-olds,'' complained a 25-year-old Washington lawyer, adding that a 31-year-old man had recently taken an unwanted interest in his girlfriend.
Some young women are unconvinced by such hard-luck stories. ''It depends on what you're looking for, but I think there's a shortage of men,'' said Risa Zaitschek, a 24-year-old graphics designer in Manhattan, who nonetheless has a boyfriend.
The strong tendency toward relationships between an older man and a younger woman presents young single men and older single women with a common problem. Demographers have written volumes on the shortage of boyfriends and husbands for single women over the age of 30. The less studied mirror image of this problem is the plight of the man in his early or mid-20's.
Although instances of men who marry older women have increased, a survey in 1985 by the National Center for Health Statistics found the bridegroom was older in two-thirds of all marriages. The average age difference was 5.3 years. ''Men in their 20's simply may not have many women available who are younger,'' said William Beer, the deputy chairman of the sociology department at Brooklyn College. ''Older men are poaching.''
A 1988 survey by the Census Bureau estimated that among Americans 20 to 29 years old, there were 122 single men for every 100 single women. The ratio reflects both a trend among men to postpone marriage until their early 30's and the many women in their 20's who marry men over the age of 29.
Among men and women in their 20's who have never married, the ratio increases to 130 to 100, because more young women than men are divorced or widowed.
Up-to-date information on the ratios in specific cities will not be available until after the 1990 census.
Graduating college seniors go from being the oldest readily available men for most college women to being the youngest and usually least affluent members of the working world. ''It's definitely something I think about,'' said Andrew A. Coburn, a senior at Macalester College in St. Paul. ''It's really a scary prospect as far as, I guess, in today's world, the material aspect: today I have nothing.''
On the other hand, some women are weary of dating men their own age by the time they leave college.
''The older men that I have met have done so much after college, have done so much that I haven't done,'' said Martha Catherine Dagenhart, a senior at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, who expressed an interest in meeting a ''sophisticated 26- or 27-year-old'' after graduation.
Bonnie L. Zweiback, a 23-year-old marketing assistant at a software development company in Roslyn, L.I., has been dating a 30-year-old man for a year and said she prefers older men: ''I just think they seem a little more mature, and they seem to know more about where they are going. Most of the guys my own age I've dated don't have a clue.''
Some women in their 20's may date and marry much older men because they cannot find suitable men their own age, said Mark R. Rank, a sociologist at Washington University in St. Louis. Under the ''social exchange'' theory now popular among some psychologists and sociologists, he said, relationships tend to form between men and women of roughly equal overall combinations of beauty, charisma, influence, intelligence, wealth and other resources.
''Someone who is extremely attractive in their 20's may be exchanging those good looks with someone in their 40's who has power, money,'' Dr. Rank said.
Some young men are too picky to find a companion or wife even if the ratio of the sexes were more favorable, said Dr. Samuel Pauker, a clinical instructor in psychiatry at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center who counsels young men and women.
''I'm not willing to settle right now'' for the wrong woman, said the 27-year-old New York lawyer who has been looking for a girlfriend for two and a half years. ''I think it's important not to lower your standards.''
Shortages of eligible women have been rare in American history and elsewhere. With the fairly brief exception of wars, the number of babies born each year in the United States tended to increase from Colonial times until 1957.
Sociologists disagree on the implications of the shifting ratio of men to women. Because most surveys on marital status and attitudes about marriage pose questions to women, reliable data on men are not available for serious studies, said Neil G. Bennett, a professor of sociology at Yale University.
In countries where immigration, war or even female infanticide have resulted in more men than women, the outcome for women has tended to be ''higher marriage rates, higher fertility rates, lower rates of labor-force participation, lower levels of education and lower rates of divorce,'' said Scott J. South, an associate professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Albany. But he added that international trends may not be a good guide for any specific country, the United States included, because of cultural differences.
Several issues in addition to the baby boom can influence the availability of single women in the United States, although their cumulative effect is difficult to gauge. Young women are thought by sociologists to be more likely to have affairs with older, married men than young men are to have affairs with older, married women. Slightly more unmarried men than unmarried women legally immigrate to the United States; the difference was 20,000 men last year. And underestimates of young men by the Census Bureau may mean that the true ratio is even higher.
On the other hand, some research has suggested that homosexuality is more common among men than women, but estimates vary and no consensus exists. And the Department of Defense estimates it has 200,000 more unmarried men than unmarried women stationed overseas.
Yet the situation of single older women who wish to marry remains more serious than the plight of young men, who grow out of their disadvantageous position in romance as they mature and as their fortunes improve. ''It's not a problem - it goes away,'' said a 25-year-old economist in Philadelphia. ''You get your flashy car.''

PUB-DATE: January 17, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 5; Living Desk

LENGTH: 1594 words

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
RESTAURATEURS across the country have seen the future and it is cheap. Or at least less expensive. While the best restaurants with opulent appointments, large staffs and high-priced food will always have their place, many have seen customers move on to less expensive food and more casual surroundings. The restaurateurs' response has been to extend their empires with restaurants where the tab is often half what it is in the parent establishment.
In New York, David Liederman, the owner of Chez Louis, where the average check is $40, is opening Broadway Grill, where the average check will be $26. In San Francisco, Stars sells its entrees for $18 to $20 while at its offspring, Stars Cafe, around the corner, the entrees average $9. The average check at Routh Street Cafe in Dallas is $75, while at Baby Routh it is less than half that.
The National Restaurant Association reports that business is generally flat and that growth is in cheaper, less formal restaurants. 
''The casualization of the American restaurant is the most important trend that is happening,'' said Jeff Prince, the senior director of the trade association in Washington, ''and it is going to change the nature of the restaurant business as we move into the 90's. Price is a very important part.''
A restaurateur was more blunt. ''I think it is 100 percent a price issue,'' said Mr. Liederman, who also owns David's Cookies and has owned Chez Louis since 1986. ''You can dance around and say that you want to do different kinds of cuisines and want to play around with how the food looks on the plate, but I think it all comes back to price.''
To get prices down and volume up, the newer restaurants rely on more informal service, fewer waiters, less costly ingredients, volume purchasing, simpler menus, smaller portions, cheaper locations and more seats.
''Volume is what cures all ills,'' said Drew Nierporent, the owner of the highly acclaimed Montrachet in New York and an operating partner with Robert De Niro in the new TriBeCa Grill. ''If you are guaranteed a certain volume you can lower your prices.''
''Right now there is a casual life style - casual dress, casual atmosphere - and restaurants are responding to this, '' said Jan Weimer, a food consultant and freelance writer in Los Angeles. ''Beyond that, the restaurants are also responding to consumers' ongoing strike against the extraordinary expense of food. After a while there has been a bit of a rebellion on the part of the public to $100 for a plate of pasta and a salad.''
The public that is driving this downscaling or ''casualization'' of restaurants is primarily the baby boomers who were in their 20's and 30's in the 80's.
''The truth of the matter is that new money always spends freely,'' said Clark Wolf, a restaurant consultant. ''In the 80's there was a lot of new, fast money and now they are getting married, having children and looking for a job. In that order.
''We don't feel rich anymore,'' Mr. Wolf, who is 38 years old, continued. ''The 'Y' word is a dirty word. Being rich and powerful gets you four years in jail. Gordon Gekko was wrong,'' a reference to the antihero of the movie ''Wall Street.''
Pretension is unseemly. ''People want more casual food,'' Mr. Wolf said. ''They know food better and are less experimental. The 80's was a period of adolescence in food and now we've grown up a little bit and can be less pretentious.''
The bursting of the bubble took the restaurant industry by surprise. ''In 1985 we assumed it would go on well into the 90's,'' Mr. Prince said. ''One would think that when the baby boomers entered their prime wage-earning period they would want even more, but other things changed. The market changed; values changed and lately begotten families arrived.''
The owners of expensive and moderately expensive restaurants all over the country are taking this message to heart. Even those who say they are as busy as they ever were are branching out into bistros, trattorias, diners and fast-food chains.
Keith Famie, who owns Les Auteurs, a bistro in suburban Detroit, where entrees are $16 to $21, is opening Famie's Chicken, which he hopes will become a fast-food chain where the average check will be $3 to $5 for chicken, salad and a roll. Mr. Famie said he sees ''the handwriting on the wall: Americans want to eat healthier and cheaper.''
In San Francisco, Jeremiah Tower added Stars Cafe in 1988 to the building where he has operated the very popular Stars Restaurant since 1984. The average main course in the cafe is $9; in the restaurant it is $18 to $20. The cafe food is simpler, more rustic. There is also less of it.
''Deep in the heart of everyone,'' Mr. Tower said, ''there is an endearing love for bistro food, meaning uncomplicated. In this country that sort of presentation and food are equated with reasonable prices.''
When Roberto Donna opened I Matti, a trattoria in Washington, late last year, it filled up immediately, with many customers coming twice a week. For $20 they can go away happy and full. The regulars at Mr. Donna's older and highly acclaimed restaurant, Galileo, seldom come more than once a week and when they do it costs them $40 without wine, tax or tip. ''The last decade,'' Mr. Donna said, ''prices went up, up, up and no one thought about opening up a moderately priced restaurant.''
Inexpensive, however, is relative. Not all of the of the new lower-priced offspring are cheap by anyone's standards. Pazzia, a baby sister to Rex Il Ristorante, the most expensive restaurant in Los Angeles, offers a meal for $35 to $40, instead of $65, the price for the food alone at Rex. ''The time is past,'' said Mauro Vincenti, the owner, ''when six people came in here every Friday and spent $2,000 to $6,000 for wine.''
The restaurants are responding, not only with lower prices, fewer waiters in dinner jackets and more in aprons, but with booster seats andreal children's menus.
''I have a son who is 2, and it's a nightmare trying to find a decent restaurant to go to with a child,'' said Jean-Louis Gerin, the owner of the expensive Restaurant Jean-Louis in Greenwich, Conn., and now also the manager and consultant for his in-laws' much less expensive restaurant, Rene Chardain in South Salem, N.Y. ''On Sunday in Chardain there are many children,'' he said, ''and prices are a little less than in Greenwich because we want to be a little more family-oriented.''
Downscaling is taking many forms. There is, as Mr. Liederman of Chez Louis and the Broadway Grill said, ''more than one way to skin the price cat.'' Some restaurants are lowering prices, even changing their names. Yesterday Melrose, in Greenwich Village, became Barrow Street Bistro and lowered its prices. ''The days of spending $50 at a casual little restaurant in the Village with paper on the tables is over,'' said Lee Friedman, the owner of Barrow Street Bistro. His former partner and chef, Richard Krause, has left to open an even less expensive restaurant called Rose Cafe in the Village.
Others are offering early-bird specials.At Chez Louis there is a $14.95 prix-fixe dinner for customers who are seated by 6:30 P.M. ''To be brutally honest,'' Mr. Liederman said, ''I never would have thought about doing this 18 months ago. There was not that kind of pressure on restaurants to evaluate their pricing.''
All of the cheaper offspring are using less expensive ingredients. ''There are no gigantic veal chops and lobster at Broadway Grill,'' Mr. Liederman said. ''There's a lot more sausage, whole things roasting on the open rotisserie - lamb, chickens, pigs - making them more economical than Chez Louis.''
At Famie's Chicken, iceburg lettuce will be served instead of the radicchio, frisee and mache at Les Auteurs. To keep prices lower at Pazzia, Mr. Vincenti said he buys only California ingredients. ''At Rex we buy from all over the world and never ask how much it is but, 'Is this the best there is?' '' he said.
Simpler food and smaller menus require fewer people in the kitchen and less experienced, therefore less costly, help. There is a staff of 24 in the kitchen at Rex, feeding 90 people; Pazzia has 14 feeding 100 people.
Stephan Pyles, a co-owner of Routh Street Cafe and Baby Routh in Dallas, describes the fare at the latter as less refined, with meats like veal shanks instead of choice cuts.
In some restaurants, like Wollensky's Grill, an outgrowth of Smith and Wollensky in New York, the portions are smaller. ''We had a feeling that a lot of customers didn't want to eat a 16-ounce steak and a full bottle of wine,'' said Alan Stillman, the owner. ''They wanted a 12-ounce steak and a half-bottle of wine.''
At his new restaurants, La Cite and Grill de la Cite, the items may be served with less expensive ingredients. At La Cite, codfish with morel sauce and potato puree is $19 and at the grill, codfish Provencal-style with tomatoes and garlic is $16.75. The grill charges $16.50 for the same roast chicken that brings $19.50 in the restaurant. The grill can charge less because turnover is faster and volume greater, Mr. Stillman said. ''People eat less and eat faster in a casual atmosphere,'' he added. ''In a more upscale atmosphere they linger longer and drink more wine.''
What people are looking for now in all price ranges is value for money.
''How much money do you want to pay for a grilled chicken breast?'' said Mr. Tower of Stars in San Francisco, referring to some of the astronomical prices in New York's restaurant heyday. ''I don't care how rich you are. $28? Excuse me.''

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Why Liberals and Their Beliefs Will Rise Again

BYLINE: By Herbert Mitgang

 BODY:

The Resurgent Liberal (And Other Unfashionable Prophecies)
By Robert B. Reich
303 pages. Times Books. $19.95.
The ''L-word'' - liberal - may be coming out of the political closet after being maligned by the Republicans and mothballed by the Democrats during the 1988 Presidential campaign. A winding down of the cold war has raised hopes of a domestic ''peace dividend'' that would benefit people in need of a bigger piece of the American promise. Robert B. Reich, a former director for policy planning for the Federal Trade Commission who now teaches at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, thinks that liberalism will soon be in the ascendancy again but, in the subtitle of ''The Resurgent Liberal,'' admits that his prophecy is unfashionable. 
Of course, nearly everyone has a different definition of political liberalism; that is, about the extent to which government is supposed to play a role in shaping life, liberty and the pursuit of a better living standard. Labels aren't always accurate for minor or major parties, in the United States or Europe. Parties calling themselves Liberal have different agendas and aren't necessarily on the left; the Liberal Party in Italy, for example, is a rather conservative party that draws most of its support from the Italian business community. Something about the claim of liberalism causes ridicule. In his 1834 satire ''The Infernal Marriage,'' Benjamin Disraeli said he considered it a great homage to public opinion that every scoundrel professed to be a liberal.
In ''The Resurgent Liberal'' - a mixed bag of popular and scholarly essays that advocates mild economic activism and government regulation - Professor Reich explains how liberals are viewed in the public mind today:
''The prevailing liberal public philosophy rests on notions of altruism and conciliation. The parable is that of wise and generous parents who skillfully accommodate the conflicting demands of their children, help their poorer cousins, and seek reconciliation with wayward relations. The modern liberal hero is a combination of Jesus and Robert Young in 'Father Knows Best.' ''
This rather far-fetched explanation wouldn't place the author in the company of the great liberal reformers of the 20th century in the United States: the New Dealers around President Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 1930's. But then he goes on to say that his parable is too simplistic. He points out that popular wisdom now teaches that the welfare system doesn't reduce poverty; that full-employment budgets cause inflation and that charity and conciliation are worthy goals in our personal lives but cannot be national policy.
''The Resurgent Liberal'' covers a good deal of ground in short bursts. The author writes about the rise of the paper economy, ''the substitution of paper for product in American managers' hearts and minds.'' He discusses the ''incapacity of the economy to generate new wealth, due in part to the failure to invest in, and give meaningful voice and responsibility to, the American work force.'' He mentions ''economic nationalism'' - the political contest with the Soviet Union and the economic contest with Japan. The final essays in the book are on American politics, social trends and political thought. In this respect, the author, sounding as if the aim of his resurgent liberalism is to win elections, writes:
''It is with some personal anguish that I confess to my closest friends (and now, dear reader, to you) that I spent six months of my life advising Michael Dukakis in his dispiriting run for the Presidency.'' He notes that Governor Dukakis failed to respond forcefully to assertions that he was a liberal and card-carrying member of the American Civil Liberties Union. ''At first, he told the American people that he, rather than George, was the real conservative,'' he says. ''Not until the last 10 days of the campaign, when it looked as though all was lost anyway, did he confess that, yes, he was a liberal. George had been right all along. Dukakis threw himself upon the mercy of the American electorate.''
Professor Reich seeks some obvious solutions that might lead to a resurgent liberalism: responding to Soviet troop reductions and arms expenditures with bold reductions and counteroffers of our own; improved education that would prepare Americans to compete in technologically intensive businesses; curbing hostile takeovers and leveraged buyouts, and spending more for children's health and learning ''as an extension of policies for guarding our nation's long-term security and prosperity.''
Much of what he advocates sounds more like pragmatic neo-liberalism than the traditional humane liberalism that led to major social legislation and court decisions in American history.
The author's language often devolves into muddy generalities. For example, he writes: ''If it is to be useful to us, a new liberal philosophy must explain reality and yield palpable lessons for the future. But if it is to be accepted, it must do so in a manner that simplifies and reassures. Sadly, these two conditions are sharply at odds in this age of turbulent change and baffling complexity. Hence, the resurgent liberal's greatest challenge.''
A number of the essays in the book are derived from previously published magazine articles. However, events have moved so swiftly in the last few months, especially in the foreign policy realm, that there is a dated feeling in several places where the need for American liberalism is linked to revolutionary changes going on in Europe, Asia and Central America. It isn't necessarily the author's fault that a book's lead time is so long; but, geopolitically speaking, we are living in newspaper time.

The Campeau Situation
G. William Miller was named chairman and chief executive of Campeau's U.S. retailing operations. [Page D1.] Mr. Miller has a dazzling resume but has never run a giant retailing concern. [D23.] 
First Boston is by far the largest unsecured creditor of Campeau's retailing subsidiaries. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
There was a sense of relief among some of the suppliers to Campeau's stores. [D1.]
 
 
 
Companies
Citicorp announced that it lost $784 million in the fourth quarter, as it set aside $1 billion in reserves to cover losses on its loans to less developed countries. Manufacturers Hanover, Security Pacific and Wells Fargo posted profits. [D1.]

Economy
The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether states can bring Federal antitrust suits charging energy producers with illegal price-fixing. [D1.]
Sales of cars made in the U.S. jumped 29.8 percent in early January compared with a sluggish period a year earlier. [D1.]
Business sales and inventories rose in November, but economists said December would probably prove weaker. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Early-Month Vehicle Sales Up Sharply

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Sales of cars made in the United States jumped by 29.8 percent in early January compared with a sluggish period a year ago, as buyers took advantage of factory incentives and flocked to showrooms after an absence of several months. Light-truck sales also surged, rising by 22.8 percent.
The upturn does not yet insure a recovery for the industry, analysts said today. But some said they were optimistic that sales would continue to improve, bolstered by expanded incentives, swollen demand and steadying consumer confidence. 
''These numbers confirm that the recent incentive programs are starting to stimulate showroom traffic,'' said John Kirnan, an anlyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York. ''The consumer isn't dead.'' 158,775 Cars Sold The eight domestic manufacturers said today that they sold 158,775 cars in the Jan. 1-10 period, translating into a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.1 million, considered robust by several of the analysts. Total vehicle sales in the period were up by 27 percent, to 260,314 units.
The surge in sales helped reduce swollen inventories of unsold cars, which had reached alarming levels at the beginning of the month despite selective plant shutdowns in early December and the holiday week between Christmas and New Year's.
The 91-day supply of domestically made cars in dealers' lots at the end of December was the highest inventory backlog for that month in nine years, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter. A 65-to-70-day supply is considered normal for this time of year.
 
Plants Being Closed
The large inventories are significant because they underscore that manufacturers are producing more cars than the dealers are selling. Mounting inventories have set off industrywide plant closings in January and early next month.
Last year, car sales in early January were particularly sluggish, mainly because rebates and low financing incentives ended the previous December. The number of vehicles sold each day in early January of this year lagged behind the daily sales rates in late December 1989. Eight selling days were in the current sales period, compared with seven in the 1989 period.
The General Motors Corporation fared the best of the Big Three, as a bevy of new models pushed its sales to 76,417 cars, an increase of 40.4 percent. Ford sold 49,369 cars, up by 15.4 percent. Chrysler sold 20,364 cars, up by 14.4 percent.
The Japanese manufacturers in the United States showed mixed results. The Toyota Motor Corporation had a fourfold increase in car sales, to 4,123, and Mitsubishi sold 1,344 cars, compared with 51 a year ago, when its plant was new.
 
Big Jump at Mazda
The sales of Honda's cars rose by 21.2 percent, to 5,531, while Mazda more than doubled the sales of its cars to 713 in early January. But the Nissan Motor Company's sales fell by 48 percent, to 914.
The sales of light trucks rose by 22.8 percent, to 101,539, in the 10-day period. Chrysler posted the largest increase over last year, with a 44 percent gain in light-truck sales, largely because of rebates offered for the first time on its popular mini-vans. Chrysler said it had sold about twice as many Voyager and Caravan models in early January compared with the period a year earlier.
G.M. sold 40,752 light trucks in early January, up by 28.4 percent. Ford sold 32,868 light trucks, a 10.8 percent increase. Nissan's light-truck sales fell by 63.2 percent, to 935.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Blue-Collar Blues: Who Is to Blame?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
ARE you better or worse off than you were four years ago, asked Ronald Reagan in 1980. But George Bush's image-makers chose not to press the rhetorical point in his Presidential campaign, and for good reason.
Young, male, blue-collar workers, part of the demographic coalition that has given Republicans a big leg up on the White House in recent decades, suffered devastating financial setbacks during the 1980's. While the real earnings of 25- to 34-year-old men who graduated college rose by 9 percent from 1979 to 1987, the earnings of high school dropouts fell 15 percent. High school graduates did not do much better, absorbing a 9 percent cut. 
Few economists are inclined to blame Republicans, or anyone else, for the way the chips fall in a free market: That would legitimize government tinkering with market-determined wages in order to right social wrongs. And the resulting efficiency losses would more than offset the social gains.
If the rich have acquired too large a slice of the pie and the poor too small - the majority view, one would guess, among American economists - the smarter way to redistribute shares is to change taxes and government benefit programs.
But it is still worth knowing how markets favor some and punish others, if only as a guide to figuring how much strain capitalism is putting on the social safety net. And probably no one has pushed the frontiers of knowledge on how blue-collar workers are faring further than the economists McKinley Blackburn of the University of South Carolina, David Bloom of Columbia University and Richard Freeman of Harvard University.
Their most striking findings, detailed in the National Bureau of Economic Research Working Paper No. 3186 (November 1989), are negative.
The real value of the Federal minimum wage fell by nearly one-fourth from 1980 to 1988. But, according to their study, the minimum affected so small a portion of the work force that it accounted for, at very most, 8 percent of the widening gap between high school dropouts and the college-educated.
Many think technology has favored ''knowledge workers'' over those who work with their hands. That might be true, say the authors. But simulations suggest that the magnitude of the impact is too small to explain much of the change in wage patterns in the 1980's.
Increased competition from women may have reduced men's wages. But this does not explain the growth in the blue/white earnings gap because the impact of the increased labor supply has been as great or greater on well-educated men.
The declining quality of public education may have slowed productivity growth since the mid-1960's. But if it were responsible for a fall in the relative wages of blue-collar labor during the 1980's, one would expect to find that those who finished school at the beginning of the decade were doing better than those who finished near the end. And once again, the numbers are uncooperative. What, then, does explain the widening earnings gap? A lot of different things, the authors believe.
The decline of unions, which typically raise blue-collar pay at the expense of white-collar workers, played a part. So did changes in the demand for labor, which channeled blue-collar workers into poorly paid service industries. So, too, did shifts in the relative supply of educated workers: A fall in the number of college graduates gave them an edge in salary negotiations.
This last phenomenon looms largest when the last decade is contrasted with the previous one. Most factors eroding the financial position of the less educated were already at work in the mid-1970's. What changed so dramatically in the 1980's was the relative supply of labor: a flood of non-college workers forced down pay rates. The universally celebrated growth in total employment during the Reagan years, it seems, had a lot to do with the declining fortunes of workers at the bottom.
This supply shift should be partly self-correcting in the 1990's: College enrollments are rising, even as the number of males reaching work age each year falls. But that alone, the authors believe, will not be nearly enough to put blue-collar workers back on an equitable earnings track.
The economic question, then, and perhaps the political question as well, is whether Washington is prepared to give lower-income workers a break on taxes or government benefits needed to narrow the gap. The capital gains tax cut being pressed by Republicans is hardly designed to win their gratitude. But a rollback in the regressive Social Security payroll tax, proposed by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and supported by some Congressional Democrats, just might.
President Reagan's chickens may, at long last, be coming home to roost.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President Is Selected At Citibank and Parent

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Richard S. Braddock, for many years a key executive in Citicorp's highly profitable consumer banking business, yesterday was named president of Citicorp and its main subsidiary, Citibank.
With the new title, Mr. Braddock is the clear No. 2 executive at Citicorp to the chairman, John S. Reed. All businesses of Citibank, Citicorp's largest subsidiary, will report to Mr. Braddock. 
Mr. Braddock, who has spent his entire business career in consumer marketing, acknowledged that he had a lot to learn about other aspects of the banking business. ''There is a lot of learning for me to do, but I still consider myself pretty young,'' he said. 'It's a time to roll up my sleeves.'' The promotion of Mr. Braddock, who is 48 years old, was one of several changes announced yesterday as Citicorp coordinates the traditional bank corporate lending business with related activities in securities markets and financial advisory services.
In the past executives were divided between those with responsibility for the institutional bank, which provides lending services, and those in charge of the investment bank, which handles financial advice and securities activities.
Now, Citicorp is dividing executives between those in charge of the most developed nations, like the United States, Western Europe, Japan, Australia and New Zealand, and the third world countries, which Citicorp calls ''emerging economies.''
The consumer banking business, which earned a profit of $842 million for Citicorp in 1989, up from $362 million in 1986, will remain the responsibility of Mr. Braddock.
Lawrence M. Small, 48 previously in charge of the institutional bank, was named vice chairman of Citicorp and chairman of the executive committee.
Michael A. Callen, 49, previously head of the investment bank, was put in charge of investment and institutional banking in the developed countries markets. Alan S. MacDonald, 46, previously head of investment banking in North America, was named head of institutional and investment banking in emerging countries.
''These are the four guys who have all along been running the bank under John Reed,'' said Lawrence Cohn, a banking analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
Mr. Braddock joined Citicorp in 1973 as a a vice president in the New York banking group, followed by stints in charge of Citicorp's credit card business and European consumer operations. Since 1985, he has been in charge of all individual banking activities, one of the three major business groups at Citicorp along with institutional and investment banking, and information businesses.
Mr. Braddock said he enjoys a range of sporting activities, including squash, running, bicycling and tennis. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1963 with a degree in history and received a M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School in 1965.

HEADLINE: Ex-State Dept. Officer Takes Job at Fujitsu By MARTIN TOLCHIN

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
In what United States negotiators consider a major loss, the State Department officer who helped develop the negotiating strategy with Japan on high- technology issues ranging from semiconductors to space stations has joined Fujitsu Ltd., a Japanese electronics conglomerate.
David Olive, an economic and commercial officer at the State Department's Japanese desk, left the Government on Jan. 1 and last week became deputy general manager of Fujitsu's new Washington office.
''It's the company's embassy in Washington,'' Mr. Olive said in a telephone interview. ''I'll be reporting on what's going on to those executives who want to know more about Washington and its processes.'' 
Mr. Olive, 39 years old, described himself as a midcareer officer who was part of a team that wrote position papers on high-technology issues including semiconductors, supercomputers, space stations and high-definition television.
Lawyers at the Office of Government Ethics said Mr. Olive did not appear to have violated any laws.
Starting next Jan. 1, a law will prevent for one year former Federal employees who had been involved in trade or treaty negotiations from aiding or assisting any foreign company or government with which they had negotiated.
Under current law, a Federal employee is banned from representing clients before the Federal Government on issues in which he or she had been ''personally and substantially involved.''
The law also has a two-year ban on representing a client on matters that fell within the official's former responsibilities. But current law does not prohibit a Federal employee from going to work for such a client.
While at the State Department, Mr. Olive said, he had no dealings with Fujitsu officials.
But Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, sent a letter of protest today to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. Mr. Helms, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations committee, said in his letter: ''I fear Mr. Olive's move to Fujitsu may represent a critical loss to the United States' trade negotiating position. Mr. Olive undoubtedly takes with him a detailed knowledge of our bottom-line positions on a number of high-tech industries which will be vital to our economy's health into the 21st century.''
The State Department had no comment on Mr. Helms's letter, which had not yet been received, or Mr. Olive's move.
American negotiators said Mr. Olive's departure was considered an even greater loss than that of Walter C. Lenahan, who helped formulate the Government's textile negotiation strategies as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce. Mr. Lenahan left the Government to work for a company that advised Hong Kong on textile negotiations.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Dull Session While Gold Prices Weaken

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in lackluster trading yesterday amid few developments to affect the currency markets.
Gold prices were weaker. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, an ounce of gold fell $2.90. to $410.80. 
Foreign exchange analysts said the dollar fluctuated during the day on largely technical factors. The dollar was steadied by rising interest rates in the bond market and uncertainty about the political situation in the Soviet Union, said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc.
Higher interest rates in this country make the dollar a more attractive investment for foreigners, and the dollar also gains from overseas political problems because investors consider it a safe investment.
The yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond rose to 8.24 percent yesterday from late Friday's 8.17 percent. The government bond market was closed Monday for the Martin Luther King holiday.
In New York, the dollar fell to 145.30 yen from late Monday's 145.55 yen. The dollar gained against the British pound, which cost $1.6585 late in the day, compared with $1.6630.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.6950 West German marks, down from 1.6967; 1.5116 Swiss francs, up from 1.5110; 5.7630 French francs, down from 5.7635; 1,262.25 Italian lire, up from 1,261.625, and 1.16375 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16575.
Gold bullion prices had moved higher overseas, before slipping in New York.
Gold closed in London, the major overseas market, at a bid of $413.25 an ounce, up from $412 late Monday. It rose in Zurich to $413 from $412.40. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid of $415.45, up from late Monday's $413.95.
Silver was also mixed. It fell 1.2 cents on the Commodity Exchange to $5.230 an ounce after rising a cent in London to a bid $5.25.

HEADLINE: A Pragmatist Is Selected by Campeau

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
G. William Miller, the new chairman and chief executive of Federated Stores Inc., has a dazzling resume in business and Government, but he has never run a giant retailing concern.
He has been a Coast Guard officer, a corporate lawyer and he helped build a medium-sized textile manufacturer into the giant aerospace conglomerate Textron. He also served as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and Secretary of the Treasury in the Carter Administration.
More recently, as a merchant banker in Washington, he developed a wide familiarity with turnaround situations as a director of various ailing companies - including two whose foreign owners, like Robert Campeau of Canada, led the concerns into financial difficulties. 
Throughout his career, Mr. Miller, 64 years old, has built a reputation as a quick study and a hard-working manager. But at the Federal Reserve he was widely criticized by Wall Street for being overcautious; some people said he was too slow to push up interest rates, allowing inflation to get out of hand.
 
Knows Directors and Officers
As chief executive of the newly renamed American operations of the Campeau Corporation, he is familiar with Federated's directors and senior officers after 15 years as a director, but has little operational experience with department-store retailing.
''He is an intense, very intellectual and yet a very pragmatic guy and not at all fancy,'' said Stephen Wald, a private investor in New York who has been a friend of Mr. Miller's since the early 1960's. ''Even though he is from Texas, I kind of think of him as a frugal New Englander. That's probably good for his new job.''
For his part, Mr. Miller said two experiences from his career would help him at Campeau: his role in the Government bailout of the Chrysler Corporation in 1981 and in the reorganization of a troubled steel company in Charlotte, N.C.
Mr. Miller said in an interview that he had learned a lot about giant restructurings from the $1.5 billion aid package to Chrysler. As Treasury Secretary, Mr. Miller was chairman of the committee of Government officials overseeing the package, which involved complex negotiations with unions, bankers and suppliers.
 
Valuable Lessons
Mr. Miller said he had also learned valuable lessons from the case of Korf Industries, renamed Georgetown Industries. Mr. Miller served as a director, when the steel company in Charlotte, N.C., avoided bankruptcy after its majority owner, Willy Korf, a West German industrialist, filed for bankruptcy protection in 1983.
Georgetown sold operations to raise cash and reduce debt, then grew by acquisition. It is now a thriving private company with more than $600 million in revenue last year.
''Everybody said I had a complex story,'' said Roger R. Regelbrugge, president and chief executive of Georgetown, ''but Bill showed he had a full grasp of all the important issues within a few minutes.''
And John J. Mulcair, president of the International Power Machines Corporation, where Mr. Miller is a director, said he had broad business contacts. ''He picks up the phone and all of a sudden it's old home week,'' Mr. Mulcair said.
 
Swiss-Style Business
Since leaving the Government in 1981, Mr. Miller has focused most of his business activities on G. William Miller & Company, which has offices in Washington and Providence, R.I. Besides Mr. Miller, the partners are J. Joseph Kruse, a former Textron executive; J. Joseph Garrahy, former Governor of Rhode Island; Michael H. Cardozo, former deputy counsel in the Carter White House, and Steven L. Skancke, a former Treasury official under Mr. Miller and Donald Regan.
Housed in a former residence of Theodore Roosevelt on 19th Street, the firm styles itself as a discreet, Swiss-style merchant bank that provides a variety of financial services to an international clientele.
It has been involved with a variety of companies, including Private Satellite Network, which beams television programming from satellites to rooftop receivers; United Press International, when the news service was up for sale in 1984; and Kleinwort Benson Australian Income Fund, a mutual fund investing in Australian and New Zealand securities.
Born in Sapulpa, Okla., on March 9, 1925, Mr. Miller grew up in Borger, Tex., the son of a a furniture-store owner who was also a city judge. After getting an engineering degree from the United States Coast Guard Academy in 1945, Mr. Miller was stationed in Shanghai, where he met his wife, Ariadna, a Russian emigre whom he married in 1946.
 
Legal Career
After earning a law degree from the University of California at Berkeley in 1952, he joined the New York law firm of Cravath Swaine & Moore.
In 1956, he joined Textron Inc., a textile company in Providence, and stayed there 22 years. He rose to the position of president and chief operating officer in 1960, at the age of 35, under his mentor, Royal Little, the company's chairman. Mr. Miller helped build Textron, which had $383 million in revenue in 1960 and 29,000 employees, to a company with revenue of more than $3.2 billion in 1978 and 70,000 employees.
In 1978, President Carter named Mr. Miller chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Despite the criticism of his performance, Mr. Miller was widely praised for recommending his successor, Paul A. Volcker, who pursued a tough program to curb inflation. In August 1979, he was appointed Treasury Secretary.
