HEADLINE: U.S. CUTS BACK TRIP QUAYLE WILL MAKE IN LATIN COUNTRIES

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Lingering anxiety among Latin American nations over the American invasion of Panama has forced the Bush Administration to limit a diplomatic mission by Vice President Dan Quayle by putting off trips to Mexico and Venezuela, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Quayle's office announced today that he would travel late this month to Honduras and Panama, two nations that are reliable supporters of United States policy in Latin America. The Administration added a third stop in Jamaica.
But objections from Mexico and Venezuela, two vociferous critics of the Panama invasion last month, have forced the White House to set aside stops in those countries by Mr. Quayle. 
 
Continuing Problems
In Panama today, the new civilian President, Guillermo Endara, said he would go to Washington ''as soon as possible'' to ask for emergency economic aid, including a $200 million public-employment program and $40 million to rebuild homes destroyed in the invasion that toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. [Page A16.] When he announced on Jan. 5 that the Vice President would visit several Latin American nations, Mr. Bush called the tour ''very important diplomacy'' and an opportunity to spell out Washington's ''aspirations'' for Panama and the hemisphere.
The diplomatic sensitivity of Mexico and Venezuela, which are important to United States regional policy, dramatized the continuing political problems the Administration is facing in Latin America after its armed intervention.
 
A Meeting in Honduras
On Tuesday, Administration officials said they had postponed plans to deploy an aircraft carrier battle group off the coast of Colombia to help prevent drug shipments from Latin America to the United States. News reports of the plan had forced Mr. Bush to assure the Colombian President, Virgilio Barco Vargas, that no such action would be taken without his consent. Administration officials said the Colombian Government was unsettled by the Panama invasion.
The White House was trying to arrange a meeting for Mr. Quayle with President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela in Honduras, where the two will attend the presidential inauguration on Jan. 27, officials said. But there were no plans for him to meet with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico.
Mexico and Venezuela have said it is too soon after the Panama invasion for Mr. Quayle to visit, warning that such a trip at this time could cause domestic political trouble and set off demonstrations against the United States, Administration officials said.
The White House was also concerned that a visit might prove so awkward for the Governments of those two countries that it would harden their position against recognizing the new Panamanian Government and make it more difficult to enlist their help in economic relief programs for Panama, officials said.
Mr. Quayle's office announced today that he would visit Honduras, Panama and Jamaica on Jan. 27-29.
In March, Mr. Quayle will visit Chile and Brazil for presidential inaugurations, and Administration officials said he could add as many as three other South American countries, most likely Paraguay, Uruguay and Argentina, to his itinerary.
But, after weeks of delicate negotiations, the Administration decided not to send the Vice President to Mexico and Venezuela, officials said.
The White House also decided not to schedule an immediate visit by Mr. Quayle to Costa Rica, because that country has elections on Feb. 5, and the Bush Administration wants to avoid any appearance of meddling in the vote, officials said. No trip is scheduled to El Salvador. The United States has long been concerned about the possibility that top officials would encounter anti-American protests in Latin America. In May 1958, Vice President Richard M. Nixon cut short a visit to Caracas, Venezuela, after violent demonstrations broke out. A mob attacked his motorcade, shattering windows in his limousine, and tried to drag him from the car.
Today, Administration officials sought to put Mr. Quayle's mission in the best light, noting that he is to meet with regional leaders in Honduras, where he will attend the inauguration of Rafael Leonardo Callejas as President.
Mr. Quayle is to also meet privately with regional officials during the Brazilian and Chilean inaugurations, officials said. They noted that Mr. Bush will meet with the leaders of Colombia and Bolivia at a conference on drug trafficking that is to be held in Cartagena, Colombia, on Feb. 15. President Alan Garcia of Peru has said he will not attend the meeting in protest over the Panama invasion, and will probably send a high-ranking substitute.
Administration officials said the fact that Mr. Quayle would not travel to Mexico and Venezuela did not mark a setback to the Administration's fence-mending efforts in the hemisphere. ''No one wanted to make the point of visiting every country,'' a senior Administration official said.
Mr. Quayle said today at a luncheon appearance: ''There are no problems with consulting with the Latin American leaders. There is no problem as far as us taking our case to the leaders and discussing how we go about building democracy in Panama.''
But he acknowledged that there were ''diplomatic sensitivities'' about the timing of his visits to Latin America.
A senior Administration official said the United States had approached the Governments of Mexico and Venezuela about a visit by Mr. Quayle.
''They said it would be O.K., but not so soon,'' the official said.
''Obviously, we wanted a trip to produce something, like recognition of the Panamanian Government or money for economic relief,'' the official said.

HEADLINE: Greater Reliance on Foreign Oil Feared as U.S. Output Tumbles

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
America's oil production suffered its biggest single-year decline ever in 1989, falling by more than half a million barrels a day, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Imports surged to make up for the drop in domestic oil production. As a result, the nation's dependence on imported oil rose to a near-record 46 percent of demand last year, the highest level in more than a decade, according to the institute, the industry's main trade association.
Experts predict that the rapid slide in domestic production will continue in 1990 and beyond. Oil is getting harder to find in the United States, they said, and prices, though rising recently, are too low to encourage the drilling needed to find enough new fields to make up for the aging ones. 
The increased dependence on imports means that if oil prices increase, the nation's trade deficit will probably widen further. The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the trade deficit grew to $10.5 billion in November, the largest monthly gap in 1989. Oil imports accounted for 42 percent of the November deficit. [Page D1.] OPEC's Influence Grows Declining American output also means that the world's oil production capacity is once again increasingly concentrated within the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. OPEC's ability to influence prices grows as oil customers become more dependent on its supplies.
The trend of falling American oil output has been apparent since the mid-1980's. But Dr. Edward H. Murphy, the petroleum institute's director of finance, accounting and statistics, said that last year's record drop was nonetheless ''dramatic,'' adding that there is little prospect that the production decline will be reversed anytime soon.
Thomas R. McHale, an economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert, said, ''We're facing a unanimous belief that domestic production isn't going to go up again unless we have $40-a-barrel oil.''
Oil prices have recently hovered around $22 to $23 a barrel.
American production last year was at the lowest level since 1963, a time when domestic demand was roughly half what it is now, and imports were 16 percent of demand.
United States production will continue to drop because exploration dwindled in the late 1980's, when oil companies cut their spending because of low oil prices. Thus, imports will continue to rise, experts said, even if, as in 1989, demand for oil does not increase.
Dr. Murphy said the decline would continue even though the count of active drilling rigs - a closely watched indicator of exploration activity - has risen, to 1,029, from 872 at this time last year. Besides increasing its drilling activity, the industry is pressing for new tax incentives for drilling and for access to coastal areas where environmentalists have raised concerns about drilling.
 
A Drop in Investment
Peter C. Beutel, an oil trader at Elders Futures Inc., said that by 1987 investment in domestic drilling had fallen to one-fifth of what it was in the peak year, 1981. ''In the early 1990's, the oil we searched for in the mid- to late-80's will be coming on stream, and it's going to be a very small graduating class of barrels,'' he said.
Because of the decline in production last year, which amounted to 6.8 percent, oil imports rose to 46 percent of supplies last year. Crude oil production averaged 7.6 million barrels a day, and imports of crude oil and products were slightly less than eight million barrels a day.
The proportion of imports was second only to 1977, when imports were 47.7 percent. As recently as 1985, when high oil prices stimulated domestic drilling, imports supplied less than a third of the nation's oil demand.
The petroleum institute also reported that by a second measure, which is less frequently used, imports last year reached an all-time high. If inventory changes are taken out of the figures, imports' share of domestic deliveries in 1989 was 46.7 percent, compared to 44.8 percent in 1977.
Imported oil's share last year far exceeded the 38.8 percent of October 1973 when the Arab oil embargo produced the first oil-price shock. It also was above the 45.3 percent in 1979, when Iran sharply cut its production after the Shah fell, touching off another oil-price surge.
Now, oil supplies are increasingly coming from the Middle East, which supplied 21 percent of American oil needs last year, compared with 19.7 percent when the 1973 embargo occurred and 36.1 percent when the Shah fell.
The cost of imported oil last year was about $49 billion, accounting for about 44 percent of the trade deficit.
Analysts say declining oil production from Alaska, a comparatively young oil region by American standards, is another disturbing sign in the petroleum institute's monthly and full-year figures. Alaska production fell 7 percent last year, indicating that the region is past its prime.
But recent statistics also contain some signs of progress in improving the efficiency of the nation's use of energy. Energy efficiency is the quantity of oil or other fuel required to produce a unit of economic growth. Improved efficiency means that the economy uses less oil - and thus needs to import less - than otherwise would be the case. America's overall energy efficiency, while still far lower than in Western Europe and Japan, may have improved slightly last year, preliminary figures from the Department of Energy show.
In addition, demand for oil products grew by a mere one-tenth of a percent last year, the institute said. Total energy consumption rose by about 1.9 percent, but the main source of the increase was a 6 percent rise in the use of natural gas, the institute said. Domestic sources along with fields in Canada can supply almost all the nation's demand for natural gas.
New oilfields are increasingly difficult to find in the United States. Even when exploratory drilling reached a peak in 1981, the success rate was declining, said James J. MacKenzie, a senior associate at the World Resources Institute, an environmental group in Washington. The industry can look harder, he said, but in the long run, ''We're not going to get any more of it.''
Given that situation, he and many experts believe that the only way to control the trend of rising dependence on foreign oil is for American households and companies to consume less.
But Dr. McHale of Drexel said of the prospects for reduced use: ''The conservation mindset that was developed in the 70's has essentially eroded. We have no one preaching energy conservation. Kids don't bother turning out the lights. Nobody really pays attention to gasoline prices.''

HEADLINE: Gorbachev in Danger, Kennan Says in Testimony

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
George F. Kennan said today the economic and political problems boiling over in the Soviet Union have put President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in ''danger,'' but he is not likely to be replaced in the near future because his troubles are so acute that even his rivals may not want his job.
Mr. Kennan's remarks were made in an appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which amounted actually to a conversation with Sen. Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, the only member who had returned from the holiday recess that ends next week.
During his 90-minute testimony, Mr. Kennan, the intellectual father of the policy of containment of the Soviet Union and for many years the dean of American Government experts on the Soviet Union, also argued that the Bush Administration should offer a much more ''drastic reduction'' in conventional forces in Europe than the proposals now on the table because the prospect of a Warsaw Pact invasion today is ''absolute nonsense.'' 
 
Warning on East Germany
He also contended that East Germany was on the verge of imminent disintegration, and that this ''very, very delicate, dicey and dangerous situation,'' must be dealt with or it will throw all Europe into turmoil.
Mr. Kennan, who is 85 years old, is a professor emeritus at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., began his testimony by reading a statement in which he observed that the ''situation in the Soviet Union, is, at this moment, unstable in high degree'' and ''has created a situation of great difficulty and danger for Gorbachev.''
''So great are the political burdens he has now come to bear that it is doubtful in my opinion that he could have remained in office as long as he has were it not for his high international prestige, constituting as it does an important asset for the Soviet state, and for the fact that none of his senior colleagues has any program to offer as an alternative to the one he has created and carried forward,'' Mr. Kennan said.
So heavy ''is the burden of troubles'' Mr. Gorbachev must now carry, added Mr. Kennan, ''that it is questionable whether there is any among his potential rivals who would like, at the present time, to assume this burden in his place.''
 
Urges Deeper Arms Cuts
In arms control, Mr. Kennan called on the Bush Administration to offer much deeper conventional arms cuts in Europe than those now being negotiated with the Warsaw Pact at the Vienna talks.
''We could take a much more forthcoming attitude in the negotiations for mutual reductions of conventional arms in Europe,'' Mr. Kennan said. ''The relief that a drastic reduction of the Soviet forces in this region would bring to the Soviet government, and, incidentally, to ourselves as well, would be of greater significance, financially and otherwise, than any direct help we could conveivably extend.''
Mr. Kennan's most alarming statements were about East Germany, where he said the Government was on the verge of ''disintegration,'' which could create a sort of de facto unification with West Germany before the rest of the continent is prepared for such a situation.
Saying that ''this dangerous situation which is developing has to be stopped in some way or other,'' Mr. Kennan suggested that the Allied powers --the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union -- ''possibly establish a unified government of some sort in the city of Berlin, and then perhaps expand that into an emergency grouping which could try to stablize the position in Eastern Germany without prejudicing the future problems of unification and of European unity.''

HEADLINE: Political Leaders in Greece Agree to Elections by April

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: ATHENS, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Greek political leaders agreed today to hold elections by early April, the third attempt in 10 months, to try to resolve political and economic crises and to allow American military bases to stay for at least another six months. 
''This government's service ends on April 8,'' said Prime Minister Xenophon Zolotas after meeting the leaders of Greece's three major political parties.
American bases were due to close by May 22 unless a new accord was signed, but Greek political leaders agreed today to a six-month extension for further talks.
Conservatives, Socialists and a Communist-led coalition formed the all-party Government in November after inconclusive elections.

HEADLINE: Panama's New Chief to Ask U.S. Aid

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Panama's new civilian President said today that he would go to Washington ''as soon as possible'' to ask for emergency economic aid, including $200 million for a public-employment program and $40 million to rebuild homes destroyed in the invasion that toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
''I know there are questions as to whether the United States owes us'' assistance, said the President, Guillermo Endara, who was sworn in near an American military base on the night of Dec. 19 as the invasion began. ''But I don't plan to go as a bill collector.''
Rather, he said, ''I just want to tell the United States, the Government and the people'' that if Panama does not receive ''the aid we really need,'' then the sacrifices in lives and resources both countries made during efforts to oust General Noriega are ''all going to go down the drain.'' [In Washington, an Administration official said the State Department, the White House and the Treasury were working on a package of aid for the new Government of Panama. ''We want to support'' the Endara Government, the official said. Funds for employment and housing programs are among the priorities, but ''we don't have details yet,'' the official said.] 'In Economic Ruins' 
Right now, President Endara said, ''Panama is in economic ruins.'' He added, ''There's horrible unemployment.''
Mr. Endara, who said he had not spoken with President Bush since Dec. 20, the first full day of the invasion, said, ''I have no definite travel plans yet, but I am seeking appointments to go as soon as possible.''
In recent weeks, American officials have been reluctant to make any specific public commitment on aid to restart Panama's economy, saying they needed to study the situation closely first.
But the 52-year-old President, in an interview in his office overlooking the Pacific, warned of ''a huge disaster'' unless assistance began flowing soon, even suggesting that in their frustration ''the people will seek other systems,'' including even Communism or a return to militarism.
''The Communists, the Marxists are really hoping that the United States doesn't come through,'' Mr. Endara said, speaking easily in English, ''because then they will make a big bid for power.''
The Panamanian leader, the first civilian President to serve in a nonmilitary Government in 21 years, added: ''For me, of course, I would be a laughing stock. I will go down in history as an awful President - weak, a traitor.''
 
Figure Not Set
Mr. Endara, settled comfortably on a sofa beneath ceremonial frescoes of eight past Panamanian presidents and two military strongmen, said he had not yet decided on the total amount he would seek from the United States. But other officials of the new Government have variously put the figure between $1.5 billion and $3 billion.
''I last talked to Mr. Bush on the 20th,'' Mr. Endara recalled. ''I don't remember his exact words, but he was very sure of aid. Of course, we couldn't quantify it then.''
Mr. Endara said a program to create jobs, ''something like the New Deal, but of course much smaller,'' would be a vital first step in rebuilding this nation of 2.4 million, where unemployment, aggravated by two years of American economic sanctions that were aimed at weakening General Noriega, has risen to 20 percent of the work force.
''We need a two-year program for temporary employment just to get the ball rolling,'' Mr. Endara said, saying it would involve putting unemployed Panamanians to work ''doing small jobs, rebuilding churches, rebuilding roads, doing jobs all around the country.''
The President also said that $40 million was needed to replace the homes of thousands of civilians in El Chorillo, the impoverished neighborhood of frame houses that was heavily damaged in three days of fighting around General Noriega's military headquarters.
 
Force May Be Expanded
On another subject, Mr. Endara said he and his aides had come to the conclusion that Panama needed ''a small military capability'' to deal with the possibility of anything from serious public disorders to the threat of guerrilla attacks.
For that reason, Mr. Endara said, he and First Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon are leaning toward expanding Panama's Public Force, the newly formed, 1,000-member police agency composed of former Noriega soldiers, to 10,000. Out of that, he said, as many as four companies would be composed of troops rather than police officers.
''Our thinking is this - our Fuerza Publica must be a very professional, efficient, very good police force,'' Mr. Endara said. ''However, we know that this is not enough.''
While the lawyer and political neophyte said his new Government did not expect to ''have to fight any wars,'' he said ''we do have to face the fact that we might have to deal with guerrillas.''
 
U.S. Vetoes U.N. Resolution
UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 17 (Special to The New York Times) - The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution declaring that the search of the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama by United States military forces on Dec. 29 violated international law.
The United States was the only member of the Security Council to vote against the resolution. Britain was the only country that abstained.
The resolution called the ransacking of the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence ''a violation of the privileges and immunities granted to diplomatic missions and agents by international law, codified in the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations,'' held in 1961.
In his statement to the Security Council before today's vote, Nicaragua's representative, Alejandro Serrano Caldera, demanded an investigation of the incident and ''proper penalty set for those who are responsible for such attacks.''
But the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, said the matter should never have come before the Security Council in the first place.

HEADLINE: Sales Tax on Religious Goods Upheld

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states may apply their general sales taxes to religious organizations' sales of religious books and articles.
Upholding a decision by a California appeals court, the Justices rejected arguments by the television evangelist Jimmy Swaggart that the Constitution's guarantee of freedom of religion prohibits states from taxing religious sales.
Mr. Swaggart's organization, Jimmy Swaggart Ministries, had challenged the imposition of the California sales tax on nearly $2 million in sales of religious pamphlets, tapes, records and other items in the 1970's. The ministry sold the material to California residents both by mail from its Louisiana headquarters and in about two dozen ''crusades'' by Mr. Swaggart in the state. 
According to briefs filed in the case, California is one of only three states that apply their sales taxes to sales of religious articles by religious organizations. The others are West Virginia and Indiana. California is the only state to tax not only local sales but the mail-order sales from out of state that are a big source of revenue for some evangelical organizations.
 
An Issue Left Unresolved
In addition to his arguments concerning religious freedom, Mr. Swaggart had also challenged California's tax on his mail-order sales on the ground that his organization's connection with California was so remote that the state did not have constitutional authority to apply its tax.
But the Supreme Court said today that it did not have jurisdiction to decide this aspect of the case because the California courts had refused, on procedural grounds, to rule on it. That disposition means that someone else is free to raise the same challenge in the future.
But it was the religious arguments that attracted most attention to the case. Religious organizations, including the National Council of Churches and a number of evangelical ministries, filed briefs in Mr. Swaggart's behalf, warning that a decision in California's favor would effectively invite other states to stop granting tax exemptions for religious sales. Mr. Swaggart and the other organizations argued that the tax was an administrative and financial burden that, by adding to the cost of the items, would discourage potential customers.
In her opinion for the Court, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said that ''we do not doubt the economic cost'' of being subject to a sales tax. But she said that ''such a tax is no different from other generally applicable laws and regulations, such as health and safety regulations'' that religious organizations must obey.
''The collection and payment of the generally applicable tax in this case imposes no constitutionally significant burden'' on the Swaggart organization's ''religious practices or beliefs,'' Justice O'Connor said. Tax Rate Not 'Onerous'
The 6 percent sales tax amounted to $166,000 plus interest and penalties over the eight years involved in the suit. Justice O'Connor noted that the constitutional analysis might be different if there were a ''more onerous tax rate'' that ''might effectively choke off an adherent's religious practices.''
The Swaggart organization had based much of its constitutional argument on two Supreme Court decisions from the 1940's that invalidated the imposition of licensing fees on itinerant preachers.
But Justice O'Connor said that those cases were very different because the fee was an unconstitutional ''precondition to the exercise of evangelistic activity.'' The sales tax in this case, she said, ''is not a tax on the right to disseminate religious information, ideas or beliefs per se; rather it is a tax on the privilege of making retail sales of tangible personal property.''
The ruling today, Swaggart Ministries v. California, No. 88-1374, was foreshadowed by a Supreme Court decision last year invalidating a sales tax exemption that Texas granted to religious publications distributed by religious organizations. The Court ruled in that case, Texas Monthly v. Bullock, that the exemption was an unconstitutional state subsidy of religion.
In contrast to the unanimity today, the Justices were deeply divided in the Texas case. There was no majority opinion, leaving the dimensions of the ruling somewhat unclear. But now that the Court has clearly stated that religious organizations have no constitutional right to a tax exemption, the exemptions granted by other states may well now be open to challenge in future cases.
Unrelated to his sales tax challenge, Mr. Swaggart was at the center of a scandal two years ago after admitting that he had paid a prostitute to pose for him in the nude. He was defrocked by the Assemblies of God, and lost more than half his television audience when he returned to the air three months later.
 
Another Unanimous Ruling
In another unanimous decision today, the Court ruled that the Federal courts have jurisdiction to decide lawsuits requiring an examination of possibly unlawful behavior by officials of a foreign government.
The Court gave a narrow interpretation of a longstanding judicial rule known as the act of state doctrine, which bars the Federal courts from declaring invalid an official act of a foreign government performed within its own territory.
The case today grew out of litigation between two American competitors for a construction contract in Nigeria. Environmental Tectonics Corporation, which lost the bid, filed a suit for damages against the successful bidder, W. S. Kirkpatrick & Company, after Kirkpatrick pleaded guilty to a Federal criminal charge of having bribed Nigerian officials.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, ruled that the lawsuit could procede. Kirkpatrick appealed to the Supreme Court on the ground that the suit should be barred under the act of state doctrine.
Writing the for Court today, Justice Antonin Scalia said that the doctrine did not apply because only the ''motivation'' of the Nigerian officials, and not the validity of the construction contract itself, was in question. Preventing Federal courts from examining the possibly unlawful motivation of foreign officials would be an unwarranted expanion of the act of state doctrine, he said. The case was Kirkpatrick v. Environmental Tectonics, No. 87-2066.

HEADLINE: H.U.D. Is Ending an Insurance Program That Lost a Billion

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp today ended a Reagan Administration program in which private lenders committed the Government to insuring mortgages.
Federal officials and independent auditors said the program has cost the Government $1 billion in losses since it began in 1983.
Under the program, private lenders supervised most of the underwriting of loans, the credit checks and appraisals for multifamily housing projects and assumed about 20 percent of the risk of insuring the mortgage. The Government assumed responsibility for the remaining 80 percent. 
 
'Bad Deal' for Taxpayers
''The co-insurance method is structurally flawed and fundamentally unsound as well as administratively unfixable,'' Mr. Kemp said. ''In comparing the losses resulting from co-insurance to the housing provided, it is clear that co-insurance has been a bad deal for the American taxpayer.''
The program, run by the Federal Housing Administration, was one of the Reagan Administration's major initiatives in public-private partnership. It was established by then-Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. as a way of allowing the private sector to perform functions previously performed by the Government in the hopes of speeding loan applications and reducing inefficiency.
But Congressional investigators found that some lenders had vastly overvalued property that was being mortgaged.
 
Economic Downturns
In the course of arranging these inflated mortgages, the investigators said, a lender would receive a large servicing fee based on the size of the mortgage. Later, when the owner or developer defaulted, the lender was able to pay its 20 percent share of insurance costs and still come away with a profit, leaving the Government responsible for the rest of the loss.
Investigators have also attributed some of the losses to economic downturns, especially in the Southwest that caused a rising number of defaults, and have said they found evidence that the housing department did not properly oversee the work of the private lenders.
Auditors from the Price Waterhouse accounding firm, hired by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, concluded last fall that the program had amassed a $1 billion loss.
Mr. Kemp said today that the Government would take over the tasks previously given to private lenders, including credit checks and appraisals, and would fully guarantee the loans.
''A careful and prolonged examination of all the available options and the potential consequences of each to the American public has led to the prudent management decision to end co-insurance and rededicate the department to an enhanced program of full insurance,'' he said.
Because some projects are now being processed by the department, Mr. Kemp said the program would have to be phased out gradually. Officials said this interim period would probably take several months, or possibly longer.
In the meantime, he ordered that private lenders seeking to approve loans under the program first submit all documentation to the housing department for approval.
Mr. Kemp identified the program as the department's No. 1 ''material weakness'' in his report last month to the President and Congress.
The Housing Secretary said the agency would now receive 100 percent of the mortgage insurance premiums. But he said the private lenders would still be doing some of the screening for a fee.
As one of the worst examples of the program, Mr. Kemp cited the case of Colonial House, an apartment project in Houston that was insured for $47.2 million and defaulted because of high vacancy rates. The housing department was forced to take over the project and recovered only $8.9 million when it was auctioned last year.
 
Review of Program
The Secretary has taken several steps to review the insurance program and reduce the housing department's financial exposure. He suspended the program last summer as evidence of problems mounted and put a moratorium on new entrants into the program. He put six lenders on probation and suspended seven others.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into whether officials at the department who supervised the program were improperly influenced to give preferential treatment to at least one lender.
The co-insurance program is just one program that has caused losses for the Federal Housing Administration.
The General Accounting Office reported in May that the agency as a whole lost $452 million in 1988. Premiums paid by private lenders are the main source of the agency's income, and they have been declining as claims have been mounting, a result largely of a depressed real estate market.
 
'From H.U.D. to the Lender'
The housing department's literature for lenders explains that the insurance program ''reduces the number of persons who have to prepare and review documents at each processing step and shifts decision-making authority from H.U.D. to the lender.''
But a layoff of auditors at the department left ''nobody to watch the store'' when lenders arbitrarily ''did their own underwriting'' in the program, Dennis Penman, a Buffalo builder, said last summer.
A report in December 1988 said inadequate oversight had led to unsound loans, inflated appraisals and inflated mortgages, which in turn led to large fees for the lenders and losses for the department.

HEADLINE: Time for a Danube Basin Common Market

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The collapse of the Ceausescu Government in Rumania provides the nationalities of the old Hapsburg Empire with a historic opportunity to establish an economic common market of the countries of the Danube River basin. An economic union of Austria, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Rumania, Yugoslavia and Italy could be modeled after the very successful European Common Market begun in the 1950's. 
The formation of an economic union would cultivate cooperation in a region of divisive rivalries. A tariff-free common market would also be of value to the Soviet Union. In the early 19th century, the integrity of the Hapsburg monarchy was a key to Russia's security. The Crimean War disrupted that, and the ensuing rivalry between the monarchy and czarist Russia played a crucial role in the origin of World War I and the demise of both regimes.
A strong economic union would provide the Soviet Union with a buffer against a reunited economic German giant. West Germany or conceivably a united Germany would also benefit. Germany in the last century has had difficulty contending with its own strength. Weak states to its east have provided Germany with the opportunity to dominate them. Until the middle of the 19th century the Hapsburg monarchy balanced its expanding northern neighbor Prussia. It is with the Prussian defeat of the Hapsburg monarchy in 1866, and that monarchy's subsequent decline, that the growth of Germany's hegemony in central Europe can be correlated.
Many of the former Soviet satellite nations of the Danube basin have fledgling democratic institutions that would thrive better in an economically stable environment. It is in the security interests of the United States, the Soviet Union and a rejuvenated Germany to promote integrated economic growth in the Danube basin.
 
DANIEL FRIEDLANDER
Lexington, Mass., Dec. 29, 1989

HEADLINE: Capital Gains Tax Cut Would Promote Fairness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Who's Demagoguing Capital Gains?'' (editorial, Jan. 11) notwithstanding, President Bush was on target in calling for an end to demagogy on his proposal to cut tax rates on capital gains. A prime example of such demagoguing is the charge that the cut would almost solely benefit the rich, when more than half of taxpayers reporting capital gains had incomes of $50,000 or less, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Those people are far from rich. To be sure, the capital gains tax cut would benefit Donald Trump on the profitable sale of real estate more than Archie Bunker on the profitable sale of his bar. But don't try to convince Archie that's unfair; he'll be happy to take the money and run. 
In contrast to your contention that most scholarly research questions the positive economic impact of a capital gains tax cut, the nonpartisan analysis of Yolanda Henderson of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston demonstrates that half the sharp increase in capital costs resulting from the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was caused by the increase in capital gains tax rates. When you and other avid supporters of that legislation realize that it increased the capital cost of investment in productive equipment (from the standpoint of the investor) by upward of 40 percent, then perhaps the 1986 law will come to be viewed as a decidedly mixed bag, badly in need of improvement, rather than the Holy Grail of tax policy.
You would exclude old investments from the capital gains tax cut to save revenue and avoid rewarding ''the nation's wealthiest families.'' In other words, those thrifty individuals and businesses that have saved diligently and now are appropriately reaping the fruits of that saving through capital gains should drop dead - only future savers need apply. Furthermore, a tax cut on existing assets makes economic sense by encouraging capital mobility and leaving savers with a larger after-tax pool of funds for reinvestment.
Confining the capital gains tax cut to new assets would not be fair to the thrifty of the past, nor is it necessary. Highly credible revenue estimates at Treasury and by private sector economists point to net revenue gains from a broad-based capital gains tax cut in the early years and at least revenue neutrality over five years. Congressional revenue estimators disagree, but they have erred significantly on the pessimistic side in estimating the revenue impact of every capital gains tax cut in recent years. Capital gains revenue estimates beyond five years depend on so many unforeseeable factors as to be little more than conjecture.
President Bush's capital gains proposal is an important first step in promoting tax fairness to savers and the lower capital costs needed to enhance United States competitiveness. It should be broadened in scope, not cut back.
 
CHARLS E. WALKER
Chairman, American Council
for Capital Formation
 Washington, Jan. 11, 1990

HEADLINE: An Alliance For All Europe

SERIES: Designs for Europe - An occasional series.

BYLINE: By Alexander M. Haig Jr.; Alexander M. Haig Jr., Secretary of State in 1981 and 1982, was Supreme Commander of NATO from 1975 to 1979.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As the new decade begins, Europe heads the surprise list. In contrast to the Europe of the early 1980's, the Western system is now clearly ascendant. But Eastern Europe's broad yearnings to duplicate the success of the West, especially its economic success, are not the same as a triumph of Western values, as some too readily proclaim.
The societies of Central and Eastern Europe are wrecked but not yet reconstructed as either democracies or free-market economies. And the final word is not yet in on how all this will play in a Moscow that now seems behind the curve of change, rather than ahead.
President Bush has asserted, rightly, America's interest in the outcome of these tremendous events. We have earned our place - in blood and treasure - at the table. The reconstruction of a new Europe, without American participation at every stage, would simply repeat the historic blunders of the 1920's. 
But there is another historic blunder to avoid: Above all, we must not become an inadvertent accomplice in a Soviet attempt to divert Eastern Europe's march to democracy into the dead end of reform Communism. Still less should we deprive the people of the East of their free choice by helping to consolidate Soviet domination of the region through a so-called political Warsaw Pact.
Indeed, as we look ahead, several myths about the new Europe are already threatening to cloud our vision. The first is that the Warsaw Pact has a constructive, stabilizing long-term role to play. No one wants the transition from Marxist-Leninist dictatorship to democracy to be overtaken by mindless violence or a Soviet military reaction. But this tactical judgment should not be compromised by a judgment that we are giving Moscow a free, even if more humane, hand for an enduring Soviet supremacy.
The tactical consideration is short-ter - very short-term. Once the East German, Czech, Hungarian, Rumanian and Polish Governments have held completely free elections, the Warsaw Pact will remain a source of instability because it embodies Soviet domination of the region.
Nothing about the pact's history suggests it could be anything else. Its member nations are looking West, and Moscow knows it. That explains why the Soviets want the U.S. and NATO to bless a future political role for the Warsaw Pact. And it also explains partly the new Soviet haste on conventional-arms control.
The last six months have transformed the negotiations on conventional-force reductions in Europe. Far from placing a ceiling on the level of Soviet forces, the talks could establish a floor that would justify their long-term stay in countries -Czechoslovakia, for example - that do not want them or need them.
Therefore, we have good reason to readjust our sights on arms control. Newly democratic governments in Central and Eastern Europe may have radically different ideas about the real threat they face.
That brings us to the second myth: that the end of the cold war means the end of conflict in Europe. As the ice thaws, old tensions warm, especially on the issue of German reunification. No one fears the Germany of good times, the Germany of Helmut Kohl. It is the Germany of bad times, with a leader not yet on the horizon, that rattles the skeletons of history.
Now comes the real test for the West - whether we and our allies believe in our own values and judgment. The heart of our postwar achievement has been the restoration of German sovereignty and respect within the political and security framework of Western democratic values. The oxygen for this heart is supplied by democratic government, economic integration and trans-Atlantic collective security.
Will the economic and political accession of 17 million poor East Germans to the Federal Republic destroy what we and the West Germans and the other Europeans have built? Do we need a strong Soviet ''counterbalance,'' still dominant over Eastern and Central Europe, to keep the German state (or states) from becoming what Dean Rusk called ''a loose cannon on the decks of Central Europe''?
If the answers are yes, then we lack both the courage of our convictions and the elementary wisdom needed for any system of security. We must never accept the idea that the alternative to a Soviet threat can only be a German threat, and that the alternative to the cold war is a U.S.-Soviet condominium to ''hold down the Germans.'' This is the realpolitik that could produce another war, not a true and lasting peace.
Prudence demands that we be prepared to deal with the dangers of wrongful nationalism as much as with the dangers of wrongful ideology. But prudence must be allied with our values if it is to have any constructive direction. We must not revert to a balance-of-power politics in Europe that sets one nation against another without any way to assert the common interest or to reflect the weight of shared values. Instead, a ''whole and free Europe'' must be anchored in the same Western collective-security system that has kept the peace since World War II.
And that leads to the third myth: that NATO must wither away as the threat of Soviet invasion recedes. In his speech to the NATO ministers last May, President Bush invested NATO with a new political mission: to secure ''a whole and free Europe.'' This mission revives what has always been the alliance's primary political purpose, a purpose shaded over the years because of continuing serious military threat. Now, the political challenges are growing and the military problem is shrinking. That clearly calls for modifying but not abandoning the alliance's essential purpose.
NATO's future role is not to become a retirement home for unemployed soldiers and bureaucrats or an arms control seminar. NATO is above all an alliance of free peoples sharing burdens and risks and reconciling their disagreements peacefully.
NATO, far more than the cumbersome Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (the Helsinki process), with its built-in Soviet veto, has the sinews of strength that sustain European security. NATO alone stations troops by consent.
While the new Europe takes shape, NATO's old role of deterring war remains valid. Once a whole and free Europe exists, a version of NATO will be needed to sustain it - an architecture built on Western democratic values and America's commitment to overall European security. Only that renovated NATO can guarantee enduring East-West reconciliation. Surely, the states in between Germany and the Soviet Union, now recreating the freedoms, will want to have their own relations with the only truly workable collective-security organization we have known.
The new Europe, then, will not be built on the myths of a stable Warsaw Pact, the end of the cold war as the end of conflict or the withering away of both alliances. It will not come from organizations dominated by selfish economic concerns or those overloaded by vetoes.
It can rise on the principles of democracy, self-determination in the context of collective security and the common values that have made the Atlantic ocean a bridge rather than a barrier. Its firmest foundations are Franco-German reconciliation, democracy from the Atlantic to the Urals, free market economics, international economic cooperation and the continued role of NATO. Only a Europe built this way will redeem the sacrifices of the 20th century with the freedom and peace of the 21st.
